author: Diana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: So I’m kind of new to the amazon device family. We just got our echo a few months ago. I’ve been a prime member for over 10 years so I’m familiar with how amazon has changed life as we knew it (for me anyway). I saw the amazon smart plug when I was searching for any brand smart plug that had Alexa control with it. It’s been in my cart saved for later for at least a month! I finally decided to just pre order it so that I could review it and hopefully help other people that are like me and have fallen way behind in the tech field. For reference I’m an almost 34 year old mom of 2. This means that my 8 year old stole my iPad, iMac, and I haven’t had a computer of my own in about 4 years! So I do everything from my iPhone. I’ve had some weird issues with our echo and my Alexa app that it will just randomly pause a song so I’m not sure what that is about.ANYWAY! I received my new amazon smart plug the day it was released (so glad it’s not like a new iPhone or PlayStation where people camp out ahead of time or do people still do this??). It was easier than I expected but harder than was described in the listing because my Alexa didn’t just recognize it.Setup:Since my Alexa didn’t recognize it on its own, I had to unplug the smart plug and quickly scan the code on the back of the plug, then plug it back in fast so that when it scanned for it it would see it plugged in. After that it was very simple. I was able to plug in my baby monitor and then tell Alexa to “turn off plug one” and it turned off! It is so cool!Future:I think homes will end up being built with these right into the electrical system. Maybe they already are.Comparing:With so many different brands offering smart plugs with Alexa integration I can’t see myself buying any more than 1 for $25.  Too many are 2 for $20. While it’s nice to have the amazon support backing this up, I just can’t afford to fill my home with them at such a high cost comparative to other brands that do the same exact thing.Overall:If you can afford to fill your plugs with these then do! This smart plug is easy and awesome! But if you’re on a tight budget like I am, I would try a different brand first and see if those will work just as well.Every time I purchase something online, I always check the reviews. I count on others to help me choose the best option. My reviews are always my honest opinion and I try to include photos if possible.If my review has helped you in any way, please click the "helpful" button below so that I know! If you have any questions feel free to ask! Thank you!
title: Great smart plug to go with echo!

author: Rachel Wright
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: Got this smart plug so I can remotely turn appliances/lights on and off in an Alzheimer's patient's home. I can remotely make sure things are off by simply turning them on/off in the Amazon Alexa app - super simple to use and really helps me out. Now I don't have to drive over there to make sure the lights are off, or the AC or TV are off, etc. Thank you!
title: Perfect for Alzheimer's Patients / Seniors

author: minmaui2002
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: For the past few years we've only used WeMo smart plugs by Belkin.  They've worked ok and rules are easy to set up BUT, like any other smart plug, WeMo requires users to manage smart plugs using the WeMo app.  The WeMo smart plugs were relatively easy to set up with Alexa, however, the moment there was a power outage, reboot of router, etc. they have been a royal pain to get back online.I received my new Amazon Smart Plug today and the setup was very easy and took minimal time.  This was so much easier dealing with one single app (Alexa) that I will now be replacing all of my WeMo devices.  I would have given it 5 stars but using the scheduling option (days and times) in Alexa required too many steps.  Users should ideally be able to add start times, stop times and days when creating a schedule versus creating separate schedules for start and stop times.  Perhaps a lower price would be good.  Not just because I want a less expensive product but more importantly, many people have already invested a lot of money with their current smart plugs.  For example, over the past years I've added (7) WeMo plugs at an average cost of $30 each and $210 for all (7).  Personally, I think it would be a wise decision for Amazon to drop their price so that they can win over customers like me at a faster rate.
title: Best Plug for Echo

author: Eastern
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: Anyone else have a problem? Surprised that the instructions (hard copy and online) were not complete. Did not tell you that the plug needed to be turned on in a specific way to allow for setting the plug up---" press and hold the on/off switch until the LED light flashes blue and red."  After that, the set up process was simple.
title: Yes I did have a set up problem.

author: Frederick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: I have owned several different brands of smart plugs, and this one was BY FAR the easiest to to set up.  I plugged it into an outlet and within a few seconds the Alexa app on my phone recognized it as a new device, prompted me to give it a name, and I was all set!  Awesomeness all around.This may seem obvious, but it you are already an Alexa user, this may be the best smart plug to get simply because it integrates so easily with Alexa.  It's really nice not to have to install another app on my phone for a different brand of smart plug and then link that app to Alexa -- eliminating that extra layer of complexity means one less thing that can go wrong.Like other smart plugs, there is a single button on the side which allows you to turn the plug on and off manually.I have just a few complaints:- First, the plug itself is very large, especially compared with other smart plugs on the market; it projects over 2" out from the wall and is over 3" wide.  Surely Amazon can make these smaller?  Please?- Second, the plug is on the pricey side as smart plugs go.  $25 is steep for a single plug.  Then again, it's nice to keep everything "within Alexa," and hopefully Amazon will offer some deals on them as time goes on.
title: VERY easy to set up, but slightly bulky

author: Valerie McCormack
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2018
review_content: I am no tech expert but the reviews said easy to set up.  I have an iPhone and use an eero wifi network throughout the house and have my echo dot on that network.  I have spent HOURS trying to get this set up and Amazon customer service put me on hold for an hour after being unable to resolve the issue.  I FINALLY read that it only works on a 2G network (I have 5G) and so I managed to somehow reset everything and get ONE to work.  In trying to set up the second, it kept reverting back to my 5G and it took me another 1/2 hour to figure out how to forget the network settings in Alexa.  I had to completely forget all the networks and reset everything several times.  I FINALLY managed to get them working.
title: does not work on 5g network

author: Dan Meier
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2018
review_content: "Smart" home automation gadgets are a mixed bag, in general, with varying levels of compatibility, functionality and reliability across many different manufacturers. I was hoping that with their own "made for Alexa" smart plug, Amazon would hit a home run in the home automation space.  However, I've been disappointed with the Amazon Smart Plug.While setup is supposed to be "plug-and-play" with the Alexa app handling all the heavy lifting, I found both of the Smart Plugs I purchased had problems connecting and I had to (repeatedly) go through a manual pairing and configuration process.Connectivity has been marginal, as both plugs occasionally lose connectivity and require power-cycling to restore communication. This is despite the fact that I have a mesh network in my home with terrific coverage, as well as 9 Alexa devices. So no matter how the Smart Plug needs to communicate with Alexa, my infrastructure shouldn't be a problem.Reliability in operation is problematic, too, as Alexa frequently and unpredictably informs me that she can't turn on one of the Smart Plugs right now, and to try again later.  Frustrating!Finally, there's no compatibility with home automation apps like SmartThings or Stringify, and the Echo app doesn't provide basic capability such as the ability to turn on a plug/light at sunset or off at sunrise.Overall, a disappointing purchase.  Hopefully a Gen 2 Smart Plug will offer more compelling capabilities and performance.  If you're looking for an Alexa-compatible smart plug today, however, there's definitely NO advantage purchasing this one.
title: Disappointing

author: mona
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2018
review_content: I had a few WeMo smart plugs before ordering these. First of all, I HATED the app because adding a plug was so cumbersome. Plus, one of the plugs never did show up on the app so I couldn't really control it. It was in a room upstairs and I thought it must have been out of range of my WiFi router. I do not have a WiFi extender and almost bought one due to this issue. Had to send those plugs back.I was excited to see Amazon was coming out with their own smart plugs and pre-ordered them right away. Controlling everything through one app is way preferable. As a huge bonus, my upstairs plug that I previously could not control with the WeMo plug and app now works flawlessly with the Amazon plug and Alexa app. I guess it wasn't out of range after all.Pros:1. if you're already tied into the Amazon Alexa ecosystem this just makes sense, and you keep things under control with a single app. And easily controlled with your Echo device if you wish.2. Really easy to add a plug via the Alexa app. Alexa will recognize it right away and you just scan the back of the plug to add it.3. Shorter and less bulky than the WeMo plug.4. Smart plugs that may have been non-responsive on my network before are working flawlessly now with the Amazon plug in use instead.Cons:1. A bit pricey. I wish they offered multi-packs for a lower price per unit. This will probably happen later.2. Adding a plug to operate on an on/off schedule was NOT as easy as with WeMo. It took too many steps, was not straightforward, and should be more streamlined. Basically, you're creating what they call a "routine." You have to add a start time. Then go back and do it all over again to add an end time. So I had to create two routines to get my coffee maker to start on weekdays at 6:45am and turn off on weekdays at 7:45am. That was silly. I did eventually figure it out, but they should really work on making it involve less steps and be more intuitive.I will buy more but will wait until the price comes down or they're on sale.
title: works perfectly

author: Scott N.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2018
review_content: Ran great the first night I set it up....then, I experienced issues as other folks are having, but Amazon Staff on the Alexa boards are failing to help.Many people are having issues the next day...Alexa fails to recognize device....then when attempting to rediscover plug per Amazon Staff suggestion, device fails to be discovered.Edit.....Although device is not working, Amazon support has been working with me to resolve this issue. I'm pretty impressed!  Good job !Edit11-1-18Recieved 2nd Amazon plug. Same issue as first plug...loses connectivity.I also recieved 2 tp link plugs that connected flawlessly and don't lose connectivity.
title: Issues...Amazon attempting to resolve for me...VERY IMPRESSED GUYS!

author: Bill D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2018
review_content: Totally brilliant is the best way to describe these plugs.  For more than 30 years, I’ve put up with the madcap craziness of my spouses’s obsession with Christmas.  That means those cheap mechanical timers eveywhere.  Guess who gets to set those up?  Guess who gets the complaint that lights don’t turn on and off at the same time?  This guy.  Guess who hates Christmas? This guy.This year, I ordered a bunch of these - they take about 2 minutes to set up.  You open up the Alexa app.  Hit the plus sign to add the device and scan the bar code on the back, then plug it in.  In about a minute, the plug is added to your system.  I renamed each and then marked it on the bottom where it’s located (“Christmas Tree”).  I set up a group (“Christmas”) and put all the plugs into the group so there’s a single word (“Alexa turn on Christmas”).  I’ve set up a schedule so all the lights in the group come on and off at the same time.One annual headache solved and the spouse is happy that the lights all come on at the same time and they can be controlled with a single word, and it’s not my name anymore.
title: Simple Solution to Holiday Decorations

author: Katherine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2018
review_content: Connected beautifully to my amazon Alexa but unfortunately when you plug it in, it produces a high pitched noise that is extremely irritating. Going to return instantly.Update: Amazon had great customer service that replaced these plugs to see if they were defective in the first place. Today I received them and unfortunately they still have a high pitched buzz.
title: High Pitched Noise

author: Anthony H
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2018
review_content: I can not get the device to connect to my WiFi.  I setup our whole house with Lutron Caseta which was super easy and painless with 20 devices. Unfortunately this setup process is obscure and impossible to troubleshoot.  Several times it just hangs with no messages and you have to start over.The failure modes are random and the most frustrating.  First, the barcode setup will just hang and never work.  You have to cancel and start at the beginning picking a plug and the brand.  Then you have to try again and know to click the link below that says barcode setup not working.  This takes you down another process where I next experienced a “provisioning failure” with an option to start over.  Next I received a “connection error” with the same option to start over.  Lastly, the manual setup process now fails over to the barcode setup which failed in the first place.Painful.  Not nearly as easy as setting up Alexa or other smart home devices.
title: Troublesome setup which ultimately fails.

author: k226
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
review_content: So far, my plugs are not able to be discovered.  Have tried many different methods recommended by the various people who respond to others whose plugs are also undiscoverable.  You should not buy these until Amazon figures out how to make this easier on their customers.  We should not have to be "IT detectives" to make this work, especially when there are competing devices that work better and have better functionality.I have a customer service request in to Amazon, will see if they respond with any solutions.  If not, I will return these lumps.Update: Well, Amazon didnt respond to my customer service request, but they DID contact me by phone regarding this 1-star review.  Started off by asking me for personal information to verify I am who I am (uhh, no, you called me).  Didnt resolve the issue to my satisfaction (although the Amazon rep seems ok with his recommended solution).  Probably going to return them.
title: Dont Buy - Amazon hasnt figured out how to make setup easy enough for us!

author: Mark H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018
review_content: Bought multiple plugs and they all disconnect constantly, unsatified
title: DISCONNECTS CONSTANTLY

author: Nina
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2018
review_content: I am very disappointed in this. I bought this for my keurig, but because it needs to be touched to preheat it didn’t work. My back up plan was the tv. Nope...doesn’t work for that either. Please keep in mind this can only be used for items that can stay on constantly. Example a basic coffee maker, lamp, scenty, etc.
title: I’m just disappointed.

author: Buck Bell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2018
review_content: I have 7 Echo devices, including two that have hub capability.  Currently, I have a range of WeMo plugs and Philips lights such that my home is fully automated in terms of lighting.  My phone calls are all routed to echo devices.  In other words, I am not a novice user.  None of the setup option worked with this plug.  It didn't auto-connect, it could not be discovered or added via the Alexa app, and even in manual setup per the instructions (hold the power button until flashing green and blue), it would not find the plug.  Terrible!  Never had a single issue with my WeMo devices, and I'll be going back.  So will this faulty Alexa plug.
title: Total Fail

author: Raptor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018
review_content: I bought one to test out in order to potentially replace my WeMo plugs (which are problematic and have buggy software).  I’ve used it for awhile now and here are my experiences.  The plug was not as easy as described to setup.  It was not as plug n play as Amazon indicates.  I agree with most that it is pretty bulky, more so than I figured Amazon could design.Only supporting 2.4GHz Wi-Fi has been pretty standard, though you’d think Amazon has the resources to develop a 5GHz model (as well as a smaller footprint).  And I’ve experienced several brief ‘glitches’ where the Alexa app could not manage the plug.  If that is a typical issue then this is unacceptable.  I’ve expected better performance on this product given Amazon’s resources and entering the smart plug business late in the game.And then there’s the price.  I think this unit is overpriced regardless of the issues I’ve mentioned.  Being a long time customer and often a fan of Amazon, I expect them to be able to do better on size, performance and value.  This product, as is, is not innovative.  Make it smaller, stable, support 5GHz, and lower the cost.  Also consider lowering the cost further on multi-packs.  If customers like this product they will likely buy multiple.  Right now, the competitors are still as good.Having said all that, the plug does generally work, with the drawbacks listed, and I would likely buy additional units if Amazon lowers the price.  As it is I don’t see any advantages to this product over certain other manufacturers, at present.  I’m hoping that these plugs show up as Black Friday deals and will be looking out for them.  Though the release so close to a holiday, and I suspect low startup stock levels may preclude these items from BF deals.
title: Generally works, with issues, not innovative and has a high price point

author: Betty J
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2018
review_content: This is the easiest smart plug ever! You just plug it in and open the Alexa app. That’s it! It’s ready to use! Unlike other smart plugs that are sitting in my drawer because it was impossible to connect them to my WiFi,  and forget help from customer service, it worked immediately. Simple and worth the purchase. One more thing Alexa can now do for me.
title: Great product

author: Dustin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: Hey I really like the TP Link Ones and still do. Non-hub, they sit on your wi-fi every now and again have issues but nothing major. I just hooked up my new Amazon one. No skills, add-on's, 3rd party apps, accounts to make. It JUST WORKS. Plug in, add device, give it a name. DONE. It's 3 prong which is nice and while I do like the status light on the TP-Link's since this is a native hardware to Alexa I expect less issues. Do note this does not support 5Ghz but honestly you goal here is better signal reach not throughput. I also like the fact that most likely your phone is on 5 Ghz but the app is smart enough to figure that out and program the 2.4 network into the outlet without fumbling around with your phone. Plug, play, use, cheap, native, #WIN
title: It Just Works!

author: Ricardo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2018
review_content: Did not immediately recognize my wifi.  I had to input wifi name manually, no biggie.  However, remember to also enter wifi password via "security" option as part of plug set-up.  Once both are correctly entered, all worked well.  Will buy 2 more!
title: Unrecognized Wifi

author: G. Garrick
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2018
review_content: These plugs frequently lose their connection and need to be re-paired, and any routines that are set up need to be re-programmed.  I go to use the item connected to it, and get an "offline" error and I have to go through the whole setup again from the beginning. This has happened to me multiple times.  I have no problem with any other Alexa compatible devices so I have concluded it's the problem with the plug, and also with an "Amazon" branded device since my other devices, strangely enough, work fine and are from "partner" manufacturers.  It's not my Wifi since I have a 90+% signal in every room thanks to a network of Eeros everywhere.  So I am returning these and getting Weemo plugs instead.
title: Frequently loses connection with Alexa, "item offline"

author: Achint
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2018
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.          I bought the smart plug to pair it with Echo dot, and both of them see to work smoothly. Once the smart plug was paired with Echo dot, it works like a charm. I can issue voice commands to Alexa and the plug works as expected.This plug is aesthetically pleasing with rounded corners. The manual power switch for the plug is installed as a small dimple in the side which doesn't protrude out sits flush with rest of the body. This plug is wide but not tall, because which it doesn't block the sockets next to it on the wall plates. When the plug is turned on or off, it makes a small clicking noise, that is probably the sound of internal relay opening or closing the connection.This looks like a well-built plug and works reliably, with rare instances of not working and when I asked Echo dot to turn on the plug it would tell me that the plug is not responding. In such instance, I asked Alexa to turn the plug off (even though it was already off,) and then asked it again to turn it on. That seemed to fix the issue. However, if your switch seems to be unresponsive then I would recommend resetting the plug by removing the plug from socket and wait for 10 seconds. Then press and hold the power button on the plug. And while holding the button, plug into an outlet. After this step, try to pair the device again with the Alexa app.There is a small LED in the front which doesn't light up when the switch is off and turns to blue when the plug is turned on. If there are any issues with the plug or when the plug is initializing (after being plugged in), the LED turns to orange.By default, Alexa adds the smart plug as "First plug". The name of the plug can be changed in Alexa app (shown in the Video of my review)SETUPWith Echo dotThe setup with echo dot was extremely simple. As soon as I plugged in the Smartplug, Echo dot recognized the plug and responded that it has recognized the "first plug".Without Echo dot or if Echo dot cannot detect the smart plugI have shown how the setup process works in my video review.1. First, put the plug into pairing/discovery mode by pressing the power button on the side of the plug until the LED in the front starts blinking between blue and orange.2. After that open the Alexa app, and add a new device of type "plug". Plug type is Amazon.3. Alexa App will try to connect to the plug. At this step, we have two options. Either scan a QR code that comes with the plug (it is also printed on the plug as well.) If scanning the QR code is not possible then the app can also try to connect to the plug with Bluetooth.4. Once the App connects to the plug, it configures the plug for Wifi by asking you to select the Wireless network. After this step, the setup is done.OPERATING THE PLUGWith Echo dotWith echo dot I can simply say "Alexa, turn on first plug" and it turns on the plug. After I changed the name of plug to "Christmas tree" in the Alexa app, I could simply say "Alexa, turn on christmas tree"ManuallyThere is a switch on the side of the plug as well which you can use to manually turn on/off the plug. The switch gives a tactile feedback when you use it.THINGS YOU NEED TO KNOW BEFORE YOU BUY THIS PLUG1. This plug supports current up to 15 Amperes, which is good enough for most of the appliances.2. Alexa adds the plug as "First plug" by default. But you can change the name of the plug in the app.3. This plug doesn't remember the state it was in if you remove it from the socket. If you remove the plug from the switch while this was on and plug it back in, the plug will be turned off. I think this might be because of safety issues and I prefer this behavior.
title: Works like a charm with Echo dot

author: pez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2018
review_content: I like the fact that this plug handles 50% more power than most smart plugs. That means it will drive the coffee maker or espresso machine.  However, after having this for two weeks, it has lost its connection twice already. My other smart plugs don’t have this problem. It is sitting right next to an echo and across the room from a WiFi router so no excuses here. Too bad, it’s going back. Amazon has to beef up this connection.
title: Loses connection every few days

author: Cosmos Joseph
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2018
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           Setup was fast and easy. I pushed over 300 watts through it and it didn't even get warm. I got it plugged into a 600 watts pure sine wave inverter. I just wish it was 100 - 220 volts and not just 120. I was hoping to purchase a few more but I got equipment that works on 220 volts, I guess I got to look elsewhere. Lost a star.Update:After using this smart plug for a few weeks I noticed: 1. If internet service drops the plug will switch off. I got it connected to the main power to my studio, when the internet drops my entire studio goes off. 2. This plug don't remember the last state when it looses power from the mains. If the main power goes out when it was on the plug will be in the off position when power returns. If it was off when the power goes off it will remain off when the power returns. 3. A little too big for my mains socket. Looses a second star.
title: Works Perfect...but there is one thing I wish.......

author: Big Al
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2018
review_content: If you want to use this plug to schedule on/off based on the ever changing time of sunset and sunrise, do not buy it.  I have several Wemo smart plugs and Hue light bulbs in my house that can be scheduled in this manner.  This is a major Amazon Echo skill routine flaw that must be corrected.
title: Cannot schedule a routine to turn on/off with sunset/sunrise

author: Candice McGuire
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018
review_content: I have to admit to being a dope, or maybe the description isn't all that clear. I bought the plug thinking it was voice activated. I wanted to be able to walk into my house and tell my lamp to turn on. I knew you have to have an Alexa product, and I do, but I assumed the plug paired up to the device and responded.  I have an Amazon Echo but I keep it upstairs, too far away for it to hear my request. I could walk all the way through my dark house, passed the lamp, to the staircase to yell to alexa to turn on my light but that seems stupid. And I dont want to move the echo downstairs. Yes, you can use the app on your phone to turn it on, but I'm old and dont want to go through all that. I'd rather save $25 and turn the lamp on myself. I'm sure for some people in other circumstances this product would be good.
title: Plug is not voice activated

author: DEB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: I have a echo and a show but I haven't bought any smart home devices because I was pretty sure I wouldn't understand how to hook them up and didn't understand the hub at all.  I sawthe Amazon smart plug and knew that it would just work and it did.  I plugged it into the wall and opened my alex app and under devices it found my plug.  All I had left to do was ask Alex to turn it on I also changed the name to coffee and now I can ask Alex a to turn my coffee on before I even get out of bed. Now if Amazon would make a light switch and maybe a light bulb i would be set.  This plug is worth every penny.
title: Very Easy

author: Takuan Soho
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2019
review_content: Prelude:  Do an internet search for "Amazon Smart Plug device is unresponsive," see how many articles pop up, then ask yourself if you want this device. I had a not-terribly-old (<2 years) dual-band router.  The setup for the plug through Alexa was painless....or so it seemed.  The plug would never hold a WiFi signal.  None of my timed routines worked.  Every time I came home, the plug was blinking red because it had lost the WiFi signal, and attempting to control it via Alexa I would get "Device is unresponsive."I read various articles on this problem, all of which seemed to involved unplugging/resetting my router repeatedly...which is stupid, since my router is working perfectly well with every other WiFi device in my home (a phone, two tablets, and two Rokus), and having to reset my router repeatedly is also not an actual solution; it's what tech support tells people when they want to get rid of them. Others had me going in and changing my firewall/port settings, or having to assign static IP addresses to the plugs, which I refused to do out of principle.  I can accomplish these tasks, but these devices are supposed to be made for your average home user who thinks a "port" is a place to dock a ship, and has never heard of "DHCP" or a "static IP address."  If it requires going into your router settings just to get a plug that turns off and on at set intervals, that's a poorly-made device.But, I had been meaning to upgrade my router, so on the off-chance the problem was with the router, I bought a brand-new one, with automatic band-switching between 2.4 and 5.0 GHz networks.  I once again went through the setup process...and the plug literally lost the WiFi signal within 5 minutes of being setup. "Device is unresponsive."It's not a question of reception -- the plug is no more than 15 feet away from the router, in direct line of sight, with no walls between it.  This is just a crap product.
title: Absolute junk

author: celt365
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018
review_content: UPDATE:Top tip: Try different devices if one doesn't work (mobile phone vs iPad). The setup device has to on the same internet connection as the Alexa plug (2.4 vs 5.0). This will work on a 5.0 network connection despite what the product description tells you.I originally tried my mobile phone's Alexa app but my mobile only uses my modem's 2.4 connection. My iPad uses the 5.0 connection and using that... the plug set up with no problems.I will buy more of these as I need them. Once set up, they work wonderfully!Pros:Plug doesn't take up the whole outlet so you can use both plugs.Great for turning on lights on different floors of a house (my primary use).Cons:Setup can be challenging for the "novice user". :) Not exactly "plug and play".Original: I got these Amazon Smart Plugs to connect lamps on two separate floors and be able to turn them on remotely. As far as I can tell, I'm on the 2.4 network like the plug needs and so is my Echo and my Android phone. I keep getting an "unknown failure" and no connection.  I'll research some more but so far the "troubleshooting" on the official website just says to "plug and play" with no more detail than what's in the box. Barcode setup doesn't work and neither does the "red and blue" light setup. Beyond those two setup options, the directions aren't very clear on what else to try.Pros:Plug doesn't take up the whole outlet so you can use both plugs.Cons:Not an easy setup as promised. Should be "plug and play" for sure.Alexa app tells me to "enable a smart home skill" to discover device. "Amazon Smart Plug" not listed as a skill???No real troubleshooting if you have problems.
title: UPDATED: Somewhat easy to set up... work great once set up!

author: Harold M. Lawson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2018
review_content: Been in the hi-tech and computer business for over 30 years. This one counts as one of the most frustrating cluster-doodles I have seen in a long time. Little to no information, a plethora of useless BS apps, none of which say Amazon, and apparently developers who don't know the difference between Bluetooth and WiFi. Piece of junk.
title: Works with what?

author: AB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2018
review_content: The plug was super easy to install.But one day, about two to three weeks after I got it the plug it suddenly just stopped working.  I get "Device is unresponsive" when I view it on the Alexa app.I was so looking forward to having this, especially being able to bypass some of the third party software that other device manufacturers use.Update Nov 6, 2018: Amazon contacted me and stayed on the phone with me until the problem was resolved.  It was my network.  All 2.4 GHz connections were disabled.  Reset the router and the plug works just fine!
title: Works-Edited

author: Tom  Ross
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2018
review_content: Bought two.  Plugged one in and Alexa told me she found it and it worked from the start.  The other I had to manually install, with and without bar code.  Reset.  After an hour it worked, for one day.... So I ordered a replacement.  Same issues  - sometimes my Alexa app would find it, it never connected to my Wifi.  Hard reset it.  Changed networks.... And I have a Dot and an Echo and they work fine, so I am not a luddite.  Finally changed time on phone to 24 hours, tried one last time and it was auto-detected and works awesome.  There is a 5 page post on Amazon Forum https://www.amazonforum.com/forums/devices/smart-home/492320-connecting-amazon-plug-provisioning-failure?page=4 where you can see they are just trying to debug it and not getting far.  Once installed, they are awesome with Dot and Echo.  Small, leave other plug open, nice in Alexa program.  They would get a 5.  However installation - until it is debugged - is a huge negative.  I'm sure they will resolve, but for now... Cheers.  Hope this helps.UPDATED 1/21/2019:  The problem plug I finally got working just "disappeared" today.  This is beyond frustrating.  Now I have to move furniture and 200 # bookcase to try to fix this - AGAIN.  Sorry, but have to say at this time I cannot recommend.  Changing to one star until they finally fix this.
title: These are buggy

author: Jeffrey A. Young
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2018
review_content: The smart plug worked for two days and then became unresponsive. Tried everything to get it to work. No luck.
title: Avoid!

author: Munsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018
review_content: I bought two plugs they  worked  the first day which was great because I was was going away for a week and wanted to make sure I could control them while I was away. They never worked during that period. When I go back home they still indicated that they were not responding to my app. Removed them a chalked it up as a waste of money
title: A waste of money

author: Random
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review_content: Got this on the 99 cent promotion because $25 is ridiculous for something like this. It works, does what it says its supposed too.Watch out for the promotion though because the $24 credit they give you has to be used in one transaction and only something sold by amazon. So it doesn't matter if its fulfilled by amazon or a prime item, has to be sold from them which when i looked like 90% of what I buy personally is not sold by them. At this point I will probably return because its nothing special and definitely not worth $25...Dropping this to a 1 since even getting the credit has been an absolute hassle. I've had to contact support 3 times and still nothing. Surprising because usually Amazon support handles things very quickly...
title: Promotion is kind of a rip off

author: KJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2018
review_content: Purchased 2 of these plugs and they were a pita to setup and pair with my Echo.  One works the other only worked once and subsequent attempts to redo the setup/pair have been  a waste of time.  I switched to Meross plugs and they work like a dream.Update.  Amazon customer service contacted me several times with suggestions for getting this product to work.  I must have gone through their reset routines 15 times and the thing wouldn't connect even though the "smart plug" was only 3 feet from the router and the Echo.  I finally told them I was done.  Magically, I received an email informing me that they were sending me a replacement and that I needed to return the defective one ASAP.  If the replacement  works I'll use it somewhere where it's not critical when it fails. I need more smart plugs but I definitely won't be purchasing any more of theseUpdate:  less than 3 months and both the Amazon plugs have stopped working. I've reset several times and they're still unresponsive.  Replaced with a Meross smart plugs.  Problem solved.
title: Unreliable

author: Michelle B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: Purchased 2.  Did everything on package, emailed customer service, did everything they suggested. Called customer service, same steps, no luck. Exchanged for 2 more. Same scenario. Purchasing another brand.
title: Does not work

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2018
review_content: These were possibly the worst smart plug choice I could have given to my parents. I thought simple setup with the alexa app would be easier than account linking with Kasa (what I primarily use) or WeMo (what my brother uses).I could not have been more wrong.My parents each have Fire HDX tablets, how was I to know that the most recent Alexa app in the Amazon app store for those tables would be from 2014?  The operating system was updated in September 2018 but the Alexa app is from November 2014.  That's four years old!!!  That ancient app has no devices tab, and cannot install Amazon smart plugs.So, tried Mom's phone. The Alexa app required my mother to put in a captcha which took multiple tries and finally the help of my son. Then the app failed completely with bluetooth detecting the plugs. It always failed the first wifi attempt as well, which I learned to recognize by watching for the wifi icon to turn off and back on (which is required to switch networks). Sometimes it failed wifi detection multiple times. "May take up to 1 minute."  Ha ha! How about up to 3 minutes each time?It took 5 or more tries to get the first outlet to reach the point where I could select the wifi network to attach. And it took multiple tries at that point before it would successfully connect to the network instead of failing as soon as I tapped continue after entering my password. Hint to amazon: your multi-digit failure codes need some explanation, assuming there is anything I can do to possibly make the next attempt succeed.Hint to anyone else struggling at that point: I suspect timeout entering a complex WiFi key. Enter the key elsewhere, e.g. a text message and copy it into the paste buffer so you can just paste it into Alexa app when prompted.Finally after over 2 hours, I have 2 plugs controllable from Echo and the Alexa app.I suspect bugs in the Alexa app, perhaps compounded by my Mom's LG phone. I have done literally dozens of Kasa devices and even more generic chinese "smart life" aka Jinvoo aka Tuya devices with WiFi setup on my phone and with my Fire tablet. Nothing has caused the pain and frustration of these Amazon smart plugs.Notes to Amazon: Update the Alexa app in your App Store for your own tablets. Please! Also improve your error messages, and how come password saving didn't work even when the box was checked?
title: What a steaming pile

author: PandaCat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: There are many cheaper smart plugs out there but I decided to get this one because I didn't want another random 3rd party app for smart home type of management.  I just wanted one that would directly talk to Alexa.  Got mine over the weekend right after it was launched.This plug was relative easy to set up - it failed multiple times after trying to look for the WiFi (it kept disabled both of my 2.4G and 5G wifi networks even though I asked it to connect to the 2.4G only).  After that, the wizard took me to take the QR code picture on the plug and easily made the connection there.On the Alexa app, you can rename the plug, add it to a group, turn it on/off with Alex by voice commend or using the phone app, or schedule a time to turn it on/off.  It is very easy to use and perfect for turning on/off my big light remotely when I'm reading at night.After this one, I wish Amazon will make its branded similar smart light bulb and a multi-outlet version of this plug.
title: Simple and no need for a hub or 3rd party app

author: E. MILLER
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2020
review_content: I had high hopes for this because my neighbor has 4 of them and they’ve worked fine for him. Now I’m going to ask him if he’s ever had issues with his. Problems from the very beginning then started to work flawlessly for 2 weeks straight. Now isn’t working at all. I have an Echo Show 8 and it’s constantly saying “plug is unresponsive” or the app will say “device is disabled”. More like Amazon and their products are DISABLED!! Plug CONSTANTLY turns off by itself from losing connection. App is slow to respond too. You’d be better off turning the light switch on & off manually which renders a smart plug useless!! I’ve had to unplug it a billion times and reset it and I’ve only had it 20 days!!Setup is a joke too! Seriously Amazon!? The barcode NEVER works so I had to set it up using WiFi which takes FOREVER!! Status turns red sporadically too so get used to that. Ridiculous piece of Chinese crap!!! I’m returning this piece of junk and buying a cheap $8.99 one to see if it works better than this piece of sh*t. $24.99 is INSANE!!!!!!!!! How is this even “HIGHLY RECOMMENDED on Amazon and low priced”!? What B.S.!! Just a big headache! 🤕🤕🤕🤕
title: Overpriced Headache!!!! 🤕🤕😤😤

author: Shelby
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2018
review_content: I had another plug from a different manufacturer and it was pretty great but on one TV, it would not turn on my tv it would just turn it off. With THIS plug, I set it up which was fairly simple. Guess what happened? It actually turned on and off my tv and it has been doing it with 100% accuracy since I set it up a few weeks ago.FEEDBACK FOR THIS DEVICE TO AMAZON: Sell this as a multipack.
title: Great Plug!

author: Ben
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2018
review_content: The setup was easy and it does exactly what it says it does but nothing more.  You cannot integrate this with any other smart home hubs or services (like SmartThings, IFTTT, Stringify, etc).  You can do some very basic automation using Alexa routines but those are missing some fundamental building blocks for triggers and times (no sunrise/sunset for example).  But you can say "Alexa, turn on <name of plug>" and it will turn on.  Neat.I got this as a $5 add on with an Echo Dot.  I would not pay any more than that for it.  Look elsewhere for other smart plugs that are useful in many more ways.
title: Works fine with Alexa but that is it

author: Curious George
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2018
review_content: This smart plug makes it very easy to add Alexa controlled functionality to any device attached to it.  It literally takes less than 2 minute to add the plug to your network on which Alexa is on by using your Alexa app.  You can also name it to your liking and Alexa recognizes that plug according to that name.  For example, if you plug in your nightlight into the smart plug and custom name it, "My Light Stand", then Alexa will recognized that plug as "My Light Stand".  The app also lets you categorize what kind of device is plugged into the smart plug, such as lights.  The reason for giving 4 stars is that even if you connect the plug and categorize it as "light", you cannot dim it by voice control - you have to do it yourself using the remote control to that device.  It may be nicer if one can associate what product is connected to the smart plug and amazon can extend the function of that plugged in product, like dimming or switching to different colors, rather than just turning on and off the device.
title: Simple to add to your Smart Home network

author: Marion McPherson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2018
review_content: UPDATE:  Amazon replaced the plug - it arrived the next day, and this one set up perfectly first time in less than a minute.  Wish I had just insisted on a replacement from the start - instead of wasted time and aggravation with the first one.  Can only think it is defective.  So, updated to 3* based on good customer service, and the fact that WHEN it works, it works great.UPDATE:  After 2 different Amazon support calls, finally got this to work.  It worked for 2 weeks, then just stopped. I tried fixes, uninstalled, reinstalled, factory reset etc - and nothing.  I am still in the return window, so it will go back.  (note:  in between my own efforts and the Amazon support calls, wasted about 2 hours on this junk)Disliked that it doesn't work for me.  Excited to receive it.  Made sure my Android had LATEST version of Alexa (check), plugged device into working outlet (check). Made sure Bluetooth on phone was turned on (check).  Selected icon to add new device (check).  Selected PLUG (check), scanned code on accompanying literature as prompted (check). Depressed button until LED light flashed both red and blue (check).  App status indicated connecting to plug, but nothing happened.  Tried again, again, again. Phone and plug within 6 inches of each other and within 3 feet of the router. Total of 11times. 4 times the App actually asked for my Wifi password, and I got excited, thinking we were in business, but no, another 'failed to connect' and "Unable to complete setup' and 'Provisioning failed' and 'Connection failure'  My Wifi worked throughout, as did other connected devices.  Dud plug maybe, but into the bin it goes - can't be bothered with a return at this stage.  (I have numerous devices, NEST products etc that I connected without any problems - so may have to try a different brand  - this one just doesn't work.
title: Should be 'doesn't work with Alexa....doesn't work at all'

author: J. Nitta
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2018
review_content: I ordered 2 of these plugs. Our success rate is 50%. After at home trouble shooting, I spoke with the Alexa device service department to attempt to fix one of them. Within a few minutes the tech found that one of our plugs had failed to update. I walked through the troubleshooting steps AGAIN with the tech to try to get the device to update. I had already done this at least twice on my own before calling. It failed to update and the tech was not able to connect and get it to update on their end. I then asked for a replacement or refund, and was placed on hold over and over again. Since it was a faulty update on their end, and no damage or user error, I was surprised that my call had to be escalated to a higher level manager rather then being solved right away. I was on the phone for about a hour for a $25 plug. The week after I purchased these, I picked up a 2 pack of WEMO plugs at Costco. Besides having to install another app on my phone, the WEMO plugs work like a breeze. Save some time and money and get a 3rd party plug. These plugs aren't working properly yet. I tried to avoid 3rd party and thought the Amazon plug would work better with my current smart home system, it doesn't. Avoid these plugs.
title: Failed updates lead to non functional plug

author: Brandon M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: I bought two plugs in July. Today at the end of November both plugs stopped working and neither are able to be reset and work properly. After a reset they connect with the Alexa app but then they are both unresponsive when you try to use them. The indicator lights on them are completely off after a reset and reinstall. I have attempted to reset them multiple times with the same results. I have also reset my router several times as well. Completely useless! Fifty bucks down the drain. Don't waste your money on these horrible useless plugs that are meant to make your life easier but only cause frustration and sadness when they fail over and over again only to finally give up and stop working altogether. I don't know of any other alternative that will work any better. It looks like I'm down to one plug now until it fails. Not kidding, it went out as I was writing this review. FANTASTIC! Really! No BS! I'd rather use my hands again and turn on the lights rather than deal with this waste of technology. Too bad they don't last longer than six months or in the case of the new failed plug two weeks. At least I can get my money back for that one. I foresee millions of these stupid plugs overfilling landfills in the future because they are complete trash. Buyer beware. You were warned. Don't buy these. They are completely worthless. You'll love them until the second time you have to completely reset and go through the entire set up process all over again for the second time and then you'll learn to hate them until they finally die and leave you in the dark. Not buying these may be the best financial decision you make today.
title: Constantly resetting the plug an now won't work

author: Jessica Nagel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2018
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           I love these plugs!  They were so easy to install and they work seamlessly with the Amazon Alexa app.  Are these plugs more expensive than other "smart plugs" on the market?  Yes, very much so.  However, you don't have to install these plugs via a different app and then connect to Alexa.  Using these plugs is one smooth installation.  They are so much fun and allows my "Alexa" environment to become more useful for me.  I especially like using these plugs for plugs and lights that are near the floor so I don't have to bend down to turn them on.  I can see these plugs being useful for people who have limited mobility.
title: Totally Fun and Easy to Install

author: Ronald Epstein
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2019
review_content: I have had a smart home long before most people knew what one was.  I started with the original Alexa device while it was still in beta, and slowly built my home into an automated one using bulbs, plugs, and sensors.The first set of smart plugs I bought were Wemo.  They worked great for a long time.  However, as of late they no longer are able to turn my appliances on/off on a set schedule.Enter the Amazon Smart Plug.  Pretty cheap plug -- certainly cheaper than the competition.  I wanted to replace my defective Wemo with this Amazon Smart Plug in hopes of turning my coffee maker on at a set time every morning.Installation was pretty straight-forward.  I simply opened the Alexa app and it discovered the plug right away.  You can also just go to DEVICES on the app and add the plug.The plug works perfectly!  My coffee maker turns on at a set time.  The only issue I have is that the Amazon Smart Plug is much more difficult to set up for scheduled routines.If this is the purpose you want to use the plug for, I think I can assist..1. From the Amazon app, select the Menu (3 lines) in the upper left corner of the app2. Go to ROUTINES3. Select the + on the upper right of the app4. Select "When This Happens" and then SCHEDULE5. Select AT TIME and enter a time you want your device to turn on6. If you want the device to turn on at the same time every day be sure to use the REPEAT BUTTON.7. Select DONE -> NEXT8. Under ADD ACTION go to SMART HOME -> ALL DEVICES -> and select your newly named plug. Click NEXT9. SAVEYou can also repeat the above to turn the device off at a specific timeOnce you get the hang of it, it's not a difficult process to set up.  However, I have to say, Amazon hasn't made this scheduling process very easy.  It's certainly not intuitive.  I am a tech geek and I had to go on the Internet and find instructions on how to set this up.Of course, you can tell Alexa to turn on or off your device as it is now integrated with Echo systems.The plug is very well built.  It works extremely well.  I am surprised that Amazon priced it so affordably.  If you can put up with the more difficult process of setting up a routine, I would recommend this over the Wemo.  The Amazon Smart Plug certainly seems to be more reliable.
title: The smart choice for smart plugs.  Better than Wemo!

author: B. Wags
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2018
review_content: It is so nice to walk into the doorway of a dark house and say, “Alexa, turn light on”, and like magic, the light comes right on. No more fumbling in the dark for the light switch. And I am looking forward to controlling the Christmas tree lights & decorations this season.You cannot use this as a timer like I thought. You cannot set the light to come in & off at a specific time, at least not anywhere on the Alexa app that I could find.  Bit you can control your switch from anywhere you are, as long as you have your smart phone and installed the Alexa app.The range of feet that my Echo Dot picks up my voice is really good. I am in another room about 20 feet away and giving commands just a little louder then normal conversation, and if picks my voice up fine and executes the command.Very happy with this Amazon smart plug. I just ordered another.
title: Works great with my Echo Dot

author: Joseph R. Shivak
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2018
review_content: Alexa will only turn this on if i say it's name is First Plug.. i can name it ANYTHING in the app and it'll shut it off by that name but will only turn it on if i say Alexa First Plug On..  i've removed it from my account a few times and it just seems a bit buggy to accept a new name to turn on.. perhaps a software update is coming.Update 10/23/18 I just got a call asking for some more information..To further specify if I name it something i type such as Window, Decorations, etc the Alexa service will only turn it on if I call it first plug.. Now If I choose a preselected activation name such as Den (Alexa, den on..) it'll turn on..  So typed names doesn't seem to work to turn on.. but the typed name off works...So when i get home tonight i'll try it again.  And I notice I did name it Window still but I had to make a group called Den and then it'll turn on that group just not the word Window last i tried.Update: 6:30pm..  Unit's name: Window  Added it to Group: Den (cause it was a prewritten group name by Amazon)Alexa Window On...  I'm sorry I don't know that..Alexa Window On... Ok...  (Turns on)Alexa Window Off...  I'm sorry I don't know that..Alexa Den off... I'm sorry I don't know that..Alexa Den off... Ok.. (turns off)Very weird..6:49pm..  Alexa Window On ...  This time zone is east Africa time....  (huh?)Update 11/9/18:The unit appears to be working now.. i can say Window On and they come on and turn off on command.
title: Alexa Does not like typed names for the unit.  so far.. (now updated working)

author: Caracy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2019
review_content: I love these plugs. When they work. You can get two in most outlets, over/under kinda thing, if you have to. They work with alexa without a third party app. Simple enough idea. Hey alexa, turn on the light. Turn off the fan. etc. Great. BUT... I've ordered three of these and two of them needed to be returned for replacement. They won't set up. I asked alexa to find the new device. She didn't. I went to the web page and clicked "discover" new device. It didn't. I used the app on my Kindle Fire tablet. It couldn't read the QR code and couldn't set it up by looking for it. This has happened on two of the three I've bought. I contacted support both times assuming they would think of something I didn't. But both times it was necessary to send me a replacement. Both times I got the replacement to work and when they work they're great. Some observations: Initially, just plug it in and activate whatever system you're going to use for set up. It will blink a blue light. If the app fails to read the QR code, then hit the button to make it blink blue and red. I tried three different outlets with the two different light color options and it wasn't "discovered". Be advised that there is a "reset" mode on these plugs. Press and hold the button for 12 seconds. I didn't know that. It didn't help in my case but good to know.Be aware that in some places a smart plug is a "device" and in other instances a "device" is only an Echo, Dot, and other Amazon things, not a smart plug.Be aware that they, for some reason, call the QR code a bar code. Bar codes are what they scan at the grocery store. The square one is a QR code so don't waste your time looking for a bar code.It would be nice if all ways to set it up, (vocally through alexa, the web page on a laptop, an app on a phone or tablet, etc), were all set up the same way and used the same terminology. It makes these more difficult to set up when icons are in different places, on different pages or called different things.I like these plugs when they work. I now have three that control different lights etc that are inconvenient to reach. I just ask alexa! They're expensive at 25 bucks each but it is possible to catch them on sale. That's the only time I get one.Jan 2020 update....after a month this last (third) plug stopped responding. I tried re-discovering it myself. Setting it up again, etc. I contacted tech support and they walked me through several different processes to get it set up anew. Different blinking light colors, by voice, by QR code, etc . Tech support finally conceded defeat and they are sending me yet another one. I don't think I will be buying this brand again. I love not needing a third party app/account etc just to use alexa but apparently amazon does not have their act together when it comes to these smart plugs.April 24 2020 update.... another one stopped working. Since its already "in the system" it can't be discovered or set up. There is no "re-discover" option for when these things quit. The serial number is on the plug and its box but not the paper with the QR code so keep them together or write on the paper which plug it goes to. You can disable it but not delete it. I thought if I deleted it and then added it anew that would work. Due to quarantine most help is unavailable now. ****Was able to to phone customer support the next day. After 45 minutes we got it working again. They had to un-register it so that it was a "new" device. Then the system (in my case a fire tablet) was able to set it up again. These really should be easier to trouble shoot on the user end. A rediscover option or something. Having alexa tell you "the light is not responding" doesn't help. What do I do now???****Bottom line... DON'T BUY THESE. the lack of reliability/quality far out weighs any benefits.May30th 2020... AGAIN third plug is unresponsive. Nothing I do can get it to reset. Unplugging re-plugging. Flashing colored lights. QR codes or discovery. Will have to call CS when calling is available. These plugs suck.!!June 4th 2020... CS is sending me another one. You can delete the device from its app page but apparently that's not enough to make it new again. Deleting it did allow me to get further into the setup process but in the end, still unresponsive. I won't buy another one but I will continue to bother CS when they go bad!
title: Amazon Smart Plug. The Good, the Bad, the Ugly.  Great when (if?) they work, BUT they just quit.

author: ThaSwampDonkey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2020
review_content: Apparently there is a disconnect between Amazon promotions and Amazon Customer Service. The promotion for a 24 dollar credit from Amazon doesn't exist according to Amazon unless you have a screenshot of the promotion. Once you buy the smart plug, the promotion dissapears. Do yourself a favor and take a screenshot if you're buying this due to the promo. Otherwise, you will end up like the rest of us, calling asking about a promo and they have no idea what you are talking about. As for the item itself, it works okay. A little issue getting it connected.
title: Good luck getting your promo credit.

author: Illusionz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2018
review_content: I own a TP link wall plug that works all the time without disconnecting. I purchased a bunch of echo’s on Black Friday with amazon plugs and regret it, because they don’t work on my eero network. My home network has multiple access points around my home for range quality and that’s probably why amazon plug is disconnecting. It should be better, to be honest. If they are competing with TP link’s quality, they really should fix this problem. If I would have known, I would have bought more TP link plugs for the same deal. Don’t bother with these unless you have a single connection in your home.
title: Doesnt work with mesh networks, on 5g or extenders

author: Steve Lowder
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2020
review_content: Read the other negative reviews. Amazon offered a $24.00 credit with the purchase of this device when activated, which honestly I was going to use to buy a second because its way over priced., but you wont get it.It was fairly easy to hook up though I wished I didn't have to download the app to my phone. Dont understand why I couldn't just work from the amazon alexa site.
title: You wont get your credit

author: aquiles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2018
review_content: is annoying the smart plug get unresponsive on regular basisSometimes they work but most of the time "Devive Unresponsive" some threat mentioned that it need to have FIX IP addresses, it did not solve the issue.cost them $5.00 each - but if Amazon is planning to use as an introduction of Smart House I will not use themI will prefer to keep using my Z wave in wall Dimmer switch or  zwave smart plugs and have the Zwave hub with all the hiccup between Alexa and the Zwave hub.I guess the product is not quite there.
title: Two Words "Device Unresponsive"

author: R Teale
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2020
review_content: The best part of these Smart Plugs is using them to prank my family. I can be anywhere and with the Alex APP, I can turn on or off anything plugged into these things. Here's a couple examples of cool things you can do. In a bedroom, hide a super bright spotlight pointed at the bed (kid, parents, husband/wife, etc) and then simply ask Alexa to to turn it on. Boom! In the kitchen, get a blender or something, put all the highest settings on and have it set to on, and then wait until mom is cooking Thanksgiving dinner and super stressed about the turkey, and then ask Alexa to make the magic happen. Got a weirdo relative coming to your house that believes in ghosts? Have them think your place is haunted by turning lights on and off while you're not even home! The fun is endless with these things.Thank Amazon! God bless and surf's up!
title: Great for pranks!

author: Richard H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2019
review_content: I've been a multi X-10 button operated remote switch device owner for 20 to 25 years.  As the X-10 devices have aged, some have become unreliable.  They turn themselves on when they feel like it.  Others turn on but won't turn off when you push the button.  Twenty minutes later they turn off as directed.  Frustrating, but they are pretty old, after all.So I figure perhaps it's time to upgrade to one of the voice activated switches/plugs.  Being heavily invested in Kindles (7), Echos (9), and Dots (5), it seemed like a "no brainer" to go with the Alexa operated plugs.  So I settled on the Amazon Smart Plug.  I now have 38 such plugs.  In theory and operation (mostly) the Amazon Smart Plugs work as desired.  No more random turn-on's, or failure to shut off, as with the ancient X-10's.HOWEVER, and this is a BIG however.  Seven or eight Amazon Smart Plugs, for no reason I can figure out, have disconnected themselves from the Wi-Fi or Internet.  Alexa announces it can't find the plugs, or no such device exists.  The Alexa app says the plug is "unresponsive."  Huh?  More than a half dozen plugs are no longer available?  After a LOT of frustration (all these plugs are physically located in hard to reach places requiring furniture to be moved and other things unplugged and moved), the plug can be retrieved.  I've found the only way to reset and use the plugs again, is first DELETE the existing plug in the Alexa app (trash can in the upper right corner) then go through the complete set-up process like when the plug was first set up.  I don't have a bar code scanner so the button on the side of the plug must be pushed and held until the light flashes red then blue and continues until the setup progresses.  This DOES WORK.  The plug is now usable again.  (Until the next time?)  Now go back on the floor and reconnect everything and move the furniture back in place.  So why did the plug lose it's "connectivity" with Alexa?  For $25 apiece, I kinda expected better from Amazon.  Not frustration every couple of days.Another irritation.  In my case the Internet (Windstream) went down for over 12 hours this past weekend.  It seems the smart plugs turn dumb as a brick when there is no Internet.  I guess the ID information for each individual plug must be stored on the Internet, and Alexa must communicate with the "cloud" to complete the Smart Plug usage.  Thus--no Internet, no Smart Plug operation.  Yes--IF you can reach the location of the Smart Plug on the wall, you can manually press the side button and turn "on" the plug.  But in my case, the plug turned itself off, after 8 to 10 minutes.  Was this a fluke?  Dunno.When these Smart Plugs work, they are wonderful.  But life living with them CAN become frustrating.  Be prepared.  Good luck, RIC
title: Sometimes they have a mind of their own

author: PBoccia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2018
review_content: What's the old saying?  It's great when it works?  I preordered one of these plugs to try when it came out.  I've had the plug for less than three weeks and it has become unresponsive three times, forcing me to delete it and re-add in Alexa.  THEN, I have to re-add the couple of routines I set up for it...Alexa remembers the time settings but not what is supposed to happen.  Also...the Alexa app is ponderous and aggravating as to how it handles scheduling of activities.  There seems to be a different screen for each step.  Why can't the steps be reduced to one or two screens....and it's slow.  I found the Meross and Tuya apps to be more user friendly, and the plugs don't give me issues.  I might return the Amazon plug.Update - 11.01.2018:  Amazon apparently pays attention to these reviews.  To their credit, I received a call from Amazon yesterday, inquiring about the problem I was having with the smart plug, stating that they were going to replace it immediately and that I would be contacted by their Labs to arrange for the return of the problem unit for analysis.  I have been informed that my new plug will be arriving tomorrow and have, indeed, been contacted by the Lab to arrange for the first one's return.  Based on this level of attention to customer satisfaction, I'm bumping up my rating to three stars and might go higher if the new unit does not give me any issues.  Thank you for your attention, Amazon.Update - 11.14.2018:  Thank you for trying, Amazon.  I installed the replacement plug you sent on 11/03.  Now it's the 14th, less than two weeks, and it has become unresponsive, too, for no apparent reason.  I'm sorry, but I don't want to spend the time dealing with it and I don't like the idea of worrying about when it's going to give out again if I do.  I'll be sending it back.  Sorry.
title: A Bit of a Nuisance [Updated 11.01.2018]

author: Mario M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2019
review_content: I bought 3 of these smart plugs believing that, being Amazon brand products, they were going to bring extra functionality to the table compared to third-party smart plugs. That or at least being more reliable and straightforward.Turns out this was not the case, as explained below.PROS:- Compact, space saving design. You're able to fit 2 of these in a regular outlet.CONS:- Pricey, compared to most of the competition (although you can find them for lower prices in deals and bundles).- The button for manually turning it on and off is very small and recessed. That makes it harder to press if under a table, behind a desk; etc.- The setup process is not very intuitive and sometimes troublesome. The instructions are not very clear (keep in mind I'm a tech-lover and setup new products often).- They don't offer local network controls when the internet is down, like most of the competitors do; and,most importantly...***- THEY TURN OFF AFTER 7-10 MINUTES OF BEING DISCONNECTED FROM THE INTERNET!***Now, everything else is tolerable: The price becomes very good when there's a deal or a bundle, the setup process is frustrating, but usually done only once, most of us will control them by voice so the button will be rarely used, and the internet is usually up most of the time so local network control is not a necessity all of the time for most.What is not tolerable to me is that these plugs are NOT reliable because the TURN OFF on their own when they lose connection to the internet. Even when still connected to the WiFi, if you internet is down, they turn off after about 7 to 10 minutes of losing connection.If you turn them on again manually (using the button), guess what? THEY WILL TURN OFF AGAIN AFTER ANOTHER 7-10 MINUTES!!!I have found many users online who have this issue but no one has come up with a solution.All other smart plug brands I've used are capable of maintaining their current state when they become disconnected. Even after a power outage, they maintain their power state (on or off) when the electricity comes back. Some even let you choose in the settings if you want them to stay off or turn back on after an outage, whatever the previous state was.This Amazon Plug doesn't let you do any of this and it is VERY frustrating that it just gives up and turns off.I have 1 in my office, in the company building where I work for turning my desk (lamp, monitors, fan; etc) off when I leave for a meeting, bathroom; etc.Sometimes due to network bottlenecks or server maintenance, the internet will be down for a while. This will TURN OFF MY COMPUTER MONITORS EVERY 7 MINUTES, even after turning the smart plug on manually. I just end up unplugging the smart plug and just directly plugging my desk's power strip to the wall. This doesn't happen because of an overload as I measured the current to be way under the 15 amp limit. And it only happens when there's no internet.Similarly, at home, I have another one connected only to a Wyze Cam (great cameras, by the way), so I would be able to reboot that camera remotely if needed. Every once in a while I would find that the camera is offline because the Amazon Plug turned off on its own.CONCLUSION:The inability of the plug to remain powered on makes it useless for my purposes. Having said that, if you need a smart plug and you have a 100% reliable 24/7 internet connection, then this becomes an option. Specially if you can manage to buy it in a bundle (for as low as $5 sometimes when bought with an Echo).Otherwise, I would recommend you buy another brand that offers more functionality and reliability, like TP-Link Kasa Mini/Lite plugs (which I have also found to have some issues as well in some network configurations), or brands that use the Smart Life app.Hope this was helpful.Happy shopping.
title: THEY TURN OFF AFTER 7-10 MINUTES OF BEING DISCONNECTED FROM THE INTERNET!

author: KENNY JIMNO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2018
review_content: Update... Amazon sent a very nice email after my post. They let me know how they can help. After a few days the plugs worked FLAWLESS. Went out and bought 4 more Amazon Plugs.Once both of my plugs FINALLY  provisioned  I was stoked because I turned both devices off and on like 20 times using two of five of my Echo shows in the house.Time to turn off switch (lamp plugged in) before going to bed, "Computer, shut off first plug" first plug turned off.Next night, I had to reset unresponsive plugs several times to keep it working.  Gave up on this plug and tried the other plug I bought. Same issue.  After not using these plugs for several hours they keep having to be reset in order to make them work.
title: Plugs Unresponsive after a few hours of no use

author: Dean Buzzell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2018
review_content: As other reviewers have noted, there doesn't seem to be any compelling reason (other that "Amazon Support") to spend the additional money for an Amazon branded smartplug, when other, similarly rated smart plugs can do more, and offer 2 plugs for not much more than the price of a single Amazon branded model. Tellingly, Amazon doesn't bundle 2 smart plugs for a discounted rate; instead, they bundle other 'smart' devices with a single plug.Just how useful IS a smart plug? From what I can see, it'll be useful only with items that use a two-position mechanical switch - on or off, like non-dimmable lights, or a simple coffee maker. I intended to use it with a floor lamp with an inconveniently located mechanical switch, but now that I'm looking closer, I see that Philips Hue is offering a 4-pack of Echo-compatible, dimmable 60-w bulbs for $40. That seems to be a much better option that the $20 for the smart plug that is only on/off, especially since I already have the bridge unit for smart lights. Wish I'd noticed them earlier.
title: Yeah, it's a smart plug, alright. Whoopee.

author: Scott Greenberg
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: UPDATE 11-26-20: Tried to setup again and all four plugs worked today. Seeing the other reviews with similar issues from yesterday, seems like it was an Amazon issue. Hopefully the problem has been fixed.Original review 11-25-20: I purchased four of these plugs in late 2019 to control lamps and holiday lights during the season.  One continues to work but the other three stopped working today.  After four attempts at re-installing the plugs on the Alexa app, the devices are still listed as unresponsive.  I also rebooted my cable modem and router twice to see if that helped.  The plugs work if the side button is pressed, but they are no longer communicating with my WiFi.  Time to invest in another brand.
title: Update: Working Now

author: Never Bird
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2018
review_content: Edit: I've bought the device a second time and it connected much better with the most recent Echo Dot. I plugged the device into a power strip and use it for my computer charger so it doesn't overcharge my laptop. I don't know if they've made improvements, but connection worked out great so I've upgraded my review from 3 stars to 5 stars.Thoughts:1. I wanted to try using this as a plug for a power strip, but it doesn't work because there must be some safety feature.2. If the Echo/Alexa has trouble finding your plug, don't panic. There is a button on the side of the device that you can press for the light to flash and for the plug to be "discoverable".3. The plugs are named in chronological order (ie. First plug, second plug, etc.) and you can't edit the names though you can group devices on your Alexa app. So keep track of which plug is which.4. Again, I don't believe that this device should be used for life saving equipment as it is dependent on your wifi connection and Echo/Alexa adds an additional command step to the sequence of using a machine.I would recommend this product!Previous Review:I waited to review this plug because I wanted to try it out with different devices and at different distances from both Echo/-Dot and my modem.Devices: I tried the plug with a space heater and with a laptop (to avoid overcharging). I plugged it into a power strip with no problem, but do note if you're using a space heater with an automatic shut off, the plug is going to be shut off just like the rest and you have to turn on the strip and then tell Echo to turn on the plug separately. I've decided that the automatic shut off is enough of a safety feature and the Smart Plug is best used for devices that are capable of utilizing a continuous stream of electricity without emergently overloading and need the plug to monitor the usage (e.g. a laptop). ***Please take note of my exception at the bottom of the review!Now for the big item issue: Connectivity.I believe the key is that your Wifi connection needs to be optimized to get the most out of this plug. If you have slightly unreliable wifi (e.g. I live out in the country with plenty of winter storms), plug the smart plug closer to your modem and minimize the distance from your Alexa. I don't know if this is a must, but it worked for me. If your internet shorts out in, you don't have to re-setup the plug, but the plug lights might get thrown off for a bit (it will stay red even when it's on and flash blue at random points). Ignore that. If your Echo/-dot is flashing red as well, the plug is going to be down.Just give the Wifi a second to settle down and you should be set to go.
