The irritating part is that the Echo resyncs with the Wifi much faster than the plug. I tried to reset it up/give it time and it took hours for it to sync up again, but maybe that was because it was further away from the Echo/modem. Either way, just know that once your wifi has been signed in, as long as you haven't changed the password, your sign in is set.Other reviewers are correct: the set up instructions are easy to overlook. Either have the instructions next to you so you have the set up password or be near an outlet.1. You go into your Alexa app2. The top left corner has the three lines3. Click on add a device4. Choose plug5. Brand is Amazon,6. Click "Next" to agree to the conditions of use and terms7. Scan the barcode on the back of the plug or from the instructions (You have to get the little box with squiggly lines to be lined up in the sights of the screen) and then follow the instructions. It's okay if you have to unplug the smart plug for a second to scan the 2D barcode, just plug it back in quickly.8. It will tell you to press the button on the side till the lights flash red and blue (keep pressing till that happens) and then make sure to follow the instructions for signing into your Wifi.***IMPORTANT and MY OPINION: I really wouldn't recommend that you use this plug for life-saving/emergency equipment even if you think that you have the best Wifi in the world. A plug with a timer or any regular plug is reliant on electricity, but, as aforementioned, this plug requires an extra step of being turned on by Echo/-Dot. If your electricity goes out momentarily, you lose the time waiting for the lights to turn back on, but with the plug you have to additionally ask for Echo to turn the plug back on and/or resync with your wifi.
title: Useful and Upgraded (Edited Note)

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2019
review_content: UPDATE 05/30/2019 - I just took away another star because these plugs do not remember what state they were in, if the power goes off and then back on again.  The power went off in my house for just a couple of minutes this morning.  Three of these plugs forgot that they were in the "ON" state when the power went off.  When the power came back on they decided to be "OFF."  This is not acceptable to me.These plugs do not require a hub and in fact CANNOT be used with a hub.  That's too bad because there is no way to get around the limitations (so far) with the software controlling the plugs.  I switched from an IRIS smart home system to these plugs.  Amazon smart plugs have only rudimentary functionality.Pros:  Easy initial pairing setup.  Fast response time when given a command. No hub required.  Pretty reliable.Cons:  Setting up routines to turn lamps on and off on a schedule is a bit cryptic until you've done it a few times.  More problematic is that there is NO WAY TO LABEL A ROUTINE for a particular device.  So if you have 10 devices, each with routines for start and stop times, you are left with a page of on and off times that are not organized in any way.  It makes it difficult to change the on and off time of a particular device without hunting through the page for the on time and then the off time for plug you want to change.  Lastly, there is NO SETTING THAT AUTOMATICALLY ADJUSTS ON-OFF TIMES FOR SUNRISE OR SUNSET.  With the (now defunct) IRIS smart home, I could set a lamp to come on 30 minutes before sunrise and turn off 1 hour past sunrise.  Or I could have a plug turn on 1 hour before sunset and turn off 3 hours after sunset.  So the plugs would automatically adjust to the changing sunrise and sunset times over the course of a year.  This is NOT possible with the Amazon smart plug.If Amazon would address those two issue (labeling routines and the ability to set times based on sunrise and sunset) these would be world class smart plugs.  Of course the ability to control these plugs with a smart hub (if desired) would be a bonus.  Right now, these plugs are pretty stupid.  They perform only very basic functions.
title: Easy set up but only rudimentary abilities

author: Christopher
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
review_content: UPDATE 10/31/2020  I thought I'd give it a go again with these, with one.  I have 52 devices and all stay connected.  So I went through the process of setting it up just 6 feet from my Eero; it worked--for a few hours , then disconnected again.  I have various devices/plugs/switches/light strips/thermostat/doorbell/locks/echos---all work well and stay online.  This is too much hassle.  Come on Amazon as I see the same issue posted elsewhere on the net.  I am very PRO Alexa, but so far these are a dud!  Maybe get one if they are on sale for $5, but no more, to try.  I don't understand how over 90% have rated this a 5 but there are many that have the same issue of disconnects.I have 4 of these Amazon Smart Plugs; that I have added since 2018 when they first came out.  Just got another one end of last year.  All were the $5 deals combined with other items.  I know why.  They won't stay connected.  At first the first few would, but then starting disconnecting.  I have a mix of approximately 34 devices around my home; from light switches, outlets, OTHER PLUGS, alexa echo series and these are the only ones in my home that will not stay connected.  I can connect, but they eventually one by one stop and flash red.  Even when I push the button to turn them on manually, the light will come on, but after a while automatically turns itself off.  I cannot recommend these.  But for $5, I suppose that is why they were $5. LOL  Nobody has time to crawl under and behind furniture to constantly reconnect.  Ridiculous!  At least I'm only out $20.
title: All devices work in my home, but these Amazon Plugs

author: Daniel Sheehan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
review_content: The two plugs I got are useless to me as they were both intended for old school lamps plugged into a switched outlet. The problem is if you switch off the physical light switch, even if you turn it back on you still have to issue an additional voice command to get the light back on. I.E. The plug doesn't remember its status before losing power.I ready on an old Amazon forum that always defaulting to off when power was restored, versus the last state the unit was in, was a "safety" feature in case someone plugged a toaster into one of these. Like someone would do that or that the toaster would be perpetually on...Either way I will have to find a use for these somewhere in my house where they aren't on switch controlled plugs, and I will have to buy more 3rd party plugs that remember the state they were in when power is restored.And before someone leaves a smart remark, there are some older people who don't understand/want to use voice control so I need a plug that works with both. I.E. The person using the room who doesn't use voice control can use the switch like normal, and the person who does can use voice provided the switch is on. And yes I know I could replace the light switch altogether but that doesn't always make sense and is cost prohibitive sometimes for just a simple lamp.
title: Not suitable for a switched outlet.

author: Thomas & Jessii
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2019
review_content: If you need a simple smart plug to work with your Amazon Alexa devices, this plug is extremely inexpensive and easy to install. Install and setup took around 3 minutes to get up and running. So far I haven't had any issues.The only downside is that this plug will NOT integrate into your other smart services, like WEMO. So if were hoping to tie this into your larger automation environment, you're barking up the wrong tree.
title: Fast, simple installation and setup.

author: Patilu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2019
review_content: I purchased 2 Amazon smart plugs to turn on lamps in my bedroom using voice commands to an Echo Dot. This is a 16x14 room that is dim even in natural light. The room has no overhead lighting, so I depend on lamps for lighting. I am in and out of the room frequently throughout the day and evening and often have my arms full. Repeatedly turning the lamps on and off (vs. just toggling a light switch with an elbow if necessary) as I entered and left the room was a major hassle. Before I got the smart plugs  I typically just left a lamp on in the room after dark so that I didn't trip on something before I reached a lamp to turn it on.The smart plugs have solved the problem. I just tell Alexa to turn on/off plug 1 or plug 2 as I enter or leave the room to accomplish the task hands-free. I instantly have just the amount of light I need when I need it and am not burning electricity when I don't.The plugs are not inexpensive but is was a cost effective investment for me vs. paying an electrician to change out my ceiling fan for a overhead light fixture controlled by a light switch on the wall (a light kit for the existing fan isn't an option).  I already had the Echo Dot but you could control the lamps with the Alexa app on your phone, tablet, etc.An added bonus: When I'm falling asleep the slightest movement can stimulate me back into wakefulness, so I LOVE being able to simply ask Alexa to turn off the lamps just as I'm falling asleep.I tried cheaper smart plugs that I ordered off Amazon and they connected with my wireless but Alexa kept saying the plugs were unresponsive. Additionally, the shape of these plugs sometimes precluded plugging in a second item on a 2-outlet depending on the shape of the plug on the second item. I took the advice of another reviewer and returned them and ordered the Amazon version.The Amazon plugs were simple to set up. I did have a problem when I tried to move a plug from one location to another. I used the Alexa app to diagnose the problem and I  was instructed to scan the barcode on the plug with my phone. I did this and boom, the plug was functioning correctly and I have had no other problems.I've already ordered a third plug to control twinkle lights on a decorative ficus tree in my living room. It will be fun to to make the lights appear every evening at my command,  or I may use the Alexa app to turn the plug controling the lights on/off automatically each evening.
title: Plugs are both a practical and entertaining investment

author: speeddeacon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2018
review_content: Here’s and update to my original 1 star review. It turns out my issue was with our profiles, not the plug. There is a lot happening behind the scenes with the Alexa smart home. I had to add the device to my wife’s account instead of mine and everything works fine now with voice control.Of note, I got a call from Amazon after I submitted the initial review to help me troubleshoot my issue. I hadn’t contacted them yet so this proves they do read these reviews. I had already got it up and running by the time they called though and they weren’t sure why my fix seemed to work because all of my other Alexa devices are registered to my account and profile. In the end, they said if it works just go with it so that’s what I’m doing.Positives: Amazon product easily integrates with Amazon smart home (when set up properly), easy setup and excellent Amazon customer service.Negatives: No dimming, no HomeKit compatibility (or Google, etc). Pricey for what you get.For me, having Lutron Caseta products in my home, with the requisite hub, their plugs have many more features I use at the same price point.Initial Review:Tried one of these out to compare to the Lutron Caseta ones since I only need one more for my application. Setup was a breeze, instructions are in the box and Alexa app easily found it and added it to my long list of devices. The only problem is that Alexa can't find the device when asked via Echo. I can go to the Alexa app, find it in my devices and turn it on or off all I want, but when I use voice control no dice. I'll talk to Amazon Customer Service to see what they suggest. Perhaps I have a bad plug, who knows. If I can get it sorted out, I may update my rating because most other people are having no problems.By the way, the Caseta smart plugs allow you to dim the lights. If you have Caseta in your home, it's probably worth it to go with their smart plugs if you want dimming. Price wise, they are the same per unit, but the Caseta only comes in a two pack.
title: Updated review- Works with app, not with voice.

author: scot m
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2019
review_content: So, updating review. This product is fatally flawed. DO NOT BUY IT ! If your ISP interrupts service or your WiFi router drops the signal. These plugs drop off the network and have to be reinitiallized. The result is if you have a critical device plugged in to one that device WILL NOT WORK until you go thru the whole paring process from step 1.  I have one in direct line of sight of my Alexa + my network dropped out and the plug failed fatally. These plugs dial home to amazon and report every activation so if they can’t dial home the don’t fail safe - they fail fatal. BAD amazon!  Amazon with a new software mod and Fix this so they work  on Zwave without dialing home.  So one can plug in and pair these with Alexa plus. So again these Do Not Work !  They work for a few days BUT then Alexa+ looses com with them and no amount of asking Alexa to discover devices works to restore their function. Something is very wrong with the software that runs these plugs. In contrast my philips hue bulbs always work and never loose com. Amazon, if you read this please send me a software patch to fix this problem or 6 smart plugs that DO “work with” actually with Alexa. Scot
title: Sadly, fatal flaw ! Don’t  “work” with Alexa.

author: Justin R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2019
review_content: I love smart plugs, they make my life easier.  I am actually going to make this review more streamlined as these aren’t much different then the TP Link plugs I reviewed. The reason why I purchased these: The first reason was the price, when they are not on sale, they are comparable to the price of other plugs on the market including Amazon but on sale, they were roughly 30% cheaper than the TP Link plugs I purchased  at their regular price.  The second reason is because I have five Echo dots around the house and although I can use the Echo Dot to communicate with the TP link plug, I can’t ask the Echo Dot if the plug is on or off like I can using TP Link plugs with  Google home,  so I figured if I have an Amazon plug and an Amazon smart speaker they should communicate better. The third reason is because these plugs can handle 15 A like the more expensive plugs, and although most of my devices are 10 A or less, I like the ability to use these with nearly every device in the house. The last reason is because the reviews I read about how easy these were to set up and I was looking forward to the set up process because of how  effortless the Echo Dot third generation smart speakers were to set up. My experience with Amazon plugs: Setting up my first plug was not as simple as it should have been. I tried scanning the back of the plug and when that didn’t work I then tried to scan the barcode on the instruction sheet.  when that didn’t work I turn on the overhead lights, and when that didn’t work then I  held down the button on the side of the plug until the blue and red lights appeared.  My phone then found the plug and I chose my network to connect with and it said this may take up to one minute. Two minutes later I got an error message.  I tried the process about 10 times over before I finally gave up.  Later on last night when I decided to try the process again, I then found the unnamed plug as one of my devices and I was finally able to use it. I figured this had to be a fluke but when I went to set up my second plug today, the process was exactly the same. The barcode not scanning, not being able to connect it to my Wi-Fi and then later on finding it as one of my devices. The other thing I learned is the echo dot cannot communicate with the Amazon plug like google home can communicate with TP Link, meaning I can’t ask if the device is already on. So far I am not disappointed with the Amazon plugs but I am not thrilled with the features.  The benefit of buying Amazon plugs is the price, nothing more. If you are patient and can troubleshoot then these plugs are worth the cheaper price, however if you are not tech savvy, if you get frustrated with repeating  steps and waiting, then from my experience I could not recommend these.  I think using my father is the best example,  The VCR always flashed at 12, you could not record anything unless you were home to press the record button until my brother and I got old enough to figure out how to program it ourselves,  and now that we are moved out, the clapper is the most advanced device in their house that he can properly use  on a regular basis, and the question is, could I give this plug to him to figure out how to use it, with the Echo Dot, yes, but it would either wait on the counter until  I set it up for my parents, or it would be in the trashcan in several hundred pieces  after he tried to set it up. By the way, I  was using an iPhone X with the most current iOS  software.
title: I honestly can’t recommend these two other customers until the set up process is fixed.

author: Jenna
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2019
review_content: You can find cheaper options. I have a number of other smart plugs that I’ve had varying degrees of success setting up. I bought these after having issues w another brand that had been working well for me previouslyI already have an echo dot (several actually). The setup of these plugs was SO easy. Plug in, open Alexa app, go to devices. Click add new, select amazon. The camera opens and you scan the code from the box. That’s it!  Took less than 30 seconds and was immediately integrated to Alexa voice controls. I was able to name these and set up my desired schedule with ease. Super easy, very quick.  I was very happy with these & highly recommend. I have other plugs that cost less and work fine but have spent a lot of time loading additional apps, struggling with setup and Alexa integration. If you are new to smart devices, these are very simple and would be a great place to start
title: Surprisingly easy setup

author: KC McGinty
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
review_content: This is a lesson to read the reviews before buying because there is no native IFTTT(if this then that) support. I have a radiant oil heater and a fan on a TP-LINK plug that would kick on when the temperature dropped below 50°s outside and off when above 50°s using IFTTT, but I wanted to be able to activate the fan separately. Well I left the heater on the TP-LINK plug since the applet is already set and I went to setup a different one for the fan with the Amazon plug. Turns out the only Amazon widget in the list is the cloud drive.I don't know why Amazon doesn't release a widget to control all devices in your Alexa interface, but it seems this is going to be another situation like Prime Video on Android devices and take years just to get them to cave. For the time being, invest in devices from other manufacturers that aren't so lazy. I like TP-LINK well enough but maybe wait for a sale, their app interface is nice and they have lots of options like setting timers, logging usage stats, and long term scheduling.
title: If you like automation, don't buy these plugs.

author: Robert
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2018
review_content: This listing doesn't explain the version-incompatibility issues.Before you buy this plug install the Alexa app on your phone and and make sure you get a (c) 2018 version that has an add device icon on the home screenAfter way to much frustration the big issues are:1) You can't setup the device from an echo, even though there is an 'add devices' command.2) You can't setup this plug from an older android phone, the required Alexa app version will not install.  From my (old) andorid device I installed Alexa from the google play store and got a version copyright 2017 - that can't add this plug.  From the amazon app store the Alexa app showed as 'incompatiblye with your device'.After spending way too long fighting 'your device can't be found' I took the plug to a friends house and installed the Alexa app from the google play store on her new cell phone - and got a version with a completely different UI that worked with this plug.
title: Don't buy unless you have a new android phone, required android version not listed.

author: Luc Garcia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2018
review_content: If it is not connecting turn low power mode off on your phone. Common issue, not sure why. Should be a complete fix.Great little product. I mean sure, it's not a tiny product by any means but the picture on the buying page itself could have told you that much. Works like a charm and has a small led to verify if it's off or on which does not overpower the surroundings. It's an odd shape but it doesn't affect ports around it. It has two settings, on or off. I've heard multiple people say they wish this had a dimming feature as some others must have but it's fine either way.Conclusion:Set up was painless after I figured out what was wrong. Great little product for the price. If you can find another company for cheaper go for it instead.
title: If you're having trouble connecting...

author: G1977
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2019
review_content: This would be a great idea, especially for those of us who are not very mobile or who are disabled. Calling out Alexa to turn on or off lights would be so convenient. I have difficulty walking, and having our house "Alexafied" would be extremely helpful. At night I have to keep certain lamps on in case I need to get up and use the restroom because I can't see very well. Amazon had Smart Plugs on sale for a fantastic price, so we bought one to try out. Our Smart Plug worked 1.5 times before Alexa could never find the lamp to turn on.The initial setup was fairly easy, since Amazon emailed me with clear instructions. Initially this worked; for one time we could tell Alexa to turn on and turn off our bedroom lamp. The second time, Alexa turned on the lamp, but when I woke up, the lamp was off. After that, the Smart Plug would not stay online, it would display a steady red light instead of a blue one. We had to keep re-setting and re-synchronizing our lamp with Alexa but it wouldn't work. It got to a point where the blue and red light kept blinking all the time. Whenever I tried to set up Smart Plug up again, I would get to the blinking blue light, indicating it was setting up. But I never did get a steady blue light again after several attempts. So we felt it best to return it.While this is a super idea, this first generation of Smart Plugs need more work--still too many bugs for it to work on a consistent basis. For me, it is critical that certain lights remain on at night, so I'm unable to use Smart Plugs until they iron out the problems.
title: Fantastic Idea For Disabled People...Ours Worked Only Once

author: daniel j paider
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2020
review_content: Overpriced for $24.99, there was supposed to be a $24 credit as soon as I activated it on my alexa app, nothing. Support couldn't find the promotion apparently. Returning it.
title: Won't get the $24 credit as advertised.

author: LMc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2020
review_content: So great, until both of them stopped working!  I purchased these before a vacation and they worked perfectly.  Deliberatly did not buy similar items, which are much cheaper, because I wanted the quality of an Amazon brand.  I was so wrong!  This product was a pleasure and I loved them, so I bought another one.  Then a week ago, one just stopped working.  It was my bedside lamp and when I unplugged the lamp and replugged without the Smart Plug, the lamp was fine!  Then I moved the Smart Plug around the house to see if if it worked in another location.  Totally dead.  Today the second one stopped working in my office. Same drill, lamp was fine, Smart Plug was dead.  Of course the warranty has just passed the deadline for return.  Would not recommend buying.
title: So great until they both stopped working!!

author: Michael
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review_content: Sorry a bit lengthy but long story short if you don't want to waste your time on the 0.99 promo then this isn't the choice. I wasted about a week just to know on the last day that I can't get the 24 credits back. First time I had any big problems with Amazon as well, and I know that my message will probably be seen by few, but good luck everyone.Product itself isn't bad it gets the job done but the price doesn't make sense. At the time I'm writing this it costs $24.99 which is steep compared to its competitors who offer 4 outlets for roughly the same price as one of these. (Why would you get this 1 for 25 if you can get 4?) But that's not the point, point is other people are having this problem as well so just be aware.[IF] you see the deal on your homepage stating that it's 0.99 (after spending 24.99 you will receive 24 back for connecting your smart plug to Alexa) don't get it unless you want to waste your time. I've spent a couple of days talking to customer support for nothing. I received my order on August 26 and it's currently September 1.First day, I connected it and didn't know when I would get the credit so I didn't do anything. Later that day I remembered that I had a 5 dollar credit from before and it automatically applied onto a purchase. So I decided to see if the same would apply with something random (to see if the credit has been applied, I didn't actually get it I just got to the confirmation screen). Nothing was there and from there I believe I contacted customer support that day or the day after (or later but not the point), in any case, I switched between 3 agents, 1st saying that he was going to get me the agent who handles this, 2nd said the usual small talk and transferred me to the 3rd (said nothing just gave me a new agent), to the 3rd and final agent of the day. I was told that the code given in the package (on a piece of paper which you would scan to connect it to Alexa) couldn't provide me the money back (understandable) so I had to use the code on the back of my device. I scan it and the agent tells me that I would receive a email and the credits onto my amazon account within 24-48 hours. Sure enough I wait for a little over 50 hours and received nothing so once again I contact amazon customer support.Now keep in mind each one of these agents took a bit to respond which is understandable, people are busy, but shouldn't lie. It starts the same with the usual small talk and I was informed that the agent I contacted isn't able to help so I got help from another agent who finally told me that no code was ever applied to my account. It took roughly 40 minutes alone for this to complete by the way. I was most likely told that I didn't have a code roughly 10-20 minutes in.If anyone else saw this ad, I wish you luck on getting the 24 credits back and hopefully don't waste your time. (I get that its 25 bucks but still I wish I could've just gotten an answer the first day I contacted customer support, I mean seriously if you get me a agent that is supposed to be know what I need help with I can't get lied and have to waste my time!)(P.S) - Last agent told me that the leadership team would be notified and there will be coaching for the previous agents I dealt with, but who knows what will happen.
title: Customer service or what?

author: D Kerr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2019
review_content: I bought some other smart plugs last year and tried to use them for turning on lamps in my kids' rooms, but they were never very reliable, so they only worked sometimes.  It was frustrating and I eventually just unplugged them.  When I saw these by Amazon, I tried them and the setup was super easy and I haven't had any issues with them not working!  Since this was already synced to my account, setup was as easy as plugging it in and pressing the ON button on the side of the plug.  It connected instantly with my Wifi network and all I had to do was rename the plug in my Alexa app.  I would definitely recommend these over any off-brand if you're looking to use them with Alexa.  I ordered this one through Alexa to get the Black Friday deal, but I wish I had gotten one more.  The deal is sold out now, so I'll be on the lookout in the future for a couple more.
title: Easy Setup & They Actually Work!

author: T. Dadr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2019
review_content: I have a number of home automation plugs, switches and sensors  connected with SmartThings, but fell prey to a discount day on this plug.  They were on sale for 4/5 off, so I got one.  I thought that surely there would be a way to make it work with SmartThings as well.  I'm still not there and still not using it.  The plug will turn on an off with Alexa, but all the other logic, programs, and automation that SmartThings supports will not be there.  The reason for two stars is exactly that "We want you to know: This plug works exclusively with Alexa"  when there is no reason for the plug not to work with SmartThings as well.  I will be more careful in the future, as all the SmartThings items and routines can also integrate Alexa voice commands, and are usually the same price.
title: Beware Lock-In to Amazon

author: Christopher Moyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2019
review_content: At first these plugs are quite easy to set up, and appear to work well, HOWEVER after every power outage, including if someone happens to flip the switch your plug is connected to, it requires a complete re-setup. Not only do you need to physically be at the location to re-set the networking, but it also looses all automation routines, including its name and whatever group and settings you had it set up for.My apartment frequently has minor brownouts, the ones that cause your microwave to lose its time, and now my entire smarthome system also needs to be re-configured every time this happens. It seems there is no on-board configuration storage at all, and the Alexa can’t remember the plug after it has been re-connected.I now have three of these useless plugs, and am looking for a replacement system. Perhaps the Philips system will treat me better...
title: Requires a complete reset after every power outage

author: Paul
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2019
review_content: setup started off painful since amazon doesn't include a way to get the MAC address for the device without contacting customer support and the first 2 people couldn't provide it and gave BS excuses as to why it's not included with the product.  Even once i got it teh device still refuses to finalize setup, won't accept saved wifi information so i have to type it every attempt, have to unplug the device between attempts because it won't reset.  Router logs show it connect and is assigned an IP but alexa app always comes back with an error that it couldn't connect the plug to the network and wants to try again (which is starting from scratch).  Really second guessing the investment in echo devices when simple accessories like this don't work taking away a big part of why I wanted them in the first place.
title: doesn't work

author: Shannon Stanhope
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018
review_content: I had a lot of trouble setting up the plug. Initially it seemed like it would go smoothly, but it wouldn't connect to my wifi, which my echo was already set up on. After about an hour of going back to the beginning and resetting the plug, I looked online and saw feedback on other alexa devices not picking up on wifi and learned that the connection can only be 2.4 GHz and the default setting for my wifi is 5. I had to separate out the wifi streams and then also change the wifi my phone was connected to to match the 2.4 setting. Once I did this, it was able to connect and work as advertised. The only other problem I had was the next day it had somehow lost connection and I had to go through the same process again, which is when I actually realized that my phone had to be on the same wifi setting that I was trying to connect the plug to. None of the information about the 2.4 GHz wifi was on the packaging or instructions, which would have been very helpful. There was also little to no online help regarding this issue from amazon, I had to find it on 3rd party forums for echo devices. I understand this is a new product, so hopefully these issues can be improved for the future. I had held off on getting other smart plugs b/c I had heard they were difficult to set up. I got this one hoping it would be easy. Oh and you have to say the command exactly as the plug is labeled (if it is labeled "living room light", you can't say turn on "the living room light" like you would in normal conversation).
title: More difficult to set up than advertised

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2019
review_content: I recently purchased your plugs ABC. Which were used on a business grade network in a residential setting. My tech friend noticed some odd behavior from the devices, The information was even sent to Cisco networks to verify. All of my four plugs randomly change MAC address’s,  or rename it self, Will appear as a LAN device also.Even with virtual VMware type software,  it’s creating network cards out of code, it is largely the same deal, except the allocation of a mac address is up to the host, effectively it "creates" the nic that is given to the guest, and so seeing as none of it is real, the mac is made up, and can be changed at any time. But only to the physical nic. However It rarely is, I want to get there was some type of technical problem. A mac address should remain same, it’s designed to be a static address for hardware.Just simply thought if a device is allowed to change MAC addresses, The MAC address is used to tie a device to a IP address. This can’t be allowed to happen randomly and commonly even if it is Amazon.It took a few weeks to figure out what was happening, and now - of course, my order says it's too late to return these.
title: MAC ADDRESS SPOOFING - THINK TWICE BEFORE PURCHASING

author: T. Dyer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2018
review_content: I received one of these "smart" plugs.  My Alexa app could not find the plug no matter what I did. Returned it for an exchange. New one arrived yesterday.  Same issue. Deleted and updated Alexa App. Still cannot connect to plug. Going to request refund. There is no where to contact anyone to find out trouble shooting techniques. Can't assign anything lower than one star.UPDATE:After reading several other reviews I tried loading the Alexa app to my smart phone instead of using my tablet. The tablet app could not find the plug but the app on the phone did.  The device now works.  The instructions that come with the plug should specify using a smart phone to make the connections.  Included instructions are minimal at best.
title: Not worth the time

author: HSNYC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2019
review_content: The entire purchase experience was a disaster. The plugs were anything but easy to integrate with my eero mesh system. I spent over 3 hours (5 different c/s reps) on the phone with Amazon C/S trying to getting them to work. They were basically clueless. OK, at the end of 3 hours, the bottom line is that there is no way to get the eero (a dual band router) to work with these (2.4 GHz devices) according to Amazon C/S. They gave up and recommended that I call eero. I did. I spent 1 hour on the phone with eero and, after they shut off the 5 Ghz band, we still couldn't get the Amazon Smart Plugs to work. Nada! Nothing! Zip!Backstory - OK so I know that eero is somewhat problematic in working with 2.4 Ghz devices. I previously had the same problem with the HUGOAI Smart plugs and had spent 30 minutes with eero getting them back on line after an update. When it happened a 2nd time (following a firmware update), I was annoyed, and I thought I would upgrade to the Amazon plugs, based on what I read, and avoid this problem in the future. That was not to be. As I said above, the Amazon plugs didn't work. At all. No matter how hard we tried.NB: In that same session with the eero c/s rep (which is without a doubt the best c/s dept I have ever encountered) I decided to go back to the HUGOAI Smart Plugs. It took all of 5 minutes during the eero c/s managed 2.4 Ghz session to get 4 plugs back up and running. If HUGOAI can get their plugs to work with eero, why can't Amazon?As an aside, eero really needs to give customers the ability to disable the 5 Ghz band without having to call c/s. There are still so many devices (especially home automation) that only use the 2.4 Ghz band that it really is a necessity so that customers can avoid the inconvenience of having to call c/s (even if it is excellent and 24/7) to get devices to connect. Irrespective of this inconvenience, I am still a big eero fan.
title: Does NOT work with eero mesh system

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
review_content: The set-up for the amazon smart plug could not have been easier.  As soon as I plugged in the smart plug to the wall it was automatically connected to my Alexa app.  I did already have other devices like the Echo, etc. connected to my Alexa so that may have helped in the smooth connection of the smart plug.I simply plugged in the lamp to the smart plug and turned the lamp to the "on" position.  I went to the Devices setting in the Alexa app, selected the new smart plug and renamed it "Lamp".  I could then ask Alexa to turn on/off the lamp.  It was also very simple to add a daily "Routine" in the Alexa app for the lamp to automatically turn on/off at a certain time each day.  There is so much helpful information and things you can do in the Alexa app.  There is a great Help button in the top right corner of the Home screen on the Alexa app that will assist in the different functions available and troubleshooting.
title: Effortless hook-up

author: D. Cormack
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2018
review_content: This is a great item from Amazon. It can be used for so many things in your house. Voice activation is great but you can also set up a schedule for when you want the item plugged into this to turn on or off. I have a Magic Mirror (a DIY project using a Raspberry Pi if you want to look it up on Google) and I use this to power it on and off. I set a schedule to turn the monitor on at 6am and turn it off at 1 am since nobody will be looking at it over night. If I want to turn the display off or on outside of these times, I can simply issue a voice command (or use the Alexa app on my iPhone).I plan to get more to control some Christmas decorations and lighting indoors. One will go to my tree lights and one will be for some decorations which are high up on a shelf. It's a great item to plug in your lamps too. You can use this while away on vacation to turn lights on or off (scheduled or manually for random activity).
title: Bought One, will buy more!

author: Ed Macias
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2018
review_content: Very nice, after some troubleshooting with Amazon tech support, which to me the best customer service that I ever had to deal with, the problem was that it would connect to my WiFi network but Alexa would say the device ( what ever name you give it) it’s not responding, some of their best tech support here in the USA called me and they found out that it was my firewall in my Comcast router/ modem that was blocking it, but now that the issue has been taking care of, it works great, I’m going to buy a few more and I know what I’m going to give my grown kids for this holiday, I definitely recommend it this product
title: Works great

author: TONY T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2019
review_content: I started the year with my first Echo.  Soon after got two Dots.  Was preparing to gradually ramp up the entire home to be "Alexa" enabled.  Rather than starting with switches and lights, I thought I would start with Amazon's own Smart Plugs.  Got the first two last week and they connected easily and quickly.  Named one for a Fan and another for Night Lights.  After that, I left them.  Tested On then Off and all was working.  A couple of hours later, Device Unresponsive for each.  During that time, I had ordered a third one thinking all was good.A day or two later, I re-added the two during the middle of the day.  All was working again.  When I got home from work, Device Unresponsive for each.Today, Saturday, I spent time with customer support.  I could not understand them well so they sent me to someone in the U.S.  We removed the devices again and added the first two.  All was working as expected.  I then added the third one on another floor and it, too, was working fine.  Set up a couple of routines for timed on and off.Went out for lunch and came home and was going to show how these work and Device Unresponsive for all three plugs.  This morning she told me to call back if they drop off so I did.  I got another difficult to understand person and he was starting to have me reset and do the same thing again.  I asked him to troubleshoot.  He said that is how they troubleshoot because the devices are too simple.  There is nothing else to do.  Not ONCE did anyone say, let's check the settings in the app.  Absolutely NO troubleshooting was done.  I had to explain that resetting the device and doing the same thing is not troubleshooting.  That is what he calls troubleshooting.He told me there was nothing else to do and was going to issue a refund.  I asked again if he would try to troubleshoot and he said there is nothing left to do.So far, my experience with Echo is that it's nothing more than a glorified music player.  Currently, that's all I can use it for and my phone did that just fine with bluetooth speakers before Echo came into my home.  The goal was that music would be the least Echo's in the house would do but instead it looks like that's all they can do.Customer service for these could not be worse.  The guy didn't even ask a single network question other than if it is a dual band network.  It is.  He asked me if it was 5G meaning 5Ghz and I explained that, yes, it is but I know the plugs only work on 2.4Ghz.  Yes, it's dual.  Yes 2.4Ghz is turned on.  That's why they connected in the first place.I would love to hear from a qualified person at Amazon who really knows what to do with these devices.  Hopefully before they are returned.  He was so quick to issue a refund.  I'd be willing to try something but no one offered anything to try but start over again.I have a dual band eero network which sounds like Amazon is about to buy.  I have great wifi coverage with the eero's in the home (7).  Nothing else drops off of the network - just these plugs.I'm sure it's too late to return the Echo's but I would at this point.  We've got playing music covered.
title: Bad Experience.  Terrible Support.  Not Recommended

author: mijagourlay
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2020
review_content: I have 2 of these Amazon Smart Plugs. Both of them power down unexpectedly when they lose their network connection. This sometimes causes severe problems. Read on.I am conversant in smart home devices; most work well, and this is the only one that causes severe problems. I have many other Alexa devices (Echo Show, Echo Dots, Echo Pros, Echo Spot, Echo Flex, Kindles, etc.) and other smart devices (Leviton plugs, Topgreener switches and plugs, Philips Hue bulbs, Amazon Cloud Cam, Wyze cameras, Furbo, etc.). I have set them up in multiple locations. Occasionally I see some of the other devices lose their connection, and others in the location will follow. By itself, that is annoying, but meanwhile those devices become merely unresponsive. In horrible contrast, this Amazon Smart Plug POWERS DOWN, bringing down whatever is plugged into it. Note that the other smart plus and switches, even when they temporarily lose network connectivity, do NOT power down themselves or the devices they control -- they simply become temporarily unresponsive to commands mediated by Alexa. But that's tolerable because they all have other ways of being controlled which I can fall back on. (So does the Amazon Smart Plug -- it has a built-in switch.) The only smart device I have used that works so poorly is this Amazon Smart Plug; it's infuriating.I have one of my computers plugged into this Amazon Smart Plug so I can power-cycle the machine remotely. So when the Amazon Smart Plug loses internet connection and powers down, my machine powers down also.In fact, while writing this review, the machine powered down twice. I want to imbue life into this stupid plug so that I can strangle it to death. I hate it.In summary, these plugs are worse than useless -- they're detrimental. Stay away.
title: AVOID. Keeps powering down unexpectedly, wreaking havoc.

author: Kevin Bender
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2018
review_content: 2/17/19 Update: I think three stars is about as high as I can go on the Amazon Smart Plug. I recently had to reset it numerous times to get it to respond properly, so the problem's still there on occasion. Also, Comcast's incompetence as of late has caused me to discover another issue in that the Amazon Smart Plug doesn't work when your Internet connection goes down. No, I don't mean that it doesn't respond; it literally won't even power the device that's plugged into it in the event that your Internet connection goes down. It's really, really dumb.12/14/2018 Update: As promised, here's another star, since the Amazon Smart Plug is still behaving itself. I'm leaving the rest of the review the same, however.I'm going to update my review, as the Amazon Smart Plug has seemingly decided to behave itself. I bought these in October to replace a TP-LINK smart plug that eventually died on me. I figured that I'd give Amazon's official solution a shot, since I already used Alexa to control a heater and some lights. On occasion, the TP-LINK smart plug would stop responding to the point that I'd have to set it up again each time. For a while, the Amazon Smart Plug was doing the same thing, albeit much more often. It happened at least once a week, and I'd set it up again each time.A while back, it happened again, so I just unplugged it for a short time and plugged it back in. I haven't had an issue with it since. *knocks on wood* As such, I'm tentatively increasing my rating by one star, leaving it at two stars. Assuming that it continues to behave, I'll potentially continue that trend and increase my rating further. I don't know if it received a stealth firmware update or what, but it seems fine now.
title: The Amazon Smart Plug seems to have finally started behaving itself. Yay?

author: robin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2018
review_content: This thing is killing me. I just got the echo dot and a non Amazon brand wifi speaker and lightbulb. They paired PERFECTLY (yay!)....so, on to the the amazon smart plug. Should be a snap since they are brand friendly, right? Nope. That’s when the “yay!” feelings ended. It’s been a couple hours of messing with it so far. Got it to work for a second. Then? Not so much. The stupid thing just won’t pair and that’s annoying since I specifically got an amazon plug with the understanding it would “seamlessly pair” with my echo dot. Nope. Not seamless. At all. For Christmas I also got a couple non amazon smart plugs. I think I’ll try them since all my other non amazon stuff has set up flawlessly with the echo dot - in just a few seconds.  Nothing I hate more than being driven crazy by supposedly simple things. I’ll just go turn on the coffee maker my dang myself and save 25 bucks and several hours of time. Bummer I really wanted it to work.
title: This thing is sucking the life out of me. Seriously.

author: Michael Tumler
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Used 5 of them for almost a year and worked great. Now they all won’t work with a message “device unresponsive”
title: Stopped working!!!!!

author: Btagent2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2018
review_content: I love that if I get in bed and forgot to shut off my main light I dont have to get up. Just tell Alexa to turn it off. One day the light in the other room got left on. I need dark to sleep. Then I realized I could turn it off from my bed. That was great!Oh no what have I done? I got tricked by my husband and daughter because my husband got the Alexa ap. They kept turning my light back on after I asked it to turn off. I thought it was defective. Then when they came in and I told them. My husband said, "It's almost as if someone was listening and was whispering to Alexa to turn the light on from another room." Then I was like "yes!" Then they started laughing so hard. Until I reminded them that I was resting because I had a headache. My husband says "Oops I forgot." It was funny.Also,My husband liked this present and then went on to buy multiple more. Then discovered the Alexa powered lightbulbs. They can turn colors by Alexa command. Lol every one of these gets a special name you choose per light. So I can turn on a light in the bedroom upstairs from any room and make it blue or pink. Wild world.
title: Great present. Read my experience. I love it.

author: Romina Contreras
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2019
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.         Me encanta 😊 😂
title: Bueno

author: Judy D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2019
review_content: I dislike the fact that these plugs are very hard to set up.  I had to scan the code on the plug (while out of the plug) then as fast as possible, plug it in and hope it would connect.  This took several tries.  I have not found a way to change the name of the plug - not wanting them to be plug 1, 2, 3, etc..  The first plug keeps going off and I don't remember the EXACT name given to the plug by Amazon  so I have to turn it on using my phone instead of Alexa, as I had hoped to do.I have 4 cheap Smart Plugs and I was able to name them and they have worked perfectly since the day they were installed.  Alexa knows where they are and she turns them on and off faithfully.I do not recommend the expensive Amazon  smart plugs.  I find them temperamental.
title: EXPENSIVE AND NOT RECOMMENDED BY ME

author: Reviewed by Charles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: When I scan the "barcode" (it's actually a QR code) it says unknown failure, then I move on to the 2nd way of setting it up by plugging it in and turning it on and holding the button until it blinks Blue/Red......After awhile of searching it says "Unknown Failure" again. I tried the "try again" several times and I also canceled the set up and started over from the beginning more than 5 times. Total attempts 18.Since the error code says "try again later", I did later that night, then the next day 3 different sessions, 8-10 times each session. Then I tried again today 2 sessions of 10 attempts.It powers on, the light blinks but it will not connect to the app and it does not allow power through it, I assume it's like that for safety reasons but like they say, if you assume it makes an ass out of you and me, mainly me.I'm done with this POS, NEXT....
title: Does Not Work !

author: Kittythecat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Purchased last year’s Black Friday sale works fine until now, just stop working today. Tried many times still won’t connect to WiFi and Alexa app couldn’t find it 😡
title: Work for one year

author: ariy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2019
review_content: I Already have TPLink plugs and switches throughout the house, so I wondered about the wisdom of adding another device that works differently from the rest, but i control everything with Alexa anyway and why not remove a 3rd party from the process?  I was also attracted by the promise of easy setup.  And so it was.  If you already have an account linked to Echos and leave the box checked when you order to link it, it arrives preconfigured.  I have poor vision so I may have missed it, but the only way to make this better would be to provide a way to name the plug at purchase.  That way it truly would be ready to use as soon as you plug it in.  That was the only thing I had to do.  Depending on the sophistication of your setup, you may also want to assign it to a group, but that is not necessary for it to work.  I did not like that it was automatically added to to one of my existing groups and not the one i wanted.  It was the one suggested by the order page, and I did not see a way of changing it there.
title: Most painless setup ever

author: Tim
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2019
review_content: I've had this for about 6 months now and it was okay until now. It is connected to a PC that runs 24/7 with a UPS backup.If you know anything about running PCs 24/7 they will occasionally freeze, blue screen, computers aren't perfect, etc.So imagine my surprise when a few days in a row my computer is off for no reason.I tuned it back on, everything seems fine, life goes on.Then I had an Internet provider outage, 5 minutes into it the PC turns off. What? Why?Turn it back on, turns right back off 5 minutes later.Well, the geniuses who built this decided that if your Wi-Fi connection drops it should kill the power to the device that's connected. So if you're doing a Windows update and it loses connection to the Internet, oops, gone, good luck reinstalling Windows.If you do a quick search you'll find people wondering why things are turned off unexpectedly and the response is 'Did you lose Internet connection?'
title: Useless for NAS, PC, or anything you don't want to turn off when your Internet connection drops.

author: Rev2010
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019
review_content: *UPDATE 5/22/19 - Saw my Echo appear to be receiving an update last night. As of this morning I noticed both plugs showing the red LED. Tried EVERYTHING to get them working again, deleting and re-adding them etc, nothing works. Echo find them and connects but then they immediately go red and the app shows a server error (Server Unresponsive I think it was). On with Amazon Support now creating a ticket. I truly hate these things, nothing but a total headache.*UPDATE 5/1/19 - have to edit my review and remove two stars. The reason is every once in a while the darn things drop their connection to the Echo and reconnecting them to the Echo is a pain that often takes several attempts. They continue to provide power, they just can't be controlled until re-synced. This is especially a problem if you control power to something remotely from your phone.Using this to control power to a wine cooler/beverage center fridge that I use as a fermentation chamber for my beer brewing. Went with this as opposed to other popular brands as I didn't want to have to create 3rd party web accounts then link them and all that hassle. Setup was a cinch and controlling on/off power to the fridge works perfectly. I've also checked and there's no unusual heat whatsoever from the smartplug, it's nice and ambient temperature to the touch. Also went with these so I could fit two vertically in the standard dual wall outlet. My firdge's max temp is 61F so for $25 it's a no brainer to be able to control on/off to my fermentation chamber with my voice and not have to keep pulling the plug out of the wall once fermentation slows and temps start dropping.
title: *EDIT - both plugs stopped working as of today 5/22!

author: 🥇Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2018
review_content: I’m thrilled with this device!  I’m tired of managing too many apps and skills for various devices.  I want everything to be Amazon only.  That’s why I purchased the Cloud Cam and now why I’ve purchased the Amazon-branded Smart Plugs.The set up was easy; however, because our router uses Mac filtering, that was a bit of a pain.  As far as I can tell, the Plug, like the Cloud Cam, does not have an easily identifiable Mac Address.  For all my other devices (Echos, Fire tablets, Fire TVs), I can look in the Alexa app for that device’s settings, tap About, and see the Mac Address.  There is no Mac Address shown for the Plug.  What I had to do was temporarily disable Mac Filtering on my router (via the router settings), set up the Plug, then re-enable Mac Filtering.  I really don’t know how Mac Filtering works, but my router is allowing wi-fi access to the Plug.When I first set up the Plug, there were no specific instructions in the Alexa app.  I had to tap the Devices icon (looks like spoons in a house) in the lower right, then the + sign in the upper right.  I changed the device Type to a Light (from a Plug) because I have nightlights plugged into my Smart Plugs.  I also kept the names short because Alexa can get fussy and we can’t remember all the names.  We’ve got Kitchen Light, Dining Light, Den Light, etc.There was a message box about giving access to my location to my Smart Plug, lol.  I elected to Cancel that; not sure why my Smart Plug needs access to my location.So far, everything works great.  It’s a much better configuration than the motion-activated lights I previously had.  It’s a lot easier to manage a single app.  However, it’s just basic on/off.  It’s not possible to do themes, or dimming, or a sundown/sunset schedule.  That’s okay with me; I want simple.The only thing I don’t like is that the Plug is bigger than I expected.  It’s big, almost like a Twinkie.  I didn’t look at the dimensions before I purchased it; my bad.  It’s too wide for a Decora combo switch/outlet (see 2 attached photos).  It blocks the switch.Addendum:  I have five of these Amazon plugs.  Now that I’ve used them for a month, I notice they all frequently emit a super high-pitched eeeeeeee.  Sometimes it’s very noticeable within 4 feet or so of the plug, other times it’s not noticeable at all.  I still love the convenience of the plugs.Second addendum:  I’ve now twice had my internet service go down for a period of time.  When that happens, all the devices plugged into the Smart Plugs also go down.  In my case, I’ve got night lights on all my plugs.  So, if the internet goes down at night, the house goes completely dark.  Annoying.  I don’t view this as a Plug problem, but it’s a downside of relying on something (Alexa and the Smart Plugs) that relies on the internet.
title: Excellent device that works flawlessly with Alexa (don’t need any other app or skill, hurray!)

author: C. L. Washington
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2019
review_content: Wow, my life has changed.  Rather, I should say that my plant's life has changed.  I'm not good on remembering things, so I asked Alexa to remind me to turn on the plant light at 1:00 p.m. which she dutifully did.  However I was often engaged in something that prevented me from actually doing it right then.  So I'd intend to turn it on when I finished my project.  However, I would forget, and my poor plant would droop because it needed light.  So, I'd read about the smart plug but thought it would be complicated and require special wiring and what not.  Finally I tried it.  Voila, my plant gets light daily now because all I need to do is call to Alexa to turn on the plant light.  I am astonished that it took nothing more than to plug the smart plug into the outlet, follow the directions on the Alexa site and start using.  It's a miracle I think every time I say "Alexa, turn on the plant light."I'm also going to get one for my computer desk lamp which I always forget to turn off.
title: It

author: John
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2019
review_content: I found this on sale at the time, so thought I'd give the whole "home integration" thing a try.  I already have an Echo Show 5 and love it, so figured I'd take it a step further like they show on all the Echo commercials.Today, I received the device in the mail.  I promptly unwrapped it, ran through the instruction book (very sparse, btw), connected it to an outlet and threw in my floor lamp.  After trying to get it set up through Alexa app on my phone along with asking Alexa to "find ne wdevices", neither bore any fruit.  I keep getting errors on the app when the device tries to connect to my network (everything is set up and ready for it to connect, and it even pulled a DHCP IP address from the router).  I tried connecting to "configure me" wifi hotspot and run through the same deal on Alexa app.After 45 minutes (closer to an hour) of frustration, I decided my time was much better spent on my other projects and not going grey over a device that I really don't need (hey, using fingers to turn on and off the light might be "old school", but IT JUST WORKS!).I'll keep the device for now, and hopefully see about getting it to work this weekend.... IF it's not a dud.  Only time will tell, I guess.  Honestly, though, it might be better to find something else to waste your time on.
title: 45 minutes wasted

author: Tim
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
review_content: I am glad I got this on black Friday at 5$, because I would have been most disappointing if I spent the full 20$ on it! It works as advertised, and its really cool, however, once I got it and set it up, I realized that I couldnt use it for what I really wanted to use it for, which was my lights. You COULD, but but plugging a light into it, it means you can basically never use your light switch traditionally again. Sometimes I dont want to use Alexa, so that was not an option for me. Once it shuts it off, the light switch is obviously not ever going to turn the lights on. I really thought about what I could plug into this that I would be ok with only using my voice to control, and the only thing I could find was our Christmas tree lights! So in the end of it all, its just seasonal. Still cool, but not sure what I am going to do with it once Christmas is over!Update *** we have moved, and since found more uses for it. We moved into a house that doesnt have as many light switches controlling convenient outlets, so this is a great way to supplement that. We are currently using this for our fishtank light, which we programemd to turn on and off every day, as well as another random light in our house. We also have another non-Amazon branded plug, and we prefer the ease of integration with all of our Echos much more than our other brand.
title: Its a cool product, but kind of useless.

author: LegoDad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020
review_content: I have gone through SO many plug types from the first set I got years ago.  I have about 80 smart devices on my wifi network at home, dozens of them smart plugs like this.I've gone through all the setup types - connect to a temp wireless network on the device to set it up, have the device found via bluetooth, etc...I'll give Amazon this much - this was the EASIEST to set up.  Plugged it in, and that was it.  Before I had a chance to do anything else, my Echo Show in the great room told me it found and setup and named the plug, First Plug.So yeah, Amazon rocked it with that setup.  Then in the Alexa app I was able to rename it just fine.I've replaced a lot of the plugs as I tried to consolidate into the SmartLife app.  I was tired of having half a dozen programs and having to remember what devices were controlled by what apps.  Yes, they all worked with Alexa but sometimes I needed to do it via an app.  So if it's not SmartLife compatible I don't buy it now.  These only integrate directly into the Alexa app, so that's a downside to me.Then there's the other ways this fails then.  This is ridiculously priced compared to just about every other BETTER option out there.And it did not pass my first test I always do - power on the plug, then simulate a power loss.  Real plugs, things designed well, should ALWAYS come back on in the last state.  If it was off when power was lost, it should stay off when power is restored.  If it was ON when power was lost, it should be ON when power is restored.  And these Amazon plugs utterly fail that.In Wisconsin here we can get severe weather, and random power losses, even sometimes just for a split second, but it's enough to render things like this useless when it doesn't come back on again.I use these for my fridge, for my aquarium, so the inability to resume power if it was on is a massive design fail in my eyes.These also lack the ability to monitor and track energy usage and cost.  SO MANY of the alternatives out there that cost less can track energy use and cost and turn back on when power is restored.So while this is amazing for how simple it is to set up, it's an utter fail in every other respect.
title: Easiest to set up but that's the ONLY benefit

author: Kelly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: Absolutely love it although I got only one on Black Friday for $4.99 I wish I was able to buy more at that price so I could plug in other things other than my lamp worth the 24 99 normal price if you could afford to spend that much and you would have to buy a few of them in order to use them with different appliances or lamps and the like. And since I'm like most people in the US and world who has pay the High Cost of Living such as rent food phone internet car insurance as well as health insurance and Medicine and everything else in order to just live a very basic life while making next to nothing it's something I would think you would have to save for it to be a splurge purchase as I did with the echo and had to save even more for the cube for my dad as a birthday gift. No complaints at all it's a very cool little Gadget the whole smart Echo thing is very cool in general. Even those things are pricey so at 2499 it's expected to be that price so it's no surprise. If you can afford it go for it, I sure would. In my case and probably many others although I could be wrong I'm going to have to buy Alexa products spaced out overtime one by one and by that time a new edition of something would come out LOL but in all seriousness it's really cool I like it it was a great price I wouldn't have bought it otherwise cuz I have to eat and pay bills and that takes precedence. And you can't just buy one plug because it takes the fun out of it or however you would describe it basically you can turn a lamp on or radio or something through voice command and that's it so you have to buy more than one plug to make it worth it if that makes sense so you can control multiple things in your house instead of just a lamp
title: Love it very cool and fun you can't just buy one plug though wouldn't be worth it

author: Christopher L. Barber
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2019
review_content: This plug is 2Ghz wifi only. That's sad to say, but it is clearly labeled as such. That wouldn't be such an epic failure if it weren't for the stupid Echo devices that happily connect to your 5Ghz band and are then unable to recognize these plugs. Really, Amazon, we're nearly 20 years into the 21st century. This whole Smart Home domain is so spectacularly immature in terms of technical quality, homogeneity, interoperability... this kind of rubbish is not the way to present your products. You, out of all of the competitors in this market, should stand up it and do it right. But instead you come up with a smart plug device that right out of the box stands at best a 50% chance of working with your own Echo products. Realistically more like 25% because I suspect that the Echos will default to 5G on a dual band network. and how many people are going to be running 2G-only networks in their home? How about in five years?  Way to poison your own well, Amazon. My Echo Dot was easier to integrate with your competitor's smart home hub than with these stupid plugs. "Smart" plug... that's being generous.So anyways, for anyone still reading, if your Echo won't recognize your plug, it's probably because you have a dual band wifi router, and your Echo is on the 5Ghz band. These plugs for sure will be on the 2Ghz band and that is a no-go.  This is typical of these kind of devices - lots of manufactures document this, or consumers end up figuring it out on their own - but in the end you've got to get your Echo on the 2G band on the and on the same SSID as the plugs. Oh, and probably whatever phone or tablet or whatever you're using to do the configuration too. That's what I just did. What a pain. I created a new SSID enabled for 2G only on my access point and rejoined the echos, the plugs, and my tablet to that SSID. And yes, I verified that the Echos were previously on the 5G band. Definitely, they were. And I could see the plugs on the 2G band. Thing is, just putting the Echos on 2G is not sufficient. I did this first, just to check. They have to be in the same SSID as well, unless your wifi gadget is willing to do some channel bonding tricks that mine doesn't do.  Really, how many consumers are going to figure this out and know how to reconfigure things?
title: Nice try, Amazon, but you're not winning any awards with this

author: James Steed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2019
review_content: Step 1) They claim Alexa will automatically notice the plug and add it. Nope, didn't happen.Step 2) Scan a barcode in the app and it will automatically be set up by the Alexa App. Nope, get a 4 number error code that is not in the documentation or Google-able. This is a Bluetooth-based install which never even pretended to make progress for me.Step 3) Hold the power button til it flashes red/blue lights and then the Alexa App will set it up "manually." Nope, it just hangs forever and doesn't do anything. This is a Wifi-based install using the Wifi emitting from the plug.Step 4) Try steps 2 and 3 a million times. Read a 7 page thread on Amazon support that provides no way to troubleshoot.Step 5) Throw it in the trash and apologize to the family members you told you could set up a smart plug for them quickly. Perhaps consider getting an off brand you've used before instead of trusting the brand name "Amazon" to mean anything.UPDATE: I finally was able to get it to work by disabling Bluetooth to force a Wifi-based install (when the phone asks to turn on Bluetooth, press cancel to avoid that step). Multiple phones errored out of the Bluetooth install and trying the Bluetooth install seemed to mess up the Wifi-based install before it even started. With Bluetooth enabled, the fun was not over though because the Wifi signal from the plug was so weak it timed out repeatedly even with the phone sitting on top of the plug. The one-star rating remains and is fully earned by Amazon by this very poor product. Amazon should stop pushing this product on customers by selling below cost because it only goes to harm their reputation.
title: Won't connect to network

author: LivingAbroad
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2019
review_content: I own two of these.  One is plugged into a lamp in my bedroom and the other is plugged into a lamp on the landing at the top of the stairs going to the second level of the house.  They both connected to my network easily, Alexa found them and I was able to change their "Name".  They are also associated with different functions so when I say "Alexa, it's bedtime" all the bedroom lights and the landing light turn on.  When I say "Alexa, Goodnight" the other lights in the house (connected to other smart devices) turn off but these two stay on.  And in the morning when I say "Alexa, Good Morning"  these two lights turn off.At least that's what is supposed to happen.  However, the one in the bedroom has always had issues staying connected and about a week ago it disconnected from the network and never reconnected.  When it started having problems I could use the switch on the side to turn the lamp on but that has stopped working as well.  I have not reached out to Amazon but at this point, since I'm only getting about a 50% functionality, I will probably stick with some of the other products I have that have not had any issues.This may go without saying but this product will not work with Google Home (probably some workarounds but I don't like workarounds).  Google Home has other issues but if you already have it and do not want to add Alexa to your network then I would look for another product.
title: Great when it works

author: Ralph
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2020
review_content: I bought this plug for 24.99 and activated during promotion that 24 will be given back. But they did not, contacted customer support and they were clueless and refused, so returned the piece of junk back. Anyways getting it to get activated is a pain in the rear. Absolutely not worth 25. I returned it as usual Amazon tried to prove what priciples it is standing on. And we are stupid to support this mega corp.
title: Amazon an empire built on deceiving and cheating proves it again. Failed to honor promotion

author: Eric Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2019
review_content: So smart implies that a device is able to do things that are helpful and should make life easier. By locking this device in the Alexa echo system is one of the dumbest devices ever made. I got it at a reduced cost and still feel ripped off. It isn’t open to any other automation so the the problem only control is on/off. No routines, no timers, no access by any other apps to build multiple smart things to happen at once. Yes I read and it said use Alexa, but why wouldn’t it be any or all of the open standards so anyone could control an on and off. The app loads slowly and is three steps to get to plugs to only have on or off. I can’t have it turn my heater on so room is warm before I am in it. As is by design, it is as dumb as I am for needing to speak to it to use it instead of automating my life like Alexa Skynet should. Only buy this if you only use echo and intend to never have a smart anything else ever. Amazon click zigbee or whatever and upgrade firmware and I will give it 5 stars.
title: Echo Alexa only makes it a dumb smart plug

author: RichL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2018
review_content: My wife and I have separate accounts linked as family.  All of my other Alexa devices can be controlled from either of our phones, or by direct command through the Echo devices.  All of my "smart home" devices appear on the alexa web interface.... except this one.I am unable to add this device to both accounts, so it can only be controlled through one account or the other.  Attempting to add it to the other account results in it being removed from the first account.Running "Discover" on the Smart Home Devices page does not reveal this product on the 2nd account, even though it is connected to my WiFi network.Also, I changed the name from "First Plug" to "Kitchen Fan" in the app, and even though the device appears in the alexa web interface, it still appears as "First Plug"...  yet Alexa responds and controls it as "Kitchen Fan"I can tolerate it, as my wife is the only one who uses that fan and we generally keep the Echo devices logged in to her account, but I will not be buying another one.  I was really hoping that this would be as seamless as it looked like, as I've been wanting to migrate from my Leviton switches and plugs to something more alexa-friendly.
title: It works, but integration is lacking

author: Sunni
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: They were great for about 1 1/2 yrs. then one sluwef in responding and then quit a few days later. Then our 2 of 2 Smart Plug died. I tried 5 different steps. Nothing. Still unresponsive. I spent over $50.00 for plugs that left us in the dark, crawling behind our couch and trying to move a bed to heavy to do it myself. Wasteof money and activation. I messaged for help and just sat in the dark. No one there when I needed them most.
title: Left in the DARK!!

author: Charles A. Burton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2018
review_content: I have two other brands of smart plugs: VeSync and Kasa.  These plugs were fast and easy to get to work with the Amazon Echo/Alexa, even though they required the installation of additional apps on my phone to accomplish the syncing.  So, I bought three of the Amazon brand smart plugs, thinking they would be even easier.HOWEVER.  The Amazon smart plugs were a royal pain to use.  First of all, their WiFi receivers must be some of the weakest on the planet.  In places where my Kasa and VeSync plugs work beautifully, the Amazon plugs stumble and stutter and say they cannot sync. And when I look at the app, it tells me that the WiFi signal there is barely a single dot at the bottom of the triangle, when my phone says I have four bars PLUS the dot, when I put it right beside the plug.  It took me multiple tries to get the Amazon plugs to connect to the WiFi network, and that happened only after I moved them closer to the WiFi source.  I had to remove them and re-insert them into the receptacles a number of times. After they connected, I could move them a little farther away, but not a lot.You would think that plugs MADE by Amazon would sync easily and smoothly with the Amazon Alexa app.  Sadly, not at all true.  I definitely will NOT buy any more of these plugs, and since I am within my return period, I am seriously considering sending them back for refunds.
title: Disappointing even though I finally got them to work

author: nedjorg
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018
review_content: 10/29/2018.  Received follow-up call from Amazon tech support.  My plug has been responding since I re-installed on Oct 28 evening with leaving the plug default name as 'First Plug'.  I did not add the plug to routines until after I spoke with tech support.  Apparently Alexis does not respond well when the name of the device includes a number.  I originally renamed my plug, 'Kitchen Light 2' and was getting 'unresponsive' messages.  The best way to name the device in this scenario is to instead name it 'Kitchen Light Two'.
