I have not had any problems since and am grateful for the quick action by the Amazon Customer Service Team to help resolve my issue.--------------10/28/2018. I received a call from Amazon within a couple hours of my original posting.  I was not at home at the time so instead am working on scheduling a time for a support call.  But when I got home that night I re-installed the plug.  For now it is working.  I'm going to hold off on making any changes to it, such as, device name, routines, or scenes until it seems stable... since my first experience it installed ok and worked at first.  I increased my 2-start rating to a 4-star rating because of the immediate follow-up from my first review posting and because it is currently working.  I have other plugs in my home to compare to the Amazon plug.  I have 3 other TP-Link plugs in my home that have been working without much issues over the past 1+ year.  I will update this review as I gain more experience with the new Amazon plug.--------------------------10/28/2018. Original review post.  The set-up was easy for me. It recognized my wi-fi with no problem connecting.  It also worked immediately after install with voice or app commands.  However, it later has problems responding to commands, voice or app.  Still trying to toubleshoot.
title: Easy and successful install, responsive customer service to user error

author: Maury Bredahl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2019
review_content: I purchased four to use with three echos.  The first echo is located in the living room and controls a plug to control a light and the backlight for the TV.  The second has worked flawlessly but the first simply stops working a couple times a week, turning the light off as it becomes non-responsive.  After a bit, it starts working.  I use the Alexa app on an iPad to tweak it to start up.The third plug is in a bedroom and meant to turn on a bedside light.  It would randomly become non-responsive.  I tried a WiFi extender with the suspicion that the Network was the problem.  It would not work at all with that.  I moved it to a different wall outlet and it is working now.I never contacted tech support.  The plugs are really neat but seem pretty flaky!
title: Neat when they work.

author: Sophia Jung
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2018
review_content: EDIT: I got a replacement device a few days ago. The high-pitched noise is still there, but it's less frequent and much less noticeable (you can only hear it if you're right next to the smart plug), so I'm updating my review to 4-stars.The setup was super easy, which is a huge step up from all the other smart plugs out there. I also really like the design - it leaves the other outlet open and it also feels like it’s made of high-quality material. BUT! When the smart plug is turned off, it makes a very small, very annoying, high-pitched humming sound. It makes a high-pitched, muted beeping sound whenever the light blinks, too. I’m hoping I just got a defective product - will return and order another one. I will update this review with 5-stars if the new smart plug I receive does not make the high-pitched noise.
title: super easy set up, annoying high-pitched hum

author: G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2020
review_content: First this Alexa app/device does nothing useful and after using it for quite a while and spending way too much money on stupid devices I can tell you this Alexa thing is stupid and a waste of time and money. Do yourself a favor and just shoot yourself in the head before buying these devices. I can turn lights on and off much better and easier without Alexa. I can search better I can select music better in fact I can do everything better than Alexa.  My life was better before Alexa and I was not angry before Alexa. She hardly ever understands what you ask her for and buy the time you repeat yourself over and over you should of just did it yourself. These AI devices are junk and have no useful purpose currently.
title: Do not waste your energy, time, money on these crappy AI devices there is no "I" in these devices

author: B. Brady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2018
review_content: I decided to wait to review this until I'd been using it for several weeks.  Set up was very simple - this is the first smart plug I have purchased and used.  I am using it to turn on a lamp in my bedroom.  Intermittently Alexa will tell me there is no lamp and/or the plug will lose it's blue light and I know it's not working properly.  Kind of frustrating and not entirely sure of the cause.  The price point on this is higher than other smart plugs I have seen, so I probably wouldn't purchase again until I had tried a different brand.  Overall I am happy, but not overjoyed with it sometimes not working.
title: Works great ...when it works.

author: Murray M Thibodeaux
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2019
review_content: If the power goes off then turns back on, the Amazon Smart Plug will not resume operation unless you MANUALLY restart the device with the power button or phone APP.  This defeats the purpose of Smart Devices.  In my case, I use Smart Plugs to control timed devices in my Greenhouse.  A small heater on a timer keeps my plants from dying.  If the power goes off and turns back on the Amazon Smart Plug will be in OFF position.  This OFF position, if occurring during a very cold day, will not turn on the heater and plants die.  The Amazon Smart Plug WILL turn back on at the preset start time but if many hours have passed before the preset start time, it may be too late and kill your plants.  I DO NOT recommend this or ANY Smart Plug that does not automatically resume the programed schedule if power is lost and restored.
title: Power outage causes restart failure, I do not recommend!

author: Irene
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: These plugs went offline and cannot be connected again!  Error message of Provisional Error.  NO CUSTOMER SERVICE!  DON’T WASTE YOUR MONEY!UPDATE:  the plugs mysteriously went back on line this morning.  It appears to have been an Amazon communication issue since other people had the same problem on the same day.Up until this issue, this was the most reliable smart plug I’ve used.  The customer service issues are still terrible though.
title: Plugs went offline ** UPDATE**

author: AmazonShopper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2018
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           This is a life changer. I have a cute little Light up tree connected to this plug. I used to have to open a cabinet, reach around until my arm was numb to access the plug. Now I just tell Alexa to turn it on & off. It was so easy to setup. Just don’t lose your setup card in case you accidentally delete the plug from your Alexa app- you’ll need the code on the back to set it up again. Wonderful product! 100% improvement from those old digital timers. I’m buying another one right now. ❤️❤️❤️
title: Works great, easy setup!

author: Stan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
review_content: It works as you'd expect a smart plug to work BUT...1. IT'S HUGE! This thing single-handedly takes up 1.5 plugs on my power strip, so if I wanted to use another outlet on the power strip, I can't. It works from a wall reasonably enough if the other plugin is a normal non power adapter plug. But that's assuming you conveniently have wall plugs everywhere you'd like them to be. Honestly though, that's forgivable.Now we move onto the things that can't be forgiven...2. The price for this single smart plug costs $24.99...For $15 less, I can get similar smart plug at $9.99 or for $8 more I could get a 4 pack for $32.99The only way to get this product seemingly cheaper is through the bundle with the 3rd Generation Echo Dot which by itself, currently is $49.99 but is on sale (Again "currently") for $29.99. The bundle price for the Dot and the Plug being $44.98.So you end up paying $15 more just because the product has Amazon etched on the on the top? -_-3. Lastly, this product seems to purposely trap you into the Alexa ecosystem or "Echo-system," pardon the pun. This plug can ONLY work with Alexa and nothing else. Other products like this can be used by themselves with the OPTION of being integrated with Alexa, Google, IFTTT and even Apple's Home kit with the less competent AI; Siri.In summary, this product to me is just a marketing ploy to convince consumers into buying Alexa products in bulk via bundles, convincing the buyer that they're saving money when they're not and trapping them into the Alexa ecosystem.I don't appreciate any company purposely trying to pigeonhole me into either buying their products or trying to lock me in their "echo-system" with their products, forcing me to use that company as my "Sole-provider" of smart devices or -insert blank-In conclusion, there are products with less convoluted and earnest marketing strategies, more functionality and adaptability, at better price points which makes this conniving marketing stunt obsolete.
title: It Works...(BUT)

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2019
review_content: I bought this smart plug in August 1, received it and set it up with ease with Alexa control. Last month, I attempted to have Alexa turn on the light that I had the plug attached to. Nothing. So I looked at the plug and no light (usually blue, small on the plug itself). I figured we must have had a power outage, so I unplugged it and waited a few minutes, the light came back on red, then turned to blue and things were working again.This morning I got up, asked Alexa to turn on the light, nothing. Checked the plug, no light. So once again I unplugged the smart plug, waited a few minutes, plugged it back in. Nothing. 2nd attempt nothing. Tried using the Alexa app to reinstall, nothing. So now it is a useless paperweight.I cannot advise you to buy this smartplug. Useless!!! Of course the time for return has passed, so it's going out with the garbage!!!!!IDo not buy!!!!!
title: Quit working after 2 months! Do not buy!

author: L Rogers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020
review_content: I received this with the special Amazon deal where you could order it through Alexa and it was $20 off.  Excellent deal!  I was very excited to get it plugged in and going.  Apparently, the night I tried to set it up was also on the day that Amazon internet experienced a nationwide outage.  So, I can't fault the plug for that.  However, when I did set it up the next day, it wasn't quite as cut and dry as the instructions lead you to believe.  It is a little bit more involved, but still relatively easy to do.  Pushing and holding the button on the side was key for me in setup.  Now that it is finally set up, I love it!
title: Great smart plug

author: MacGuyver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2018
review_content: I was sick and tired of my old TP-link plug being "unresponsive" more often than not, so I sprung for the pricier Amazon smartplug. I was sure that I'd be wasting my evening trying to connect it, like I did with my old one.I plugged the unit in, and before I could even open the Alexa App, I got a notification on my Fire tablet that the plug was set up and ready to use! Yes, you read correctly- It. Set. Itself. Up.This is how home automation should work. All I had to do was rename it. Thank you, Amazon!Now how about discounting some multipacks of these little gems?
title: OK, so I'm impressed...

author: L. C. Gasper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2019
review_content: The plug is super-easy to install and operate. It suffers from one very important limitation that I understand is NOT found in smart plugs from other manufacturers. This plug will only work with one Amazon account; other plugs will work with commands from any account in an Amazon household.I easily got the plug working from the app on my phone. I was immediately able to control the plug from an Echo dot that was registered with my account. but other Echo dots would not work the plug until I switched the account from my wife's to mine, although we are both in one Amazon household. Apparently Amazon refuses to change this because they consider this arrangement more secure. I think most users consider that erecting such a security barrier against other members of your won household is at least unnecessary and perhaps is best described as absurd.I have read several complaints about this on line and it seems that other smart plugs that are compatible with Alexa do not have this limitation, but I do not know this from my own experience. Nevertheless, if I buy more smart plugs -- and I think I will -- I'll not repeat this purchase.Later: the plug lost its registration when the power failed. This did not happen with other brands of smart plugs.
title: Only works with one account

author: R. Higgins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2018
review_content: Thought the smart plug would be better than a mechanical timer.  It certainly is not.  I've had it less than a month.Took about 2 hours of work, which included a couple of factory resets, and help from Amazon support to get it connected.  Should be much easier.Found out that while you can control it via the Echo, it is not really controlled by the Echo.  I set up a couple of simple routines to turn a lamp on and off.  While the Echo is unplugged and offline, those routines still work.  So the Echo isn't controlling the device at all.  Something outside my house is sending commands to the device it seems.The routine to turn off the lamp didn't run tonight.  I used the Alexa app to re-run the routine, which failed.  I used the app to try and turn off the lamp, and that also failed.  Turns out the physical device was flashing red.  So I unplugged it and plugged it back in.  It started working again.  But neither the Echo, nor the App, nor Amazon ever notified me that the device had become unresponsive, and that my routine(s) would no longer function.A device that you have to reboot every couple of weeks doesn't seem to be worth having.  Maybe a future generation 2 device will be better.
title: Not controlled by Echo, no notification of failure(s)

author: srblock
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020
review_content: I am so frustrated with these plugs. We purchased three and were so excited to use them. They work maybe 1 out 10 times. We either get an error that it’s not responding or Alexa says ok and I can hear the plug click but it doesn’t work turn the device on or off. These plugs are expensive and so not worth the price. I had faith that they would work but I’m finding them more frustrating then they are worth. I believe these will be going back to amazon until they can come up with a better product.
title: Only works some of the time. Not reliable!

author: Jack
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2019
review_content: It turns out that as far as I know, one must use either a tablet or a smart phone with the Alexa app to install these devices.  I would prefer to do it on a desktop computer, but I don't think that is possible.  I have a number of Amazon Echo and Fire TV devices, so I know the installation drill by now.  However, for the first few times, it was confusing in that I could move through the menus faster than the devices could be initialized, etc.  All in all, setup and installation could be a bit more user friendly, with real people and not tech experts writing the instructions.I have two of these plugs in operation at the moment.  My only complaint is that often times, it is hard to get the Amazon Echo (aka Alexa) device to wake up or understand a command. Viz. "Alexa, turn on 'fan.' and either the Echo does not respond or it gives me some kind of runaround message about playing a tune called fan, etc.  So I have to yell, "Alexa, STOP!" and try again.  This is particularly true if there is a lot of background noise.  It is annoying and defeats most of the convenience of having an audio enabled device switch when this happens and it happens fairly frequently.Yet when it works, it seems to work well, with most of the issues being with the Echo command device.It is possible that I have made problems for myself by my choice of name for each dedicated smart plug.  One can rename the device when it is set up or anytime thereafter.  As I sometimes cannot remember complicated names such as "Alexa, plug (number) on!" where I have to remember the default plug number assigned on setup, I rename the plugs to things that are simple and easier for me to remember and to pronounce.  And it is possible that unless a specific order of words is used a miscued command results.  I find that to be true with some of the Fire TV units especially.  Unfortunately, no where have I found any information from Amazon on these issues of a preferred command syntax.
title: Convenient for selected applications, but barely ready for prime time.

author: George Warren
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2018
review_content: I've gone through our house and added 13 Z-wave smart switches, dimmers and Kwikset deadbolts and everything is controlled by a Samsung SmartThings hub. I love it.I bought a couple Amazon smart plugs to handle floor lamps and Christmas tree lights. I plugged them into the wall near an Echo Dot and the pairing took about a minute. You can buy cheaper smart plugs, but I didn't want to be forced to use a third-party application to set them up. It just seems like one more thing to go wrong.Here's one observation (not really a complaint): The Amazon smart plugs will NOT pair with the SmartThings hub. I was not aware of that when I bought them, but it's explained in the documentation. The plugs connect via wifi and are controlled directly by the Dot with no hub or other interface. So the Amazon smart plugs live outside my SmartThings ecosystem. It's no problem because you can still add the plugs to lighting groups and control them through Alexa-- and execution of commands is instantaneous with both systems.One other note: The plugs initially show up in the Alexa app as "First plug," etc. You can rename them in the app, i.e. "Living room lamp," but the original name "First plug" remains in the Alexa web interface. I guess that could be an issue if you had a bunch of them .
title: Setup is simple but it's strictly an Echo device!

author: HL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2020
review_content: I bought it to turn on the auxiliary LED mood lights that have a housing to respond to a remote control. When I hooked the cord to the Smart plug, it won't turn back on. It is again same issue for another LED-lit Christmas Tree.I was looking for other uses, perhaps, in the kitchen, rather disappointed!Then, I realized, it is useless again, as my cuisine art Kettle has the electrical temperature setting, not a rocker type on/off switch. And, it won't turn on any of those kitchen appliances I have, and, to be honest, I would not trust anything with the heating coils to be left hooked to this plug, anyway, for example, would you leave the smart phone to control your the toaster oven, from the distance? That is no, no.I can find one thing to connect, Braun Tooth Brush Charger. But, Do I really need to yell at the speaker to switch it on and off? This doesn't have the timer feature with Alexa app, to connect the floor lamp while we are gone for a holiday for a security at night time.Today, with the crazy afternoon gusts that shook the Electric cable in my neighborhood for just brief 2 seconds, the smart plug did not come back on, unlike other older amazon fire TV sticks or echo speakers. Alexa App did not provide any Troubleshooting, or How to reset this darn plug. I had to google troubleshooting from a website outside Amazon domain, what the problem is, and how to reset it. In short, whenever there is a blink of power outage, you need to google how to reset, by reconnecting it to the phone via bluetooth all again, and, put in your network password again, each time.  That is clearly not worth calling it SMART or CONVENIENT.Fancy name, "Smart" but just another "Buy! Buy!" trendy junk I got fooled by.Maybe it is useful if one's home has simple corded on/off power switches for their light fixtures, and the occupants may find using this smart plug using connected to the  table lamps, and, with the Echo speaker, and, the wifi connection,  That is still far slower and more inconvenient to motion sensors and timer-operated or smart switches on the walls.For some other homes  whose household is wired with motion/occupancy sensor switches, or smart switches, they rarely touch switches off.For them, this smart switch is backward, and not all-connecting, susceptible to any outage.Amazon simply sold this without testing compatibility of other electric products they sell.  That is really lazy!
title: Not all-connecting, Limited Usage, Useless after Power Outage, No Troubleshooting on App!

author: Master of Puppets
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019
review_content: Okay so you have an Echo or an Echo Plus and maybe some Echo dots. Now what? Well if you want Echo and Alexa to be able to do more then give you information or play music then you are going to need some of these switches. Essentially anything you plug into these can be automated, you just simply turn whatever it is on and plug it into one of these switches and then set the switch to be turned on and off with a voice command to almost any Echo device. You can in this way automate lights, fans, etc. Virtually anything that just needs to be turned on or off to do what it does. They are also competitively priced and since they're an Amazon product you know it will work seamlessly within your. Echo/Alexa enabled home.
title: Alexa/Echo compatible smart switch

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Easy to setup and a convenient device to have in your home. We have used the plug with our Alexa everyday. It has been almost two years to the day since I first purchased the plug. Today after spending an hour trying to reconnect the plug to my app I was unsuccessful. I think I will try a different brand to replace this one.
title: Lasted less than two years

author: DWF
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: So I’ve been using Alexa Smart Plugs for awhile now, no problems, but on Nov 25th a few recently purchased plugs all failed (Device Unresponsive) on the same exact day.  Coincidence?  I don’t think so, sounds like an app or plug update is causing mass failures.I tried all the troubleshooting, reset to factory defaults, start over setup, reboot router, etc., but keep getting ‘provisioning failure’ repeatedly, and my network is good since everything else works fine including Echo shows, Hue bulbs, smart lock, etc., so only the Alexa smart plugs failed today and can’t be reset or reconnected.May be time for an investigation?  What if Amazon IT folks pushed an update today and bricked our plugs?  Could be accidental or lack of testing, or is it intentional?  Don’t know, but looking at all the recent reviews with plug failures today, there ‘appears’ to be something happening across the country around the same time.Fortunately, for me, my recent purchases are under the covered period, so sending them back for free replacement, which is a hassle, but new ones should arrive in a few days.  We’ll see if the new ones have the same issue?Good luck, and I’d suggest avoiding buying the Amazon brand of plug until the failure mystery is solved...UPDATE:  12/1/2020I recently discovered that all the Amazon Smart Plug failures on Nov 25-26 were apparently caused by a problem with Amazon Web Services (AWS) servers, which lasted a couple days.  The same plugs I was having problems with, I tried one last time on 12/1/2020 to reset and reinstall, and all three of my plugs now were able to reset, connected fine and are working again.Amazon should have published or notified customers of the AWS issue and informed tech support so they could let customers know there was a backend issue at Amazon.  Lots of customers may have thrown away good plugs thinking it was a hardware issue, when it was just a backend server issue.  The plugs were likely good.So, in my experience, there was nothing wrong with the smart plugs, it was just a backend server issue, which once they resolved the server issues, all my plugs could be reinstalled and were easy to setup again and started working fine.Now, the issue this caused for me is that I requested replacements which are on the way, but there was really no need to replace because it wasn’t a hardware failure after all, it was an Amazon server problem all along.  So, I will likely just return the replacements at this point.  I’ve increased the star rating to 3, now that I know it wasn’t a plug issue, as the plugs had been working fine prior to the server glitch.The lesson learned here is that a failure with the smart plugs may not be a plug hardware issue, but just a backend server or software issue, so wait a few days, maybe a week, and try resetting again.  In may case, all three smart plugs that failed on Nov 25th, are now working, and reset process worked fine after server issue was resolved.
title: Update:  Dooms Day Nov 25th - Plugs Failed

author: Brian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2019
review_content: Pretty neat device. There are just a few things you should know before you buy and set it up. First, you must have the Alexa app on your phone to set it up, or at least this seems to be the easiest. You plug it into the wall, launch the Alexa app, and scan a QR code that comes with the packaging. Also, make sure you are in a well-lit area and your phone camera can focus well on the QR code. My first install failed to find the plug after scanning the QR code, but that's because it was dark when I scanned the code. After turning on the light to get a better picture of the QR it worked right away. So don't throw that QR code away. I'm betting you should keep it and somehow mark which QR code belongs with which plug if you have more than one, in case you have to set it up again sometime later.Once it's set up you can turn on/off with Alexa voice commands. It starts off with the name "plug 1" but you can change it to whatever you want. So you say "Alexa, turn on plug 1" and it switches on the plug. Pretty neat. If you want to schedule on/off times you have to program routines in the Alexa app, which is a bit confusing at first. I bought it to turn on a light at dusk and turn it off again at bed time. You have to create a separate routines for turning it on and off. One neat thing is you can choose sunset or sunrise as a time. You have to tell the app what location to use if you want to do this. You can also offset it up to 60 minutes before or after. I have it set to turn on the light 10 minutes before sunset. Routines are pretty versatile. You can have the plug do several things based on several forms of input, not just scheduling. You choose "when this happens" then "do this." So it can be when a particular voice command is given, when your phone is at a certain location, when a button is pressed on the Echo, etc. Because routines are for more than just the smart plug, you're presented with a list of things for actions in the "do this" part. Here after you choose "Add action" you have to choose "Smart Home" before you can see your devices (smart plug). The packaging comes with no instructions about all of this. I figured it out intuitively, but there is probably Alexa help somewhere on Amazon. I haven't tried, but you can probably also program it by talking to Alexa (e.g. "Alexa, schedule plug 1 to turn on 10 minutes before sunset."One disappointment is you need to add a third party skill to control the smart plug with the online Alexa interface (alexa.amazon.com). I was surprised not to find this feature built in. I didn't want to use something else for fear of causing problems using it with my phone app. For example, what if I program it differently with the two different apps. One more neat thing is you can turn the plug on and off using your phone.
title: Versatile but a bit difficult to program

author: I'm Real but My Name is Not
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
review_content: While we have a number of different Echo devices, Nest thermostat, and a couple of light sockets that can be controlled by Alexa, I'm realizing how helpful switchable plugs like these are going to be around the house.Truthfully, I only have this one so far but right out of the box I put it to use for turning on my outdoor Christmas lights that used to require me to go into the garage and plug in the cord.  No more.  Accessible from my phone or any of our Echo devices.It's a wirelessly controlled plug and does what you ask it.  I anticipate being able to control multiple different lights and items that were all running on the same switched outlet, but now I can address them individually.Set up on this was pretty easy, though I suggest holding onto the box.  It has a code you will want to scan to help setup your light.  Yes, it's also on the back of the plug, but the image on the box was clearer.
title: Realizing what a help this may end up being!

author: Timothy Fish
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2018
review_content: I’ve bought 2 of these. One of them I exchanged and I’m about to exchange the other one as well as the one they sent to replace the first!  They work great and are easy to setup, but each of them eventually become unresponsive. Even after resetting them, deleting the old device in the app, and adding them back, they work, then become unresponsive... usually the next day. I don’t know if it’s the software or hardware, but I’m almost out of patience. I’m giving Amazon a chance with more exchanges for now, but only because I got these for $5 during their packaged Echo Dot sale. If I have the same problem with the replacements then I’m buying more of the AUKEY smart plugs, which work consistently for me and have never had this issue.
title: Unreliable plugs that stop responding

author: Jayson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2019
review_content: I just spent 30+ minutes on the phone with Amazon/Alexa customer service only to find out that these Amazon plugs do not have the same functionality as any of the 3rd party plugs. We have an Amazon household setup, so my wife and I can control all of the devices through our Alexa app. When we buy a new Alexa device (Echo, Echo dot, Echo show, etc), it automatically shows up on both of our Alexa apps; regardless of which one of us registers the device EXCEPT for the Alexa plugs. If I setup an Amazon plug, she cannot see or control it from her Alexa device.  Same thing happens to me if she sets it up initially. Amazon customer service says this is normal and the ONLY way to control that device is to switch profiles back and forth on the Alexa device. Why would I do that, when I don’t have to with my TP-Link/Kasa plugs?Third party plugs can be linked across both Alexa apps by enabling a skill and logging in with the registered email address. So why would I buy another Amazon plug, when they don’t even function as well as a 3rd party plug. I won’t.The customer service rep said he will pass this information on to the Amazon engineers, so we will see. In the meantime, I can not recommend buying an Amazon plug if you use a shared Amazon household. If you’re running the entire show and nobody else needs to control an Amazon device from their Alexa app, then the Amazon plug might be for you (especially when they mark them down to $5). Otherwise, I’ve had amazing success with our Kasa/TP-link plugs and they typically run a sale on multiples at only $10/each.
title: Doesn’t function with Amazon household

author: David Hiett
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2020
review_content: I'm giving this product 5 stars for ease of use, but 1 star for the deception that it comes with a rebate.  The sole reason I bought this product was because it was 99 cents after rebate which was said to be applied to your account immediately after product is activated.  That never happened and when I chat with customer service they seem to be largely clueless.  So having said that, I will be returning this product because though it is a nice to have, it is not a need to have for $25.If you do decide to purchase it, the set up is easy and Alexa commands are easy to implement.  I set mine up, named it lamp, and had Alexa turning the light on in off in under 5 min.  Like I said, 5 star product....just wish I wasn't lied to about a rebate.
title: Product works great...but the rebate is a lie

author: Whitebomber
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: I like this plug and it works.  However reading many reviews and from my own experience, they missed the boat for those just wanting to turn a light on and off.  There should be a much easier process for creating a routine to accomplish this action.The sequence below worked for me.  There might be an easier path but this worked.  If you want your plug to come on at a certain time, run through the procedure and choose “On” for step 16.  Unfortunately you will need to repeat the procedure to create another routine to turn it off.  So if you want a light to turn on/off in the morning and in the evening, you will need to create four routines.1. Open the Alexa app2. Tap on Devices3. Tap on Plugs4. Tap on the name of your plug5. Tap on “Create A Routine”6. Tap on the plus (+) button to the top right of the screen7. Tap on Enter a Routine Name, type in a name, then tap next8. Tap on the plus (+) next to when When This Happens9. Tap on Schedule10. Tap “At Time”, then tap Select to set the time11. Tap Repeat to set when this occurs, i.e Everyday or particular days, then tap Next12. Tap on the plus (+) next to Add Action13. Tap on Smart Home14. Tap All Devices15. Tap the name of your Smart Plug16. Select On or Off to choose what effect the Routine has on the Smart Plug17. Tap Next18. Tap SaveHopefully this helps.  The process above isn't difficult to go through once you do it a couple times.
title: Cool device but setup could be more friendly

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
review_content: I was very pleased with the plug. I specifically bought the Amazon brand since I figured it would be most compatible. I used it to operate a floor lamp in my home office just behind me.  When I would go on Zoom calls, I didn't want to be backlit so I'd turn off the light with a voice command. One or two cycles per day. Less than 100 watts so I wasn't "overloading" the wattage. Six months to the day from when I purchased it, it stopped working. Nothing had changed for my network. The plug is one foot from the Echo device and about 20 feet from the wifi router. I reset it using the barcode and then manually. Tried the setup on my cell phone and on my laptop with the Alexa app. Tried five or six times unsuccessfully. It would tell me it was connected, but then when I went to use it, it said it was not enabled or it couldn't find it. The replacement window ended at four months, so I guess I'm out of luck.
title: Worked great while it lasted -- Just stopped working after six months

author: Tiffany
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2019
review_content: Shipped quickly, in good shape (no damage to the box).  Pretty straight forward set up, plug it into an outlet, press and hold the button on the side until it starts to blink red and blue, then add the device via your Alexa app. However, the little pamphlet that comes in the box does not tell you the information about the red and blue light.  It just mentions the blue light, the rest of the included instructions are correct though.  You will also need to have the most recent version/update of the Alexa app installed on your phone.  It took less than 5 minutes to set this up. I use it for my living room lamp and my TV.  It does not control the channels on my TV, but it does allow me to turn it on/off; same with my living room lamp.  For a non-Alexa or other non-smart hub enabled TV you will need to do the following: Make sure the TV and Smart Plug are turned off, plug the TV into the smart plug, turn the Smart Plug on via the app or telling Alexa your phrase for that action.  Then turn on the TV.  When you want to shut the TV off, do not use the power button on the remote or on the TV....leave it on and tell Alexa to shut the TV off, or turn off Plug 1 (however you set up the phrase in your Alexa app).  To turn it on, tell Alexa to turn it on instead of using the power button on the remote or TV.  In essence you will leave the TV on and use the smart plug to control the power to it.  I love being able to  say "Alexa, turn on the TV" or "Alexa, turn on the living room light" and I don't have to stop what I'm in the middle of doing to do these. Same luxury to turn them off.  I'll be ordering more to put around the house for different items.  Just too easy!
title: Easy Set up with my Echo but you need to wait for red and blue blinking light to pair

author: Patti Griffith-Stiles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2018
review_content: I just plugged it in and waited for it to connect which only took a minute and I fell in love with them.  I just say "Alexa turn on the coffee pot".  Wonderful, and easy.  If you have an Alexa get a couple.I had wemo but could never get it to work.  I was skeptical about getting these but I am so glad I did.
title: Great gadget.

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Got three plugs in July, come November they stopped working. Spent an hour on the phone with support only to be told it was a developing issue and the programmers were looking into it. A little background about me. I live in the USA and am an IT guy.
title: Worked for months than stopped

author: A. Rose
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2018
review_content: Bought this device as an alternative to another Insteon Wall Plug.  It was half the price and seemed like it would be a great enhancement that did not depend on an outside (of Amazon's ecosystem) device for operation.  If all you want is a way to use your voice to turn on and off a device then it's perfect and I'd give it all the stars they wanted for that.  Setup was easy and it does that without issue.What if you want to schedule things?  This device relies on the "Routines" function in the Alexa app.  While I'm generally very impressed with what the software developers at Alexa are doing I feel they fell flat on their face with creating this Routines function in the app.You cannot trigger on sunrise and sunset!  Let's say that again... YOU CANNOT TRIGGER for sunset?  What?  Are you kidding me.  Hey software engineer - are you living in someplace where sunset comes at the same time of day all year long?  Let's say, for example, that I want the light at the front door to come on when it gets dark.  Well sunset is at 4:29pm tonight.  That's the only option in the app.  Set an actual time.  Fantastic.  So in June when sunset is at 8:30pm I guess my hall light will just have to come on in the early afternoon.Come on Amazon?  What did you think we ere going to use these devices for?
title: Achilles Heal is the Alexa App - You cannot schedule on sunset/sunrise in the app

author: Web Addict
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2019
review_content: I purchased 5 Amazon smart plugs for my home. The Amazon smart plugs have repeatedly toggled between a state of working and then not working. This is a continuing theme since I purchased the plugs back in November 22, 2018. The plugs are currently back in the state of not working and have not worked for 30 days. Amazon again has not reached out to me for the trouble ticket created 30 days ago. At the same time, I have both WEMO brand smart plugs and Dilisen brand smart plugs installed in my home and they both have worked flawlessly since the first day they were installed back in June of 2018. What is strange, and tells me there is some issue on Amazon cloud servers that maintain my account profile, is that when one plug stops working, all 5 fall off the network and stop working? I have spent over 10 hours on the phone with Amazon support working on this issue. With each call to Amazon they repeatedly have me walk through the install process over and over and over. I am now unwillingly an expert at installing the smart plugs. I have been told with each call to Amazon, for support, that they are creating a trouble ticket and someone will get back to me. Amazon does not get back to me. Later, when I call to ask why they never replied to the prior trouble tickets, Amazon again has me try to install the smart plugs. After the install process is unsuccessful, Amazon tells me they are sorry and they will again create yet another new trouble ticket and someone will get back with me. This pattern just repeats over and over. All I can say is if you wish to be aggravated, have your personal free time wasted, and be out right ignored, then purchase the Amazon smart plugs. IF YOU DON'T WISH TO EXPERIENCE THESE NEGATIVE ATTRIBUTES, THEN RUN FOREST RUN!
title: **DO NOT BUY THE AMAZON BRAND SMART PLUGS, THEY DO NOT WORK!**

author: AJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2018
review_content: I have several of these. I also have several other brands. This one from AMAZON is by far the easiest to install! Being it is their own brand it works seamlessly with echo products. I did have one that stopped working after 2 days and Amazon replaced it. So far, its about 2 weeks out and no problems. IF YOU HAVE MULTIPLE PEOPLE ON YOUR ACCOUNT...BE AWARE IT TIES INTO WHOEVER ORDERS THE ITEM. I say that because we do have a small issue  being that with the plugs only (not any of the other devices I have),the Alexa app gets confused and does not put the plug on the primary account persons Alexa app if not ordered under primary persons name. You will have to de register  it under the second person and regegister under the primary persons name. I have not been able to do this yet. As I attempt this I will update.
title: Love the ease of installation...Multiple users on account beware.

author: NW Grandma
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2020
review_content: I plugged these smart plugs in, turned them on, plugged in my lamps, started the Alexis app on my iPhone, and followed the easy steps to set up. These two smart plugs were recognized within two seconds, and are working flawlessly.I'm new to the convenience of smart plugs and Amazon Echo. For several years, family and friends tried to convince me how I could integrate it into my daily (retired) life. After a couple of falls (one which required surgery), I admitted I needed assistance and purchased two Echo Show 8s when they were on sale.I started simple, asking the Echo for weather updates & local news stories, then decided to add smart plugs, replacing the decades-old timers on two of my lamps. With these smart plugs, I no longer have to fuss with changing those hard-to-reach timers to adjust the on/off times. My arthritic joints appreciate that.My only regret is that I waited so long to make my daily life a little easier on these old bones. I will be ordering several more of these smart plugs to help me safely move around in my home.
title: Easy Setup & Seamless Integration with Echo Show 8

author: Isabelle Hart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
review_content: I was very happy with the product when we first received it. One day I noticed it wasn't plugged in. Turns out it stopped working and my husband couldn't get it reset. I also tried with no luck. It was great while it lasted but we had only paid a dollar with a promo Amazon was offering new echo dot owners so we received more than our moneys worth. We received it in Jan 2020 and it didn't make through July 2020. Found out this had a warranty. Trying to figure out the process to return was horrible so we tried one more time to reset. Alexa kept saying setup was complete but nothing happened.  Found out by accident while unplugging that you have to press the side button again so that the blue light is on. Success! - Amazon please add this step for all future smart plug owners.
title: Didn't last a year-Update working again!

author: Skyhound
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2020
review_content: I put this on a light with a switch that is difficult to get to. Alexa, turn on light. Alexa, turn off light. Works fine. But then there was a brief power interruption and the light went off and I could not turn it back on again without pulling out the piece of furniture it was behind and pressing a button. Then the internet went off for a few minutes. Not my router-it was fine-but the connection to the internet. The light went off again and I had to push the button. Then the power went off for a couple of hours (its been a rough winter). I had to unplug the unit and reset it so that it could talk to Alexa again. If this is the future, I think I may stick with manual switches.The first one I ordered was DOA, but they did replace it. I wasted a lot of time trying to get it to work before I finally decided it must be broken. Also, the link on my order now brings up an error page to the product, and tells me I can't write a review. Weird. So I looked it hp and did the review manually. At least this is a consistent experience , I guess.
title: Dumber than a wall switch

author: Timbo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2020
review_content: I gotta say I used the Wemo plug and the Sengled light bulb. I have had trouble intermittently when wifi goes out or just for no apparent reason with these devices communicating with Alexa and/or Siri. Then I have to set them up again which with the Wemo involves using the Wemo App and unplugging the Wemo in the middle of setup to scan the darn code and then Alexa setup. This last time just couldn't get the Wemo or Sengled to hook up. I got disgusted and found this Certified for Humans plug. WOW! Literally just plug it in and scan the code on the card that came with the unit and I'm IN! :) I gotta say it's $24 which is more than the Wemo and a lot more than some other units but for me this is so worth the money to get rid of the aggravation. Thanks Amazon!!!
title: EASY!

author: GPbo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2020
review_content: Despite grabbing the plug on sale for $4.99, I'd still rate it 3 stars:- Good to give your old appliances a smarter tag. And if you have any elder around, this will make an amazing gift at their convenience. So they don't have to go around to manually turn on/off stuff.- User interface is alright. It's merely turned on/off. You can't insert the plug into any routine. Which sucks big time because you lose the ability to schedule it. You just have to manually toggle it on/off in your Amazon Alexa phone app, or talk to a nearest Echo.- Alexa integration is ok. But like I said, you're locked into Amazon Alexa phone app, or find an Echo. Lack luster.- Voice recognition is not the best but would do. I wholeheartedly believe they push this product out fast to compete with other smart plug brands. But they fall far behind in terms of app features.- You could just grab a similar smart plug for a much better price with much more to offer, in case you didn't grab this one on sale.
title: Just ok

author: sakurat8
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2020
review_content: Can you say SCAM!!?? This plug works well with Alexa but when I saw it on the Amazon website for $24.99, the reason I purchased it was because I saw "receive $24.00, Amazon credit once you connect to your Alexis device".  So I did and there's no credit and nothing telling me how to get that credit! Disgruntled customer!!
title: Can you say SCAM!!?? No promised credit given after connected to Alexis!

author: JMS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2018
review_content: The device works as advertised, but the setup can be tricky. It's getting 4 stars because I had to get help from Amazon customer support about issues not mentioned anyplace I could see. This is what I had to do:1. The plug works with a 2.3GHz network only. This is not a big shock, since 2.3GHz is more common in my experience, but I didn't see it mentioned anyplace in the documentation. The phone or other device hosting the Alexa app can be connected to either a 2.3GHz or 5.0GHz network, but the plug itself won't connect to anything except 2.3GHz. Of course, the Echos, Dots, or whatever that are controlling the plug need to be able to "see" the network that the plug is using.2. Turn off power saving. My Samsung S8, where I was running the app, has a power-saver setting to extend battery life. I was unable to set up the plug at all (phone couldn't find the plug) until, at the suggestion of Amazon customer support, I turned power-saving off entirely. Then the phone fould the plug, no problem.3. During the setup the plug may attempt to connect to the wrong WiFi network. In my case, it tried to connect to a network that I can't access, and the setup failed with a "provisioning failure". If the plug connects successfully to the wrong network, you can change the network from the Alexa app via devices -> plugs -> first plug (or whatever plug you want) -> vertical-dot menu in upper right corner -> Wi-Fi Network change. In either case, you want to hold down the power button until you get a blue-red flash and then retry the setup. If you got a provisioning failure, this is the "retry" button on the failure screen.4. During the retry the Alexa app will list the visible 2.3GHz wifi networks. Select the one you want.5. This time the setup succeeded for me.Note that, for me anyway, the initial (wrong) network selection had no relationship to the network my phone was connected to. Even when the phone was on a 2.3GHz network, the plug tried to connect to the wrong network.This setup isn't really that complicated, once you know what to expect and once you know how to deal with a wrong-network selection. I plan on buying more of these little things, but, sheeze, a bit more documentation and error troubleshooting in the box would be appreciated.
title: Good device, tricky setup

author: Brian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2020
review_content: OK. First (obviously) I just need to point out that this review is just my own personal experience and I'm sure each person's experience can vary with a product like this. So, my personal use circumstances are as follows...I have one Echo Dot (3rd gen)I have a 2.4 GHz wireless routerI have a 7 inch Kindle Fire tabletI have this smart plug For me, when I plugged this in, the little blue light on it started to flash periodically. I hadn't yet read the instructions so I just plugged a lamp into it (so I'd know if it did anything) and left that be for a few minutes to see what would happen. Shortly, Alexa announced that she had found the plug and told me to say "Turn on first plug" to control it. It was pretty much that simple. However, the first time I tried it, she said it wasn't responding. So, thinking there was something else I might need to do in the app. So I started the Alexa app on my tablet and tried once more to tell it to turn on the plug. Which this time it worked. So I tried a simple timer routine to turn the plug on at a certain time and turn it off about ten minutes later. That worked. So I don't know what else to say. I was able to purchase this for a dollar as (I guess) a special offer. These are normally about 25 dollars. I had been thinking about getting one for a while but there was no way I was paying 25 dollars. Of course I understand they have to make money but this will probably be the only one I buy unless the normal prices come down at least by half. It would be nice to have more of them but not at 25 dollars a pop.
title: Works for me

author: CLTGUY
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
review_content: Latest update - the device is not responding is too frequent, even after a full reset, it states it is not responding during setup...getting a different brand.Updating review - I have another smart plug as well as smart light switches that are not Amazon brand and connect with an app called Smart Life, but they can also be controlled with Alexa devices.  The Amazon device is connected with the Alexa App only - and when I ask Alexa to turn off the switch, it will tell me "The device is not responding" and I have to manually walk to the Echo Show or go into my Alexa App on my phone to press the switch.  I do not get the same response from Alexa when I tell her to turn my other devices on and off...So I am dropping the review from 4 to 3 stars.  It is still a good build with a strong wifi signal, but I think software needs worked on.I got this on Prime Day for $5 by ordering through Alexa, and that was a GREAT deal since it's a quality device!It's VERY simple to setup through the Alexa App on your phone.  You can name it whatever you want so when you ask Alexa to turn it off/on - it typically responds very quickly.  You can set up a schedule in the Alexa app, but you have to create a Routine - which is not straightforward.I am using this to control my fish tank lights - it will ALWAYS turn the lights off at 9pm, in case I turn them on and forget to turn them off.  But I just like telling Alexa to turn on the fish tank lights and have them pop on quickly!Downsides - only control through alexa app, I have another smart plug that works with Alexa but connects, can be scheduled and controlled through a Smart Life app and this doesn't work with that - so it's the odd ball out.  The alexa control sometimes hangs up and says she's having trouble communicating to the device - even though it turns off/on.
title: Device is not responding...  That is all I get after a month

author: Khiem D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2020
review_content: I've used other plugs before with Google Assistant and it always felt cumbersome to use. You always had to get a separate app to set it up (each company has a different one) and then you register it to that app first and then you need to link it up to Google Assistant. Once it's setup it works but man was it a pain. Imagine then that you buy different plugs from different manufacturers and now you'll deal with even more apps. It's really ridiculous.This smart plug, you just plug it in, check your Alexa app and boom there's a notification about adding it. I literally had it working in less than a minute (yes literally, as in less than 60 seconds, I bet you could get it done in 15-20 sec tbh). If the price was cheaper I'd buy a bunch of these and ditch my Google Home Mini speaker but alas I'm not that into home automation. I'm really impressed by how easy it is to use this one though. Great work Amazon!
title: Wow! Doesn't get easier!

author: commorancy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
review_content: When I pulled this brand new smart plug from its box and attempted to set it up, I ran into an issue with setup. The device couldn't be found by Alexa. I could see from the device's status light that it wasn't doing what it was supposed to be doing. When I first plugged it in, the device flashed red a few times then stopped. Red == bad. According to the tiny guide, that means the plug failed to set up. I hadn't even set it up before. Makes me wonder if this has been used before, but the device was fully wrapped and the box sealed shut.Anyway, after figuring out how to get the thing configured by pressing and holding the power button to get it into setup mode (no, this isn't documented in any of the included instructions... I just took a wild guess), the device hooked up like a champ.Unfortunately, the reason for using this plug is negated by a simple, but major design flaw. If the plug loses and then regains power, the plug does not return to either its previous state or on. Instead, it returns to off. For a lamp or a fan, no big deal. For my home router, yeah, that's a no go... literally... for the router.The router must turn back on after a power failure. Unfortunately, this plug's failure to return to a powered on state after power loss firmly loses it 2 stars. Every smart device like this needs to remember its last powered state or default to on. If it can't do this one simple thing upon power restoration, then it's of no use for many applications. Be forewarned of this design flaw if you're thinking of buying this smart plug for a similar use.
title: Great plug, except after power loss

author: R. Carlson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2020
review_content: I purchased this in mid-November for use with Christmas lights THIS year, not for next year.  It connected to my Alexa devices easily and worked fine at first. Within 30 minutes it displayed a res flashing LED and was no longer connected to WiFi. I am not a novice at this, so I know the device is defective after making various tests.I returned it for replacement weeks ago and the replacement still may not arrive before Christmas.  Terrible planning by Amazon!!!!  How can you run out of these?  What’s worse, they have dozens of these in stock at Walmart.  So apparently selling to Walmart for Xmas is far more important than your loyal direct purchase Prime members.The smart switch is HUGE compared to most others and won’t fit next to many other plugs in an outlet strip.I’m also frustrated that it doesn’t used the built in hub in my Echo plus, it connects without a hub.After the device stopped working, the Alexa app still identifies the switch as still connected and won’t delete.  I absolutely despise this switch and Amazon for selling it to me.  What a piece of garbage that I don’t even have the ability to use because Amazon no longer cares about Prime members getting timely deliveries.  COVID be damned, stop using that as an excuse for terrible customer service on your own products.  My Alexa won’t play multi-room music reliably and support hasn’t helped with that at all. I’m ready to dump all my Alexa devices and switch to Google assistant.I will never buy another one of these switches and I suggest others heed my warning.
title: Too large, lots of problems, terrible support

author: MomOf2Goobers:)
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2018
review_content: I have several smart plugs and this is by far the easiest to connect with Alexa.The first time you plug it in, it enters pairing mode. It pops up a notification that you can connect your new smart plug (assuming you have the Alexa app and newest version). Click it and it's added. No need for an additional app however it's not clear how to set a schedule, which is the whole reason I bought it. For this reason and the fact that it was confusing to figure out I'm deducting one star.All of my other branded devices require another app to set them up or to set schedules, this one does not and is set directly from the Alexa app which is nice but the HOW to do it is missing from the printed directions. Also I don't see a brand.Others have asked HOW but the answer was not provided that I could find. I'm hoping by including how to set a schedule in my review that this will show up when someone asks the question "How to set a schedule"After the plug is added to your smart devices (via pop up for me) you can schedule it on or off by the following....Open your Alexa app and go to smart home (far right bottom corner)Click "plugs" top middleScroll and Click the plug you're going to scheduleClick create a routine (in blue middle bottom of screen)Click the + in the top right cornerClick the + "when this happens"Choose "schedule"Click "at time"Click the time that pops up and set the time you want it to come ON (or off)Click doneClick repeatChoose your day or daysClick done top right cornerClick doneClick the blue doneNow you need to set what it does on those days...Click "add action"Scroll down and click smart homeClick control deviceChoose the plug by clicking the name of itChoose the ON (or off) position of the toggle switchClick nextThen click "create"Your plug is now scheduled for turning on or offTo add the off schedule, follow the same steps above but choose the "off" toggle position when setting the action. Make sure you click create at the end and it should be good to go with turning on and off.
title: No instructions on how to schedule, but I figured it out! You're welcome.

author: Ken Shumake
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2019
review_content: Got one for 99 cents as promotion. Not going to bother returning, my time is worth more than what I'll get back. I've already wasted 2 hrs trying to get this thing to connect! Constant "Provisioning Errors" that many others are complaining about. Yes I'm connected to 2.4g wifi, yes my Bluetooth is on. I have Nighthawk router, Note 10+, Tab S6, nothing works. I have 9 other smart plugs, several smart led bulbs, none of them have come close to giving me fits like this thing has. I feel like a fool paying even 99 cents for it. HEY AMAZON, I'M A GOOD CUSTOMER! DON'T PEDDLE YOUR OLD OUT-OF-DATE JUNK OFF TO ME ANYMORE..... PLEASE! And thanks so much for duping me this holiday season!Update: OK Amazon, I owe you an apology...... sort of. I got the plug working. Here is how I figured this out. I don't use Alexa to control any of my other smart devices. Everything I read said you "must install the Alexa app"...which I did on two devices & could not get this plug to work. But NOWHERE on this website (or in the directions that came with the plug or in the app) does it say you must physically go to the Alexa device & push the action button to link the app to each phone/tablet! NOWHERE does it state this! So frustrating & so much wasted time! At no point during install/opening of the Alexa app for the first time did it ask me if I wanted to add my Alexa/echo in the app. You would think it would automatically search for an Alexa/echo & prompt you to link them or just do it automatically! You cannot set up any smart device with the Alexa app until it is physically added/linked by pushing the action button. I hope this saves someone else some frustration & wasted time. We won the Alexa dot in a second chance lotto drawing. I would never buy one of these things. I'll raise my rating to 3 stars. I'm keeping 2 for the massive frustration & wasted time.
title: Total fail, don't buy...UPDATE-READ IF HAVING PROBLEMS

author: Jennifer Hinson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2020
review_content: I recently replaced my Google home devices with Echo devices (during Prime Days) and have been loving getting acquainted with everything Alexa has to offer. One of those was the daily prime deals she tells me about and this plug was one of the first ones....all the smart plugs/bulbs/etc kinda stress me out, I thought they were going to be too much of a hassle to set up and honestly I didn’t feel like I HAD to have any of it. However for $5 I figured it was worth a shot to try. It was a big mistake, but not in the way you are thinking.....now that I have one I want so many more (too bad they aren’t all $5 plugs lol).It took absolutely no setup, I just plugged the smart plug into the outlet then plugged in my Christmas tree lights and bam I was all set.....Alexa immediately recognized it and it worked. It was easy to change the “name” to a more personalized/specific one (from plug 1 to “Christmas tree”) and it’s worked with no issues.The one problem I have aside from wanting more is how much fun my 5 yo old thinks it is to tell Alexa to cut them on and off, but this is also the kid that uses his Echo Flex in his room to constantly make “announcements” to the rest of the rooms CONSTANTLY so I guess I should’ve expected him to be fascinated with this feature as well.If you don’t have one of these and have Echo devices, see if you can take advantage of the Alexa deal (through your Echo) because its a STEAL. I’m just hoping I can eventually find a great deal on these again so I can stock up bc they are amazing.
title: I had NO idea what I was missing out on.....

author: DirtDiva
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2019
review_content: I have two Chamberlain garage door openers, one installed in 2002 and the other in 2006 for a 3-door garage.  Occasionally,  both garage doors open at the same time for no apparent reason.  It doesn't happen often, but enough to make me feel unsafe.  I've tried everything to recoding, unplugging, including calling Chamberlain for help (they gave me a long protocol which didn't help) same thing with researching on line, apparently its common with a wide range of openers, not just Chamberlain.  I never have both doors up at the same time, so I know when it happens.  I decided to try this last option before replacing both openers.  I plugged the separate garage openers in their own Amazon Smart Plug into the outlet in the garage ceiling.  Got it all up and running easily through the app, named the plugs and had my Echo Plus find them.  It worked!  I told Alexa to turn the plugs off, and I could not open the garage doors through the wall unit, or the outside garage unit, or from my car.  When in my car, through the app, I could easily turn the plugs on or off.  At night, I turn them off via voice command with Alexa, and I have peace of mind.  What a difference this has made for me, instead of replacing two units for hundreds or dollar, not to mention installation, I spent just $50.
title: Works with garage opener

author: J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2020
review_content: I got my first Echo Dot free with the purchase of a tv and it has changed my life.  I am the last person to adopt new technology, the last of my friends and family to get a smartphone, and only just got internet in my home when I started homeschooling 3 years ago.  I now have a Dot in every room and 5 Amazon Smart Plugs.  I have the motion sensor, clock, fire sticks, tv's, and cameras.  My smart setup has eased my anxiety and dampened my feelings of burn out in ways that I never considered or thought possible. I can now ease into my day with routines designed to do all those little things that add up to one big stressor first thing in the morning. No longer do I feel like I am constantly forgetting something and this has boosted my self confidence. I am homeschooling 2 young kids and managing a household. Alexa is like having my own personal assistant and somewhat of a companion. If I could, I would hug everyone involved in the creation of these devices and their ongoing development.  They have improved my mental health and help me be a better mother and manager. I truly am grateful that this system exists and is so user friendly.The plugs specifically are great because I don't have to go around turning things on and off any longer, which sounds silly but really took a lot of time with so much else to do at once. I just set a routine and Alexa turns my fan off, dehumidifier on, and lights on in the morning. Then, at bedtime, she shuts everything down and turns the fan on which forces me to go to bed.  I now go to sleep at the right time and feel much better in the morning.  I am constantly watching for a deal on the plugs because they are pricey, but they work seamlessly.I rave about this system to everyone because it has benefitted me hugely.  Thanks Amazon!!
title: These are life changing!

author: M. Martin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2018
review_content: UPDATE: Thank you to the Amazon product team for reaching out to me directly, by phone, to go over my one-star review and attempting to fix the issues I was having. After a hard reset on the product, it has been operating properly. It is nice that the Amazon Plug works natively within the Amazon Alexa app without needing a third-party app for the product. I also like that you can stack two on the same outlet. They need to update the QR code scanning feature in the app so that you can turn on your phone's flashlight in order to scan the code in dark places.Original Review: I needed another home automation plug. This one runs my living room lights on a routine and replaces the mechanical timer we've typically used during the winter months. I purchased the Amazon version and paid a little more because I thought it would be more convenient to stick with a native Amazon product. Unfortunately, my unit has become unresponsive twice during the week I've had it. That means I've woken up twice and saw a glow from the hallway like someone was awake and in the living room, only to find that the time-based routine couldn't execute. The wifi route is approximately 20 feet from the plug and in clear view. Now I'm disappointed and need to consider buying a non-name-brand replacement.Setup was very easy, but make sure to set it up in a brighter area, otherwise you'll have issues scanning the QR code.
title: Updated Review: Now Works As Prescribed

author: Me
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2020
review_content: I have an alexa household, she controls everything. I would say that if you're going to get a smart plug, get the Amazon brand one, which is specifically designed to work with Alexa. The app integration is seamless. Once you purchase, it remembers your Wi-Fi signal credentials if you already have other Alexa devices signed into your Wi-Fi network. So all you have to do is plug it in, and it sets itself up. With these plugs, you can use them to turn electronics on or off. But if you want to use it with a lamp, just plug in the lamp, and in your Alexa app settings, choose to "treat the plug like a light". Once you give it a name, designate what room it is in, you can just tell Alexa to turn off the lights, and it will control the switch. In other words, you can treat the switch like a plug or like a light, which is really important when it comes to setting up routines and giving Alexa commands. The thinner profile means that you can put two of these plugs into a standard socket, it saves space. However, it is still the same initial design. I would like to see for Amazon to come up with a multi socket smart plug surge protector. This would be more practical. I currently own five of these plugs, One controls the fan, One controls a light in a room, I'm setting one up to control my TV. Keep in mind, though, that this will only give you power functionality. You can only turn things on or off. It's not like a smart bulb that you can control with Alexa using various voice controls to change the light settings.
title: Easy to use, works great.

author: Stover
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2019
review_content: I received this Amazon plug Feb 1, 2019.  It is now May 22, 2019 and it has already quit. After three months and 22 days of coarse I am out of my return window which is quite irritating.  I shopped through the smart plugs thinking this is the one that would probably be the best. Every Amazon product we have bought has been great. The plug started off that way. We plugged in the humidifier and it has worked great till this morning. I woke up and the humidifier was off and so I tried to get Alexa to turn it back on. That was a no go. I saw the red light blinking and new something was wrong. I tried everything I could find in the help section and then some. It always goes back to device unresponsive. It disappoints me to give this plug a low rating but considering I have a $25 plug that doesn’t work after not even 4 months it is kind of  necessary.Yesterday I left a review of the Amazon smart plug. I received a call from Amazon technical support to help me fix the issue. I missed their call so Jeremy said he would email me. I returned the email with a day and time to get a call back. I plugged the smart plug back in the wall and forgot about it. A few minutes ago I noticed the light was a steady blue. Once I saw that I told Alexa to turn on the plug. It did. I am totally confused as to why but it works now. I also have to add I am impressed with Amazon technical support and how they actually try to help. Kudos for that! So Jeremy if your reading this you can cancel that support call. LolI must add that before this little incident the smart plug worked perfectly fine. Easy set up and no problems. I just hope we don’t have anymore hiccups.Update: Still working good! Love it!
title: First Amazon product I wish I could return (Updated)

author: Formware
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Have three of these smart plugs. Installed two in our living/dining room area and one in our family room. I used these to turn lights of and on while would be out of town for extended periods.Since we returned home in April 2020, i have had reset the plugs multiple times one of the plugs is about 10 feet from the wireless router. All of my other devices connect without issues. Tablets, phones, computers, all wireless and connect fine. If there is a glitch in the WiFi connection all of my other devices are smart enough to reconnect. These Amazon smart plugs aren’t that smart. When I set it up, I only want to do that once.At this point I’m tired of having to reconnect over and over again. Is anyone else experiencing this?
title: Purchased in 2018 and worked well, now in 2020 constant failure.

author: Ryan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
review_content: We bought this for my dad/parents for Christmas.  They decorate every inch of the house.  Lights inside and out , banister, 4 trees, poinsettias, animatronics, wreaths that light up etc.  Its quite lovely.  Anyway we thought it be great to for them to be able to turn off the lights, trees with voice command.  And before you ask no they do not use timers.  They did know why either when we asked.  These were SUPER EASY to connect to WiFi.  They already have an Alexa so maybe that made it easier.  I don't know but it was not at all hard.  Your not suppose to need Alexa to use but they do have it.Steps1. You must set each one up separately (1 at a time)This makes your life easier if you have multiples.2. If you do have multiple plugs I recommend LABELING them with tape, post-it note something.  This way if your using only for the Christmas and not during the year you'll remember what you named it because you can change the name of the plug if you want. Write it down and KEEP IN SAFE PLACE.3. KEEP the QR CODE in a safe place.  We found that we needed it when we decided to move one to a new location.  We had to rescan it so it would reconnect.We love them. They loved them.  It made turning the lights on and off so much easier.  You CAN NOT use this outside.  But if you have a cord that is inside for outside lights then you can use it INSIDE!
title: No more bending or searching

author: Average Joe
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2020
review_content: The Amazon Plug set up was very easy for me. I have several WEMO plugs which are a bit temperamental to set up and remain activated. The Amazon plug has been working flawlessly for over a month on various lighting devices as well as appliances. It is controlled by use of Alexa and iPhone app. I have found no difficulty in it reconnecting itself back to wifi after a power outage. With and without an outage I have found connectivity issues with the WEMOs, which caused me to have to manually reset the devices or "forget" them on the Alexa webpage so that they can be rediscovered. This is almost impossible without being physically present at their location. The Amazon plug has been reliable in this aspect. So why not 5 stars? Because the plugs can be controlled by any stranger that has access to your Alexa! I changed the name of my plug, which Amazon has defaulted as "First Plug". Even though the app shows the new name, the Amazon web account page still shows "First Plug" and not the new name. When I tell Alexa to turn on the plug by its new name, she does. BUT also will turn on the same plug when you tell her to turn on "First Plug". A co-worker's young child thought it humorous to tell Alexa to turn on First Plug, Second Plug, Third Plug, and on down the line until he found the one wanted activated. The problem was that many lights were activated causing alarms to be activated as well as an electric heater in an outside shed. All the plugs had been renamed and the name kept confidential to prevent accidental activation, yet they were all being activated by their default names. I searched the Alexa/Amazon help section and was not able to find a solution to remove the default name from Alexa's control nor was I able to change it to the new name from my laptop on my Amazon account. I was looking to replace all my WEMO devices with more Amazon Plugs, but will wait for Amazon to resolve this issue. Could it be just my and my co-workers plugs? Possibly. You be the judge if you already have one of them.
title: Security issue

author: ChibiNeko
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2020
review_content: This is a handy little device, but part of the reason I'm rating it at three stars rather than higher is because honestly, I don't entirely see the necessity in it and it's not nearly as small as it claims to be. Plus this is pretty expensive and I really feel that there has to be cheaper options out there.Set up for this was honestly a little bit of a pain. The unit didn't connect quite as cleanly as was promised, but once it was completed it was generally fairly easy to operate. Mostly the unit didn't want to connect with Alexa unless I scanned the barcode.This wasn't quite as unobtrusive as was promised, as some of my other devices didn't really fit, either because of how the cord was set up or because the general plug as a whole was too big. It's not a huge deal breaker, but it was a little frustrating having to shuffle everything around.Since then it's generally been pretty nice and I'll admit that it's handy to be able to walk into the bedroom and turn out the light in the other room, omitting my having to walk to my bedroom in the dark or backtrack once the bedroom light is on. That in itself wouldn't be so bad except that there are things to stub my toes on and a cat that likes winding around my legs in the dark, so being able to see is pretty awesome.Overall this isn't bad and if this was half of its current price then it'd be much more reasonable of a purchase.
