I got this when it was on sale for a dollar, which I recognize being far too cheap to sustain on a regular basis, but something less expensive than its current price of twentyfive would be ideal.
title: OK enough, some issues with outlet space

author: benjamin bannister
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2019
review_content: At $25 this smart plug is overpriced, however, when it goes down to $5 (with the purchase of an Echo Dot; or asking Alexa to order one during a promotion), then it's totally worth it.What does it do? Depending on the device you plug in, you can do many things. Some examples of how I use it:EXAMPLE 1: In my bedroom, I plug a floor lamp into a smart plug and can tell Alexa, "Turn bedroom light on/off."EXAMPLE 2: I plug my sound receiver and subwoofer to a plug (with a separate triple adapter) and it turns on when I say, "Alexa, turn on sound system."EXAMPLE 3: In my living room, I plug a floor lamp into one plug and I plug a table lamp into another plug, and I can say either, "Turn on floor light," or "turn on table light." But, then I also can set it up as a group and say, "Alexa, turn on living room (lights)." In addition, I can add a routine (timer) so that my living room turns on after sunset, and off before I go to bed. And each plug can have separate on/off timers set.Honestly, these plugs have been convenient when it comes to finding remotes or turning switches physically on. They save time as well from having to manually do things.If you have Alexa in your home, these smart plugs are the next items you should have on your list. Recommended.
title: Make Your Home Devices Smart

author: S.D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020
review_content: When it works it works great..  but loses wifi connection all the time..  IN the same room as my expensive powerful router!  Seems if it isn't directly in sight it loses connection all the things and at random.I have THREE of these plugs that operate under the cabinet LED lighting for my kitchen they're all in the same room and the router is very close to them within 15-20 ft.But they still lose Wi-Fi signal at random.I'm not buying any more of these until they can get a stronger Wi-Fi signal. I have to contort myself to reach in and turn the power button on and off manually to reset them. if I wanted to do that I would just turn the under cabinet lights on myself.
title: Loses wifi in the same room as the router...

author: Drew Bolton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: While I feel Amazon has their hands in too many things in too many areas, I still cannot help but put a scoop of faith in most of their tech offerings. A clear example is this little handy device.  I recently strung up some outdoor string lighting in my backyard that sort of zigzags across the backyard area, between my roof eves and my gazibo. Looks great, etc. However, I also wanted an easy way to control them not just at home but also remotely, as I also run a VRBO out of our guesthouse. And, we all know that not all guests are considerate so if they turned those lights on, I'd want to be able to remotely turn them off if we're out of town and they forget to do so.In comes this device. While it's not rated for outdoors, I actually plugged it into an outlet that runs into my gazibo, which is mostly covered from the elements.  So I felt comfortable that it would work perfectly fine. Plugged it in, tested it, and it works as expected. So now I'm able to tell Alexa to turn it off/on and even our guests can utilize it should they want to.The only trivial inconvenience was the QR code that you supposedly are able to scan and have the Alex app determine how to set it up. That unfortunately didn't work for me so after many attempts, I just had to manually go through the process. Again, trivial.
title: You Just Cannot Go Wrong With This

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2020
review_content: This smart plug took me 2 minutes to setup!!!  I was familiar with setup for these plugs for I had ordered a Gosund Mini Wifi Outlet that works with Alexa back in Dec 2019.  I worked with it for over 4 hours and no success and returned it. So when I got this smart plug I was ready for a couple hours work.  I got my phone connected to my 2.4 mHz wifi (these plugs only work on the lower mHz), plugged the new plug into the wall outlet next to my router, turned on Alexa on my phone. VOILA!!!!  Alexa recognized the plug immediately and asked what it was to operate. If it was a light, plug in the light. Well I had to take the plug and run into the bedroom and plug it in with my floor lamp that I wanted to operate. Alexa recognized it.  Now I just had to setup the commands to turn it on and off.  Easy...Alexa had already identified the turn off phrase "Alexa, Goodnight".  I identified the turn on phrase.  The light is next to my husband's side of the bed. Before he jumps into bed he gets by the bed and faces the great room where Alexa is located and says loudly "Alexa, Goodnight".  Off goes the light as he jumps into bed. Then we both laugh and laugh at how neat this is!!!  If I could give it more stars I would. So easy to setup and to use.  I am trying to think of what else I need a smart plug for.....
title: What a smart plug!!

author: Vincent
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
review_content: Very easy to setup. Just open Alexia App, press device icon in lower right corner of app, then follow onscreen instructionsAble to sync with camera* by scanning QR code on back of device, or press the physically press the sync button.For QR code scan, Kindle tablets may not work due to low resolution camera. Must use smartphone if you plan to use this sync featureOnce setup, can you name it like"lights" for example.All you have to do is use an Alexia enabled device (echo series, echo buds, Fire TV, Alexia enabled media control, etc): say "Alexia" followed by name of your plug, then "on" or "off" to activate plug.So if i have my lamp wire plugged into the device, and it's off; all i have to say is "Alexia lights On" and my lamp will turn on. 3 prong plug. Fits standard outlet, and power strip well. For power bricks with plugs running horizontal instead of vertical, it can block outletsWorks via wifi (must have same wifi network as Alexia device).Noticed there's a deep discount if you use Alexia device to purchase during Prime Day, Black Friday and/or Cyber Monday Makes life way simpler at home. Save a few seconds here and there, but it adds up overtime, especially when you're busy
title: Easy setup. Fits Standard Wall Outlet, Power Strip

author: Jerry M Josephson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2020
review_content: Received this smart plug in a package deal with a new Amazon Dot. You need to use the Alexa App on a smartphone or tablet to set it up and I found the Alexa App to be flakey and hard to use. At first it would not detect the plug, then it did find the plug but kept trying to connect it to a city wide WiFi network rather than my home WiFi network. The App had me scanning a digital picture during setup but that never worked. I finally stated that I did not have the digital scan and proceeded without it. I was then able to successfully identify the correct WiFi network and connect the device in this manner. The fault appears to be in the Alexa App rather than the smart plug itself.
title: Works well but can be difficult to set up

author: Rich S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2019
review_content: Works fine, blocks only  outlet but theMeross WiFi Smart Plug Mini, 16 Amp & Reliable Wifi Connection Powered by Mediatek Chipset, Alexa and Google Voice Control, App Remote Control, Timer, Occupies Only One Socket, No Hub Needed, 4 Pack for $29 does the same.The Sonoff S20 at $10 does as well and works with the eWeLink app and ITFFFas well as Alexa.In fact Sonoff has a complete line of products. I just converted a ceiling fan with light at my friend's place to voice control for $15 with the Sonoff IFan03 including a 8 button remote that you can use as well as the Android/IOS app or your voice which only does on/off. I gave her a Dot for music and info since Spanish is now an option so that gives her voice control.The only reason I bought this "Stupid Plug" is it was $4.99 during Prime Days. It's worth $7-8 at most.None of what I do with automation is difficult or new. Many people have been doing it for 3 decades or more.What's funny about these new "wonder" devices is none can control the brightness of a lamp or the speed of a fan (the Sonoff IFan03 has 3 fan speeds using the wireless remote) but my 30 year old X10 products can do that with the PC interface, the wireless remote or my voice by Alexa, eWeLink app or IFTTT via internet or by a phone call to the PC.My Panasonic KX-TGF575 Link2Cell house phones have an intercom function so I can pick one up, push intercom and give a command to the PC from anywhere in the house or use the Google, Samsung or Siri function to do it via my cell phone's WiFi. It also informs me when my cell receives texts, emails, Whatsapp messages and more.I can receive or call any # in the world easily and cheaply from my house phones, base unit or cell phone.My 25 old X10 "Powerhouse" IR/wireless remotes control all my electronics including my alarm system.The small X10 interface connected to an old laptop PC runs the whole house including turning lights on/off when people enter or leave a room or turning lights on/off pseudo randomly if away.It sets my Echos to detect glass breaking or loud noises when I leave, calls me if a problem is detected and prepares the house for my return. The alarm system works independently and notifies me and the police if something is detected and I can look at all the cameras and in the house and grounds if needed.There are IR and other sensors which signal the laptop and alarm system and take appropriate action a well as timers scheduled and with the Sonoff TH16 and the eWeLink app it will turn my fans or AC on/off as needed to keep the house comfortable. Add the new IFTTT app and you'll find over 600  actions which can be cascaded to do almost anything easily. The old app was sometimes difficult to use.The new one is very easy to understand and have it do what you want.Voice control is handled by Windows and the mic built into the old laptop that runs 24/7 or Alexa and IFTTT.I can even use any phone in the world to control everything. and have for the last 25+ years.All the info needed is on the internet. Go find it and a smart 12 year old to show you how to get it done.
title: Works fine at 2-3 times the price of others.

author: KenjiFox
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2019
review_content: Sadly, this smart plug ain't it chief.The good;Should you have the misfortune of owning two of these, you can put them both next to each other in one standard wall outlet.This device is automatically recognized and set up by Alexa within seconds of being plugged in.The bad;This thing SHUTS OFF if there is a lack of either WiFi, or internet access on said WiFi. That's madness.Okay, so there is a power button on the side... we can sorta deal with that by hitting the button to manually turn it on. Kinda okay right? WRONG! It will shut right back off after a few minutes without internet. WTF? REALLY?Deal killer.Deal still twitching? No problem;This device will not resume the last known power state after unexpected (or expected) power loss.This really sucks. It sucks even worse than the IF internet != 1 Shutdown problem I mentioned earlier.I am currently using this for a small and highly efficient AC in my RV. The thing is, that AC is life or death for my pets. A lack of internet, WiFi, or temporary power blip will result in the AC shutting down. This makes the "smart" plug almost useless. You couldn't even trust to it keep your Christmas lights on.I got it for $4.99 along with a generation 3 Dot for Prime Day. I'm glad I didn't spend a penny more than that. Its not worth even $10. Let alone $24 that they want for it.  The Gen 3 Dot however is amazing and I am so very glad I got it.If you have a 100% frivolous use for it such as watching a lamp power on and off for your amusement and absolutely REQUIRE insanely simple setup, maybe this is the smart plug for you.
title: This thing kinda sucks...

author: Bob Woodridge
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 1, 2019
review_content: This smart plug falls short compared to ones I have by Bn-Link, Tp-Link and Wemo.  The difference is that this one has issues if the internet goes out, even if my local wi-fi network is still working. For one thing, if the internet goes out, after awhile this plug turns itself off. I've had to manually push the button to turn it back on a couple of times until the internet was restored, a pain. Secondly, it depends on the Alexa app for remote control, so if the internet is down, so is Alexa. My other smart plugs have their own phone apps, and I can still control them via their apps as long as my local wi-fi is still working, even if my Comcast internet is down. Since I use the smart plugs in locations that are hard to reach, having to manually control this one if Alexa isn't available is a pain. Luckily it's only happened two times so far this year.
title: Requires internet, not just wi-fi

author: Ali
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2020
review_content: I was reluctant to spend $20 on an outlet but this is really handy. We originally bought it for our Christmas tree so we didn't have to climb behind it every time we wanted to unplug it or plug it back in. Simply tell Alexa to turn it on and done. Once Christmas was over I moved it to where I had an old light timer that made a loud ticking noise and wasn't accurate anymore. With the app you can easily set a routine so lights (or whatever) come on and go off when you want them to. It's super handy and you could even adjust it when you were out of town or even on your way home from work if you wanted lights on. Overall I'd recommend them for making life a little simpler!
title: Convenient and easy to use

author: J. Watkins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2018
review_content: This works perfectly for what we needed! My parents bought a new fancy curved tv this past year, and the dumb thing keeps losing connection to the remote or vice versa. So if it's sat there for while and we tried to press the menu button on the remote to access Netflix/Hulu etc, it wouldn't work. We were having to pull the plug behind the tv mounted high up on the wall to get it to reset. And the tv wasn't being returned because it was already mounted on the wall. Huge pain in the butt. Enter the smart plug. Ordered it on a whim to see if it would replace us having to reach in behind the tv to plug/unplug and it did just that. We named the plug tv, plugged the tv into it, and now every time we need to re-sync the remote we just tell Alexa to turn the tv off and turn the tv on and Bob's your uncle. There might have been a way to fix this issue with the remote or tv without this, but my dad hates technology and he certainly wasn't taking it off the wall to take it back so this was the next best fix. I've quite enjoyed the functionality of the smart plug so I'll probably be purchasing a few for my house in the future!
title: Perfect!

author: Donut
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2019
review_content: My main gripe was with the setup. It seems that having my router config with a hidden SSID was a problem for the smartplug. It isnt able to detect a wi-fi access point unless the SSID is broadcasting. That was awfully annoying because I was not going to cut access to everything else just to switch the SSID to publicly broadcast. Seems like somewhat of a security risk to endure just to connect the smartplug. Instead, I connected the smartplug to a different router in the house that does have its SSID broadcasting publicly.Once I got that all sorted out I came across the issue of not every simple appliance being compatible. My lamp has a simple touch-based switch. Did not work whatsoever despite powering it on and off before powering the smartplug on and off.After a few different devices, I put it to use with my record player. The record player is the one device that I would always have to plug in when in use and unplug when I knew I was not going to be using it for days at a time. This is where the smartplug was just perfect. Instead of having to reach down into the corner with all the wiring and plug that sucker into the UPS unit, I can now simply use the remote on firestick 4K , and simply say "Alexa, Power on the plug". Right away the plug switches on, the record player is powered, and I can immediately reach for some vinyl to listen to.So while its not hassle-free from the getgo and won't be ideal for a lot of devices, once you find just the right device for it, you'll enjoy having it installed.For the low price that it was during purchase,  I am certainly satisfied with what I got.I have never been one for the smart home trend, but little things like this add lots of conveniences to otherwise minor annoyances.
title: it was just what I was needing

author: jll544
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
review_content: This smart plug does its job well, and because I opted-into linking this device to my Amazon account during the purchase, setup was incredibly easy - just plug and play. What's disappointing, however, is that this device produces a constant high-pitched sound, also known as coil whine.Whether or not someone detects the noise depends on their hearing ability and sensitivity to such sounds, and unfortunately this one does fall into my hearing range. There are various techniques that manufacturers can use to reduce this type of noise, including gluing-down the noise-producing components or filling empty voids (potting) inside the device, so it's sad to experience a preventable issue in this product.I now see that other customers have been mentioning this problem since the product came out, so it's partially my fault for not reading through the reviews before purchasing. Alas, the coil whine produced by this device is annoying enough that I currently have it unplugged and not in use. I might still be able to find some purpose for this plug, but it would have to be in a room that I don’t spend much time in. As much as I want to like this smart plug, I can rate it only three stars due to the coil whine it produces.
title: Constant high-pitched noise aka coil whine

author: Bruce Gilbert
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2019
review_content: I received an Echo Dot for Christmas last year, and wasn't really using it, so I bought one of these to see what more I could get of a device that repeatedly says, "sorry, I don't know about that" unless I'm asking about today's weather.I live alone with my cat, I work late hours, and I don't like to leave him alone in the dark, so this Smart Plug makes it easy for me to remotely light up the living room, where all of his toys are.  It can operated manually, or set on a timer.EDIT: Six months later, it has to be paired with the Echo Dot once every few weeks.Both the Echo Dot and the Smart Plug have been destroyed, and thrown in the trash where they belong.I am getting timers for my lights.  This product is an overpriced piece of garbage.
title: Good for controlling appliances remotely...for a few months

author: Stephen CJ Nesbit
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019
review_content: For the past 3 years I've been using SONOFF smart switches that I had to literally strip wires and wire myself to update my apartment that was built back in the 70s.  My living room has NO overhead light, and there are no functioning light-switch-activated outlets anywhere in my apartment.  So every night I had to stumble into a pitch black apartment and seek out a light.  The Sonoff smart switches were ok, but they also require a setup on an account in China, and any time I want to turn on / off my lights, the switch routes them ALL the way to China, and back. And whenever their server is down, or the internet is having issues, none of my devices will turn on or off.Enter the Amazon Smart Plug.  No hub required, no funky accounts needed.  You need a 2.4 Ghz wifi router (or one that has 2.4 and 5, but it REQUIRES the 2.4 Ghz network) , an Echo / Echo Dot, and about 2 minutes to set up.I opened the package, read the instructions, stuck the plug into an outlet, plugged in a light, Opened my Alexa app on my phone, told it to add a new device, it asked to 'scan QR code' , and one was provided on a slip of paper, and it automatically set the entire thing up.  It was a snap!Now I"m going to replace all of my old SONOFF switches, with Amazon Smart Plugs a few at a time as I can wedge them into the budget. Thanks Amazon!
title: Super easy to use, easy to setup, no special hub required

author: Brian W. Antoine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2019
review_content: So yes, easy to install via the app, but after a half hour or so, it goes offline.  I can push the button for local control but there is no access via Alexa or the App until I unplug it and plug it back in.  Then it works for awhile before it dies again.Waste of time and money.Edit:  Shortly after publishing my review I got a call from Amazon Support asking how they could help me.  I explained what I thought the problem might be, given that I'm a network engineer and had done some technical investigation of my own.  Support promised to contact me and put me in touch with Alexa Support.  While waiting for that, I left the device plugged in, on the off chance it would update its firmware, since there was no way to update it directly via the Alexa app.  A few days later I got an email asking me to retest the device since Alexa Support had noticed a firmware update had been pushed to it.  Sure enough, it now operates correctly.  It still has a few tech issues, but those would not normally be something an average customer would notice.So I've upgraded and updated my review.2nd Edit: A month later, it still isn't reliable.  It will fail to renew it's network address at times and go offline, I've also seen it turn off the device plugged into it when it really gets confused.  All I have plugged in is a Salt Lamp as a test, I would not trust this plug with anything that needed reliable control.  I also notice Woot deeply discounting these the week after I originally reviewed it.  I've sent Alexa support log files from my network server demonstrating the failure but I never heard back from them and it's still on the same firmware version it originally updated to.
title: Works for a few minutes then goes offline

author: James S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2018
review_content: I’ve set up my entire house with  smart switches and plugs.  I’ve only used the GE Zigbee products and I’ve never had an issue. I tried two Amazon plugs and they’re garbage. Error codes and connection issues. There is an entire thread on this very issue on Amazon’s Community Help board.Update: 5 stars for Amazon’s customer service. They contacted me after reading my review offering to troubleshoot. But the plugs have already been shipped back.
title: Waste of time and money

author: Six20Seven
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2020
review_content: Disclaimer: I have quite a few smart home devices and can use Alexa and routines to control lots of things, so I have experience setting up this type of item.This was purchased so I could remotely activate my candle warmers. There were so many times when I'd light a scented candle and forget to put it out before leaving the house or going to sleep. So smart plug plus [candle warmer] plus Alexa equals being able to set up routines that will activate whatever is plugged in to the smart plug under whatever circumstances I set. Like they will automatically turn on when I'm within half a mile from home then turn back off an hour later. I can have them set to turn off 10 minutes after my usual bed time, or to turn on whenever I say "Alexa, turn on [my smart plug]". The possibilities are limitless.Setting the unit up is as simple as plugging it in, opening the Alexa app and following the prompts. After that you can then turn it off using voice commands as stated above.The unit is fairly small and feels light but well constructed.So far they work well and have never failed to change modes when I gave a command.I highly recommend these to anyone who is trying to add smart cont
title: Excellent way to add smart control to many items

author: Evan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2020
review_content: Works as intended overall - bought these only on promotion, I have 3 of them. I think a base price of $25/plug is steep. The most I’ve paid for 1 unit is $5, the least 0.99 cents. The only complaint I have about these is their supposed synchronization. Whether it’s turning these on/off on a schedule like sunrise/sunset or at a given time, if I use the Alexa app and set all 3 devices to power on or off using the same schedule attribute or time, there always seems to be some asynchronous action. In other words, there can often be seconds difference (even 30-60 seconds, I’ve timed it) where the same exact product, all on the same WiFi network, meant to be triggered at the same exact time, does not trigger simultaneously. The only thing I can think of is that these IoT devices are speaking to different servers within my region/time zone, or the actions (when there’s more than one schedule-sensitive routine item) get triggered in succession. I have tried as Amazon support recommended to reset the device to factory and re-join it to my network, Re-build the routine and everything. It does not resolve the issue. I’ve just moved on, because it really is not a dealbreaker. At a rock bottom price, I love buying these things to control low voltage lighting on a schedule. I recommend overall.
title: A bit pricey, but they worn

author: MalakJoe
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
review_content: First of all, let me say setup was a breeze. I plugged it in, Alexa found the plug right away. This is because Amazon registers it on advance with your account and WIFI info before it arrives. Don't want that? Be sure to buy it as a gift.So what can I say that hasn't been said? It's functions: ON and OFF. That's it. What more do you need?The only problem I have with it is the price. At the time publishing, it was nearly $25. I know it's vetted and branded by Amazon, but there are other off brand versions out there for cheaper.This is ON and OFF. If you plan on hooking it to a lamp, you might be overspending. I have two LED smartbulbs that together cost less than this device and they turn on, off, and dim with various levels of brightness. For less you could even find RGB wifi bulbs to add more functionality.Of course, if you want to use this with a coffee maker, fan, or uhmm... I'm sure there are other uses... Then this will give you the option to add ON/OFF functionality .I think my next smart plug will be one of the cheaper (less than $10) off brands. I'll update this if they are significant worse than this one.Regardless, if being virtually presetup is worth the premium for you, go with this one. But remember.. on and off. That's all it will do. If you're buying it for a lamp, consider a smart bulb instead.
title: ON and OFF functionality makes it pricey to control a lamp, but useful for other things.

author: Jimmy James
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2020
review_content: After a very disappointing experience with Philip's Hue lamps, I am happy to report that these actually work. The first of 8 did not want to pair with my echo dot but it did eventually but would not turn off and on.  Moved it to another receptacle 6 feet closer to router/ap which is on another floor and probably 50' away and it and the other 7 work fine. Going to test remote capability today from 90 miles away. Got these for an all lights on function for security and emergencies with a dedicated table lamp in each of eight rooms. Cheap security/lighting control.  I say cheap, you are paying a premium for Amazon branded gear but IT WORKS compared to the 3rd party "stuff".  Amazon if you are reading this you need to make more Amazon branded accessories to go with Echo system. Switches, lights, tstats, outdoor lights, security hardware, video surveillance,  camera doorbells, etc.  I dont want to talk to other companies to try and make their stuff work on your system.  Oh and here's a nifty little nugget of helpful info.  ALL THIS STUFF NEEDS TO WORK ON 5GHZ BUT IT ONLY WORKS ON 2.4GHZ. That's why the HUE lamps I bought would not work but neither Amazon Echo "techs" nor Philips "techs" knew that.
title: Need more Amazon branded Echo items like this

author: The AffA-Way
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2020
review_content: "They read my mind”! The 1st exp. w/ smart plugs was subpar dissovling  any consideration as a viable option for future endeavors.I had hoped that since becoming obsessed with lighting again and, despite going ⁹5%  LED (energy efficient low-cost lighting) entirely, I inadvertently doubled the number of lights camceling out any positive energy bill reduction. Therefore my solution was to by several smart plugs 2 force me to remember to turn off lights that were being unused and wasting much-needed resources. needless to say the plugs did not last very long and again there was no plan to revisit that chapter as it was a frustrating endeavor.Luckily Amazon helped me realize I needed to give the plug idea another try.I'm pretty excited about it.I'm actually keeping it!I need like 5 more.I'm determined to prove it helps reduce the energy bill! ⟵(๑¯◡¯๑)Thanks again Amazon!←(*꒪ヮ꒪*)ATTN AMAZON:Greetings!When corps faciliate awesome things like this for select consumer accounts, I am very inclined to return the favor with thoughtful, rich content inclusive of seemless, advanced level vocab and precise, organic, keywords framing each situation intentionally as to reflect context-specific tonality.  Writing is a natural ability of mine that I certainly love using as a means to convey gratitude. Despite my genetic predisposition concerning said afro mention skill set, invaluable, incredibly long term, personal discipline and dedication to the art form has refined its characteristics to be highly sophisticated and professional. I recently scored a 99% during an impromptu writing exam officially faciliacted by Grammarly.com .Copy of results available upon request ⟵(๑¯◡¯๑)Qualitative interactions and direct ux feedbackcombined with content sharing/promotion /interconnectivity between diverse consumer accounts or uploading profesional content, adding reactions adding dedicted user retention with UX enhancements solidifiying integrity awareness and relevance.
title: Plenty Smart (*❛‿❛)→ THANKS AMAZON!

author: mj
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2019
review_content: I had a table lamp on an old-fashioned rotary dial manual timer.  It was in a hard to reach outlet, so when my kids came over, they would turn off the lamp itself rather than at the timer. Then I'd wonder why the lamp didn't turn on. Plus, everytime there was a power outage, I had to reset the timer.Because I already have an Ecobee in-wall light switch, I knew that with amazon integration, the switch could be configured to turn on at sunset, and would stay on schedule after a power outage (once the power returned).I wanted to use the Amazon smart plug to do two things:1. Turn on the table lamp on a schedule2. Turn on the table lamp with a voice commandIn the Alexa app, I was able to enter a schedule (routine) to turn on at sunset and turn off at 11:00 PM everyday. It wasn't the most straightforward thing to do, but it appears to work.The problem I've discovered is the voice command. When I actually read the little pamphlet that came with the smart plug, it said it needed to be within 30 feet of an Echo device. It turns out that you have to give voice commands to Echo, as the Smart Plug is not smart enough to hear anything. I didn't expect this, because my Ecobee light switch has its own built in Alexa interface. Of course, that switch cost >10x than this plug that cost $5 on special.Anyhow, the smart plug setup works for the specific table lamp, but since I only have one Echo in a big house, I'm a little disappointed the plug is so simple.
title: Smart Plug doesn't have its own voice interface

author: Gail from Lake Geneva
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2020
review_content: We have lots of indirect lights in our house that were controlled by ten timers.  That meant that, as the amount of daylight changed, we had to reset the time they turn on, sometimes crawling on the floor to reach the outlet, sometimes moving furniture.  Plus, since most were analog timers, it was hard to be exact in our settings, so they came on at different times.We replaced them all with the Smart Plugs, and it's a wonder to behold!  They are grouped together on my Alexa app, and all set to turn on 10 minutes before sunset, then turn off at 11:30 PM.  Poof!  Lights!If we happen to be awake later, it is so easy to just ask Alexa to turn the lights back on, then turn them off again when we go to bed.We did have to watch a YouTube video to learn how to program them, but once we knew what we were doing, it was easy.  I was thinking a "Routine" would include an on and off, but they have to be set up as separate routines.  Also, I had to Google how to delete a routine that I had set up incorrectly.  I could figure out how to disable it, but I wanted to remove it.Buying so many plugs at once was a bit of an investment, but well worth it.
title: Replaced Timers

author: AJ Dalton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2019
review_content: This started out as an experiment.  It does have a hefty price if one wants to deploy them all over the house.  But, after experimenting with the one I have, I started thinking about where else I'd like more of these - but was stopped by the overall price.Anyway, it integrated with Alexa very easily and I use it every day.  I don't want to use this technology where 'hacking' might really do some damage, however.I did have one instance of a problem with it, which makes me re-think wide deployment of them:  Once, for some reason, I had Alexa turn this outlet "on" as was commanded - but when I asked Alexa to turn it "off" Alexa said that it had lost contact with it - so the outlet remained "on" indefinitely until I looked for a switch and discovered the almost-invisable On/Off switch on its side.RECOMMENDATION:  Maybe, someday, engineers could build-in a routine "ping" system - wherein the plug would obey the owner's commands (in Setup) of what to do (stay "on" or turn "off") after an owner-set period of "no contact time".  So, for instance - it all contact is lost (no pings) for 30-minutes - it would shut-off and reset itself - OR - if after contact is lost for 5 minutes, it could reset itself and turn back "on" if so programmed.  [Just a suggestion]
title: Amazon Smart Plug

author: Francis C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2018
review_content: My toddler son kept messing with a mechanical timer I was using for Christmas lights, so I got this smart plug in order to set an on and off schedule through the Alexa app. Setup was easy, just followed the instructions. And I set up the schedule and it just works. Pretty simple. It turns stuff on or off. If you need something more than that, then this is not for you.
title: It works.

author: Dustin Ortmann
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2019
review_content: This plug is a huge let down for one primary reason. Multiple users, even if they are in your household, can’t see the plug on the Alexa app. For example, user 1 installs the plug. User 1 can control the plug using the Alexa app. User 2 who is in the same household cannot see the plug on their Alexa app. This is a deal breaker for this plug. Go on vacation and want to turn on the lamps in your house? Well User 1 can control them from their app but User 2 cannot. User 1 has to create a skill and have User 2 use the skill as a workaround but this is far from ideal. Amazon needs to push an update that allows all Household members to see all Household Amazon plugs or this plug should fade off into oblivion because it’s just useful. It takes the smart out of smart home.
title: Doesn’t work for multiple user households

author: Doug
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2019
review_content: As soon as I plugged this device into the wall, it was like plugging in to the Matrix. Everything made sense, everything flowed  flawlessly with a rhythm and cadence I felt myself being totally mesmerized by. It was as if I was transported to an imaginary world where everything was perfect and happiness ruled all. With the beautiful and sultry voiced Alexa as my guide, I was able to control the most mundane objects with a simple wish. What I said became law. Like a deity from ancient text, I spoke and things came to life. Where it was once darkness, I brought light with simply a word.It's important to note that one must remain vigilant about not abusing one's power. The amazon smart plug powered by Alexa is a force for good, but can be corrupted to serve the forces of evil. Do Not let the power beguile you. For a moment I felt the pull of the dark side, bellowing out edicts and commands on a whim until sanity rushed back and I realized destroying the world with but a command to Alexa was not worth it - I like pizza and burritos to much.You will not regret purchasing this product - EVER. It is quite simply one of, if not THE, greatest thing to exist. Period.
title: Mind-Blowing Technology of the Future

author: Airpower
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2019
review_content: I'll start by saying that once you have it set up, and you figure out how to set up a schedule, the plug works great.  I can simply tell Alexa to turn off and on.  I have mine on a lamp to use as a timer too, which is where the first issue comes in.  I would think you'd be able to just make a routine to have it turn on and off an certain times, but it isn't that simple.  I found I needed to add a "turn on" event, then a "delay" and then a "turn off" event in one routine just so I didn't have a dozen different routines.  There should be simpler way to set up a timer function.The other issue was the initial set up, which for me took quite some time.  Firstly, the provided paper instructions and those I found online are different, so you need to be aware of long pushing the button for set up.  After this was discovered, it still did not connect.  I showed up on my Alexa app, but to no work, telling me the "server is offline."  Through more trial and error, I discovered that you need to give it a lot of time to find itself between steps.  First I'd get the plug in set up mode, and leave it for a few minutes.  Then I'd add it in Alexa.  I then had to wait a solid half hour before it became connected.  This just doesn't live up to the whole idea of plug and play.Again, once it's working, it's great, but there is much more work and creativity required to get it working than there should be.  I think I'll try some other plugs too to see if they are better.
title: Works, but slow setup, and some weird functionality

author: It's Just Me
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Smart plug was defective in less than a year. It was fun while it lasted! Customer service was no help either - I got transferred 3 times, and I was told to call back in a few hours the third time (despite calling during daytime hours). Regarding the device, great invention! The downside is that these plugs should be redesigned to rely on network/router connectivity when the internet goes down, cuz Alexa is sorely limited without the internet. In my case, I used it for indoor lighting. As stated, in under a year it failed. To attempt to fix it, I tried a software update, deleted and re-added it to the Alexa app, manually reset it and tried re-pairing it, power cycled it, verified the internet connection was good - nothing worked...except replacing it with a different one. Replacing it worked like a charm. Too bad that’s not what I intended when buying the defective one. 😀 Despite the unfortunate events, these plugs have a lot of potential. It’s nice for rooms such as mine where the light switch is on the opposite side of where I normally enter and exit the room. I’d still buy more, but I may steer clear of the Amazon version due to my experience.
title: Transformed into a Butt Plug

author: Bill B
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2019
review_content: Update (Dec 2, 2019):I bought a second one of these and the setup process was not as effortless as the first one was. My Echo Dot did not announce the new plug as it did before so I had to go through the arduous setup process. I tried scanning the tiny included bar code with my Fire 7 tablet and could not get the camera to focus close enough to see the bar code clearly. So I installed the Alexa app on my phone and got the bar code to focus but the app still could not read the bar code. Then, the app switched to a different screen and had me press the power button on the plug until it flashed blue and red. I did that and the app started scanning for the plug. That failed and I ended up going through the setup process multiple times until it finally found the plug in the blue/red mode. Now, my Echo Dot announced it found a new device, "Second Plug". Okay -- or so I thought. I then moved the plug to a different outlet and told Alex to turn on "Second Plug". Alexa announced "Second Plug is not responding". After trying this a few times, I ended up deleting the plug from the app. After wasting an hour trying to set this up, I was ready to return it when the Echo Dot announced it found a new device, "Second Plug". I then asked Alexa to turn on "Second Plug" and was back with "Second Plug is not responding". What?! I deleted the plug and unplugged it, waited an hour, plugged it back in and waited for the Echo Dot to find it. This time it found it and could turn it on and off.My best guess is there were dueling Alexas trying to setup the new plug: the Echo Dot; Alexa on my Fire 7; and Alexa on my phone. Unplugging and deleting the new plug then closing all Alexa apps must have cleared it from Amazon Central. My best advice if you buy one of these is to let your Echo Dot find it and do not use the Alexa app. Also, I would like to see a larger bar code included in the box so the Alexa app can see it and allow that step to work for those without Echo devices. I dropped my rating from 4 stars to 3 because of this difficult setup process.Original:This smart plug is very easy to setup if you have only one wi-fi network and allow Amazon to store your wi-fi password. After opening the box, I read the instructions with a number of fairly involved steps. As it turned out, all I had to do was plug it into the wall outlet. After a few seconds, my Echo Dot announced the smart plug was ready and even told me the voice command needed to rename it. I'd rate that experience 5 stars.However, I prefer these IoT devices be on the guest network and not my primary network so I had to go through a fairly involved sequence to switch to the guest network. I put the smart plug in setup mode, connected my Fire Tablet to the smart plug (the Fire Tablet took a couple of minutes to scan and find the smart plug) , selected the guest wi-fi network. The Fire Tablet then took a couple of minutes scanning again for some reason. Not too bad but if Alexa had asked which network to connect the smart plug to, I would have rated this 5 stars.The other concern is the relay inside this new smart plug. This smart plug replaced a different, obsolete smart plug. The old smart plug had a substantial, loud click when I turned it on. This new smart plug has a soft, quiet click. The fan I have connected is well within the rating of the smart plug and I'm hoping this smart plug holds up with such a small relay inside.
title: Easy To Setup For Most Folks - Or Not

author: The Masked Reviewer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2019
review_content: It's hard to imagine why anyone would want to go with smart outlets when you can just plug and play with these. Moreover, if you move or go on vacatation, they go with you! The looks good. They work well. They practically set themselves up. All you really have to do is ask Alexa to rename each plug, preferably as you plug it in.Installing switches and outlets can get hairy because screw holes and the srewes themselves can get stripped, causing undoreseen hassles,  multiple fruitless trips to the hardware store, and expensive visits by the handymab.  The handyman won't hang around until you get them working on the app. If for any reason you think you need to unscrew the face plate and pull the switches or the outlet out to tinker, you're liable to run into another screw hole scripping issue and go back into the endless cycle of stuffing all those wires back into the sttupid box!Just use these! The best plug on the market, and unlike the Tliinks, these don't have that annoying whining sound that really grates people with good hearing.Better than installing an entire new smart outlet. Better than any other plug on the market. Works best with Alexa.
title: The Amazon smart plug is THE best smart outlet option out there, bar none.

author: Ronald Lee Weagley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: Within five days after working adequately on each command the equipment FAILDED to open on commands. ALEXA acknowledged failure to open. Rebooted Wi-Fi router, FAILURE. The ALEXA  rely repeated was FAILURE. Attempts at resetting by holding the side button and waiting for the "blue" signal, FAILED. Attempts to open in alternate electric wall terminal locations, FAILED. In other this is a failed purchase of a "come-on" sale. I wish for a return of my investment! I also warn others to expect FAILURE.
title: FAILED within four days

author: RT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: Update- what a pain in the a**. For no reason, no power loss, no power surge, the plug just stops responding. I bought this because my lights plug and switches are in a very inconvenient place to access behind furniture and a panel. I had to move furniture, remove a panel, get on my knees reach in an awkward area and pull out the plug. I can't believe there is no way to remotely reset the plug. Or the plug to automatically detect loss of service and reset. DEFINATELY NOT READY FOR PRIME TIME!! Pass on the home automation. It's not ready!It was super easy to set up. I basically plugged the Smart Plug in and plugged the light into it. In about 20 secs my Echo Show said "new device found named first plug, do you want to rename it?" I renamed it to living room lights and that was it. Didn't have to push the button on the plug or anything. Not sure why users having issues with setup.
title: A total let down

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2018
review_content: I bought six (6) of these to quickly turn our Christmas lights on/off easily.  Initial setup was fairly straight forward and I was able to put the plugs in to a group easily.Unfortunately, problems began after getting all the plugs set up and then plugging them in to wall outlets and Christmas lights.  Initially, all the lights came on OK, but after 30-40 minutes, a couple of the plugs just turned off on their own.  On top of that, the plugs started becoming unresponsive.  They would get stuck in either an on or off position, and nothing I could do via voice commands or from the Alexa app would get them to respond.  The only way to get them to work again (for a short while), was to unplug the smart plug from the wall, wait a few seconds and then turn it back on.I've read the reports about separating 5Ghz and 2.4Ghz networks.  Tried that.  No luck.Tried resetting the plugs back to factory defaults.  No luck.I'm a server admin, and I'm very familiar with computers.  I've also been a network administrator in the past, so I'm familiar with both wired and wireless networks.I'm going to keep trying to isolate the problem, but if I don't get it resolved soon I'm going to request a return.
title: Unreliable

author: Pharmtech
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2019
review_content: This is my first smartplug. Bought it long with echo dot 3rd gen that was on sale for $29.99. I put a lamp in corner of living room because previous one was small, difficult to get to and my big hands could hardly fit under lampshade and I never felt like putting in the effort just for a small lamp. So I plugged in the smartplug and connected lamp cord to smartplug and opened my amazon alexa app and clicked devices asked alexa to " find device" and it did, I named it and was good to go. One note was the echo dot connected to it's own wifi echodot4hq, which is an open network so make sure you connect your echo dot to your secures home wifi network. The convenience of lighting the room now with my voice makes me happy.  It's a tough pill to swallow spending $25 for one smart plug but once its hooked up and doing its thing, the joy makes it worth the investment. I would recommend everyone to get something in their house hooked up to smart devices, especially elderly, really could benefit elderly people. Now black Friday has come and at $27 for a echo dot and smart plug we bought 4. I sent three away to family and kept one for myself because I love having the ability to turn lights on and off without moving. These are wonderful.
title: Love my smart plug

author: Richard H. McCann
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2020
review_content: The smart plug works great but will not work reliably with Eero wifi.  Eero (Eero is owned by Amazon, BTW) shuts down the 2.4 ghz portion of its transmitter if it goes unused for a certain time period - typically every night.  When this happens, the smart plug loses its link to your wifi system and has to be installed in the Alexa app brand new again every day.My solution was to now have TWO wifi systems running in my house (the Eero and the Linksys system I had prior to Eero) so that the smart plugs can work off the Linksys system and I don't have to reset them every day.  I called Tech "Support" at Eero and the guy basically said, "Yeah, we know about that problem.  Sorry.  There is no fix for it."  This is unacceptable; especially since Amazon now owns Eero and sells smart plugs under the Amazon name.Other than that significant problem, the smart plugs (I have several) work well and I would buy them again although I will check into see whether Wemo or other brands of smart plugs have the same problem.  I would imagine that they do since the problem is caused by Eero in the first place and not by the smart plug.
title: Doesn't work with Eero wifi

author: Howard and Shikha
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2019
review_content: This plug can be a pain to setup.  I have purchased two of these plugs and here is my experience with each of them.First PlugThis plug is used to control a lamp that has an on/off switch that semi-broke when a labrador retriever tipped the lamp over.  The switch still works, but you have to turn it just right or the knob comes off completely.  So we left it in the on position permanently and we used to manually plug/unplug the lamp when we needed extra light.  Amazon often runs promotions for these plugs so I think we picked this up on Prime Day or Black Friday.  This plug for some reason I couldn't scan the QR code and had to manually setup.  Once setup, it worked fine with Alexa controlling it as a light.  We renamed it to "light" from "first light" so we could just say "Alexa, turn on the light" or "Alexa, turn off the light".  It was setup so long ago I have no idea how it got grouped into lights.  Our lamp doesn't have a smart bulb.Second PlugThis plug is also used to control an on/off switch.  This plug was a major pain to setup.  I tried both the QR code and manual setup.  Sometimes it would connect to my wifi and sometimes it would not.  If it setup, I couldn't turn it off or on using Alexa app for android for a quick test (my Alexa speaker isn't nearby).  If the setup timed out, I would get various errors on not being able to see the plug or not being able to connect to wifi.  Finally, I figured out the plug was flaky because of the distance from my wifi router.  I happened to have a Netgear EX2700 (2.4Ghz only) laying around because my wife used to need it for an old Lenovo Yoga when she was in college.  I setup the wifi extender again (after a factory reset as it was setup for an old password) about half way between my router and the Amazon plug.  This time the QR code scanning worked.  I used the same password for my network name plus "_EXT" on the end.  I think the Amazon smart plug must have tried this network with the strongest signal and the saved password because I didn't have to pick the network and retype my password after I previously chose to save it.  Finally, I could control the lamp from my phone which this time was grouped among my smart plugs.  I renamed "Second Plug" to "Piano Light" and it was good to go.One thing the Alexa app can't tell you is the signal strength and reliability of your WiFi network.  It might show it briefly when choosing the network (signal strength), but it would be nice to see it constantly displayed within the app when showing the network your plug is on.  This way if you're going into your device list settings to see what's wrong with the device it might show a flaky signal which would explain why you can't control the plug with your voice or the Alexa app.  It doesn't have to constantly show this signal, only when you open device settings.  I can understand the limitation of the wifi radio they can put into these plugs and thus the need for extenders if you get far enough from your router.  I am using a NETGEAR R6700 Nighthawk AC1750 Dual Band Smart WiFi Router, Gigabit Ethernet (R6700) also bought from Amazon.
title: Used to control multiple floor lamps (setup can be tough)

author: Erin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2020
review_content: This is a cool product for changing a “dumb” product like a fan in to a smart one. With the Alexa app you can set up different timers/routines for it or use your voice with the app or an echo device. I used it for a lamp and a fan it worked great with both. It was also very easy to pair. Every once in a while when I ask Alexa to turn it off or on, or I tap the plug button on the Alexa app it won’t respond. I usually just ask again and or restart the app and it works but every so often it will take me pressing the button on the plug. Overall 95% of the time it works without issue. It’s funny cause it wasn’t doing this when it was on the otherside of the room that’s closer to the router so that may be the issue but really it’s not something that happens enough to bother me. I would recommend this plug but Just try to get a deal on it because 24 bucks is bit much for any smart plug. One last thing is I used it on a power strip and it worked.—Update—Keeps having problems with cutting out still works but I’ve bought a Kasa plug to use on the same outlet and it is much more reliable so far. Also you can get two Kasa plugs for the price of one amazon plug. The other downside of the amazon plug is it doesn’t work with ifttt.
title: It’s smart so we can be lazy

author: Daniel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2019
review_content: Sucks. Go third party. Had 4 of these for months, worked great. Now the developers pushed an unfinished update that made it useless. I reset, reconnected, restarted, with no luck. I called support and got nothing beyond our developers know. What the crap is that? The product I bought worked fine, now after my return deadline is up they push out an update that I did NOT authorize and break the device. How the heck do they have the right to break my devices after purchase? Do they not have an update rollback feature like every other electronic device in existence since 2000? I now have 4 useless hunks of plastic that cost me $100 with no recourse but to eat the money spent and say oh well! Also I now own an echo that does nothing more than let me know amazon is delivering another package now, thanks amazon!
title: Amazon broke them with an update months after my return deadline. Now they are useless.

author: Brian W
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2018
review_content: I've picked up a few other brands of smart outlets, and with those products, I had to install special apps (Tuya, Kasa, etc.) on my phone to configure the outlets and interface them with the Amazon Echo. This device, an Amazon product, obviously was made to work smoothly with Alexa devices. It took all of a minute to plug it in and add the device to the Alexa app's Devices page. Since I already use the Alexa app to control my Echo devices, I didn't have to install any additional apps. Setup instructions are provided on a tiny card shipped with the device, but really that's all the help you need to get it going. I'm using this to voice-control a 170 ft chain of outdoor Christmas lights, and so far it's been working great.
title: Easy to set up and use

author: SFey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2019
review_content: Well, what can I say, it does as advertised but is it necessary?  I bought 3 of these when they recently went on sale for $4.99.  Figured for that price it was worth giving them a try.  I didn’t really consider how I would use them at the time, more just excited at another Smart Home device.Did some research on what other people used theirs for and largely it came down to 3 functions...turn on window AC units, turn on table lamps, and turn on coffee makers.  Well, I have Central AC, overhead recessed lighting and my coffee maker can be programmed with a schedule so I was out of luck for this applications.  Well, the time of year does work as it turns out these are great plugs for timing Christmas lights and tree.  That is what I am currently using them for and for the most part they work great.I have had no issues setting routines.  I have some lights scheduled to come on at sunset and go off at 1am and then other routines for different times.  It all works perfectly, so no complaints.  Alexa integration has been seamless and I have had fun terrifying my kids by remotely turning on and off lights.End-of-the-day this device turns on an outlet in a smart manner you can control.  Any device that you plug into it that also needs it’s power button pressed in order to operate is really not going to work effectively with these plugs.  It is a simple, smart device....just keep your expectations realistic.
title: Smart, but Simple...Make sure you can use it before purchasing

author: L. L. Maron
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2019
review_content: This plug was included as a promotional when I bought an Echo Dot. I was pretty excited about being able to use it to turn my bedroom light off and on, but no matter what I do, I cannot get it connected. I have followed the instructions on the Alexa App on my laptop,phone, and through the Amazon Alexa site. I have tried to install it by reading the barcode, and manually without reading the barcode. My Echo can't "find" it. The two times the app said " plug found" and told me to "continue" it spent 20 minutes trying to connect to my WiFi and "failed". I have no clue what else to do. My laptop suggests I update the app, but when I follow the link it says the link does not exist. I had planned on buying  several plugs, but not now. At least this one was "free". They really need to update the Alexa Apps, especially the desktop version. It took me half a day to get my Echo and two dots set up. There is so much potential here. I hope they get the apps and peripherals straightened out.UPDATE - 04-04-2019: Kelly, from Alexa Support, contacted me concerning my problems with the plug. She was extremely pleasant and helpful, and spent several hours working with me on set-up. Since we could not get the plug connected to Alexa, she is sending me a new one and will call back after it arrives to help set it up. I still stand by my one star rating for the plug I have, but I would easily give Amazon Support a ten star review!UPDATE: 04-09-2019 After many more attempts at trying to set the plug up, it is finally working. My husband put the plug on an extension cord and held it within two inches of my phone. The app on my phone "found the plug" and prompted him to select setup. He did. It failed with the usual (-1:-1:-1:-1:) error code. He then selected "Try Again" and miracle of miracles - this time it found it and accepted our WiFi code. We are using the plug to turn our bedroom lights on and off and it is working flawlessly. I will also add that Amazon support regularly emailed me concerning the problem and requested I call them so their support tech could work with us. I asked my husband to call them, but he decided to give it one last try. Amazon provides great support.
title: Updated from "Nice Paperweight" to "Works Great"

author: Christopher Catherman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019
review_content: Super simple to use... Plugged it in, opened the Alexa app, go to add device & follow through it will say to scan the barcode on the instruction booklet, or you can open the app first & click add device & scan the barcode on the back of the smart plug then plug it in... Still simple... It setup WiFi & was working right away... I have a wemo & it was simpler then setting that up... IWinded up using it as a light because I needed one for it already had one wemo for my fan... So easy I really like it... Also I only paid $5.27 for it... You say ‘Alexa order smart plug’ & you checkout through Alexa & you get $20 off!!! Usually $25 but with this it’s $5!!!!!! What a steal!!!
title: Really like how simple & easy it is to use!!!

author: Baron
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2020
review_content: I wanted a smart plug so a light would go off when my camera picked up someone walking up my door.  It is impossible to use the plug that way.  You can only control the plug with your voice which is great if all you wanted to do is turn it on and off with your voice.  Unfortunately for me this is almost useless.The plug does not work with IFTTT nor does it work with amazon own routines. So if you wanted to say turn on the plug when your ring detected motion or rang the bell you can't do that even though both devices are amazon devices.Almost all the other smart plugs can work with IFTTT, be setup with amazon routine, or has their own system to be triggered by multiple devices.  So amazon plug is probably the worse plug to buy, it isnt even good for use in its own amazon garden.I started off giving this a 3 stars but after writing this down I wish I could give it less than one.  I honestly don't think there is a worse "smart" plug on the market.  I have three other plugs that work great.  I wish I bought one of those again instead of this piece of junk.
title: Pretty dumb for a smart plug.

author: Trevor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2019
review_content: Works exactly how you would expect. Love the added control, no more getting up to turn off the light when watching a movie.  Lots of great ways to use this in combination with Alexa.  The GPS feature allows your lights to turn on when you connect to your home wifi, no more coming into a dark home, also allows them to automatically shut off when you leave.Replaces any need for the older light timers peoe use when they go out of town or for xmas lights.There are times, maybe 5% of the time where they wont respond, normally just turn it off and on a d everything's back to normal
title: Great addition to your home automation set up

author: Jeff Hall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2018
review_content: This is the third day I have been trying to set up the Amazon Smart Plug. I was happy to get it because I already have one Kasa plug and it only took me 10 minutes to set it up, mostly because I had to download the Kasa app. Well, Amazon Smart Plug has an unknown problem connecting to my wifi. The app finds the plug as long as the red and blue lights are flashing, then it takes like five minutes trying to connect the plug to the wifi, only to come up with the message , "unknown failure". I have tried conncecting it manualy with the wifi password but the problem persist. In the future I will buy Kasa plug, I even like the design better and the fact that its light shows me it's conncected to the internet. For Amazon Smart Plug, I know that I will try a fifth time and if nothing works it will be returned.
title: Setting up the Amazon Smart Plug is not a walk in the park.

author: mrc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2020
review_content: The product works great. I bought on the premise I would get a $24 account once I hooked the device up through my Echo Show and verified it worked. How about it Amazon? I lived up to my end of the deal. Time for you to do the same.
title: Where is my rebate???

author: Mike B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2018
review_content: This is my second plug. I sent the first one back when, after a week or two, it stopped working. It was handy to have the light come on by voice command when I entered my house. The plug displayed a flashing red light, indicating it was not working. I tried a few dozen times to reconnect it, and failed. The Alexa app would sometimes display "Provisional Failure." I ordered the smart plug with two Echo Plus speakers and the subwoofer.After I connected the new devices, my old Echo (first generation) and older Echo Dot no longer would stay connected for more than about ten minutes, even after resets. I finally gave up on them. Additionally, my older fire tablets would not allow me to stream music, stating that there was no internet connection, even though non-music apps were able to connect normally. I gave up on them also, after hard resets and router restarts failed to correct the problem. After about a week, the new plug stopped working, with the flashing red light displayed. The instructions seemed a little different than the first plug, but I still could not successfully complete reconnection until I unplugged the new Echo Plus speakers and subwoofer. Whether it was coincidence or not, the new plug worked again. It seems possible that the new stereo subwoofer pair is causing conflicts. I don't know why I have these issues, and it has been frustrating and stressful instead of making life easier. Every time I request the Alexa app to turn on the light I have connected to the plug, I have a moment of anxiety that it will not work. If this keeps up, I will consider abandoning this whole smart home technology. I certainly have no incentive to delve deeper into it.
title: Handy device-when it works.

author: Ed K.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2018
review_content: I have three of these. Every few days one or another will be "non-responsive" (an Alexa term for "It stopped working"). The solution is to take several minutes and reinstall the plug. The plugs take turns - it's not my setup; it's the plug as they all do it (one stops but the other two continue on).In the best of times it's an annoying inconvenience. If the plug controls something that's needed immediately then it's worse than a simple inconvenience.Bottom line - Undependable!
title: Great.....when it works

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2018
review_content: It does everything you would expect it to do, turn off a switch and turn it back on. It does its job well, the only problem is, you have to use an Amazon product (The Echo, Alexa app) to control it. For example, I can't tell my google assistant or Siri to activate the plug.I know this doesn't seem like a big deal, but cross-platform accessibility to your devices becomes very important when you have multiple devices to connect to and interact with.
title: Obviously only works with amazon products

author: TPBayAMZN
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
review_content: I have several other smart plugs with no real issues. The TP Link plugs can be finicky once in a while, need firmware updates once in a while, and are VERY bulky (taking both outlets). The Smartthings outlets haven't had a single hiccup (once paired), but were expensive and also bulky (can't use second outlet). The Amazon plug worked with Alexa just like you'd expect an Apple peripheral to pair with an Apple product: Seamless. As soon as I plugged in the Amazon plug, I got a notification on my phone that Alexa detected, added, and named the plug. NO SETUP. I did go in to rename it and put it into a group later, but I was really impressed with the zero-setup. Bought another the next day and will surely replace the others when they grow old or malfunction. Great purchase, highly recommended.
title: Easiest Integration Ever

author: __barnett
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2019
review_content: The fact that these are wi-fi really limits the out-of-the-box integrations if you've built up a smart home with a hub. I wasn't careful enough when ordering this to realize I was purchasing a plug that wouldn't really interact with my smartthings hub.I use alexa products and just naturally gravitated towards the Amazon name. Unfortunately, the entire reason I wanted a plug was to use a smartthings automation that would allow me to chain on/off events from a sengled bulb (acting as a switch) to this plug. My girlfriend hates voice control lights, but with chained events, I can still leverage smart home controls to connect my living room switch to a handful of lights rather than one specific outlet. Now it's just a 'dumb' switch on a lamp that we continue to manually control.
title: Good Quality, Lower Integration

author: Son of a GV
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2019
review_content: Worked great at first. Had new Wi-Fi service installed And then plug would not work/not recognized by Alexa app, Amazon echo spot. My suggestion is to wait  until Amazon improves their system Or do not change your Wi-Fi as you will have to manually try to delete and re-add every device which is a nightmare. While troubleshooting, I found out that Amazon records your voice through the Alexa devices! You have to manually go in and delete your voice recordings so watch what you say if it pisses you off as it may be held against you. Smart  or do not change your Wi-Fi as you will have to manually try to delete and re-add every device which is a nightmare. While troubleshooting, I found out that Amazon records your voice through the Alexa devices! You have to manually go in and delete your voice recordings so watch what you say if it pisses you off as it may be held against you. Smart devices Devices have a drawback is they can be used for recording your likeness as with all new tech that will be using “IOT” (“Internet of things”).
title: Not worth the tech headache and invasion of privacy through Alexa device recording your voice.

author: Hannah Lomax
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Works well... for a while. Ordered in may 2020 and now in november 2020 it will not work. I have done all the troubleshooting and resetting I can it just wont work. And they are too pricey to replace 2 times a year
title: Good while it lasts

author: Elle Em
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
review_content: I had this in my shopping cart for a while. I’ve been on a crazy spending spree so I splurged and got this. It’s a very cool gadget. I plugged a lamp into it and have been having a lot of fun turning it on and off. I love this product, already. My only “complaints” are it’s pretty bulky, it’s a bit expensive and I had a hard time getting it to connect. I’m not completely technologically illiterate, but I had problems getting Alexa to find my new plug. I plugged it in and pressed the button until the red/blue lights flashed. After 20 mins of nothing I went to a different outlet. Another 15 minutes of being frustrated. I tried to “scan” the little reader but nothing worked. I tried different lighting and different positions and nothing worked. I tried to call amazon but their recording said due to virus they weren’t taking phone calls. In a last try, I once again pushed the little side button and magically it worked. After the Bluetooth worked it was smooth sailing and I’ve had a lot of fun using it. I love it so much I ordered Alexa light bulbs to try those out. Right now I just have a Kindle but considering getting the Echo to go with my new purchases. I just wish the plug was a little thinner and cheaper and it would be 5 stars!
title: Fun product

author: Randy W.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2019
review_content: Story 1:  The plug stopped working after 5 1/2 months. It stopped working a few weeks after the replacement time period. Don't buy this product. Story 2: Amazon reached out to me to see if they could get the plug working. I was appreciative of them making that effort. After working with two different technicians and receiving an exchange for new plugs, the smart plug started working. It worked for several weeks. The problem is getting the plug to work required a lot of technical gymnastics and time. However, the smart (dumb) plug stopped working again. DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT! THERE ARE TOO MANY PROBLEMS WITH IT.  I am out about $50 because I was fool enough to buy two of these things. I think the time for replacement was about 30 days. Good customer service would be to have me send these things back and to credit me (gift card?) for the cost. I have been with Amazon for over 20 years. This is the first time I have received a bad product. I am highly disappointed!
title: Stopped working

author: Stephen Sapp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2019
review_content: I really didn't need this gizmo but it was on sale so I bought it. I finally decided to use it in our kitchen where we charge our cell phones because I don't like to leave transformers plugged in to live outlets when not in use, and I got tired of unplugging the charger all the time. Now we leave it plugged in and just start the smart plug when we need it. [Edited: Kelly replied to my original critical review with a very polite and helpful response. Following her suggestions, I am able to rename the plug anything I want, and I learned that the best commands are "turn on/turn off," which do make sense. I'm leaving the rest of my original review to show why these changes are important: I think it is amazingly stupid that I can say, "Alexa, start first plug" (I assume that's because Amazon assumes I will have many of them, which means of course that I would have to remember the number of each one!), but I can't say, "Alexa, *stop* first plug"; instead, I have to say, "Alexa, *end* first plug," which is a very peculiar word to have to use for that function.
title: Happy with this product (after correspondence with Kelly in Customer Service)

author: Vincent
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2020
review_content: I have had several smart plugs over the last few years, some good, some not.  I got this one because it was on super-special Amazon deal and was worth having an extra one just in case.  What I learned from past smart plug purchases,  amperage capability is important.  If my tired eyes haven't deceived me this will accommodate an appliance up to 1500w,  about the electrical draw of most appliances like electronic tea kettles and the like.Currently my go-to smart plugs have been the Meross brand and have done well for over a year. I have to say that the Amazon smart plug is beefier than the the Meross, so I have every confidence in it, even though I haven't used it that much.  Setup is pretty typical using the Alexa app.When I ordered it, it was cheap, and like the proverbial box of chocolates, but so far it seems better than one that would cost me 3x as much.  But again, this was on super-special flash sale and I don't know what the retail price is, but would refer you to the Meross for price comparison.
title: I think it's going to be ok

author: Allison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2020
review_content: This smart plug works well.  But I have my Alexa in my kitchen, so this smart plus has to be used on something close by in the kitchen and I am finding that to be inconvenient.I have a lamp plugged into it (which I do not need to use in the kitchen); I can ask Alexa to turn on the “first plug” (my lamp) or I can use the Alexa app on my phone to turn it on.  It was easy to integrate and set up with Alexa.  A good use for this smart plus is some product that you need to turn on/off on demand without getting up out of the chair and walking across the room to hit the switch.  Or something that you want to turn on/off via your Alexa app while away from home—that you can’t simply use an ordinary timer switch for.  But since I have to use this in my kitchen in range of my Alexa, I feel limited.  I am disappointed that I can’t use it for my crockpot.  The problem is that when Alexa turns on the crockpot, the lights on the crockpot are initially flashing and you must then press buttons to select warm, low, or high in order for it to start cooking.  Unfortunately, Alexa can’t push buttons on my crockpot.  I can use this smart plug only with my much older model crockpot that has the rotary dial style of control.  I can set the rotary dial to low or high, and then when Alexa turns on the crockpot, it comes on to that setting and starts cooking.  Don’t need it for my coffeemaker—it has an automatic timer already built it.  So I have this cool smart plug, and am lacking for way to actually put it to use.
title: Works well.  Don’t like that it has to be in proximity of Alexa.

author: Gnemik
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2020
review_content: This smart plug is exactly as described and depicted in the product details. Very easy to setup, using the Alexa app and a barcode to identify the smart plug.
