Great aspect is this particular smart plug does not hog all the outlets.When activating, linking the plug into the Alexa network, I needed to press the button to get the plug into setup mode. Then, I went into Alexa to add the device to my account. That sequence went quickly and smoothly. You are then able to set up schedules, or turn the plug on/off via voice command or a toggle switch in the app. Of course you're also able to turn the plug on/off with the button on the plug.Must confess, recently started building my Alexa network with 3 echo dots and assorted plugs. So far, very impressed with the ease of setup and usage. Adding this Amazon brand smart plug looks unobtrusive, appearing somewhat plain, which is ideal for a smart plug. It is balanced, not heavy, and has the expected Amazon quality (well designed and constructed). The only downside is the cost. I am surprised that it's one plug for $25 (some companies offer 4 Alexa compliant plugs for $30, with some sale specials making the cost even less. If this plug had a mic included to accept vocal commands directly, it's be great. A speaker would be even more fantastic, but I understand that would make it a totally different product. Anyway, the plug can be controlled with the Alexa app or with activated echo dot 3 units I own.An aspect that may slip notice to many, but I think is critical: the 15A capacity. This is important if you're using any device that draws significant power. Many of the other smart plugs have a 10A capacity, which is fine for lamps, but is a huge difference compared to this smart plug. This difference is probably a significant factor in the cost. My thought is better to have a higher Amp rating, to provide 'buffer' room.Overall, I love this smart plug. Want more! That's a definite endorsement.High, high recommendation for this smart plug.
title: Exactly as described and depicted. Perfectly sized to not hog both outlets.

author: D. Morrison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2019
review_content: Yow. This was way harder to configure than it should have been. I'm setting it up to use for something at my place of work, which has some network security stuff. Two things made it really hard:1) I needed the MAC address. It is printed on the box and on the device, but is REALLY tiny. But making matters even worse, it's in a font that makes it near impossible to distinguish the letter 'B' from the digit '8', a disaster for hex stuff like MAC addresses. Made far worse by the minisucle size, and, extra stupidly, printing it as gray instead of black! Three things would make it better: make it bigger, make it black, and, most important, use lower case letters.2) It comes with no instructions, and the the Alexa app never suggests that may you need to go down deep and do fancy configuration. It just says presents you with the plug and encourages you to turn it on and off. But when you do, it says "device unresponsive." Eventually I discovered I had to dive down deeper and push a mysterious '+' sign in the app which let me configure the network to use. They really, really, really need to be up front with how the heck to say what network to be on.
title: Hard to configure for all but the simplest networks

author: David J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2019
review_content: Not much to say, I was happy with how easy it was to set up and so far it has worked perfectly. The plugs location is relatively far from my wireless router so I was concerned about signal strength, but it seems to have plenty. I always feel awkward making a review with something that I haven't had long, so one caveat with this product is that I have only been using it for a little over a month now, but all seems fine. I use the plug to control a fan. On a side note, before I ordered the plug I made sure that it would work with the fan. I turned the fan on and then unplugged the fan, it turned off (obviously) and when I plugged it back in, it turned on, so that meant it would work with the plug. For example, I have another fan that uses electronic controls, so I can turn that fan on and then unplug it and then when I plug it back in, it would be off and I would need to turn it on again, so that type of fan would not work with this plug. And of course that would be the same thing with any item you want to use the plug for, so just check prior to ordering it.
title: Works good. Check to make sure it will work with equipment prior to ordering.

author: A Jones
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2020
review_content: I've only used this for a couple of weeks now for my coffee maker. I leave the power switch on my coffee maker in the 'on' position with the plug set to 'off.' It was paired with my Amazon account when shipped so when I plugged it in, the app on my phone prompted me to finish setting it up, which wasn't hard at all. I will say that setting up the 'routines' was a bit much. I had to set up two separate routines- one to turn it on at a certain time during the week and one to turn it off at a certain time. Overall, it's a big help as I am always running behind and before this, I had some days when I didn't have time to make my coffee. I prep my coffee at night and now it starts brewing a few minutes before I get up and I have it set to turn off before I leave my house. Even without setting a 'routine' you can use the app to turn it on and off. I believe you can also turn it on and off using Echo devices but I haven't tried it yet. Got it for a really good promotional price also so I'm happy with it.
title: Great for my coffee maker

author: Bmcgnh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
review_content: This is *PERFECT* for my wife's Christmas trees. She sets up three--and each year we have purchased the remote controlled 3-pack from Lowes...that lasts one year and then the remote gets lost or out of synch, etc.This is great. I have already installed this first block outlet and I named the outlet Family Room Tree (there's a small table lamp plugged in their now) but this means no more trying to find the remote (was it in the Living Room last time?) or trying to recall if the Family Rooms Tree is button 1? Or is that the hallway?AND--we can easily set up a schedule to turn on the downstairs trees at dusk and the upstairs trees closer to bed time, have them on all day while we are home, auto-off when we are out, etc. etc.Great application. I hope they make some outdoor blocks for our exterior lights. That would be kind of neat too. I'd love to be able to control the lights on the lanai from inside--and have them auto-turn off at 2300 if we forget about them.
title: Easy to setup and use

author: Irene Abreu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
review_content: ****Update**** So one day I had to change my wi-fi password for security and the plug stopped working completely. After an hour on the phone with Amazon tech support we could not get it to work. Amazon sent a replacement but while on transit, I kept trying to figure out the issue and after a day of tinkering with it, I realized that my router had blocked the smart plug because for some reason my Xfinity modem reads it as if it was a kindle. This is why I never realized it got blocked. I assumed that someone else with a kindle had tried to connect to my network...So I got one of these plugs on black Friday sale and now I regret not buying more!I have been  contemplating whether to get some of these for several rooms of my home and Amazon had an amazing deal for those ordering with voice commands via Alexa so I figured why not give it a try. Now I seriously wish I would have bought more of these.Set up was super easy. Basically plug and done. No additional apps to download. It all syncs with your existing Alexa app and voila! "Alexa turn on/off lights". I will definitely hunt for another sale and get me some more.
title: I wish I had bought more!

author: Zero
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
review_content: Voice control is finally easy!  I'm a home automation nut starting from the X-10 days to my current Openhab setup.  I've purchased and installed a wide variety of devices from name brand to Chinese clones of ESP8266 boxes and this has been the only time I've ever been impressed with the installation.  Granted, amazon knows my wifi passwords and alexa account so it wasn't hard for them to make this work out of the box but I'm glad they did.  Yay! I benefit for once from all that information on me existing in the ether.I have Openhab integrated with Smart Things and some Sonoff devices running all kinds of things in my house.  Visitors are always asking "How can I do this at my house?" and get all "Zzzzzz..." and foggy looking when I mention programming a raspberry pi and setting up an MQTT broker.  They typically walk away before I get into reprogramming the ESP8266 and making custom wall plates.  I use Fire HD10 tablets in every room for local dashboards and IP Camera displays.  It's a lot of work and I'll never be able to sell this house.The next time someone asks me how I turned on the back yard lights with Alexa I'll tell them they can do it too with the amazon Smart plug.I didn't have to do anything at all to use this except plug it in.  I renamed it from first plug and that's it!  Pretty neat.Way to go amazon!
title: The easiest plug I've used so far

author: curiositykeeper
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
review_content: After spending a half hour trying to get the stupid thing to work, I finally gave up. It feels like the directions are incomplete. Yes, my iPhone can see the device, so I can turn it on and off from my phone. Why on earth would I want to use my phone to turn the lights off? I wanted to be able to say "Alexia, nightlight on" but I just can't get it to work. It feels like the software was designed by a committee, with everything in the world added on there and it ending up going in circles. Alexia doesn't see the device, she says to enable smart home, I click it, it shows me a list of new apps with no explanation. I've created a routine, a group, restarted, unplugged. Why on earth aren't there directions for setting up voice command? What do they think people buy these for anyway? And why can't I use my laptop to set this up instead of the phone? UPDATE a couple of hours after posting this review, someone from Amazon called me and  fixed it. Alexia needed to switch accounts, which is not visible to me. The rep was very helpful and it works now!
title: Couldn't get it to work until Amazon contacted me

author: citadel1980
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2020
review_content: Please hit the HELPFUL button if this provided you with information that helped your buying decision.I got mine for $1 through a promo code from my insurance company and love it.  Not too sure I would pay the full $25 for it…ummm, actually I KNOW I would not.  Love it; just not the price.This is not complicated.  It turns things on and off and that is great when you are in bed and see a light on from downstairs (kids STILL cannot turn off a light) and you simply tell Alexa to turn it off.  That alone is worth the price!  LOLInstallation was ridiculously easy as Alexa finds it and sets it up in no time.  You can either use the manual button to connect it to your Alexa app on your phone, or you can scan the code to do the same.The only negative is the size…this bugger is large for what it does and I would have LOVED it if it had a thinner profile so it would be less visible.  Other than that, it is a great little device.
title: Easy setup and easy to use-but pricey!

author: c g
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2020
review_content: I had NO issues with getting this connected - I do have an Alexa Echo and an Alexa Flex in another room so I don't have to YELL into another room lol - I plugged in the Amazon smart plug - went to my Alexa app - went to devices - then the 3 little lines in left corner and hit Add Device - gave permission and then it asked me to scan the code (by the way - the code is on the back of the plug BUT its also on the little pamphlet that comes with the plug) and that was pretty much it - OH it did ask you to name it I just chose Dining Room Plug just randomly I can remember that - One thing though if you have never had one of these smart items its a little scary and strange at the same time LOL - I plugged in just a random light because I wasn't sure what item I was going to use and asked  "Alexa - turn on the DINING ROOM PLUG" and THE LIGHT CAME ON - little spooky lol - then asked to turn off and again spooky - still getting used to it - =) But that was pretty much it - I have never had any issues with an Alexa products! Not sure I would pay $25 for each one but I did see that Amazon sells 4 for around $20 from Amysen? something like that - so I might try those unless Amazon comes out with their own reasonable 4 pack - This was a great deal and find to actually test it out to see if I they would come in handy =) My Mom on the other hand got one too and we were never able to get it working - she lives in another state - now she does have an Iphone???? Could that be the problem? Her phone would never get to the "scan" screen - so I gave up after hours of trying to help. BUT I love mine! =)
title: EASY PEASY!

author: Ryan M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2019
review_content: I own about four different brands of smart plugs and was looking forward to "standardizing" once Amazon released their own. Unfortunately, the Amazon smart plugs work more slowly and less consistently than the other plugs I own, and have had many more problems w/r/t connectivity and pairing on a home network made of enterprise-grade equipment.At a basic level, the Amazon Smart Plugs appear to need to send traffic back and forth to an Amazon server to connect with a phone and the Echo, based on their pairing process and the sheer amount of delay between commands being received and executed. What's worse is that a single plug can't be paired to more than one phone for use in the Alexa app, so if you want multiple people to be able to modify routines etc., you're out of luck. Whoever the first person is to set it up will be responsible for that plug, forever.This is in stark contrast to the other smart plugs I own, which all work over local wireless, and pretty flawlessly - once they're paired up to an Echo and their respective skills are downloaded, they stay paired. The WeMo plugs have easily performed the best of the ones we've tried, and have the cleanest-looking app.If an Amazon plug gets un-paired, for whatever reason - issues staying connected to local wireless, in my case, where other plugs had no such issues - good luck getting it to work without factory resetting it. You won't be able to just unplug it and plug it back in, like another plug - no, because of Amazon's pairing process, it will need to be completely set up again. The Amazon Smart Plug changes its name to "First Plug," Second Plug," etc. based on how many plugs you have paired and what order they're connected. Guess how many "First Plugs" I have?Apologies for not writing a more comprehensive review, but my end point is this: these things are fundamentally bad on a basic level, because Amazon can't let them just sync locally like a regular plug, and that leads to issues. I'll still be standardizing my smart plugs, but I'll be sticking with WeMo, and I suggest you stick with whatever non-Amazon brand you've likely already started with.
title: Worse than WeMo (and most other plugs)

author: T. Mayer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2019
review_content: We need a circulation pump for our hot water tank.  From the bathroom it can take up to 10 minuets with running the pump.  I had used a timer in the past and also a remote wireless turn on turn off switch.  The problem was never knowing when to have the timer turn the pump on.  With the remote switch you still  had to find the remote to turn it on and you had to remember to turn it off.  I was able to program the plug with the Alexa app to turn the pump on just before I needed hot water ( three minuets later) the pump circulate the water and I am ready to go.  I programmed the app to keep the pump on for 10 minuets so I don't have to worry about some one remembering to turn it off.  You don't have to worry about finding the remote.  Unless the unit fails because the hot water heater is in a closet that can get up to 120 degrees I can say anything bad about it.  All I had to do was plug it in and the app found it as if it was always there.  The app was a little odd to program because the steps did not get entered in the order I put them.  I found that I could use my finger with the app to move the step order so all worked out in the end.  I would get another one  but don't know where I would use it at this time.  May be as a spare?
title: Easy to set up and works great.

author: Keilly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2020
review_content: I got this because there was a deal where I would just pay 99 cents for it! When it arrived all I had to do was plug it in and it was automatically connected. I went in my Alexa app and easily changed the name. We decided to use it to power our cat’s water fountain because it’s such a pain to reach around the back and look for the tiny switch, splashing water around and unplugging it in the process everytime they want to drink water. We also don’t want to keep it on all the time because of energy usage and because the motor is so loud. They’re not drinking water all day either but when they do, theyll only drink from the fountain and they will definitely make a fuss when they’re thirsty! We now just keep the water fountain switch on, and anytime I see them sitting in front of it from across the house, I can just tell Alexa to turn on the water fountain instead of walking over there! What a life saved! We feel super high tech. We don’t have many other appliances where this plug could apply to, but I look forward to applying it to other uses!
title: Super easy setup, makes life easier

author: C. Anderson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2019
review_content: When this plug works, it's great. We use it instead of a timer to turn on a light in our house using an Alexa routine. We were sad to realize that when you have the plug bundled in a routine with other actions, it does not function consistently. From what we found online, it appears to be an issue with Alexa and not necessarily the plug. However, since both products are produced by Amazon, I would expect seamless integration. Thus, I removed 1 star. The other issue we recently experienced was when we had a brief drop in our wifi connection. The smart plug would not automatically reconnect until we unplugged it and plugged it back in. This resulted in the "security light" being on all night. I would have expected some sort of "reconnect" feature. And if it already contains one, it doesn't work as expected. Again, minus 1 star. I have bought a few more before we noticed these issues and intended to use them in a vacation property we have but I don't know that I can trust them not to turn on what we have plugged into them or worse, leave them on constantly until we return for vacation.
title: Works with a couple of exceptions

author: icedcap
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2020
review_content: I plugged my TV into this plug.  Now I can listen to the news at bedtime and when I am ready to go to sleep I just tell Alexa to turn off the TV plug. It turns it on, too.  I don't have to use the remote unless I want to change the channel or mute the TV.  I don't have to reach for a remote that I end up dropping on the floor most of the time at night.  I love my Smart Plug.  It works every time.  I have had no problems with it. I would recommend it to others.
title: Plugged My TV into the Smart Plug

author: D. Williams
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2020
review_content: I ordered two Amazon smart plugs and was not able to have them connect to Alexa after trying multiple times on my own and with the help of an Amazon representative.  So, I had to send them back.  Both plugs came to me in one package, but in order to get the full refund, I had to send both of them back in separate containers.  I had to pay $2.06 for the second package which was not reimbursed.  So, in the end, I got nothing from this transaction except the opportunity to pay $2.06 for nothing gained and a couple hours wasted.  I was told that these smart plugs may or may not work depending on characteristics of the home's  WiFi.  If the smart plugs are to work, they have to be matched to the characteristics of the home's WiFi.  If not, they won't work.  So, how is the consumer to know this and use this information to get the right smart plug?  Because of this type of complication, I would recommend no one buy them.  If you do, proceed at your own risk.
title: A waste of my time

author: Michael J. Irise
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020
review_content: I like the idea that Amazon/Alexa is making life a lot easier the older I get! We purchased the smart plug as an addition to a Echo+ 2G. Everything went as smooth as silk! I was able to have Alexa turn on the light after following the instructions but later that night before retiring I couldn't shut it off with voice command. Next morning I did some troubleshooting and found that the well built cabinet that was directly in front of the plug controlling the light had lost connection and was displaying red. After maneuvering the cabinet around and away from the plug it was able to maintain the signal. Sometime during the day my wife slid the cabinet back close to the wall and when I went to turn it on, unable to connect. Evidently these plugs need room to maintain signal because as soon as I moved it away the signal returned. Just be aware of this when planning your application and make sure you have a strong wifi signal. Otherwise, I love the concept!!
title: Nice Idea but!!

author: D. Dion
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2020
review_content: Try as I may, it was impossible to pair this gizmo with my Alexa, by using alexa.amazon.com.I tried many many times. It just wouldn't 'discover' it.BUT, here's the kicker that isn't written anywhere in the flimsy manual: If you PRESS AND HOLD the power button it actually goes into DISCOVERY MODE!I bet you i would have been able to pair it, without the Alexa App....But no, I did install the Alexa app, and only then did it mention to put the Smart Plug in discovery mode.....Anyway. It works great. Easy to configure and operate via the Alexa app on your phone....You can also easily create "Routines" to turn it on or off at specific times and/or sunrise/sunset, etc.Love it. I'd love to buy more of these, if only they were at a more reasonable price.Bought this one for 99 cents during a Thanksgiving promo. But regular price of ~$25. Hell no.Reasonable price would be around $10. No more.
title: Works great.... as long as you install the Alexa app on your phone....

author: MGB2
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2020
review_content: Very simple device to set up, which is what Amazon was going for with their smart devices.  Not that complex setups are a problem when you have an IT and Engineering background, but not everyone has that.How easy is it to set up really?You simply plug it in, Alexa finds it within seconds, then let's you know your new plug is ready for use;. You don't have to play with WiFi settings, or anything else. You can rename it in the Alexa app if you wish, but it's not necessary.I've had several different smart plugs such as WeMo, and bulbs from Philips, and others, but all of them have required either setup with their own apps, and manual WiFi setup to get them on your network. Not that these other devices are difficult to set up really, but can be confusing, or at the very least annoying for some.Overall I recommend this product to anyone with an Echo device. You simply can't get another smart plug that integrates easier with your Alexa enabled devices than this. Amazon did an amazing job with this one.
title: Easy as 123!

author: Kyle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2018
review_content: Easiest setup ever. Was literally connected through the Alexa app in less than 20 seconds and it works like a charm.I chose to start buying these smart plugs because I feel that it’ll really help conserve even more energy. You can easily turn these off from anywhere, even when you’re not home, so if you forget to turn off a light, tv, etc that’s connected to this plug you really have nothing to worry about.These plugs also serve as a great security feature. When you’re away from home you can easily turn your lights on and off to make it look like someone is inside the house.A more harsh, but still very real and possible scenario: You’re asleep upstairs and you know for a fact there’s someone in your house that just broke in downstairs. Chances are that the ability for you to turn on a light or TV from your phone while you’re still in bed should be enough to scare off the intruder.There’s so many practical uses for these smart plugs. You just have to get one for yourself so you can see how useful it really is. I waited way too long to get one of these, but I’m really glad I did.Combine an Echo with a smart plug and you’ll have a truly great experience.
title: Great Investment! Cheap Home Security & Energy Saver

author: Lady in Jax
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2019
review_content: Worked fine for 2 months and Alexa decided not to find my plug anymore this morning, so I tried a bunch of troubleshooting fixes to no avail.  I got another plug that was unopened, so I tried that one, too.  Alexa can't find it, either.  The app  on my phone finds both alright, but they could not seem to connect to either of my wifi routers. Then when they did finally connect, Alexa couldn't find them, even when on the same network.  Upon reading various blogs, this seems to be a common issue with plugs or devices coming in and out and sporadically not working. I am not wasting any more of my life trying to figure this out. I would get different errors such as 1-3-1-1, and error 2-1-0-3 on the phone app when trying to reset them. I am sending both of them back and using my good old fashioned fingers and light switch to turn the light on and off.  Alexa also decided to lose my reminders that I had coming up, so I missed an important bid in eBay. Such unreliable garbage!
title: Unreliable Garbage!

author: Joyce and Carl Roberts
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2019
review_content: At present we have 19 smart plugs in our home and all are controlled through Alexa.  We only have one of these Amazon Smart Plugs and purchased ours in October of 2018 for $24.99.  We bought this brand for the ease of setting up an Amazon plug with Amazon Alexa and in this regard it gets high marks.  The reason for three stars is its large size.  We originally wanted to use it in a floor outlet but the plug's large side-to-side size prevented it from working for this purpose.  We were hard-pressed to find a location where this would work for our needs as the width of this model often interfered with either furniture or other plugs needing to share the same outlet. We eventually found a use for it in a garage power strip that had plenty of real estate to spare.  We have found both the Gosund and TanTan round design smart plugs, also purchased here on Amazon, to offer more flexibility due to their smaller footprint.  We also found these others brands to be better values when we made our purchases.  All of the smart plugs we have purchased are touted to work with Alexa, they all have without exception, and were all relatively easy to set up.
title: It's very wide

author: M Overton
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2019
review_content: So we own 4 of these now.  We have a multiple people in our house.  My wife and I both have accounts connected through the Amazon/Alexa Household.  I set up our first plug (on my phone/account) and my wife set up the other 3 on hers.  We can’t see the Amazon plugs the other set up on their account, yet all of the other devices connected to the Echo (or Alexa Household) are visible by both of us).  This really limits the user friendly-ness of these plugs.  You can’t even use a workaround by adding the plugs to more than one Alexa account as the other account then gets disconnected.So with these challenges, I figured hey, I’ll just add them to my SmartThings hub... well wrong again.  They are not controllable directly with SmartThings (at lest not yet).I prefer Z-wave devices, but given the sale price of these plugs, I thought I’d give them a try.  I will not be buying any more unless these two issue are addressed.
title: Limited household functionality

author: William Dempsey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2020
review_content: I bought this 8/29 because of a Amazon special offer.  The cost was $24.99 with a credit of $24.00 after activated. I have it working and on the Alexa app like I was advised after several chats with Amazon being transferred from one person to the next all asking the same questions I finally gave up.  And will be returning the plug.
title: The special offer was not honored

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2020
review_content: I have purchased three of these. Only one of them is still working.  All three were working fine for about a year. Then they simply stopped. No other changes were made in the house. They just didn’t work anymore. I tried several times to set them up on different outlets thinking the outlet was a problem, but it wasn’t. The bottom line is if they don’t last.
title: Unreliable

author: Brent S
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2020
review_content: I ordered the Amazon Smart Plug during the Prime Monday sale.  Approximately two weeks after I started using this plug, it quit working.  I contacted Amazon and I was shipped a replacement Amazon Smart Plug.  I use this smart plug for my Christmas tree lights.  After three weeks of use, my second Amazon Smart Plug apparently reset itself.  Consequently, I had to perform another setup in the Amazon App.  I’ve had two Amazon Smart Plugs within the last three months, and both have had issues.  While it works fine at this time, I didn’t expect to have issues with two different Amazon Smart Plugs within three months.  This shouldn’t happen.  I have several smart devices in my house, including 11 Alexa devices, 23 Phillips Hue lights, three Ring cameras, one MyQ garage opener, one Rain Machine smart irrigation system, a Smart Things hub, and four Z-Wave light switches and plugs.  I’ve not had issues with my other smart devices.
title: Inconsistant connection

author: James Lang
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2018
review_content: I've setup 3 of these plugs in my office, 2 powering lights and one a fan.  Now when I walk into the room in the morning I just say "Alexa, turn office on" and things are ready to go!  I did have to add them to a "group" but that was painless in the app.All in all, a fantastic addition that has me considering using them elsewhere.  I'd really love a light switch that Alexa could over-ride.  "Alexa, turn on outside" or even "Alexa, turn on outside at dusk" (which would rule! but isn't possible today I don't think.
title: Great little addition to my office

author: jamo002
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2020
review_content: Maybe I bought used plugs this time but I just don't remember doing that. These came package in just bubble wrap with a simple little card with instructions. The card said scan the QR code on the back of this card but there was no code there it was quite a hassle to get these to connect I like the first ones I ordered which connected instantaneously. One of them connected but no electricity would flow through to anything that was plugged in. Yes, the blue light comes on and off when I ask Alexa turn the light on but I've tried several different things plugged into it and no electricity comes through I'm returning that one and keeping the other two. These or great plugs the last time I bought them but you should pay the 2495 and get the brand new ones and Amazon will also make them reading to connect to your Alexa (S) before they ship them. Don't try to cut corners and save money or you're going to be frustrated like I was oh, and I was frustrated!
title: Not the same as the Amazon Smart plugs I bought the first time

author: Just a guy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2019
review_content: Got this, on sale, for the sole purpose of having an automated means of turning on the Christmas Tree Lights.My parents had me to do this for them and I, despite having kids of my own, decided to use technology.  This, combined with outlet location, tree placement, and ornaments getting knocked off the tree made for a quick easy set up that the wife/kids could simply state, "Alexa, Turn on the Tree".  This also prevented my children from doing the stupid things I did such as hold the plug-prongs while 'searching' for the outlet holes...  Yes, I was got shocked a few times. Yes, I knocked over a tree or two.  No, I am not completely sure there were no long-lasting effects.Set up was easy and had no issues with lost signal (Wireless signal strength is strong in the locations that I've used these).  Instructions were easy to follow as was pairing with my Echo devices.There is an audible 'click' in the device when triggered on/off.Overall very pleased with these and am only wondering what I want to use them with until next Christmas.
title: Better than kids at turning on/off the Christmas Tree

author: Scott R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2019
review_content: Got this to control some new under-cupboard lights for the kitchen.  The reason I gave it four stars instead of five is because you must set it up on an open 2.4 GHz network.  After disabling my MAC filtering, I was able to set it up without issue.  Living in an apartment complex, network security is a large concern of mine and having my wireless open for ANY amount of time is not something I care to do.  Once connected, I was able to get the address from my router, enter it in my MAC filter list, and re-enable security.  I can now set a schedule for when the lights will turn on and off and when I want, turn them off/on by voice via the Echo or my cellphone.Amazon, if you read this - record the MAC address of the unit somewhere in the documentation so the owner doesn't have to open up their network to security concerns!!Edit 2019-04-18It quit connecting to my network hence the 2-star reduction.  My network has a wireless input filter that only allows specific MAC addresses access.  When a manufacturer does not provide the MAC address, I have to open my network up, allow the new device to connect so I can find the new address, add the new address to the authorized list, restart the router and hope things connect back up.  I had to do this again for a new piece of equipment and now the plug refuses to connect.  Customer Service has been minimally helpful.  Pretty frustrating.
title: You must set it up on an open 2.4 GHz network

author: Jaxsen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2020
review_content: I actually love the plug and then again I dont cuz if you dont have Alexa in the same room you have to yell at her to get her to hear you...now mind you my apartment isnt that big, so you'd think she could hear a mouse fart but no... I dont like coming home to an unlit place so that's why Alexa and the plug i thought were perfect but if i have to scream into my place to get her to turn on the light, i can just flip the switch...the plug will be moved to a new location that doesnt strain Alexa's delicate sensibilities of doing actual work
title: Alexa and the plug have to be in the same room

author: Home. On. A. Hilltop
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2020
review_content: So glad I picked this up as a Deal of the Day, I wouldn’t have purchased it otherwise, but it’s great. It was incredibly easy to set up the app, very intuitive.  I am using this with an early generation Dot.  Currently, I have our Christmas tree plugged into the Smart Plug and have it set to turn the tree lights on and off at specific times but I also love that if I want to turn the lights on at a different time than the established schedule, I can just ask Alexa to turn on Plug 1.  Even with the earlier voice command to turn on, it will still revert back to the schedule when it’s time to turn off.Most of us are creatures of habit, so it is easy to schedule things with the Smart Plug, whatever your needs may be. Once we can all return to taking vacations, this would be useful to have lights turn on/off at the house while away, even making schedule adjustments on the go, through the app, if needed.It’s great to have the option of scheduling events or using voice command in the the moment. This would make a great gift for those who own Amazon devices. Just check model for compatibility.
title: Handy and easy to use

author: Fenway1
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2020
review_content: I never NEEDED a Smart Plug. I just wanted one. Big difference. I tried one (from one of the HUGE home improvement stores) with a different brand name. Leviton I believe. For some reason this wasn't compatible with my network. So I decided on the Amazon brand plug. Lucked out with a great promo and picked it up for $7 and change. Wanted it for a bedroom lamp. I also have an Amazon Echo 8 which I love. Literally from the time I took it out of the box to the time I was saying "Alexa...turn on my lamp" and "Alexa turn off my lamp", no more than 2 minutes had elapsed. By default, Alexa assigns it the name of "Plug 1" which you can change very easy to whatever you'd like. While I never NEEDED this plug, I'm so glad I decided I WANTED one. Others may be equally as great but with those you often have to work with a separate APP and then sync that with the Alexa APP. With the Amazon plug you only have to worry about the Alexa APP which I already had on my phone. If you give this a shot, you will NOT be sorry.
title: Great! Great! Great!

author: Darla Popmarkoff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2018
review_content: I simply want to set up an on and off time for the plug for my Christmas tree.  I do not have a smart home or other devices I want to be on the same schedule as this plug.  I simply want to schedule my Christmas tree.  I can see the plug and do it manually with my iphone.  I bought the plug so it would turn on and off with a schedule.  I can manually activate this outlet with a wall switch for this single outlet.  Therefore, the plug is not helpful without a schedule, which I have tried to setup without success.  Can someone please send me clear instructions???
title: Instructions to set a schedule are not clear

author: GadgetGuy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2018
review_content: The product is great. It does the job. But be ready for a challenge if you have an Orbi mesh network.During the setup, the plug shows up right away, it finds your network, and that’s pretty much it. If you have an Orbi, the chances that it will not connect are high. The issue appears to be to the fact that amazon smart plug can’t just choose to connect to 2.4 GHz. It tries to connect to the 5 GHz. I have over 12 devices at home. And they all connect to the network they are compatible too. Not this one.After a lot of research, I learned that if I change the 2.4 network to a fixed channel, I had a better chance. After I did that, I had no issues. I was up and running in less than a minute.But how many users will have the knowledge (and the courage) to change an Orbi configuration?  Most people are used to plug and play.I took away one star because of this challlenge. I was going to take away two stars, but I like the fact that it worked so much that I already forgot the fact that I wasted 45 minutes trying to configure a plug and play device.I confess that I was ready to return it and purchasing a device that is compatible to both networks out of the box.
title: Very challenging with Mesh network (Orbi)

author: Jeremy M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2019
review_content: I have 3 of these amazon smart plugs. I love them and hate them at the same time. The part I like is that they are easy to set up and when they work they work very well.... however, they problem lies at "when they work". At least 4-5 times a week I have to manually turn them on or off to get them to start working again. You ask alexa to turn one of them on and (like I said 4-5 times a week) Alexa will tell you that they are "not responding please check their internet connection". This can be frustrating when your stuck on a ladder or have your hands full and you have to stop to go turn them on. And I know what some of you may be thinking... We had to turn them off and on ourselves in the past. Your right, but the whole point of these plugs is so that you dont. If you have to turn it one manually it defeats their purpose. So they are nice but be prepared to have to reset them on a simi-regular basis.
title: Must reset plug 4-5 times weekly

author: Luke Woodruff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2019
review_content: I have several smart plugs and got recently got one of these amazon smart plugs for christmas and the thing constantly disconnects (red light on plug) and i have to unplug it from the wall and plug it back in for it to work again. I have yet for it to last more that 24 hours before needing to be unplugged and plugged back in. Needless to say this makes in nearly useless. I'm not sure why it does this on my network, i saw posts saying once people set the plugs ip address to static that this stopped happening but that is an absolutely ridiculous thing to have to do when the other plugs i own that are half or 1/3rd the price rarely if ever have issues.
title: Constantly disconnects

author: DTB
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2019
review_content: These plugs evidently work well for some, not well at all for others.  I found the setup process incredibly frustrating.  After spending way more time than it should have taken I finally made a connection.  That lasted for about two weeks.  trying to reset the plug was even more frustrating than the initial setup.  Barcode scanning did not work at all.  I finally got it connected to wifi, but the plug would not respond to alexa commands.  By this time I was just randomly trying stuff to get it connected and responding.  I finally succeeded.  That lasted about a month.  Until yesterday, when it all stopped working yet again.  If you want to take a chance and try connecting this plug so you can amuse your friends by turning your lights on and off with your voice, go for it.  It might work a time or two.  If you are depending on it working regularly I'd advise just continuing with whatever is working for you now, and giving Amazon another year or so to work out the bugs, or just give up on it altogether.Update: Just a few minutes after I posted this review I got a call from Amazon offering help in getting things working again.  I declined, since I have decided to give up on getting this to work consistently.  I thought it fair to point out the quick response and my hope that they will be able to assist those more resilient than I.
title: Not worth taking a chance

author: Mack R
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2019
review_content: I have many "Smart" devices around the house that can be controlled with Alexa and other apps. These are very easy to get used to and you start to "miss" devices which don't have those features. With these regularly going on sale for as little as 5 bucks, I decided to give it a shot.As soon as I plugged it into the wall and went in my alexa app, it had already detected and set it up. I just had to give it a name.I plugged this into a fan, called it "Fan" and immediately was able to say "Alexa, Turn  on the fan" (or "Off") and it worked perfectly!The thing to remember is that the device needs to have a physical switch for it to work properly. My Air Conditioner uses a digital switch to turn it on/off, so this Alexa Switch will not work with it. My coffee maker and fan have an On and Off switch. I could plug my coffee maker into this, turn it to the "On" position and then use the Alexa Switch to turn it on/off (basically cutting power to it and plugging it back in). This would let me load a coffee machine the night before, wake up and say "Alexa, Turn on the coffee machine" and have it automatically begin. A Light (with an on/off switch) is another great use here.
title: Great plug (for the right price) if you understand how it works!

author: Nick D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2019
review_content: After buying 2 different "other" brands of smart plug, wrestling with their apps and still not succeeding in setup, I returned them both and submitted to the highway robbery price of the amazon branded one.  It's almost worth 25$ per plug.  Incredibly easy set up, the alexa app instantly recognizes each new plug, and you can use alexa to name it or rename it within a minute of receipt of the package. No charge time. The only downside, other than the price, is that it's only an on/off switch- it can't do anything more complicated. When they are >10$ each, I will be ecstatic with them.
title: easy to set up, don't even need instructions

author: Miguel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
review_content: For starters, I didnt even buy this device, my sister did with her own account. Not sure why Amazon is asking me to review it, aside from living in the same household.That aside, it works as expected for a smart plug. Its fast to set up with Alexa, works like youd expect it to. The only problem, and a big problem for me here, is that it only responds to one Amazon account. So for example if you have two or more Amazon accounts in your household (like a roomate has their own), you can only set it up to respond to one account. If you switch accounts on your Echo, it will act like the plug doesnt exist. And you cant set it up on both accounts.  Ive got a TP Link smart plug that works just fine with multiple accounts, so Im not sure why Amazons own device wont?
title: Not so great if you have multiple Amazon accounts in your household

author: Sam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2020
review_content: Hands down this is my most favorite purchase of 2020. I did get it during prime day at a more discounted price and I am so glad I did! I have many smart plugs at home and my office that use both alexa echo dot and google home mini. I find the Amazon smart plug to be more intuitive, easy to set up and overall a better experience. It was super easy to set up with my alexa echo dot. I have it power on my power extender which then turns on my monitor, stand up, desk and desk light. It allows me to turn off the extension cord to all my electronics without having to go down underneath my desk at the end of use.I can see it would be worth $24.99 if I only needed one, but I find myself needing multiples and I cannot justify $24.99 for each plug, which is why I use the amazon smart plug for my main "electronics hub" and a cheaper smart plug alternative for everything else. Get it!
title: Best wifi plug to connect with alexa devices

author: Julie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2020
review_content: Around Christmas time, I bought a bunch of plugs to make all of our lighting easier. Most of the plugs I have are the GoSund off-brand, which are 4 for $25. They require downloading an additional app for initial setup, but they have worked flawlessley for almost 8 months, without ever having a hitch. Separately, I bought a couple of these Amazon plugs at 1 for 25 (significantly higher) thinking that it would be the better product.At this point, I have most lights in my house set up on this variation of plugs. WITHOUT FAIL this stupid Amazon plug gives me problems! It quits responding to Alexa, it quits responding to my app controls, it disconnects from wifi completely and refuses to reconnect.I really hate giving bad reviews for things - especially from the Amazon company because I rely on them for so much. But it's crazy how terrible this stupid plug is, at such an elevated price, and how many times I'm so angry at it I want to throw it across the room. After owning plugs from other companies that are SO much cheaper, and have never once given me a problem versus this happening monthly, I cannot imagine ever buying one of the Amazon plugs again.If you're going to spend the money to set up your house with smart plugs, look for third party options with high ratings.
title: I HATE this plug!

author: B1948J
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2018
review_content: I had a number of smart plugs from Jinvoo but they all stopped working for some reason. So, I bought two Amazon plugs and since have gone back to buy 6 more.The advantages of Amazon plugs over others:1) They aren't as sensitive as other plugs to change in your network, signal strength, etc. I switched to a mesh network in the house and 3rd party plugs just won't connect - even when I set up a dedicated 2.4 range extender.2) They are MUCH easier to set up. Plug them in and they pop up in your Alexa app. You change the name from "4th Plug" (or whichever number this is for you) to something like "Tree", assign it to a room and when you say "Alexa, living room on," the Christmas tree turns on with the rest of your lights. Truly plug and play.3) They work seamlessly with the rest of Amazon's products. They work ALL the time you have access to Alexa on any of your Amazon devices. If Alexa is working, you know the plugs will be working too - no frustrating troubleshooting necessary.The only negative is that The Alexa app still shows them in "device" listings under their original names (1st Plug, 2nd Plug, etc.) rather than the name you assign them. It doesn't seem to affect anything else though. Alexa still understands when you call them by the name you assigned them.
title: No Skills Required

author: Gerald Senear
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2020
review_content: After buying two sets of inexpensive smart plugs off Amazon  (Could not get either set to work with Alexa Voice Control) I broke down and bought a smart-plug that is made by Amazon and designed to work with Alexa. 4 hours plus trying to get the other two sets of smart plugs to work. The Amazon one worked right out of the box. It set itself up. I did not get the Alexa app on my tablet fully opened before the smart-plug paired and started working.  It has kept on working perfectly from that time on. All I wanted was a smart-plug that worked with my echo and now I have it. With the light turned off in our bedroom at night it is pitch black. There is not a light switch by the entry to the bedroom so we have to go searching in the dark for the pull chain mounted to our bedside Lamp. Now that is taken care of by simply saying, "Alexa turn on the light" or "Alexa turn off the light. I am impressed.
title: What more could you ask?

author: Arlen E. Breiholz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2020
review_content: I have several smart plugs, the Amazon product being the most recent acquisition. The device works well under most circumstances, as do the others. However, we had a couple of disruptions from our internet service provider over the last few days. The Amazon device and two others are connected to lamps in our living room area. About the time the Facebook Portal and Echo Dot started complaining about losing internet service, the Amazon-switched lamp went out. The other lamps stayed on. With the other devices, I can still control the devices over our local internet router using the manufacturers' apps, bypassing Alexa.The Amazon device is dead in the water until the internet comes back. Even the manual switch fails to activate the lamp, so I had to remove the device from the circuit to have light.  I suppose one might argue this as a safety feature, but I see it as more of a bug. It's a minor annoyance, but enough to make me regret going with the Amazon product.
title: Works Well Except in Internet Interruption

author: Whedon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2019
review_content: My original plan was to keep all of my smart plugs, bulbs, etc tp-link brand. My very first smart plug was tp-link, as well as my router, and it made sense to stick with a brand I trust and keep everything together in their Kasa app. I bought this Amazon plug because the price was irresistible and I needed another plug for some Christmas lights. It paired quickly and painlessly through the (slightly clunky) Alexa app and made me realize that since I'm using echos/Alexa to control my smart devices anyway, skipping the middle man (tp-link) and buying Amazon brand works fine too. I'm sure I'll continue to buy tp-link smart devices but now I have another option with Amazon's own devices.This plug has operated without a hitch since I set it up through the Alexa app on an automatic routine to turn my Christmas lights on every day 10 minutes before sunset and off at 11 pm.
title: Fits in fine with my tp-link smart devices

author: Vlaster
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2019
review_content: I always dread turning the Christmas lights on and off. I have to crawl under the tree, walk my hand up the wall, and pull on the plug with all of the strength in my arthritic fingertips, just to have to crawl back under the tree the next day, find the plug, walk my hand up the wall, and hope that my arthritic fingers can work together to fumble the prongs effectively into the outlet on one of the first few attempts. Ugh.With this smartplug I can say, "Echo, turn the tree on," and like magic, it's on. Yay! OH, and if I forget to turn the lights off and I'm in bed already, all I have to do is grab my phone and turn them off from the Alexa app. This thing is awesome!I don't really know what I will use it for other than Christmas lights, but it's made my life easier during the holidays and isn't that what almost everyone is looking for, especially during this time of year? Yeah, 5 stars.
title: This makes the holidays easier!

author: Mike Jr
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2020
review_content: Received this as a "free gift" with a purchase from BestBuy. With that, didn't think much of it at 1st, for it wasn't something that I needed at the moment nor was looking for...BUT when I finally hooked it up (which was very easy) it wasn't until I was about to go to sleep and had forgotten to turn off the living room lamp, that I realized, "this thing is freaking niiice!!!" Hahahaha. It comes in clutch! Freaks my cat out which is historical, she's like, "who the heck turned off/on the lamp!?!" I also like the fact that I can use it in the am upon waking because the light gradually gets brighter as it stays on until it reaches it's peak.Anyhow, I recommend it to anyone that has something that they could use remotely...I feel the lights are a good find because one can be coming home from wherever, and have there home illuminated before getting in, letting them feel more secure.
title: I like it!

author: R. A. Edington
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
review_content: Works fine. easy to set up. Read the instructions -- it doesn't arrive "ready to set up" in that you have to hold the button until it starts flashing blue/red so that it can then be discovered by the Alexa app.On the downside, I don't like devices like this because they're a pain if you have to switch your wifi password. On the upside, it'll work just fine if you DON'T have an Echo Plus with a zigbee hub built in.It's a shame they don't make dongles like this any more that can dim lights, but I guess too many idiots were plugging in their toaster to it and setting it to 50% brightness and then wondering why their toaster wouldn't work. On the plus side, this plug can provide a full 15 amps, purely on-off -- you COULD plug your toaster into it :)
title: NEEDS WIFI NETWORK -- Not a Zigbee "Hub" device

author: John G. Nguyen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2019
review_content: Let me start off by saying that I have installed multiples smart plugs and devices throughout my home and this is the first time I am having problems with getting one of these smart devices to connect properly.One of the main draw of purchasing this versus another brand (TP Link) was suppose to be the easy connect via Alexa.  I updated my Alexa app to the most current and then proceeded to follow the simple instruction to add a device via the Alexa app.  It gets through the setup just fine until the very end when it just goes into an eternal spin trying to connect to the wifi.  I tried both the scan via the Q link and the manual setup.  Same result.  Keeping getting error (-1:-1:-1:-1) or something similar.Maybe I just got a dud.  Will see about getting replacement and will update.Update - 01/03/2019 - User Error - Apparently, the unit did setup properly the FIRST time and it gave it a name of "first plug".  I never saw that in my list of devices (i have 40+ devices currently connected and counting!!) on the Alexa App.  All my subsequent attempts failed because it was already registered to me and my account.  Thank you Amazon tech support.
title: Can't get it to connect to home wifi - Updated

author: Sam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2020
review_content: If the Alexa home system is already setup, adding Amazon plug switches are essentially plug and play, similar to the Phillips Hue bulbs. I plugged the switch into the wall, plugged the lamp into the switch, and turned on the light using the Amazon push button switch. When I opened Alexa, she had already recognized the device. There is no need to download a third-party app, which seems to increase the difficulty of the installation process.I purchased two TP-Link plug switches, which died at about 30 months of use. I would think that they should have an expected life similar to a router of range extender. which is measured in years rather than months. I'm hoping the extra cost, vis-à-vis Tp-Link and Amazon will provide a much longer service life. So, the five stars are contingent many years (5-10) of service. The Amazon switch's are comparatively new and have not established a track record.
title: Plug and Play

author: Charles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
review_content: The plug works really well with a traditional lamp. With Alexa I can control it remotely by voice. It works directly with wifi and doesn't require a hub means I don't have to spend extra money on a hub.This plug works really well if you only plan to have this ONLY work with Alexa and it does a great job. I like how Amazon have the option to link it to my account to simplify the set up process so I don't need to manually pairing it and enter my wifi password those kind of things. It's just plug in and you are done.However, I would not buy this on my own if this doesn't comes with a discount bundle with the Echo Plus. This works ONLY with Alexa which means I cannot add it to homebridge to control it with Siri on my phone. I believe this also will not work with Google. I like to have a device that works with multiple platforms so I can have some redundancy, in case if any device goes down.If you are a iPhone users, don't buy it. If you are android users, there is a lot of other smart plug at a better price to consider.
title: Works well with Alexa, not recommend for iOS users

author: Eva M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2020
review_content: Amazon’s smart home devices are reliable and simply work, this plug is no exception. You might have a small hiccup in setup here and there but they always seem to correct themselves. This plug is used to power a set of 4 lamps in my living room and is integrated with the Alexa so I can turn it on by command if I need the light before my routines turn it on 30 minutes before sunset. I rarely have to think about it because it is so consistently reliable. The regular price is a little more than I’m comfortable paying so I was happy to snag it for a great promotional price a while back. It’s a bit large for a single plug, but again, it works reliably so I guess I can forgive that. I’ve had other smart plugs that were only slightly larger, but accepted 2 devices plugged in. However, those were more finicky and one crapped out altogether. Have I mentioned how reliable this plug is? It brings be joy to not have to think about it.
title: If you want a reliable smart plug and are happy with the price, this won’t let you down.

author: Jackie Gill
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2020
review_content: I really LOVE this smart plug. I really HATE its price. I ordered some of the other smart plug options on Amazon that are much less expensive and the problem is, they are a pain. You have to download plug specific apps, it takes a bit to set them up, if they lose the connection you have to do it again, just too much trouble for my liking. This one you take out of the box, plug it in, and go to your Alexa app. The only issue I've had with them is, if the internet goes, all of my lights turn off - that is very irritating. Now, I have my house set up using echo devices, so I cannot speak to how the other plugs or this would work on a different system. I was able to order the ONE Amazon allowed on Black Friday for $5, but the $25 price tag really is ridiculous. Admittedly, I have paid it for several of these, but I would have a lot more if the price wasn't so high.
title: Best Smart Plug I've used

author: CamRed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2020
review_content: I had purchased smart plugs that were not genuine Amazon plugs. Tried, with no avail, to integrate with my Dot. Caled my "whiz" grandson also. After trying all he knew, downloading an app, even he couldn't get these plugs working with my Dot.This time I saw an offer from Amazon for $off on 1 of their plugs. Purchased the 1, plus 3 others. Voila! All I did was put one in my outlet and my Dot recognized it (& the other 3) & within minutes it was doing its thing - no fuss, no muss!While I am an advocate of smaller businesses getting my business, I  will concede that corporate items are sometimes better. This is one example.I would heartedly endorse using only genuine Amazon products for the Dot & Echo. My daughter, who has Dots throughout her house says she same.Of course, do as you wish, but I think with the Dot/Echo, you may find the genuine Amazon accessories are far superior to other companies products.
title: For Dot/Echo, purchase only genuine Amazon

author: ZurkeyDurkey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2019
review_content: This plug is easier to setup than all the others with Alexa.  The reason being is because you don't need to download a second app for setup (i.e. for the Wemo plug you gotta download that app, for TP-Link plug you gotta download the TP-Link Kasa app, etc).  All you need is the Alexa app you're already using.The biggest missed opportunity with this Amazon Smart Plug is the lack of Zigbee.  You can't ask your Echo Plus 2nd Gen or Echo Show 2nd Gen to discover this plug.  It won't find it.  While it is easy enough to add the plug to WiFi in the Alexa app, having the option to have this plug connected via Echo Plus/Show would be of great value to me.  These devices have what is called Local Voice Control, which means you can control Zigbee lights, plugs, etc...without internet access.  It can do this because the lights/plugs would be connected directly to the Plus/Show, and not directly to WiFi (in combination with Local Voice Control).  If your internet goes down, have are you going to reboot your router with your voice?  If you have your router plugged into a Zigbee smart-plug, and that plug is connected directly to the Plus/Show, can easily turn it off and on for a reboot; no internet access needed!
title: Doesn't Require An Additional App, But Lacks Zigbee

author: Osvaldo Barrera
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2019
review_content: It’s very easy to connect and it really works as expected except that when I try to connect them to my wife’s Alexa app on her iPhone (account), the “smart” plugs got disconnected from my iPhone (account). Looks like it Cabot connect to more than one account in the same home. Now, that is horrible. Should I buy 2 coffee makers and connect them to two different smart plugs? What about the Christmas lights? The other downside is that let’s say you buy 10 smart plugs. In the Alexa app they will be automatically stored as first plug, second plug, third plug, and so on until you change their name. The problem is how to keep track of which smart plug is which. They all look the same. Amazon didn’t think this well. They should at least come with a sticker for you to write on or a designated space you can embed numbers or letters on so you can identify every of your smart plugs.  Other than that, I think this Amazon smart plugs are awesome, but I’m not buying anymore until they fix the no more than one account user issue.
title: This must be the best one out there, but it has two downsides.

author: rlu888
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2019
review_content: Setting up the Amazon smart plug was a breeze. In less than five minutes it was up and operational.The hardest part for me was trying to determine where to use it. Most of our lights are built in and I didn’t have any other appliances that I wanted to turn on and off. Finally I thought of our hallway night light that I like to turn on after dark. The light makes walking up and down the stairs easier. Also after we go to bed, I prefer that the light is turned off, so this was perfect for using with the smart plug.Let me address two complaints that I noticed in the reviews.1. Naming the plug - Some reviewers seemed to think that they were stuck using the default name. You can easily rename the plug using the Alexa app to whatever you want to.2. Scanning the bar code - While I didn’t need to do this, there is a copy of the bar code included with the plug so you do not have to unplug to scan.Only time will tell how long the plug will last, but for now it works great. I don’t think I would pay full price for one, but for $5 it was fun to try out.
title: Easy Setup

author: George Sanchez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: EDIT after letting it sit on the outlet it finally worked but about 24 hours later. I'm not sure if I would purchase another but as of now it has been working with no flawsTrash. Absolute garbage. I got this on a sale and I see why, this device sucks. No matter what I do it says device unresponsive. No matter how many times I reset the app, the "smart plug", the echo device or my router it still says unresponsive. I have great wifi coverage so I know that is not an issue Because I even plugged it right next to the modem/ router. Don't buy this. I will be returning this faulty device
title: Didn't work for the first 24 hours.

author: Koty
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2020
review_content: My echo dot hasn’t always been the easiest smart device to work with, but this smart plug has been a great accompaniment. I’ve been using it for a couple of weeks and the verdict is:1) packaging: simple and easy packaging. The plug came with a thin cardboard closure and no additional packet of info or bells and whistles2) setup: setup was just as simple as described on the packaging. Plug it in, go to your Alexa app, and click on devices- plugs. As soon as I plugged mine in, my echo dot started setup by itself and asked me what I’d like to name my plug; if not it would be named plug 13) use: great great great! I use this plug for my heater. I’m now easily able to heat my room before getting in there to start working from home in the morning. When it gets too toasty, I simply ask Alexa to “turn off heater”, and voila! Definitely going to get one or two more of these.
title: So easy to set up and use!

author: rothm41
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2019
review_content: This is easy to setup and reliable. I can turn it on and off from Alexa without issue. For my use case, it has one fatal flaw- I am using it to switch my hot water heater, which has an electronic control unit and flue which can be switched to turn the unit on/off. Since the Smart Plug does not remember its last state when the power is restored after an outage, the heater doesn’t turn back on after an outage. Depending on your use case, this could be an issue. For this reason, I will probably swap it out for a z-wave smart plug, which brings up another item for consideration- if you are looking to integrate the plug with a home controller (SmartThings, Home Assistant, etc), you might be better server to find a less proprietary solution. If the Alexa ecosystem is your solution, and you don’t care about the plug remembering state, this might be your best option.
title: Nice smart plug with limitations

author: ST
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2020
review_content: I bought 2 of these in conjunction with my new Echo to (1) turn a lamp on and off automatically in a dark room before entering and (2) to have Alexa turn a TV on and off on command.  I had to read the instructions carefully, and even then had to call Amazon for help in coordinating how to do this using my cell phone.  They were very helpful in guiding me through this process and I was very proud of myself to accomplish this, since I'm not a techie but do follow instructions.The Echo had been a gift, but adding first one Amazon plug and then a second one, made using it even more enjoyable.  These plugs seem to be more expensive than other similar products, and I would love it if the price was less, but so far I am very pleased with how they are working and the fact that they took the place of buying compatible bulbs to use this feature.
title: It Works Beautifully

author: Michael W
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020
review_content: Previously I had been using another brand of Alexa-compatible smart-plugs. This one was on sale for a great deal by ordering via voice with Alexa, so I thought I'd give it a try.Set-up was a cinch and so far everything is working well. We are using this to control a small Christmas tree as a part of a set of 3 in our house (my wife loves to decorate!); it's been fun to set up voice groups/controls to turn all of the lights on or off simultaneously. I'm excited to figure out what other things I can do with this smart plug.
title: Easy to set up and use!

author: R. Rideout
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2020
review_content: I previously purchased an Amazon plug and tried to save some money this round. Well, I started with a no name brand "Amazon" recommendation and never got past the install for the plug's app.  What a waste of time/effort.  Next, I went with Wemo (I already have 4 of these devices working) and I never got their smart plugs it to work.  It worked with HomeKit but nothing else.  Belkin migrated to Cloud and could NOT figure out how to get any of the 3 new smart plugs.  I spend over 3 hours troubling shooting / wasting time.  No customer service, no real help.  There recommendation was to return the plugs to BestBuy.  Fast forward to today, I got my 2 new Amazon smart plugs and plugged them in and the Alexa app recognized the plug and within 30 seconds it was working!  The morale of the story is if you are using Alexa don't bother with another Brand.
title: Works Right out of the Box

author: dashadow
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2018
review_content: This is the first smart plug I’ve purchased. And I only got this one because it came bundled with an Echo Dot for a great discount. There’s no way I would have paid $25 for one plug.The Alexa App recognized the plug once I plugged it in, so setting it up was simple. I bought a second plug from Best Buy with a certificate I had, and that one had to be added in the app. It wasn’t automatically added like the first one.As far as performance goes, both plugs have worked pretty well. I’m using one to turn on a Bose L1 Compact that’s connected to my Echo Plus. Whenever I want to listen to music, I tell Alexa to turn on the ‘speaker’. That way, I don’t have to leave the Bose on or manually turn it on and off.I’m using the second plug as a timer for Christmas lights. There are no instructions to show you how to set up a routine of turning the plug on and off, but you can find guidance online. However, most of the information I found online was poorly presented. I figured it out through trial and error. It’s more difficult than it should be.The connections have been fairly good. But I’ve received notifications from my Alexa App telling me a new plug has been found. That would indicate that the connection is being lost and refound from time to time. It hasn’t happened often. And since I don’t have anything critical connected to the plug, I’m not too concerned about it.Overall, I’m content. But I wouldn’t be inclined to purchase more in the future unless the price was $10-$15 each. I do like the convenience of having all my devices in one app. That’s the main reason I’m not looking at other plugs. I hope Amazon adds smart light switches to its offerings in the near future.
title: Works fairly well.

author: sking
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
review_content: I just installed my second one and plan to order more.  These plugs make any device a smart device. They are perfect for anything you don't want to physically turn off and on.  I put the first on a fan in my bedroom because I frequently get hot in the middle of the night.  Now, I just tell Alexa to turn my fan off or on without getting out of bed.  LOVE IT!  I just put a second on on my coffee pot.  Works great.  Easy to install.  Plug in and instantly recognized by my Alexa app on my phone.  I highly recommend these to anyone.  They are certainly worth the price.
title: I LOVE these plugs!

author: Mike P
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2020
review_content: Plugged it in - waited maybe 2 minutes and Echo Show5 announced that it had found the new outlet and asked if I wanted to change its name.  So basically it was working automatically with no configurations needed.  Cool !Alexa 'Turn on the laundry room outlet.I had noticed a banner advertisement while looking at the Amazon Alexa Skills webpages so I had one delivered on a Sunday for a dollar us.  Think it was $24.99 but a Special deal if you had bought or connected a new echo device recently, which I had just bought the Show5 new on eBay auction site a few days earlier, less than a week I think.Put it in my windowless laundry room into a receptacle that is really hard to reach, and plugged a light into it that ran previously full time, so maybe it might help to save a bit on my power bill if I take the time to decide on an on/off run time routine.
title: Easy to use.

author: Ziggy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: My smart plug died today, after only four months of usage.  I love the product, and it was great while it lasted, but as of today, it stopped working.  I can reset the device, and then go through the setup to add it back to my network again, but it then immediately becomes unresponsive the first time I try to turn it on, and the light just flashes red.  Unfortunately, my 90 day replacement window ended a month ago, so I guess I'll go back to turning the lamp on and off the old fashioned way, because I'm not paying $25 to replace it.** 11/26/2020 - Update - Well, I got disgusted that I couldn't return the plug, so I just plugged it in and let it sit over night.  Some how, this morning, it is working again.  So I don't know what what the issue was, but I want to bump up my rating, since it seems to have healed itself over night!
title: Glad I only paid a dollar for it on flash sale!

author: Vance Jochim
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2020
review_content: I bought this on a good sale, and set it up near a wifi extender to turn an outside carport lamp on and off when saying the command "Alexa, turn on First Plug" while still inside the house.  This is the first electrical outlet device I have purchased for use with Alexa.I have three Echo Dot devices and use them mostly for verbal commands and questions like "Alexa, what time is it in China? or "Alexa, set the crock pot timer to two hours" ...(which only verbally reminds me when the time is up).  I also use Alexa to play various podcasts or Pandora radio channels in my office, kitchen and carport.  First Plug is the default command for this device, and I haven't bothered to change it to something like "Carport lamp".  So far, after two months, it still works, so I may get some more to turn on devices like fans or other lights.
title: This works as my "First Plug" with Alexa, and is fairly simple to setup and use

author: IanTH
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2020
review_content: A bit of a bummer that they can't just allow mixed control from any assistant in a mixed assistant home. I use both Google and Alexa, but this plug only has native integration for the latter. I get certain Amazon/Alexa items only working within their ecosystem, but these items are money makers & there are plenty of people with mixed assistant homes. There's no real reason for them to make this plug exclusive in its function.It itself is fine - a bit larger than some of the more compact plugs, quite a bit smaller than a lot of the early and mid generation plugs (even smaller than the 2nd gen WeMo). Functionality is fine, though somewhat limited by Alexa itself. There is more one could do with Google Assistant routines, but for basic things like controlling lights and fans on simple timers or schedules, it does the job just fine.
title: Works fine with Alexa, No Other Assistants

author: DJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019
