review_content: I have several smart plugs and this is the dumbest of them when attempting to set a schedule for lights on/off.  I purchased it thinking it would replace several WeMo and other switches for setting up recurring on/off schedules.  For example, I want my Christmas lights to come on at 5:00PM and go off at 10:00PM.  The online instructions for timer scheduling are wrong.  I spent a frustrating hour trying to figure this out.  Finally, I had to go to a user forum to figure out the non-intuitive lengthy sequence to set a simple recurring timer schedule.  It's like WeMo switches were several years ago until WeMo made it easy.As of pros:  It does connect to the Amazon Echo network quickly and is easy to initially set up.  It is small and takes up only one-half of an electrical outlet leaving the other available.  It is also easily recognizable by the Amazon Alexa App on an iPhone.  Voice commands to any Echo device activate or de-activate the switch.  For this purpose it's excellent.  However, that's not my main purpose as I state above.
title: Works fine but frustrating to set recurring on/off schedule

author: Ken
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2020
review_content: I've had so many different timers going in the house, I've tried the dual timers, which let you have multiple on/off's during the day, I've had electronic versions that are supposed to make it easier to work, but ultimately just confuse the hell out of me, but this was the first "smart" timer for me.I purchased it through a super promotion on the site that made it a no brainer to at least try it out, and it made sense as I already have an echo and had the app already on my phone. It was dead simple to connect, but I did have to look up on youtube as to how to set it up, as some of the labels aren't as intuitive right at the start. I will say that as I was going through the how-to video, it made sense and I know that the next time I have to change something, or if I get more of these for the rest of my house, it'll be dead simple to get it going.I use it as a timer primarily, and it works great for that purpose, and best of all, there isn't the ticking sound that hums in the background. I would heartily recommend this product!
title: So much better than the ticking time bomb timers out there

author: R. H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2019
review_content: I bought this on a Prime Day discount, but I don't think I'd buy another one at full price. Granted, it's totally easy to set up and use, but is it worth the extra money?It only integrates with Alexa, so if you use or buy similar plugs that work with Smart Life or Tuya this one does not integrate with those apps.One plus to this plug is it has a 15 amp max. draw while others are only 10 amp, but I don't really need 15 amps for a lamp or small device.This one is great and as advertised, but I have several other cheaper ones that work just as great and they are 1/3 of the price.
title: Easy to set up and use, but is it better than the cheaper alternatives?

author: Susan Dunn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2020
review_content: I was excited to order these plugs as I have an aquatic frog light and a terrarium light that need to be turned on and off every day., What a great feature, I thought, I can set up routines and they will go on and off automatically every day. This will be great when I am out of town! And when I am home, I won't have to go down to shut them off at night or in the morning if I don't have time! The app made it so easy to set them up as well as setting up the routines. There, I've got this problem solved. I tested it out and it worked. That evening, I checked to see if they were off at the time I had set them to go off. Yes! And then...the next morning, they were not on when I checked. Darn!  Alexa said that the plug was unresponsive. So I  reset the plug and tried it again. Same thing. I tried the one I had ordered for my husband. Same thing.  It works great for the day but I have to reset them EVERY SINGLE DAY. No.
title: Every single day!

author: Bookjunky Pat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
review_content: So I loved this at first but then I started having to reinstall them. It is so bad now I am having to reinstall at least one plug a week into the app. After waking up at 4am hot and sweaty and telling Alexa to turn the fan on the plug had once again gone belly up. After trying every possible way to fix the issue I called Amazon tech support. At a bit after 7am I had to order a new plug of a different brand because these were on back order and mine was apparently a useless plastic brick. This is not the way to start the day and has ruined my day. These plugs are just plain not dependable.
title: NOT DEPENDABLE

author: Peas on Earth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020
review_content: So, if you only want to use this with voice, then this is great. And at $5 on sales, hard to beat. BUT - we also have the kasa one, and much prefer that one. ***Reason 1: SCHEDULING. Creating a schedule ("routine" on alexa) is about 10,000 times easier on the kasa plug. Totally trivial. It's a "pita" with the alexa routines if you have a lot of different on and off times.  ***Reason 2: ONLY the person who's account this is connected to, will see it in their devices list. This means other people in the household CANNOT operate it remotely, or without voice. In the bedroom, when one person is sleeping, you don't always want to have to use voice to turn the lights off... The kasa can handle multiple users. So, at $9 for kasa vs $5 for this on sales, if you need anything more than just voice control, I recommend opting for the kasa.
title: Inferior in two important ways relative to Kasa (tp-link) smart plug!!!!

author: sarah kate 82
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2020
review_content: I actually received a coupon code to buy the plug for nearly free.  We had purchased the Ring Doorbell and Alexa Dot combo for Christmas and they sent us a follow up offer to try out the smart plug.  Honestly i may have not purchased this at full price, only because we didn't really need it and don't have a lot of extra money to spend.  Anyway, the plug itself is great and easy to use.  We plugged our two lamps into it in the living room and quickly figured out how to get Alexa to recognize it.  So we have been using it to turn our lights on and off for about a month now.  No complaints so far.  Works well and has no issues.  Makes it easier than before.  I don't know the longevity yet of course and hoping it lasts for at least a few years, but no complaints so far!  I would recommend if you have the money and like this type of gadget.
title: Alexa Smart Plug

author: Jim R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2020
review_content: This was my first smart plug, and although it retails for $25, it was a great deal at $.99. For some reason there was a special deal where you can get one if you just started getting Alexa, and it was on sale for $.99. I got one.Now my wife and I are hooked and we want to get more smart devices for the house like light switches and all sorts of stuff.It was a little bit difficult to set up at first because it needed both Bluetooth and Wi-Fi, and for some reason it wasn’t picking up Wi-Fi in the available outlet that I plugged it into, but I moved it to a different outlet that had a clear shot to the Wi-Fi and it set up like a champ. Now I can just say “Alexa turn off the fan”. I sleep with the fan on for tinnitus since I was a kid. So now I created a routine for good night and good morning to turn the fan on and off along with my weather and news.
title: My first smart plug and I love it! Even better at 0.99

author: Stephen F. Yegge
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: I have a fast Netgear Orbi network with 50+ devices on it -- game consoles, laptops, desktops, smart plugs from several manufacturers, smart phones, tablets, heck, even several TV sets.So I know this problem isn't my network.I have 7 Amazon-branded plugs (the one I'm reviewing here).  The all were super easy to set up and they worked beautifully up to the point where I had to reconfigure my network.  I moved them from a Google Home network to the Netgear.  They all worked for a while and then a few days ago they all just "died".  All blinking red lights, all unresponsive.Every other device in my house is still working fine, mind you.  Just the Amazon plugs.I have individually gone in and reconfigured every single one of them -- deleted it from my devices list, added it back in, scanned the barcode, set up the network, SUCCESSFULLY for all of them.  But immediately after setup completes, the light goes off and the device becomes unresponsive.  Unplug/plug it back in, and it's back to blinking red lights.This to me sounds like Amazon has a serious software or firmware bug affecting their plugs.  I'm going to have to replace every single one of them.  I'll go with TP-Link or one of the other brands I've got in my house, all of which were perfectly happy on the new network.Very, very disappointing failure from Amazon here.
title: Every single one of these in my house suddenly decided to quit on me

author: JoeTAZ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2018
review_content: I've been using Wemo smart plugs for a few years. They've mostly worked OK and I like the ability to set up routines, for example, I like to watch TV when I go to bed but the sleep timer on my TV is not very useful so I programmed the Wemo to turn it off after it's been on for an hour and a half if it's turned on after 6:00p.m.  The biggest problem I've ever had with the Wemos is with the Echo.  Saying, "Alexa, turn on the TV" works most of the time but not always which is frustrating.This plug couldn't have been any easier to install. I plugged it in and opened the Alexa app on my phone. At first I was concerned because my phone told me that my Wi-fi was under attack but that got resolved and my Echos immediately recognized the device.  I could turn it on/off via the Echo and, through the app, I can set up schedules. I'm using it in a living room and I have it turn a light on/off each night.The big plus with this plug is that I got it for a mere $5.  Amazon had a deal that if you bought any Echo (which were on sale) you could get the plug for $5. Your basic no-brainer.  Would I pay list for this? Maybe, it doesn't do as much as the Wemo but it seems to work with the Echo better so it'll depend on usage.
title: Good but fewer functions than a Wemo

author: T.Perraut
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2018
review_content: What I like:- easy and fast setup (the barcode to scan helps)- works with very low latency (feels instantaneous)- can fit 2 on a regular wall outletWhat I do not like:- I do not know how to prevent the blue led to be on when the switch is off. (a piece of electrical tape on it fixes it. Using a black sharpie would have worked too likely). For something likely to be used in a bedroom, this is a pain. An option to turn it off permanently would be great.- this likely only works with Alexa. i.e. Samsung Smarthings hub will not see it most likely. I'm not sure that HomeAssistant (open source automation SW) will be able to connect to it.- it's unknown how secure this is (runs on your wifi network), but I trust Amazon to verify and patch security issues that might be found in the future. So I guess this part is a pro and not a cons.
title: works great. Annoying blue LED when light is off (with workaround)

author: coldcoffee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2019
review_content: I finally gave in and started down the slippery slope to AI devices.  It quickly became apparent that AI is not really intelligent, it's actually an assistant who speaks it's own language and it is up to us to learn of to talk to it.  For instance, if I give the unambiguous command to Alexa to "Set a ONE TIME alarm for 5AM tomorrow morning", why would it ask me if I wanted to have the alarm EVERY DAY.  It's the same for many of my simple requests.  On a more important note, make sure that you turn on Two Step Verification (2SV) on your Amazon account and install all of your IoT devices on a separate VLAN on your network router.  Most routers these days will let you setup VLANs or at least a guest network.  This is especially true when you choose the option to allow your SSID and password to be saved on Amazon's servers.
title: Works well, easy setup, however.....

author: Jason Lu
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2019
review_content: I wish I can set up this plug default to turn on the power.I bought this for a switched plug to control mt bad room lamps.It's useless because if I turn off the power from wall switch, I expect next time when I turn on the switch will turn the light on also.Instead of that, turning wall switch off and on will not turn on the plug.I have to1. Turn on the wall switch2. Wait until the smart plug to connect to wifi - takes several seconds.3. Say "Alexa, turn on the light"This is stupid. Such a simple feature can be done using firmware update. Come Amazon, you can do better.
title: Default to off

author: Pamela J. Peerce Landers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2019
review_content: I bought this on Prime Day because it was $20 off and I expected no problems integrating it with Alexa. Boy, was I wrong.I own 3 different brands of smart plugs, this one included. This Amazon plug was by far, the most difficult to get Alexa to recognize. While it worked fine with the Alexa app. It was there and I could turn it off and on, my Echo Dots refused to recognize it. After over an hour playing with it, I called Amazon Customer Service and spent about 40 minutes on the phone with a technical specialist. She gave up after 20 minutes and had me on hold while processing a replacement, when, I pushed in the button for 5 seconds. When I released it, suddenly it automatically connected to my WiFi, remembering the password, and, voila, it worked.When the rep came back on the line after 20 minutes, I told her it was working and she was relieved.Bottom Line: I got this for a great price, $4.99, but I would never buy another one.
title: Very Difficult to Integrate with Alexa

author: B. Johnson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2018
review_content: So far it works great.  Initially had a problem finding the smart plug with my Alexa phone app so used app on my tablet and it worked great.  You have to scan a bar code for setup.  Setup is very easy and I like the fact that I don't need to download another app because it works with my Alexa app.I have not yet set up a routine because I am only using one on my living room lamp and it is super easy to just tell Alexa to the light on or off.  Love smart gadgets and plan to purchase more plugs in the future.
title: Love smart home products

author: James Cosentino
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2019
review_content: Echo devices are an essential luxury gadget in my home. Before Amazon released their own brand of smart plugs, I had relied on 3rd party generic wifi plugs that required their own app and a few hoops to jump through to setup and enable for use with Alexa voice control.I am absolutely pleased with the official Amazon Smart Plug! Just as stated on the box it comes in, you just plug it in and find it in your Alexa app and bam! It's so stupidly simple to add to your Alexa home I'm planning on replacing all my generic smart plugs with these.One of the big issues with the 3rd party plugs, beyond setup procedures, is anytime there is an Alexa system update, those other plugs tend to stop being responsive for a few hours or longer until they catch up with the updates. Though I haven't had this plug for long, I'm expecting it to function flawlessly through Alexa updates.The ONLY criticism I have of this product is that it does not have a USB port incorporated into the design, a feature found on a number of 3rd party smart plugs. While this doesn't cause TOO much of an issue, as I can always add a USB extension outlet to it, that just adds unnecessary bulk to the unit.As soon as Amazon releases a version with integrated USB, I'll be buying without hesitation.
title: The BEST choice of smart plug for your Alexa home!

author: T. J. Brown
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2018
review_content: The switch works as advertised, but I was looking for some additional functionality to set a regular timer. For example, this plug controls my Christmas tree and I have easily set it to turn on with "Alexa turn on Christmas tree". There seems to be no way to set it up so that the tree will turn on at 4:30pm and turn off at a specified time or after a specific duration. The goal is to automate that timing while I'm away during the holidays. I have several WEMO switches that work fine (along with the ability to schedule with timers) and probably should have just gotten an additional one of those, but thought I'd give the Amazon version a go. For $20, I'll keep it, but will be relegated to voice-only control from here on out.
title: Cannot set to operate on a timer

author: PhotoGraphics
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2019
review_content: Being an early adopter I bought some of the earlies generation smart plugs, when they were gigantic compared to this one.  I actually have been using the original predecessor X10 modules for many years before that, those were the ones that used signals embedded in your home power lines, a product developed in 1975 by Birmingham Sound Reproducers (BSR) and later one of the staple products at Radio Shack.The current crop of smart plugs have one very major drawback that needs to overcome, and it is the reason I’m excited to see Amazon producing their own brand, because it may help drive the industry toward fixing its #1 problem – lack of standardization.  You see, smart plugs can only be smart if you download and install the brand of app that works with that brand plug.  You can’t use brand A’s plug with brand B’s app.  The unfortunate thing is that the more popular smart plug become the more companies are selling them, each with their own proprietary app that only works with their products.  Some of the apps are simplistic and easy to use and some would drive Einstein up a wall with their complexity.  And every day there are companies who jumped into this business going belly up, leaving customers with hardware but no app support.That’s why I’m glad to see Amazon getting into this.  There is no reason to waste 1000 words on describing this plug, in fact that would defeat everything I’m trying to say about its simplicity.  There is no need to overcomplicate it – you plug this little adapter into your power plug and Alexa sets it up for you automatically in a few seconds.  You don’t need an app to operate it (although you do have to have the Alexa app installed to use your Echo devices).  Once your device learns it and you name it from then on all it takes is for you to tell it what you want it to do, like “Alexa turn on the porch light”.  Building combination commands is very easy, in my case as I’m adding more plug controllers I can say “Alexa I’m leaving now” and various lights and other things adjust themselves accordingly.Of the many companies in this space I have standardized my house on Kasa because they get it better than anyone else but now that Amazon has jumped in over time I will slowly replace everything I own with their brand for what I hope is full compatibility and reduced concern that they won’t be around to support their systems like I predict will be true with 95% of the other brands.
title: What history teaches us

author: Bo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2020
review_content: I just want to turn on my coffee maker from the bed in the morning, and this plug won't do this.  In fact it doesn't work on ANY plug-in device that requires power to activate on the "on" button.  I.e. my coffee maker - if there's not power coming to the appliance, the button won't turn on, so therefore the Amazon Plug isn't able to turn the unit on.  Going around my home, most newer items I'd want to use with this are similar.  It WILL work on things like lamps and Christmas tree lights though, just not things with power buttons.The other thing I don't like is that I had to activate the Alexa app in order to use the Plug.  Then the app wanted access to all of my contacts, and wanted the ability to talk to all of them too.  Why does Amazon need to contact my best friends in order to turn on my coffee maker?
title: Doesn't work on anything requiring a power source to activate the "on" button -i.e. most anything

author: S. Nelson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Worked great for 6 months and then just died.  Outside the 'warranty window'.  Would love a replacement but will not buy again.UPDATE:  I set the plug on a shelf over night.  I'm a retired electrical engineer so I have mad troubleshooting skillz.  Next morning I picked the plug up and shook it real hard.  In the biz we call that 'punitive maintenance'.  I plugged it back in and now it works again.  Go figure.  My experience with punitive maintenance is that it works way more often than it should.  So my advice is if you have something that's broken give it a real good shake and try it again.  This technique probably shouldn't be applied to broken bones.  I've updated my review to 5 stars from the previous 2 stars.  If you'd like me to shake things for you my rate is $1,500/hour, 2 hour minimum.
title: Lasted 6 months.  We liked it a lot when it worked.

author: JamesM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2018
review_content: I have a double-boiler espresso machine that's pretty heavy duty and this plug handles it well.  I've been using it for several weeks to turn on/off the machine in the morning so I can just ask Alexa to turn on my coffee instead of going all the way downstairs to turn it on manually.  By the time I'm out of the shower and dressed, the machine is at temp and I can make my morning Americano.  My house is also pretty challenging for some wifi signals and this plug hasn't had a problem yet so impressed with that as well.
title: Use this daily for a 10 amp draw espresso machine.

author: Alyssa R-T
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2020
review_content: I love having smart plugs. When I was little, I dreamed of living the a smart house (thank you, Disney, for inspiring that wish at such a young age) where the lights turned off with a simple voice command.What I didn’t anticipate was the painful high pitched squeal that comes out of the Amazon plugs any time they’re actually plugged in. The dogs kept burying their heads whenever we plugged it in, and I kept trying to figure out why I’d get a migraine every night right at bedtime (where this plug was used). The second we unplugged the smart plug, the noise stopped and the dogs went back to normal.It is super responsive. It is beyond simple to attach to your existing Alexa/Echo suite. If your hearing isn’t overly sensitive, and you don’t have pets, this is the smart plug for you!
title: Decent

author: janee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2019
review_content: Our wi fi works fine with Alexa, but the plugs don't always work, I have to redo them about once a week.  I did have one that no matter what I did it wouldn't work so I called Tech support.  Tech support had me on the line for about 30 minutes trying to figure out the plug, I must have done and redone, what he told me about 3 or 4 times, finally I said, "just send me a new plug, obviously, this one doesn't work."  I was reading what my phone was telling me about the plug to him, obviously I wasn't trying to put one on him just to get a "New" plug.  He finally told me he'd send me  a new one BUT I had to send the one that didn't work back to Amazon.  That meant, TAKING the plug to UPS and dropping it off.  I don't mind doing that if I order something and I decide to return it, but having to go through that hassle for a broken plug...I wasn't happy.  I returned it though!
title: Love it when it works

author: Poc Network // Tech
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2019
review_content: Clearly these are some of the best plugs for Alexa. Given, the reason for this is quite obvious. They were design to function with Alexa. Thankfully, they pull it off as well as they should. Some of the plugs we come across well but sometimes fall of the network forcing you to manually pull them out and plug them back in so that they will reacquire the network. Not these. Some we find have issues where they cycle power to the devices connected to them, or they have built-in night lights that come on by themselves for no (tellable) reason. Not these (they don't even have a built-in light). These are easy to get connected to your network, Alexa sees them just fine, and responds to trigger them every time (unless you have a thick accent or something of course). Nothing much else to say. They work!Update: It does seem that the plugs are sadly hit and miss. Sometimes you get one that won't connect and you get something like "unknown failure 5:9:100405:3" and you wind up having to send it back for a new one. If you have trouble connecting one, save yourself the trouble and send it back. It shouldn't be a hassle to connect. Once you do get one to connect, then the above information applies.**If you have found our review helpful, please vote it as helpful below so I know. This helps me provide quality feedback in the future.
title: One of the best for Alexa

author: Michelle Daniels
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2019
review_content: I debated getting one of these because we didn't really "need" one.  We don't own any Smart appliances yet except for TVs and I couldn't think of a real use for this.  But they were on promotion for $0.99 so I grabbed one, because why not?  We ended up putting it with the lamp in our bedroom and I'm actually quite glad that we got it.  It was easy to set up and it's a quality of life improvement for sure.Our 1-year old sleeps in the bedroom with us, and I set up a routine on our Dot so that we say "goodnight" and it tells us goodnight, starts playing white noise, and turns the light off.  He gets a kick out of it doing all that and it's nice to be able to control the lamp with our voice.  I didn't realize how many times I got into bed and forgot to turn the lamp off until I didn't have to do it anymore!
title: Easy to set up, helpful to use

author: R. Hummel III
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2019
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           I'm fairly tech savvy, having once been the head of technology for an Animation studio.  I was an early adopter of Smart Home switches and plugs for controlling things in my home starting in 2007.  Well, while I always like the devices once they're set up, the setup itself can often be PAINFUL! Taking half an hour or more trying to get the device to stay linked to your local wifi, etc...I plugged in the Amazon plug, and within a few seconds, a message appeared on my iPhone that said "New plug named First plug found. To control it, say 'Alexa, turn on First Plug.' "  Which I did say, and it immediately worked.  All in less than 30 seconds after plugging it in.  I then opened the Alexa app, promptly found it amongst my devices, and renamed it to "The Enterprise" so I could use it to control turning on my treasured Starship Enterprise model (See the video).  It worked on the first try.  I am sold, sold, sold, and extremely pleased with the elegance of this integration.
title: Astoundingly simple and FAST to set up! Especially when compared to Insteon or Belkin WEMO

author: Tr@cie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2019
review_content: Purchased this Alexa Smart Plug on a whim, not because I needed it but rather it was a good deal.  Thanks to my daughter, I now have an Alexa Spot and an Echo Dot.  Neither one do much but sit quietly and I've come to the conclusion that the Echo is definitely a special needs Dot with a pronounced learning disability and suffers from hearing loss.  Honestly, I'm just not into the whole smart home technology craze and even admitting to this really shows my age!I like the compact size of the plug, no overlap of the other receptacle and it fits behind my love seat just fine.  Set-up was simple, once I plugged it in, both my Alexa Spot and the app immediately recognized it and pretty much walked me through the process.  In less than 2 minutes, one of my living room lights was connected and functioning as expected.  Since the plug is located near a wifi extender, I wasn't concerned whether it connected to my 2.4 or 5 ghz.  Now if I could only get my husband to stop turning the light on/off manually and let Alexa do her job......Happy with my purchase.
title: Wow, technology is just unbelievable

author: TheyKeepOnRising
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2019
review_content: My Insteon hub died recently, leaving me and my family in the literal dark.I was already pretty unhappy with Insteon as of late, and decided to jump on these plugs instead.Pros:- Very easy setup, works with either bar code scanning or traditional pairing- Less delay from commands when compared to Insteon- No hub required! Just Alexa and the Alexa app- 3 prongedCons:- Loud CLICK when it toggles on or off. I have a couple of these in the same room for the lights, and it's pretty obnoxious to turn all the lights on at once.- Awkward shape, but so far hasn't obstructed other connections on either a wall outlet or surge protector.- No dimming or other bonus featuresOverall:For now, this is my preferred smart home plug. Hubs have always been an annoyance in terms of being moody and space-consuming. This plug skips the middle man and offers what you want for the price you want.
title: Smart home without the dumb hub

author: Mr. Howard, Tampa Fl. U.S.A.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2020
review_content: I bought one and plugged it into the outlet, waited a bit, asked Alexa to turn on light. IT WORKED, GREAT!A few weeks later ask Alexa to turn off light ALEXA ERROR FAILED TO COMMUNICATE. I tried everything I could to get it working again, spent 2+ hours with no success causing me to return the item, and ORDER A REPLACEMENT SINCE IT WAS NOT WORKING.I have SPENT A LIFETIME MANAGING COMPUTERS, NETWORKS, PHONE SYSTEMS, AND THESE PLUGS ARE THE MOST CONVOLUTED THINGS TO SET UP OF ANY SMALL DEVICE I HAVE WORKED WITH. It literally took me 4 hours of trying various things to get the new plug connected and afterward I tried again to get the one I thought to be defective working.This entire process is one of the WORST EXPERIENCES OF MY LIFETIME GETTING A DEVICE TO WORK. I am sure things would not have been so bad if Amazon opened their phone lines. There is no reason to keep people from calling, those jobs can be done from home especially for a company as huge as Amazon.
title: Great device when I can keep it working. :-)  HELL TO INSTALL or REINSTALL!

author: User
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2018
review_content: It works, you can make a script for Alexa to follow, its all pretty straightforward. Electrical spec on it is actually very good compared to many other smart plugs and supports 3-prong.However, there isnt a "reboot" function on the outlet. Its missing an ability to 1-button reboot or "Alexa reboot my plug in the garage" for example without the script. I need it to be self contained where the plug itself turns off after X seconds, then turns itself back on even when wi-fi or internet access is not available due to the reboot.I'd like to be able to remotely reboot my network devices and know it will power back on as internet and Wi-Fi would be offline in the process. Alexa, reboot my router... OK! Outlet 5 seconds off, then outlet back on.
title: It works straight out of the box

author: KMW
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2019
review_content: I have a main light in a bedroom that plugs into a switched outlet.  That outlet is controlled from outside the door of the room so this light is usually turned on when entering, and is the only light needed.  That meant: read in bed, start to fade to sleep ...  get up and turn on a bedside light, go to the door and turn off the main light, back to bed and turn off the bedside light, now sleep.  Well, that is inconvenient.  Adding an additional switch for the main light near the bed would involve akward wiring runs and wall patching/painting.Enter this smart plug.  Fading to sleep: "Alexa turn off bedroom plug".  Done.Have patience with the setup.  It took several tries before it properly finished the setup, but just rinse and repeat until it does.  Once done, it sticks.
title: Relocate/rewire a switch, or...

author: Tyler2018
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2020
review_content: The smart plug is simply the best. How many times have you laid down on the couch or bed, and get more comfortable than you have ever been, only to realize you left that pesky light on? That is now a thing of the past. The plug features a button on the side of the device as well, although I never use it because of Alexa. Through the Alexa app you can rename the plug to whatever you want. For example I have a side table lamp in the living room, so all I have to say is, “Alexa, turn lamp on.” and about half a second later it’s on. There is a small bit of lag in between the command and the action, however it isn’t so long as to be a problem. Overall, I’d buy more of these plugs for devices like multi-bulb floor lamps that require too many smart bulbs or anything like that, so you could keep the “smart home” cost as low as possible.
title: Great addition to Echo!

author: Rashmesh
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
review_content: I just launched my Alexa app and got a notification "New smart plug found".I was able to control it immediately, I also like the sleek style.
title: Setup was amazing

author: Megan C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: It was pretty good for a while. I have had this for one year, but it took me a few months to find out how I wanted to use it. It has been a bit spotty. Sometimes Alexa says it has an issue with connecting to it and I have typically unplugged and plugged back in with success. Today, it stopped working completely. I don't expect this plug to only have the shelf life of a year! Cannot imagine replacing them all. 🤦🏽‍♀️ Also, consider your internet connection when getting these. If your internet isn't great, it will disconnect your Alexa and also affect these Amazon plugs!!! We had an issue a few months ago and (much like now) I had to dive under the bed to press the button to turn it on manually. I won't be getting anymore that are exclusively through Amazon. Next one has to have it's own app.
title: Lasted one year. Then kaput!!

author: B. DeMarco
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: I'm hugely disappointed; I have 3 of these, and they worked great until I upgraded to an eero pro 6 mesh WiFi system a couple of days ago.  Now I can't get them to work.  I've tried everything -- removing/deleting them from Alexa, unplugging and plugging back in, holding the button on the side to reset, every possible combination of those actions, probably 10 times for each of the 3 plugs.  I tried disabling the 5 Ghz band in eero.  Nothing worked.Then I hooked up a TP-Link Kasa smart plug I had, and everything worked easily and beautifully with the eero.Considering Amazon owns eero, the Kasa plugged worked great, and every other of the 40 or so devices in my home works great with the eero, this is a huge disappointment.  Get your act together, Amazon.Update: I'm updating this from 1 star to 4 stars because they're working now.  I ended up contacting support and describing the issue, and he did some kind of reset of settings on Amazon's end that made them all magically start working.  Unless that was a coincidence, I guess if you change your internet settings significantly, you might have to contact support to get these working again.  I'm still pretty irritated that I had to contact support after struggling for hours to get these working, so I won't give it 5 stars.
title: Doesn't appear to work with an eero mesh system (Updated)

author: North of 30
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Had this smart plug for about a year. It worked flawlessly until today - it suddenly stopped working! I spent about 45 minutes on customer service chat with no resolution. The agent mentioned they were dealing with a global technical issue and to try chatting again I. A couple of hours. Maybe the “global technical issue is what’s causing the problem with the smart plug.  I’ve spent over 1 hour trying to get the plug to connect and work. Once it finally seemed connected, I kept getting “device unresponsive” in the Alexa app.  I had a 2nd identical plug that was brand new and still in the box. Tried setting the new one up and encountered the same issues!  So disappointed! Hoping for some great Black Friday deals on other brands of smart plugs. I’m giving up on the Amazon brand of plugs - complete junk!
title: Amazon smart plugs are junk! Buy a national brand instead!

author: NS
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2020
review_content: First the pros, it has compact size, fully integrated with Alexey app, and has a lot of features. Compared to other smart plugs, its app setup is a little bit too complicated. But I have nothing to complain there since it provides a lot more features. But to my disappointment, it does not work for some very basic function. I configure it auto power cycle my router during early morning hour. Essentially, power off at some certain time and power on a couple minutes later. Sometimes it worked, but more frequently it did not. It stayed in the power off state that I had to manually power back on. It really puzzled me. One possible explanation I could think of, when it powered off the router, the plug lost network connection and thus could not execute the subsequent power on action? I might never know, but one expect any "smart" plug could still function some basic feature without Internet.
title: does not function as you would expect

author: ChampStamp
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2019
review_content: Works fantastic and was extremely easy to setup. I purchased this for my Bearded Dragon terrarium. My previous timer (for UVB light) stopped working, so I decided to get an upgrade and go with an Alexa smart plug. I already use many echo devices in my home, so it was a no brainer. The plug is small and only covers the outlet you plug into. My previous one was big and covered both outlets, so this was a big plus. Also, because all your settings are done through the Alexa app, when the power goes out your settings are saved online and will be automatically applied once the power comes back on. The voice functions are nice as well. I set it up so I can say, "Echo, put Sheila to bed" in order to turn the light off; Or, "Echo, wake up Sheila" in order to turn the light on. (Sheila is my lizards name). All in all I am very glad I purchased this smart plug and I plan on getting more plugs in the future to further automate my life.
title: Made my life easier.

author: studentmess
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2019
review_content: I got this on prime day and the price was great! (4.99) I was excited to use it on my bedside table with my lamp.I had a little trouble setting it up. It has to be plugged directly into the outlet so I had to remove my usb outlet device. Now the only other thing I can plug in for now is my alarm clock. I had to update my Alexa app, the barcode wouldn't scan with my fire tablet and I also missed the pressing the button until it flashed red and blue. After that the setup went great and I was able to set up Alexa to respond to the voice commands, "Alexa turn off the lamp" and "Alexa turn on the lamp."In the middle of the night I woke up and was wondering why there was so much light in the room. That little blue light on the plug puts off a lot of light in a dark room! I was having trouble going back to sleep so I ended up pulling the whole thing out. I will have to find another place in the house to use this plug (not the bedroom!)
title: Works great! but maybe not for my bedside lamp...

author: Chris B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2020
review_content: I had bought my first Echo Dot very recently, when I got an email for a promo for this plug for only 99 cents, so I figured why not and bought it! It was a breeze to set up, and I'm using it for some extra lights in my bedroom. I do like having the option of using the little button to manually turn the lights on or off, but now I'm getting more used to Alexa, I just use my voice and it works perfectly every time!Would I pay the normal price for this? Probably not. There are other brands out there that also work flawlessly with Alexa, are exactly the same size, and you can get 4 of the other plugs for the same price as this one.Is it a great product? Absolutely! Worth the price? I don't think so. If you can get a discount like I did, or on a flash sale, then take advantage of it.
title: Works perfectly!

author: Randolph Roshon II
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Became “unresponsive “ after 4 months of use. Tried product support and they said call back in 3-4 hours. This thing was too inexpensive to go through the hassle of calling them back again. No returns. No warranty. It was a cool product while it was working.
title: Lasted 4 months

author: superlatives
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2019
review_content: I bought the Amazon Smart Plug for ONE reason: to save energy for what is THE most power-hungry device in my home: the cable box. When it's "on", the cable box uses over 25 watts an hour. Which may not sound like a lot, except for one thing: the cable box has no "OFF" switch. And the box's power- save feature saves ONLY 2 watts an hour … so effectively the box is powered 24/7. Now that the box is connected to the Smart Plug, I can turn the box on and off using my Echo. And with the Alexa app I can schedule the cable box to turn on and off if and when I need to record to DVR. So now, a box that used to use 18 kW now uses only 4.5 kW!
title: Probably the BEST purchase I made for my Echo -- and my electric bill.

author: Penelope Pitstop
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2020
review_content: Bought a couple plugs on Cyber Monday's $5 sale price.  Both arrived a couple days ahead of schedule, and had them set up within 10 minutes of opening their boxes.Alexa was able to rename them to "tree" and "wreath" in a new device group called "Christmas lights", now I can turn on or off my lights by asking Alexa, no more crawling under the tree for that pesky switch, or going outside to deal with the yard decorations, one command and each or all are done for me by Alexa.  Until I get an outside-ready model, 'wreath' will have to suffice in the laundry room with an extension cord running out the basement window :-)So much easier to control the holiday lights!...wonder what I'll connect to the plugs to after I pack up the lights when 2021 finally arrives?
title: Amazon's "Certified Human" products are so easy to connect!

author: Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2020
review_content: UPDATE - If the router is restarted, this smart plug completely loses it's whole configuration and takes several tries to get set up, again.  Definitely NOT worth purchasing.I bought this plug so that I could plug my smart garage controller into it because when I reboot my router, the smart garage controller sometimes hangs and needs to be power cycled and is at the top of the ceiling. Well, guess what, this device is literally 15 feet from the router and is unresponsive with a flashing red light. The Alexa app shows it as unresponsive. Well, all I can say is that I'm glad I paid only 99¢ for it (Amazon special deal). Definitely not worth the regular price of $24.99.  I'm going to try another brand which works with Google and Alexa, rather than locking me into Alexa. When in the same room as the router it worked fine. I'm disappointed with Amazon. I expected better quality.
title: Disappointed with Amazon

author: Cranky24/7
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2020
review_content: When my two computers can access the internet wirelessly, plus my Echo Dot access Sirius or Prime music at the same time - but the plug cannot connect so that it turns the light on, the problem is NOT with my wi-fi network. The problem is with the plugs. (I tried to return the two I have but one was outside the return window so I'll throw it out, I suppose.)I got tired - very tired - of having to move the couch to reach the plug to hit the reset button to initiate the connection process (or to scan the bar code; or to unplug the plug, wait thirty seconds, and plug it back in as frequently directed to do by Tech Support).Love the idea of these plugs but suppose I'll have to find another brand that is actually reliable. Amazon's plugs are NOT.I cannot recommend these.
title: Sent it back!

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020
review_content: It works.  BUT first you are supposed to read an instruction book in very small print with thin letters the magnifying glass does not pick up well.  I am 70.  Things that are low contrast are hard to read. This plug is for my mother who cannot reach the lamp.  The directions should read " If you are older, you still have to read all the directions.  Either use a camera to take a picture of each page and blow it up on a monitor, or find a younger person who can read the directions to you. "
title: Directions are in tiny print not conducive to magnifying glass

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2020
review_content: Well I took the dive on a amazon smart plug, when it was on sale for 6 or 7 bucks I think. Anyways I've always wanted to try one but I think 25 bucks for one is a little absurd when wyze is selling packs for a fraction of the price. However the quality of the smart plug is great and the integration and setup is super convenient. At first the commands for the plugs were flawless and then I changed up the phrases accidentally. I tried to change the commands back but then I started noticing errors and command failures while turning the plug on and off. Maybe I have to do a hard reset on the plug. I have no idea but it does work great and it is very convenient. 5 stars for the quality and the sale price but I probably wouldn't pick up another one until they went on sale again.
title: It works!....the majority of the time...

author: Bill from Bayfield County, Wisconsin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2020
review_content: To start here, I fully intend to buy several more of these "smart plugs."  These devices are so convenient and easily linked to my Alexa; I used this one in the living room installed into an obscure outlet that I used to light the Christmas tree for the Holidays.  With this "smart plug" in play, I no longer needed to maneuver the rocking chair and risk upsetting the tree to turn the lights on and off; a simple command issued to Alexa and the Christmas tree was lit up and darkened efficiently and conveniently.  I will buy several more to place in likewise "out of the way" outlets.The first thing I noted is that it was incredibly easy and convenient to link the plug to my Alexa.  I literally did nothing more than plug it into the outlet and it was ready to use.The second thing I want to note here is that the plug is no larger than a typical surge protector.  It doesn't get in the way and is not bulky at all.I will note here that it does include a ground post so any outlet targeted for use with it must be a fully ground outlet with the ground pole configuration.
title: Simple, Efficient And Very Convenient

author: Denise Miller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2019
review_content: Amazingly easy to install. About two years ago I tried a smart plug and it was difficult to set up and would need to be completely re-installed every time there was a power outage or a hiccup in the network. More trouble than it was worth. I stopped using it after a few months and didn't bother trying to replace it. I received this smart plug for Christmas, plugged it into the outlet, scanned the barcode on the package and magically it was all set up. So easy. Added it as a device to my Alexa app and now I just ask Alexa to turn the Christmas tree on or off. So far, no problems. Will probably move it to my bedroom light after the tree comes down and see how it lasts. If there aren't any problems in a few months I'll definitely be buying a few more to make my home smarter.
title: My first smart home device

author: Shesinstpete33710
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2020
review_content: I have a lamp on the table by my bed that is hard to reach because my bed is a Tempurpedic adjustable.  I purchased this plug with the hopes it would work with Alexa so I could turn on or off the light while in bed when needed.  I'm a senior and not very tech savvy.  Boy am I surprised.  Talk about simple.  The super easy instructions walked me through the very simple and quick set up.  What a really kool plug!  I can now lay in the bed no matter what angle it's at and  command the lamp to turn on or off by voice command.  This is the koolest thing since... air conditioning!  Very pleased with this purchase.  You will be too.UPDATE:  I wondered if this would automatically reconnect if the power went out.  Transformer blew behind my home and 2 hours later power was back on.  This DID reconnect automatically.  No need to do anything to reset it.
title: Really kool!

author: B. Larson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2019
review_content: Had a flooded basement, and for the next couple of weeks until the pipe was fixed, had to (manually) fire up a pump at varying intervals to keep the water in check.  A timer wouldn't work, as the cycles varied somewhat, and I didn't want to risk either more flooding or running the pump dry and wrecking it.  When I needed to be away for more than a few hours, I could check on the floor drain with a wifi security camera pointed at it, then use the alexa app (which worked perfectly) to start & stop the pump as needed.  When I'm home, I just use the button on the side of the plug to turn it on & off - which is much easier than pulling the plug in & out  to start & stop.  One time it didn't work, but I found out I must have held the button on the plug too long, and that apparently reset it and the app had to re-find it.  I'm a pretty fussy consumer, and overall, I'm thrilled with how well this has worked, and how quick & easy it was to set up.  Highly recommended!
title: Did exactly what I needed it to do

author: Travis Siegel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review_content: I swiped this plug from my wife who wanted to use it for her lamp.  I put the air conditioner on it, and now I don't have to get up and walk across the room to turn on/off the rather aged air conditioner in the living room.  I've been able to tell alexa to turn it off when it's a reasonable temp, then turn it back on when it gets too hot again.  Previously, I'd have to get up and walk across the room to do this.  Not a bad thing, I mean, who doesn't want exercise, but now I can continue working on my programs or web sites without having to break first, that helps a whole lot, and makes our electric bill better, because I don't have to wait until I come to a break point before turning it on/off, and that helps a lot.  Of course, buying another air conditioner with a thermostat would serve the same purpose, but hey, this one works, so why bother.
title: Works well

author: William Royce
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2020
review_content: A year ago I purchased a different smart plug than this Amazon model. It sat around for over a year because the set up  instructions were kind of murky and every time I tried to get it working, I failed.Well, this Amazon model of a smart plug was a million times better because the set up literally took under a minute. It just required me to open my Alexa app on my phone and 'viola' Alexa found it.  So I am very impressed. I have it working with our Christmas tree with a routine I built in the Alexa app. Again pretty easy and slick. I can set up lights to turn on and a Christmas tune to play through Alexa. Routines are strong suit with Alexa integration.Only drawback is that it is more chunky than my other model. But that really is not a deal breaker. It is not a wall wort by any means.
title: Set up quickly but chunky

author: Brian Green
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2019
review_content: This really is the only smart plug I'll buy.  It's so simple.  I plug it in and before I even get to my phone I have a notification that it found a new device.  I click the notification and my Alexa App opens to the device.  I rename the device and done.  I've had some other third party smart devices that have been a real pain to connect.  I wish Amazon would make more smart devices that connect so seamlessly without having to connect to other apps and struggling to get Alexa to discover.  This thing just works, does what it says.  To say it's easy to set-up is an understatement.  Because there really isn't anything to set it.  If you want it called Smart Plug, you literally don't have to do ANY set-up.Finally smart devices that are...you know; smart.
title: Easy.  Only smart plug I'll buy

author: P. Moran
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2020
review_content: Once in a while streaming devices (including Amazon Fire TV) will lock up (like a computer) and need a reboot.  Most of the time going to the system menu and selecting the 'Restart' function is enough to get these devices working again.  On rarer occasions, power must be removed from the device.  Since our entertainment center arrangement makes getting to the power cords difficult, the Amazon Smart Plug now makes this so much easier to accomplish.  What I especially liked was being able to name the SmartPlug -- I named it "Yourself."  People were astonished when I called out "Alexa, turn yourself off," and then "Alexa, turn yourself on," each time receiving the reply "Okay.".People couldn't figure out how Alexa could reply to turning 'herself' on after being turned off -- it was quite amusing.
title: Easy to add to Alexa app -- makes a 'Cold Reset' on the Amazon Fire TV much a breeze now

author: Jesi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2019
review_content: I LOVE THESE THINGS! My kids are forever not shutting lights off in the house. We only have a couple lamps in the house that plug in so I could only get a couple of these. They are so damn handy though to get the lights turned off without having to go downstairs to do it. Extra bonus is you can set a routine, so I can have lights turn on in the house when the sun goes down so we don’t come home to a completely dark house or if we have to get up in the middle of the night there is always a light on and I don’t have to trek across the dark rooms praying I don’t step on a Lego or something to turn a light on. You can also turn lights off and on when you aren’t even home. I had read a review that said you couldn’t do that unless you were home on the same wifi as your plug. That isn’t true as I have Nest cameras and was able to see if the lights actually turned on or off when I wasn’t home. This brings great peace of mind for when we rarely go out of town, we can at least make it look like someone is still home by turning lights off and on. I intend on buying the light bulb style ones but we have to see if they will fit in our fixtures and they are pricey so I’ll have to buy them over time. But I love the simplicity and ease of use and the electricity savings I can’t really tell because our bill fluctuates with the seasons anyways so there is no way of knowing that we’ve saved a lot of money or not. My only peeve is when one of the kids turns off the light with the light switch, so when my routine goes to turn it on again, it can’t actually turn on because the lamp is switched off making me think that my smart plug isn’t working.Also I’m not sure if that phantom electricity is a real thing or not but these stay plugged in all the time. So if that really is a thing I’m not sure how much money you save.
title: Routines and ability to use while not home makes these so much better!

author: Pammy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2020
review_content: Easy set up, however, every day I've had to do a complete reset and then pair the plug again to my Alexa app. The plug is less than 10 feet from my Amazon Echo 8. I have a mesh network using Eero that keeps a consistent Wi-Fi connection throughout the house. I am using the plug for LED lights that are plugged into an outlet over the kitchen cabinets, so it means getting out a ladder to do a full reset. Not convenient at all.I have another brand of plugs that have been reliable and consistent since day one.I got this by ordering via my Echo device for 99¢Despite the great price, it's inconsistent and unreliable. I'm not a fan and will go back to the other brand of plugs.
title: 99¢ Promo price was the only good thing about this plug.

author: Mainah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2020
review_content: I purchased this one plug during cyber Monday and then lost it amongst all the paraphernalia associated with the holidays. I actually didn’t read many reviews before the purchase, nor did I read the instructions when plugging it in. Honestly, if there were instructions they were lost. So I plugged it in, connected the lamp to it and immediately I received confirmation from my phone that Alexa recognizes it. That simple. Then I read the reviews and saw I should give the plug a name, like my dots. Again, process was that easy and fast.  Unless there’s something that occurs later on, I feel this device is a 5 star winner. I will purchase more and will be curious as to how well they all work together. I suspect it’ll be fine as I have three doors with zero issues.
title: Great device. Easy and Responsive.

author: Gilbert Escobar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2018
review_content: Very cool plug. Set up was easy. Setting routines is ideal. It just works.My main complaint is the price point. The Alexa exclusivity limits the potential of the plug. There are other plugs for less that do the same thing yet are compatible with more ecosystems.My complaint and reason for taking away 1 star mainly stems from Alexa not supporting Apple Watch widgets (I can't control my dots or smart devices using Alexa on my watch). I tried using IFTTT as a workaround, but even though Alexa is compatible with IFTTT, the plug isn't.Even though I own Apple products, I prefer the Amazon ecosystem. I use Amazon exclusively for my media consumption and I love the echo dots. I don't have a dot in every room though. But I usually always have my watch on. I don't want to always have to reach for my phone to control the plug. It's too many steps. Funny enough, I don't use HomeKit or Siri. But even if I did I don't think the device would connect to those systems either.Amazon, please make the device compatible with other apPS, or better yet, please make Alexa compatible with Apple Watch and support widgeta(the 3rd party apps are no good). For example, Phillips Hue Lights have Apple Watch Compatibility and support widgets, which allows me to easily control my lights from my watch. Fix this and I will change my rating to 5 stars.
title: Please add Apple Watch compatibility

author: DJC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2019
review_content: I bought this for one real reason, I have my whole house filled with Echo Dots because I love being able to walk around and trigger actions/music wherever I am. The only problem with this is that obvious the dots are on and listening at all times. I wanted a way to quickly disable all dots and enable them all, without needing to go around turning things off.I work from home sometimes and some of the discussions I have are sensitive, so I need to ensure all the Alexa voice control items are off when I'm working. My solution was to buy one of these for each dot, and then using the Alexa app, I can turn the dots on and off with one tap. When I start working I just open the app, I've grouped the plugs and I turn them off. When I'm done, just open it again and turn on.This works really well. Very happy.  My only complaint is that the plugs are quite large. To be fair I don't see how they could really make them much smaller, but they do stick out from the wall a considerable amount.
title: Setup and use, could not be easier

author: Here, There, & Everywhere
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: **Update:  While I still love this smart plug, unfortunately it does have an irritating feature. When we lose our Wi-Fi signal, the switch turns off automatically.  We have other smart light switches and such, but they don't automatically shut off if there is a disruption in the Wi-Fi like this smart plug does (you just can't voice control them when internet is out, which is obvious) .If our internet is out, you can manually turn the plug on with the button (located on the side of the plug), but then it will auto shut off after awhile, even though we physically turned it on.  It's pretty annoying at times.*Original Review:  I received this smart plug when I ordered another Echo Dot.I love it.  I plugged it in (and then plugged my cabinet lights into the smart plug) and my echo dot knew that I had plugged it in.Alexa asked me what I wanted to name it and set everything up for me.  I didn't even have to go to the app or enter anything on my own.These do stick out from the outlet more than an average plug, but it's fine with me.I'm definitely going to pick up a few more of these to put through out my house.
title: Super Easy Set Up, but Will Auto Shut Off if We Lose Internet/ Wi-Fi Signal.

author: Radologist
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2020
review_content: I liked this product up until 6 months later when at 12:30am the plug blew out and almost caused an electrical fire. I use it everyday to control my LED light which I leave on for 12 hours a day and use my Alexa or app to turn off. It’s never been unplugged or touched. My outlet still works, but the plug and the light plugged into it are completely toast :/
title: Burnt out almost caused a fire

author: Sue Z. Q.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
review_content: This outlet was super easy to set up with Alexa. I didn't have to install any other special apps. The Alexa app itself loads terribly slow but at LEAST adding any devices with it is quick. So with just a few taps it was installed; picked up the plug riiiight away. I was able to program it with Alexa routines to turn some lights on and off whenever I wanted. Again; NO need to install any other apps, yesss!!  When power starts going through the outlet, there IS a tiny 'bump' sound, like you would hear if you've ever used any type of timers for your appliances, but otherwise, no noises or ticks like old timers. The plug itself is pretty huge and feels solid, but at at least it doesn't cover up the other receptacle on the outlet. I would totally buy more of these if the price went down again to $5 hehe.
title: convenience, and easy to use

author: Durr Adoya
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2019
review_content: **First off, please note ahead of time that you MUST have a router with 2.4G and that this setting is enabled or you will not be able to get the smart plug to work.** I'm saving you the hassle I went through.  XDSecondly, the plug will only work on things that turn back on automatically when plugged in. So it might not be effective for devices like TV's, speakers, computers, or game consoles. I use this plug to turn a room heater off/on and will be using it when I switch to a fan during the warmer months.Third, this plug has 3 prongs so you can only use 3-prong outlets. An adapter can be added for 2-prong outlets. The smart plug will stay snugly attached to the adapter, however it will look clunky and a bit unsightly.The huge plus in my case is that this is the only thing I've ever bought that works perfectly with Alexa each and every time. Considering the constant connectivity problems with Alexa and my FireTV box (both made by Amazon), I was hesitant to purchase this smart plug. It also seems safe enough, as it doesn't get hot while being used.I'm happy with this purchase. I payed twenty bucks and it's a good buy.
title: Works Extremely Well With Alexa!

author: Cowboy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020
review_content: The Alexa enabled smart plug is a neat product, but far from perfect and I don't see the value when paying full price.  I have two installed on lamps in the house and one seems to recognize the commands just fine, while the other is like a child and requires being told several times.  I'm not entirely sure if this is an Alexa problem or a smart plug problem, but nevertheless it is frustrating.When working properly, it does add a level of convenience by being able to turn on/off a lamp with just your voice.  Besides the lamps, I cannot find too many practical purposes for this device since there aren't many items plugged it that need a switch.  Both switches were purchased on Prime Day for $5 so they were a good value, but I don't see these as being worth the regular price.Overall I would say this is a three star product
title: Neat product, but not that neat to justify the full price.

author: Kimberly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2019
review_content: I have an Echo Dot (Second Generation) and paired this plug with my TV. Setup for the device is straightforward and easy. I noticed two issues when using the smart plug these past two days:1. You have to make sure, when using the plug, to turn on/off the device the same way. For example, I turned on my TV using my Echo Dot then, out of habit, turned it off manually before going to bed. When I tried to turn the TV on using the Echo Dot the next morning, it wouldn't work. I saw a blue light on the plug, which I realized meant the smart plug still thought the device (my TV) was on. I ended up having to tell the Echo Dot to turn my TV off (even though it was already off) and then I could tell it to turn back on. With my Smart Plug being behind the TV, the blue light was hard to notice. With that said, I now realize what to do next time this issue arises.2. The other issue is my Echo Dot decided to either update or restart today. When that occurred, the TV instantly shut off, in the middle of an intense gaming session no less. So customers should be mindful of this when deciding what appliances to use the Smart Plug with.All in all, it works as intended. I will likely end up switching the plug to another appliance (like my lights) in case the Echo Dot updating/restarting issue is a regular occurance. I've never noticed my Echo Dot updating in the past, so it may have just been poor luck.
title: Overall good

author: Steven R. Russum
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2019
review_content: Ordered a Alexa Smart Plug and it arrived two days later.  Packaging was fine.  Was as described in the ad.  I read the directions, plugged it into the wall outlet, plugged a lamp into it with a 40w bulb in it and blue sparks started flying.  Never got a chance to see if it worked or not.  I got onto Amazon’s return instructions and followed them to a tee and two days later had another brand new plug in my mailbox.  UPS came by and had a return label.  All I had to do was package the defective plug up and hand to him.  Amazon paid the return shipping.  I plugged the new plug in.  I plugged the same lamp into it and it was recognized by my Echo Show and now I control that lamp by voice.  It cost me $19.99 and I would order another one if I needed it.  When I come home now with a armload of packages I can turn that one light on by voice to see what I’m doing.  It also features a dimmer option so you can have that full on bright or a very low background light.  The bulb I’m using is soft white.  I don’t have a need for one of those 8 million color Hue bulbs but this Alexa Smart Plug would handle it if need be.
title: Alexa Smart Plug works great by voice command

author: S. Ghoddoucy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2019
review_content: I have 2 of these smart plugs, each controlling a table lamp. Setup and voice control are very easy with Alexa. I love that it doesn’t require a third party app or account—it just connects directly through the Alexa App. This plug only works for things that turn on/off with a mechanical switch, as opposed to a toggle. So most lamps are great.The plug connects through 2.4GHz WiFi, and it doesn’t seem to have a super strong antenna. So if your WiFi network is congested, slow, or spotty, this plug won’t reliably work. I initially put one of these in a bedroom and it worked fine for a couple days. Then it got disconnected and couldn’t hold a WiFi connection in that spot for more than a minute. Checking the WiFi status through the Alexa app, it looked like the plug was getting zero WiFi reception though my iPhone showed full WiFi reception in the same spot. I moved the plug to another room, and it’s been working fine. But strong WiFi reception is key to this plug functioning.These plugs are a nice way to ease into home automation without spending a lot of money and effort. I’d recommend them for a couple devices here and there, but not for deployment en masse due to their reliance on WiFi.
title: Fast and easy to use, with some limitations

author: Starlet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: Great plug and easy to use. 🔌 💕  i wanted to show how easy the instructions are and set up.Just make sure you have the latest update of the Alexa app. All you need to do is plug it in, download the latest alexa app, then tap the devices icon on the lower left and follow a few steps. That will pair the plug device to your amazon devices.I love using this device by turning on and shutting off my living room lamp by asking alexa. It just makes life easier by using your voice. Amazon was really nice as they sent this to me as a promotion. This has been a Great plug and a nice edition to my family life! 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦😍😍 👍🏻 If my review was helpful, please hit the like Like button (thumbs up) 😃 ❤️Thank you so much,Starlet 🌸
title: Great plug 👍🏻❤️🌟 Pairs up easily 💕

author: David W. Nesbitt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2019
review_content: I've now got all the Great Room light (including 2 can lights) set-up. It was very easy - the 2 can lights were a little tricky as there were not Alexa light bulbs. But once I downloaded the app they work great.I expect this will be a big help next winter when we come home and the house is dark. My wife can turn them on in the garage or when she first gets in the house. It does seem Alexa responds to male voice a little better which has led my wife to say Alexa must not like her (LOL).I just set-up one of the plugs in our bedroom and plan on doing more of them over the next several months.I would give this a very rare (for me) a 10 out of 10 - hard to imagine this being much better!! The only thing I can add is to wait until this goes on sale!
title: This is GREAT!

author: J.D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2019
review_content: Unfortunately, I made the mistake and went all in on TP Link smart plugs (own around 12 of them) and initially they worked well. However, as I've added more TP Link plugs they disconnect from my network and never attempt to reconnect. I've attempted to reset them, ensure my wifi strength is adequate, nonetheless, they disconnect.I purchased an Amazon smart plug as part of a new Echo Dot bundle and I have not had one single issue with connectivity. They work seamlessly with Alexa including all my routines; however, I wish they'd come out sooner before I wasted all this money on TP Link plugs. The only negative with the Amazon smart plugs is I cannot setup a sunrise or sunset timer option. I use these plugs as timers and one of my favorite features of the TP Link plugs was the ability for the plugs to adjust the timer as the days get longer/shorter. I have no doubt this is a feature Amazon will add in the future but it is curious it wasn't an option from the beginning; hence the 4-Star rating.I hope Amazon will have sales in the future and offer double packs at a discounted rate so I can convert all my TP Link smart plugs to Amazon smart plugs. Ultimately, if you have Amazon products including Alexa, don't waste your time with cheaper alternatives, go with the Amazon Smart Plugs and save yourself some frustration.
title: More Reliable Than TP Link

author: Diamond Jim
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2020
review_content: These things are fun but too bulky! You can’t use them in situations where you have other bulky plug-in devices. So many things require such oversized power bricks, meaning that if you want to plug another device in to that outlet, you’re out of luck. Similarly, if you have some other type of extension device that you would like to use with it, well, good luck! Until these things shrink to be low profile enough to allow them to be plugged in with other things, they will remain only a novelty item. Wifi, Alexa, voice control work perfectly. But none of that matters if you can’t plug it in! For something intended to be a permanent installation, it should instead integrate into the outlet itself and sit behind the wall without blocking your ability to use the remaining space on an outlet.
title: Works Great...if you can plug it in.

author: JAS32
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2018
review_content: This is my first Amazon Smart Plug.  I have a handful of TP Link Kasa (plugs and switches) and SonOff devices installed.  This one is definitely easiest to install since you do not have to go through an intermediate step of installing it to another iOS app then in turn having the Echo to recognize the device.The reason for 4 stars (instead of 5) is mostly for the slowness of the Amazon Echo iOS app on the iPad/iPhone.  If you want to control this plug using your app, it takes about 15 secs for the Amazon app to be ready to control the plug.  TP Link app will be up and ready in about 5 secs.Granted the Amazon app is much more complex and controls quite a bit of devices.  Also if you use only voice commands via Alexa then this would not be an issue at all.  I know this is nitpicking but I thought I'd point it out just for awareness.
title: Works like any WiFi smart plug BUT....

author: Mr. Green 808
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2019
review_content: Very nice product by Amazon, I like how they made the shape and size to where if you had two plugged in it will perfectly cover your outlet. I do have to say as nice as these may be there are other brands that sell for almost half the price and I really hope that Amazon will see that and maybe be able to bridge the gap. They do work flawlessly with Alexa and are as simple as plugging in and naming, which maybe that's why they charge more because with the other plugs I have it does use a 3rd party app that you have to download and do the setup through it. But really if I could buy twice as many with a different name for the same price I think y'all know which way I'm gonna turn. All that being said they are very nice they are super easy to use, you just have to make the choice for yourself whether it's worth the price or not.
title: A little pricy but still..... nice.

author: Wellcraft19
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2020
review_content: It is a plug. It works. Do not use it as much as I had planned, but that will hopefully come.Biggest thing is that is is very easy to set up, connected to your Alexa app (or rather eco-system).It does support WiFi on both 2.4 GHz as well as 5 GHz which can be important for people not that familiar with networking, or for people using various Mesh products (like Eero) where same SSID is used regardless of frequency and one cannot turn off broadcast on 2.4 or 5 GHz independently (which is needed in order to ensure that phone connects to 2.4 GHz when setting up products that only supports the lower frequencies.
title: Easy to set up - and supports 5 GHz

author: Dan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2018
review_content: I would not recommend this product.  I bought it because the WeMo's were out of stock and have regretted it ever since. It set's up fine, easily in fact, but within a couple of hours it is flashing red and has to be deleted and re-added.  This has been going on for 3 days straight, I will be returning it.  I have 7 WeMo's and do not have any problems with them.*Updated review. I was reached out to by Amazon and offered a replacement. I have received the replacement and it works great. It seems the original one received must have been defective.
title: Works for about couple of hours then has to be reset.

author: BC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2020
review_content: I received my first Echo Dot along with the Smart Plug this week.  No trouble at all setting up the Echo.  But I've been trying to get the Smart Plug to work for an hour and a half.  I looked online for troubleshooting ideas.  I've tried countless times and ways but keep getting a "provisioning failure".A little embarrassed to say that the main reason I bought the Echo was to be able to vocally start my coffeemaker since I wake up at irregular times.  This was a terrible waste of my time and money.
title: Huge disapppointment

author: S.O.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2018
