review_content: My Amazon smart plug was incredibly easy to set up.  I was amazed as I have tried other brands that were so frustrating to install that I: 1) threw one out to trash and 2) returned one (realizing that throwing out a second was just dumb).  My Amazon plug was working great until...last night when I lost connectivity.  I tried operating (turning off the floor lamp) with Alexa, who just would not acknowledge my existence, and on my phone.  I admit it was late and I was heading off to bed, so I was a bit cranky, so I pulled the plug out of the socket.  I place it back and asked Alexa to turn the lamp off again and it work.  I am really hoping this will not be the norm.
title: Easy Set-up

author: A. Haney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: I would not buy them again.  Have three and they were simple to set up and connect to Echo.  Worked well for a week before all three lost connection suddenly.  Reading on the Internet this seems to be a common problem.  It said to reset the Smart Plugs to factory defaults then re-install them.  You can reset them to factory defaults in 12 seconds but to re-install them doesn't go as well as the first installation. I worked 3 hours on just the first one before I got it installed but then it still will not connect to Alexa.  I paid a lot of money for problems.Update:  I learned later that night about Amazon's massive Internet outage and believe that may have caused the Smart Plug problem.  They worked fine early that morning but mid morning all three stopped functioning at the same time.  What I said earlier was all true, I did read about others having a problem and how to correct it and I did follow all the steps.  It was only one plug that I worked on and in fact did the steps 3 times.  However, the next morning all three plugs were connected and working perfectly and still do.  I would have raised this to five stars but I haven't had them long enough to really test them.
title: Loses Alexa connection

author: JT Steve
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2020
review_content: I had two living room floor lamps that I used a Wink hub to control.  That worked through an app that allowed my Amazon Echo to control them by voice.  In late April or early May I got an email from Wink saying that the hub I bought 3 or 4 years ago would no longer work unless I strted paying $4.99/month.As I had ben having trouble with the hub dropping off of my wifi system recently, I decided to replace the hub with two of these Amazon brand smart plugs.  Two were less than the yearly payments to Wink would be for a hub that didn't always work anyway.No problems setting up the new ones.  They worked using the Alexa app on my phone after ust plugging them in.  The only thing I had to do was rename each light so that Alexa wasn't looking for the old names I used for the hub  .
title: Super easy install

author: Bronco Stirfry
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2020
review_content: Well I've only had this plug for 4 hours and now I know why Amazon offered it at the special price I paid for it. It continuously loses connection to my wifi. In the 4 hours since I've set it up I have literally only been able to successfully connect it two times and both times it lost connection after about 15 minutes.Both of my Amazon Echo works great but this plug has been a nightmare. I will try more tomorrow and will update my review it I finally get it to work.**Update** after seeing another review do this, I had to input my wifi information manually and it took and low and behold the plug hasn't lost connection since then. So I updated my review from 2 to 3 stars since it seems to be working now. So if you're losing connectivity, make sure you're not on your 5g WiFi connection and then input your WiFi information manually. Seemed to have worked for me and one other person in the reviews.
title: Cannot stay connected *UPDATE*

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2019
review_content: Just purchased this plug and am using it paired to an Echo Dot 2nd generation. It took all of maybe two minutes to set up, if that. I opened up the app on my phone, which I had previously updated according to directions, plugged the plug into the wall socket, followed the directions which popped up on the app, asked the Echo Dot to scan the plug, which it did, I plugged a lamp into the plug, and turned on the light. I then asked the Echo Dot to turn the light off and it did. Tested a couple of more times to turn the light on and off using the Echo Dot and all is well.The plug is on the wall down low behind a heavy piece of furniture in a room next to where my router and modem are located, but with a closet between the two rooms. However, it is very near the Echo Dot, which is on top of the piece of furniture in front of the plug.I will get more of these if the need arises. For sure. EDIT: I have since ordered five more when they were on sale down $5 over Valentine's Day. Time frame. I'm likely going to get one or two more when they go on sale again the next time. currently all are being used to turn lights on and off my only complaint is that in their routines that you can set up ahead of time, the only option is to either turn the light on or turn the light off. So far they cannot be used like a timer to be turned on AND off at specific times. They can only be turned on OR off at specific times.
title: Works perfectly!

author: Kimoeagle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2019
review_content: We're planning an overseas trip, and I decided to use two of these (TP-Link Smart Wi-Fi Plug Mini (Model HS105) to illuminate our home periodically. One of them works well (A), and KASA software discovered one.(A)..not the other (B).  I tried a) different locations, b) unplugging/replugging the unit, and using the Alexa app to supplement KASA. No luck whatsoever. The orange and blue LEDS light up, but the plug simply does not - apparently- transmit/receive a signal I have tried a location nearby by the router (10-15'). The functioning unit (A) is distant (30-49') and around the corner, and works as advertised.All of my other TP-Link devices work: router, 2 extenders and a Smart Plug.Conclusion: Item B Smart Plug doesn't work.
title: Sometimes you get the bear, sometimes it gets you!.....Daniel Boone)

author: Neil Waldhart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2019
review_content: I live in an apartment complex that has installed a Charter/Spectrum WiFi network (hundreds in the U.S.). No routers in the apartments, only an access point in one of the closets. To install a device like a printer, speaker, smart plug, etc., you must have the MAC Address of the device. That address has to be registered in a Charter/Spectrum database before installing the device. This Amazon smart plug, does not display the MAC Address anywhere on the device or in the box, therefore it can't be installed.In the install process, Alexa correctly finds the network that the device is on, but it cannot then connect to the device. The Alexa program needs to be changed to allow login at that point.FYI, TP-Link Kasa smart plugs have the MAC Address on the back of the device (very clever).
title: Doesn't work on Charter/Spectrum WiFi Network

author: Scottish Las
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2020
review_content: I bought one for turning on/off a neon "Open" sign light in my game room located in an alcove that I can not reach but has an electrical outlet nearby. I then changed the default name of the light to something I liked in the Alexa app.Liked it so much that I bought one for outside patio to separate patio lights from outdoor TV which has to use the same house electrical wiring circuit. The Amazon Smart Plug is more expensive than many others but I like having everything Alexa on one app. There is an Alexa Echo outside and the TV is older and requires a Fire Stick.I started out a beginner and now have gone off the deep end with these products. They work great. Just have a little bit of patience adding devices and properly name your smart home items from the get go.
title: Ease of use

author: John Ash
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2019
review_content: I have been using these plugs now for about four months and these are by far the best of all the smart plugs that I have tried. They do have the occasional connectivity issues but I simply unplug them and plug them back and everything works great again.  They work as advertised and work very well with any smart assistant that I have tried. Would highly recommend these to anyone looking to add smart plugs to their home.
title: Best of the bunch

author: Patrick R. Raley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2020
review_content: What is there to say that you don't already know? I guess one thing I can tell you is that patience may be required. I kept going through the installation process over and over and it would say it connected yet it would fail to respond over and over. Finally, I gave up and left it there and tried it on a whim the next day. Low and behold, the plug finally responded as it should. So in conclusion, if you feel like you are doing everything correctly and the plug is doing everything but the very last step, try going to bed and seeing if it connected overnight after the plug runs updates and whatever else. I am so used to having everything work immediately, I guess I am spoiled. Hopefully this helps save you some first-world problem frustrations.
title: Pretty Smart But Requires Patience

author: Alexander
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: Very cool, only bought it because of a special Amazon sale. Works really well and I love how I can voice activate a light downstairs as a I travel up and down stairs and also when exiting/entering the house. Definitely not a necessity but super cool to have. I integrate with Alexa- not sure how it works without an Alexa speaker device
title: Love It

author: FUN*RUNNER
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
review_content: I purchased this smart plug to use for plant grow lights.  I intended to simply use my phone to both turn on and off.....it worked great for several days (and I got comfortable) then one day I went about my day.....assuming the lights would be on like they had been.....OOPS !The lights were off all day due to the device losing connection.....maybe a wifi glitch? in any case.....this device STAYED OFF and didn't resume connectivity once wifi restored.  This is a BIG problem if someone is counting on the device they connect to remain in the on position !Now I have a useless plug......since there are no devices in my home I wish to control with my phone. Live & learn.  Luckily I got it as a Black Friday deal....so there is that.
title: Bummed.....loses connection.....can't use :(

author: J. Frank Shofner
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2019
review_content: I bought four outlets. I hooked one to the refrigerator, one to my Roku device, one to my cable box.  During setup, when I had the Roku and cable smart plugs on the same power strip, I could not complete setup for the second plug, I thought maybe they were interfering with each other, I don't know.  I moved the Roku plug about 3 feet away from the other plug using an extension cord. I got them all to register, so at that point the plugs were all registered on my Echo Alexa app, and were fully functional.  The next morning, I went to open the icebox to find it was powered off. I went to turn on the Roku and cable boxes and Alexa told me they were "unavailable," which was the case on the App.  What happened? Beats me.  I can't afford to leave town with the refrigerator plugged in apparently. I looked at my router, seemed fine. It is possible there may have been a power outage on the refrigerator plug, but the Roku/cable plugs are on battery backup.  Since there is no tech support option I am aware of, other than wasting time searching help and miscellaneous web pages, I will now pull the Amazon plugs and try some different smart plugs.
title: mystery disconnect

author: David
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2020
review_content: This works with the Echo dot, and the Alexa app. What annoys me the most is when it loses connection and shuts the plug off. Why would it function that way? I have great WiFi coverage, my router confirms the device is constantly at full bars, but if the internet connection cuts out for a bit, then it turns what is connected to the plug off, and I have to power cycle the device it to get it to work again? Shouldn't I only be unable to change the settings but the plug stays in the position it was before connection loss, and shouldn't it automatically regain connection once internet is back up? Annoying. Seems like its happened about once a month since got it. Otherwise it is very convenient, I don't know if they can fix this with an update or down the line or what. Would be nice.
title: Does what I want, some connection issues

author: AR
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2020
review_content: Does it work? Yes most of the time its quick to respond from Alexa and you can schedule routines, BUT it falls far short of being 'smart' in several ways:1) Isn't great about attempting to reconnect to the network, sometime have to manually unplug and replug.2) Making a simple schedule is ANNOYING at best.  Make a new routine, name it, throw it in the other stuff you programmed Alexa to do.  It gets messy fast.3) No fail-safe:  If your internet is out when a scheduled task should happen, then since the commands originate on Amazon's servers your plug won't change.  Unlike other plugs (At least TPLink) where the schedules are stored inside the plug, so as long as theres power the plug can keep to the schedule.  This is in my humble opinion a huge over sight to be considered reliable.PRO:1) I do like the sleek design and solid feel on both the plug and button.2) Very easy to pair
title: Yes its a basic smart plug that works - but I expected more from Amazon

author: B. Harrah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2020
review_content: Voice Recognition and User Interface values don't really apply to this, since those are part of Alexa/Echo. But the integration works great so far. I used it instead of a timer in the plug (in this case, I have a fan that I put on the dishes after the dishwasher is done ) but setting up a 'routine' in the alexa app (3 parts, 1) turn on <whatever you named the plug when you connected>, 2) wait 1 hour 3) turn off <whatever you named the plug when you connected>. Then I named that routine "Dry the Dishes" ... so now when the dishwasher is done, I just open it up, point the fan (that's plugged into this smart plug) and say "Alex, Dry the Dishes" , and voila (unfortunately, "Alexa, put away the dishes" still needs development).
title: Works well so far

author: Joe in Sacramento
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2020
review_content: Modern life is looking more and more like science fiction. The Smart Plug gives you voice control over any electrical device plugged into it. Like a si-fi movie, the Smart Plug makes it possible for Alexa, my 24/7 empathetic and intelligent virtual assistant to control just about and electrical gadget. Setup was amazingly easy. I simply plugged it in and Alexa knew immediately it was there. Alexa asked me to rename the plug to identify what it would control (I named it Christmas lights) and I was done. No more difficult than putting on your shoes. Now I simply say: "Alexa turn on the Christmas lights" and they come on immediately with Alexa telling me to enjoy the sunny day. Turning them off is just as easy. Simple and simply amazing.
title: Simple and simply amazing Alexa voice control for electrical gagets

author: Brian Z.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2018
review_content: Like this so much I bought a second one. I already have several Amazon devices. So when I unpacked this and plugged it in it already knew what wifi to connect with. NICE. Showed up in my Alexa app without me doing a thing. NICE. All I had to do was add routines to turn it on and off. That is where it gets a bit complex. Took me only a few minutes to figure it out. But if your not technically minded then I think it would be frustrating. Hint, you find the plug under "Smart Home".For the power user you will appreciate the tremendous capability and flexibility the Alexa routines give you. I have one of the plugs set to turn a terrarium light on in the morning and off and bed time. The other plug turns on and off a hot water pump at various times of day, night and weekends. But I could have tied it to my garage door opening or just about any other trigger under the sun.
title: No other app needed but setting up Alexa routine it not intuitive

author: Kris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2018
review_content: Set it up for my grandparents who were having network issues with a Wemo device. They don't have a smart phone (nor do any relatives nearby). I was hoping to set this up via the Alexa webpage for them so that they could fix it on their own, but that capability doesn't seem to be there yet (even after the device is recognized by Alexa). It would be helpful if there were more extensive set-up tips. I did not formerly have the Alexa app set up (because I don't really want it on my devices), so I set up the plug via the app, but I did not realize that I also had to connect their Alexa device to my tablet for it to work (not obvious via the directions). Both devices have to be set up in the app for the Alexa device to be able to operate the plug -- the Alexa device doesn't just "discover" it once you run through the set-up dialogs for the plug (so I had to go online for instructions of how to connect Alexa to my tablet). After that, it was fine. I was able to rename the plug to "light" so that my grandparents can just say, "Alexa, turn on light". The set-up probably took 45 minutes though of trying to figure out whether Alexa needed "skills" (which looks to be a hodgepodge of apps of dubious quality) or if the plug was the problem or if Alexa needed to "discover" the device from her end... or what... I think that their "easy set-up" assumes that you are already running Alexa on your smartphone and interfacing with her there... and the Microsoft store Alexa app looks nearly useless unless you just want to talk to Alexa on your computer (instead of work with peripheral devices including Echo). It could use some work on the software development end to make it accessible & easy to set-up/use on any device or via the web (and make Alexa able to "discover" it on her own if you ask her to)...
title: Set-up still leaves something to be desired

author: Southern Girl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Worked great for months, so we decided to buy a second. Installed fine this morning, bed stand light turned on and off when I gave Alexa the command. Walked back into the bedroom an hour later and the LED plug light was blinking red. Tried to reinstall, nothing worked. It was unresponsive. Then I walked into my husband's office and his plug was blinking red too, it had worked for 6 months perfectly. Tried to reinstall it, nothing worked. Something happened on Amazon's part: either a firmware update gone bad or the Alexa app update was bad or Amazon's cloud was bad.  At least four hours of my life wasted.Edited 11/27/2020 They are both working fine now. Evidently Amazon had a cloud problem and fixed it by nightfall.
title: Stopped working today Nov 25 2020

author: Tom
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
review_content: When I received my new Smart Plug that I got such a great deal on during Prime Day, I was eager to open it. I did so without my reading glasses and just skimmed the box at arm's length. I sat down with it and my phone and proceeded to install. I plugged it in and scanned the QR code and it locked onto the local Xfinity hot spot instead of my WiFi. Several tries and resets later, I got out the old Fire tablet. When I tried with it, I got an "Invalid Pin" error. That told me it was wifi. I had set my Echo 5 up on the 5GHz band of my dual band router. Once I reset the Echo and logged in into the 2.4GHz side, the plug set up with no problem. So, the box has 2.4GHz printed on it but the quick guide does not. I set mine up on the lamp close to the night table with the Echo. I played around with the skills and now have it so that I only have to say "computer, lights" (yes, I grew up in the 60s) for it to turn on, "lights off" and "goodnight" to turn the lights off and start some sleep sounds music. The regular price is a little bit high for my liking but was a good deal during the sale.
title: It works only on 2.4 gHz which is only printed on the box and not the quick guide

author: Margie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2020
review_content: Very simple set up. When it comes to design, Amazon didn't try anything new here. The plug looks very similar to what we've already seen in the market. It's a white rectangle with one power button and one LED indicator. Measuring 3.2 inches wide and 1.5 inches tall, the plug's space-saving design keeps adjacent outlets free for other devices.The Amazon Smart Plug can do what nearly any smart plug can these days in terms of scheduling, routines and remote control. Add the plug to an Alexa Routine or set a schedule for that plug individually from the Alexa app. In addition to scheduling and routines, you can control the plug remotely via the Alexa app to turn the plug on or off while you're away. If you're using Alexa in your home and looking for an affordable, reliable smart plug, this one will get the job done.
title: So worth the price. One of my favorite buys on amazon so far!

author: SarahWV
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2018
review_content: I have six plugs.  Three of them work fine, three of them only give me a "Provisioning Failure" (3:12:0:3) each time I try to connect them.  I've tried all of the advice I've found through Amazon Forums  -- uninstalled and reinstalled the Alexa app, restarted phone, tried connecting through home computer, set phone to 24 hour time, pushed side button  on plugs for 12 seconds, unplugged and tried again, used barcode method and non-barcode method, manually entering my wifi password, removed my phone from the battery case -- with each new method trying all three plugs multiple times ... I do appreciate the three plugs that work, they're very useful and make my home work better for all of us.  But the three that don't have me so frustrated that the thought of sending them back to get MORE of this ... !!!!  I just don't want to do this again yet.
title: Half of Mine Work

author: Jamie connolly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2020
review_content: Quick easy setup. Works as well as most other Alexa enabled outlets. If you’re in the market this is as good as any and probably cheaper than the other ones you’re looking at. Also while most external smart outlets are a little bulky, this one is bulky in width only and won’t block the socket above or below it. Consider if installing in a double or triple ganged outlet that it could block the socket to the left of right. Other than that this one is good to go.
title: Good stuff!

author: Lewie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2018
review_content: The plug has a bright blue LED to indicate power is available. I couldn’t find a way to disable the light through the app. It lights up the whole bedroom. I was able to fix the problem by covering the light with several layers of tape.The plug doesn’t work with outdoor outlets that have covers. You’ll need a one foot extension cord to get it to work.What I love about this is a routine I have setup to control my lights and start a white noise machine when I go to sleep, and stop it when I wake up. The machine stays out of sight and I don’t need to get down to turn it on/off each day.
title: Blue lights bad for sleeping

author: zSprawl
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2019
review_content: For a simple on/off plug, the Amazon Smart Plug is the simplest plug I've ever setup. Literally just plug and play.For any device that you use, where the default setting is off, it works fine. For example, I have it on my printer, which is normally powered off. However, I also have it connected to a camera where the default setting is on. However any time the wifi signal gets weak, for any reason, and the plug loses wifi connection, it will shut off the device plugged in.
title: Loss of Wifi Signal will Power Off Device

author: Warren Weigel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: I dislike that the product suddenly won't connect properly.  I just cancelled an order for the 3 more plugs I had ordered for Christmas (I currently own a total of 6) and it was very difficult to add the last new one.  Now one that I've owned for two years has gone offline and refuses to connect properly.  I've gone through the setup multiple times and one of two things happen: 1) Alexia find the plug then says the device is unresponsive or 2) Set up fails with a provisioning error 3:11:500:3 - what ever that may mean.  I've deleted and reinstalled the app from my phone, rebooted my modem and router.  After doing that ALL of my plugs failed.  As a last resort, I've completely disconnected, unplugging and deregistering both of my Alexia devices.  I successfully registered the echo dot, and plugged in one plug.  It did an auto device discovery and then returned a Provisioning Failure.I was finally able to contact support via my Alexia App.  They were very polite and when pressed admitted it was their technical glitch and asked me to to try again in 'a few hour hours'.  After 12 hours I tried again and was able to connect and configure as desired.  I'm still disappointed that it occurred, that it corrected without any explanation and my biggest fear is that it will occur again.  But for now it's working properly and I can say my issue is resolved.
title: Proceed with caution

author: Leithead Family
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
review_content: Easiest installation ever- I selected the option to have it pre-integrated into my Alexa app, and when it showed up, I simply took it out of the box, plugged it in, plugged my lamp into it, and my Echo told me it connected, before proceeding to let me rename it, and that was it. Boom. Done. I am a parent of two small children and help run a large business, so I'm active enough... but this opened a whole new world of beautiful laziness I didn't even know existed, masking it by making someone look more "fancier" and technologically inclined. Genius. I love it. I want 50 of them now! I ordered on a whim when I got the ad that they were $5 if you ordered through Alexa, and I'm really kicking myself for not ordering more!
title: If you enjoy being a lazy POS like I do, this is for you!

author: H Roller
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2020
review_content: I love having smart home control using Alexa, and this integrates right in.  However, a problem I have is that my internet provider only allows 8 devices total (including my computers, my echo dots, my smartplugs, my printer, ect) to be connected on my internet plan.  So it's a problem that each plug uses up one of the allowed connections.So although the Amazon plugs are cheaper, I've recently been using a philips hue hub to control hue smartplugs.  The reason is that the hue hub only takes one internet connection, and then I can connect many lights and plugs (controllable through alexa) without using up an internet connection for each one.  My internet provider simply doesn't now how many things connect to the hub.
title: Works, but problematic if your internet provider limits the total number of connected devices

author: Mo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2018
review_content: I bought this to replace a smart Lutron plug for a lamp in our family room that did not work consistently. The Amazon plug was very easy to set up and turns the lamp on/off with every request from Alexa, unlike the Lutron. My only disappointment is that the plug does not have a dimming feature which the Lutron did, I can't dim the lights on the lamp. Other than that, so far so good but I do wish that Amazon comes out with a dimming option.
title: No dimming if used for lamps

author: EDISONTECH
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2020
review_content: Not surprised that it wasn’t compatible with Google Home..... anyways, on to the review- of a smart plug! It does what you think it does. It turns on and off objects with a voice command. I connected these to my RGB lights as I wanted to control them with voice instead of the remote. All I have to say is “Alexa, turn on RGB lights” and they turn on! I just have to say the opposite to turn them back off. I renamed the smart plug to RGB lights as then it could respond to that. It feels very well built as well. There is also a way to manually turn on and off the plug with the side button. I have it pretty close to the router so no issues so far and response is almost instant. Overall, great plug with a amazing price for Black Friday! Still wish it did Google Home but oh well...
title: Great Smart Plug!

author: Shawn Maus
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2020
review_content: How are people turning on their lights, locking their doors, and operating the coffeemaker just by the sound of their voice?  I thought this technology was only available to the Bil Gates' or Steve Jobs' or the other rich and famous of the world. But no, it' here for me as well, thanks to the Amazon Smart Plug!I took advantage of an intro offer for the Amazon Smart Plug. I plugged the plug into my bedroom wall socket to control two lights. I'm always doing the toss and turn, reach over the dog, Olympic-style maneuvers to turn off the lights at the end of the night. But with my Echo, Amazon Frames, and Alexa, I can close my book, get comfortable on the pillow and tell (in a nice way) Alexa to turn off the lights.The device was simple - just plug into the outlet (in my case I added a three plug adaptor to control the two lights) and Alexa talked me through the rest of the setup. Quick and easy!I'm going to order more to connect my whole home. Take that rich and famous! I can do this without the click of a button!
title: It's no longer about the click of a button

author: Zak
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2019
review_content: I used the plug to remotely control the large TV in our living room. We have a surge-protected multi-outlet extension cord into which a number of devices are plugged including an older 42" flat screen TV. We used to have to walk over and trip the switch on the extension in order to completely shut-off the TV or turn it on. We do that because the TV uses electricity even when off and throws off heat affecting our nearby thermostat.With the multi-outlet extension plugged into the Alexa controllable plug, I just tell Alexa to "turn on first plug" or "turn off first plug" and it does the job for us. Very convenient and, so far, very reliable.  The plug connected to Alexa and my wifi first time around with no problems. I got the plug during Prime Days and it was a great deal.
title: Easy to set up

author: Bezoar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2020
review_content: This was the easiest smart plug ever to set up.  I didn't have to press and hold a button to get it into set up mode.  I already had the Alexa app installed so there was nothing else to download.  Since I had previously setup Amazon Echo devices, my Wi-fi network and password was already known to Alexa and she immediately found the smart plug, set it up and it was ready to go.  There was no need for a third party app or Alexa skill since it's already in the Amazon ecosystem. All I had to do was to figure out where I wanted to put the plug, what to plug into it and what to rename it as. Best yet, it was only $5 on Prime day when purchased with an Echo Flex.  It works great under app or voice control.  I'm happy.
title: This was the easiest smart plug ever to set up.

author: rv8tor
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2020
review_content: My mother in law is 94 and staying with us because of Covid-19. This plug-in works with the Alexa her grand children bought her for Christmas. I use it to control LED lights located in two different cabinets both her favorites. One is too low, the other is too high. When she goes to bed she just says (or should say...read on) " Alexa light off" or conversely "Alexa light on". This works nicely except that my Mominlaw tends to want to converse with Alexa rather than just issue commands. It isn't polite you know. Still, she has gotten the 'hang of it' and maybe just as important, this experience has opened my eyes to the possibilities for really helping people contained within many of these new technology devices. Given all that, not a bad purchase at all.
title: A device that can really help people

author: Crystal
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2019
review_content: I’ve always wanted to catch up with technology but since I live a VERY old school life and often off the grid have never found any real use for things like this. After all,  I got my first dot last year. This year I saw this plug for .99 cents so I thought what the heck, I’ll get 2 and try. I really love them so far. It’s a fun convenience to have. It connected right away and super simple set up. That was the best part for this old school gal. I don’t much like trying to figure technology out. Hahahah!  Thanks for the promo Amazon. If you targeted me more I might be more inclined to try things. Isn’t everyone down for a bargain?! LOLL! Just so everyone knows, I was not paid for this review, just a lucky customer in the right place at the right time. 🙃
title: A fun convenience for someone who lives off the grid half the time.

author: Robert M. Lopez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2018
review_content: Update: Amazon came through with outstanding support. Extremely responsive with clear and realistic tech support, not the typical "did you plug it in?" type, which I recognized and appreciated. Replacement device works as advertised and I will be ordering more for the rest of my shop and house.Original post:Had high expectations for this one but so far it's a disappointment. I have updated my Alexa app, followed the instructions, checked the forums and searched the web and I'm still not able to get this to work. The app won't see the device at all. I was on the preorder list for this, I was happy to see Amazon distribute it's own version, even if it might be a rebrand. I figured their name on the product gave it some credibility. That is not the case in my situation. I'll continue to try to see if I can find a solution but for now I would look elsewhere. There is an Amazon branded security camera as well, I passed it by and purchased another brand because of this experience.
title: Outstanding support and great device!

author: jon g
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2019
review_content: After trying cheaper models, gettin frustrates and sending them back I swallowed my pride and ponies up for actual Amazon Alexa outlet plugs.Best decision I’ve made.There was no downloading of third party apps, no endless “device not found” notifications.  Really just plug and play- the way it should have been.These were up and running in under five minutes using my already installed Alexa app.  I can’t begin to describe how much easier these outlets were to set up and use.Take my advice and stop trying to save pennies with those unworkable knock offs.  Spent the extra to get plugs specifically designed for your Alexa.You won’t be disappointed!
title: Worth the extra money

author: DAC
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2020
review_content: This is how a smart device should be. Set was a breeze- just plugged it in, my Echo asked me a question (I don’t recall the question but I think it had to do with naming) and in 2 minutes was using my voice to control Christmas lights. Later I went into Alexa app to categorize and change the name. Not in love with usability of Alexa app but that’s a different review.This plug can carry a decent sized electrical current and ratings for resistive, inductive, and motor loads are listed in the instructions.I love the fact that when I buy via Amazon the Amazon device is already registered and ready to go on my network via the Alexa integration and when I buy as a gift is super easy to deregister.
title: Quick and easy setup

author: Travis J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2019
review_content: I bought 3 of these.  The first one controls a lamp behind the TV, and a stereo amp that give us great sound for the TV.  It works great!  We just tell Alexa to turn on first plug or turn off first plug and she does automatically.  No more reaching around the TV to turn on the lamp, or opening the cabinet to turn on the amp.  We ordered 2 more to control air conditioners.  The living room air conditioner is hard to reach, and its nice to have alexa turn on the bedroom air 30 minutes before we go to bed.  The problem though is that after about an hour of running the living room air conditioner, the switch got very hot and failed.  That made me worry about fires.  After it cooled down it began to work again.  We took them off the air conditioners and currently the only one we are using if the TV light and Amp.  We couldn't find anything in the documentation that described any load limits.  I think Amazon needs to warn customers about such things.  When it works on a light load though, it works great and is a great convience.
title: Don't use them for a heavy load.

author: iREViEST
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2019
review_content: hey, after echo dot, I was looking for perfect smart plug and what can be better than amazon smart plug itself, So far I have been using this plug for tower light ans its has been working great.Setup process was really easy and I was able to set it up under a min using my ALEXA app.SIDE NOTE: I would like to make a suggestion as a customer to Amazon that why cant they offer this kinda basic smart home devices (echo dots, smart plugs) at "Non profit price" .So more people can try this and adapt towards amazon smart echo system and I guess that's how amazon can easily grow and attract more customer base toward their echo system, as I really that think that we are moving towards smart home things but slowly So someone big like amazon has can definitely speed it up by making to affordable to max consumers.
title: First smart plug, and Amazon nailed it.

author: Charlie H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2020
review_content: Best part? So easy to sync-up! Works as designed. Sync-up and forget it - you can take for granted that it's gonna work without fail... I used mine for my CLOTHES DRYER that wouldn't shut-off anymore, rite by "drynees sensor" OR timer - we could no longer leave the house if we had stuff in the dryer! But now, we can have Alexa turn offb the dryer! Mind you, Alexa DOESN'T have the skill, suck that, "Alexa, turn off the dryer in 30 minutes" and I don't know WHY - seems simple enough, but... Still, we can set a timer on our phone, then bring h up the Alexa app, turn off the dryer from wherever - then, turn it back ON again, for normal operation (you if course have to turn in the dryer, manually - but if you forget to turn the plug back on, you might scratch your head, trying to figure out why the @#$! dryer won't go ON, now..!)
title: Easy to sync - completely reliable operation!

author: Kevin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019
review_content: This smart plug I have it connected to my bedroom fan controlled by Alexa. I hate having to get up out of the bed to turn on the fan once I’m already laying down. The setup is very easy, I had had to do was open my Alexa app and press and hold the sync button on the plug. Once I did the that the app picked up the plug in the matter of seconds. So now with my voice or cell phone I can turn it on or off my fan with no problem. I plan on getting more of these plugs to setup in my hallway and kids room if they want to turn on the fans too. You can also setup a schedule to turn on and off automatically if you want. Great product easy to use and setup will definitely recommend this to family and friends.
title: Works great buying more soon!!!

author: Heartland Indiana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2018
review_content: Got this specifically for use with my Amazon Echo Plus. It was straight forward and connected with no problem, no third party wanting my Email or membership. I'm starting to see that some of the "Alexa compatible devices" REQUIRE you to join (membership) another 3rd party website but NOT this one. It shows in my Alexa app and I just say, "Alexa fan on". Some of my "works with Alexa" cameras, motion detectors etc require another signup with the maker. It's not a big deal except just another party to have my email and another ID and password and URL to remember. I did this with Wyze for a couple of cameras, which do work great and a great value.Update: Removed 2 stars. Erratic operation and problems getting them to connect. Some do, some don't. Too pricey to have these problems. One still has the old update.
title: It has the Amazon logo!

author: David C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2020
review_content: Update 12/13/20: They both stopped working. I had to reset many times. Now they will connect at all with many attempts. Very disappointed that Amazon would have a low quality product like this. I messed around with other less expensive plugs that did not work. Finally bought these. Pricey but they work great. You get what you pay for. I use them for under cabinet lights in my kitchen, nice not having to click them all on. Naturally they work great with Alexis.Update 5/27. I have ti knock two stars off because I had to reset two plugs after 3 months and now I am resetting one plug. No apparent reason, no power outages or changes to the ap. It is very annoying because it takes numerous attempts to get them reset. Sometimes deleting and then reloading the ap. I paid double what other plugs cost so I expected more.
title: Pricey but they work the best

author: GoBeavers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2019
review_content: Easy to setup; work flawlessly with Echo and Alexa app.  Down sides: the plug size esp. the width; constant high pitch buzzing sound.  Prefer KASA.(Updated): Amazon rep contacted me within 24 hours after the first review.  They asked about the detail of the problems I had reported and offered a replacement.  The replacement plug came in a day later.  It was working OK and much much quieter than the previous one.  I could still hear the tiny buzzing sound only if I have my ear 1 inch close to it.  Anyway, great support from Amazon.  Hope they will improve their design.
title: Noisy plugs

author: Butterflykisszz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2020
review_content: Will not connect no matter what I do. I searched and searched and tried all the trouble shooting out there (there is tons because this is obviously issue and has been since at least 2018. I mean, it’s 2020 now so what do I expect? Everything that can go wrong, will go wrong in 2020.I have an Echo Show and a Dot. Was hoping adding the plug into the mix would be as easy as set up was for both of my devices. Nope! I even have both 2G and 5G options and used only the 2G as others have suggested. Still won’t work.I’ve held the button 12 seconds to reset. I’ve plugged in and unplugged and signed out of the app. I’ve waited for the red and blue lights. I’ve talked nice to it. Pet it. Made it breakfast. The thing refuses to connect to the network. It’s maddening. My plug came with my Echo Show. It wasn’t worth the hour I’ve spent trying to get it connect. Or the time I’ve spent searching the topic. I hate it.
title: Won’t connect. Worthless.

author: Amy M.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2020
review_content: Literally the coolest gadget you never knew you needed.My husband used to sarcastically say, "Alexa, turn the lights off" when we were too lazy to get out of bed to do it... and NOW it's an actual reality!You can rename each plug to whatever you want, so I named mine "light".Just say, "Alexa, light OFF/ON" and viola! Done. Obviously you can do this with whatever item you'd want to plug in, set timers, etc... it's quite nifty.I don't know how I lucked out and got it for .99 cents the day I bought it- but I tell you, as cool as it is- I'm not sure I'd go as far as to pay the full price of $25 dollars.Soooo, if you're totally committed to the Alexa lifestyle- WORTH it.But if you're on the fence about purchasing and think the price is a little steep- meh, you'll probably be okay without it!
title: Pretty Neat-o.

author: TFran
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2019
review_content: I bought this for some of the items in my room that aren't within reaching distance from my bed, like my lamp and a small tower fan. The plugs work nicely for things with simple manual switches, but anything that has an electric on/off button doesn't seem to work. With my lamp, all I had to do was switch it on, then give the command to my plug to turn on and off, but the fan has an electric on/off button, so even when I ask Alexa to turn the plug on, I still have to press the button on the fan which defeats the purpose of the voice command. Basically, Alexa is just controlling the power going to the fan, not the fan itself. Also, I thought the plug could be controlled "hands-free", but this is not the case. You still have to open the app, touch the icon to activate Alexa, then speak your command. In the time it takes to do this, you could probably just get up and turn on your appliance. *shrugs* I guess I just expected too much from what I thought would be a really helpful little gadget, it works but it's nothing I'd brag about.
title: Meh

author: Dana Rock
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2020
review_content: This is the second one I've purchased. I've had some trouble getting Alexa to call it what I want, but I think there is just a learning curve. They work though. In the living room, all I have to say is "Alexa turn on the lights" and in the bedroom I have to say "Alexa, turn on second plug". I want to rename the one in the bedroom to "Bedroom", but it is not apparent how to do that. Like I said, a learning curve. Anyway, I highly recommend it.
title: Pretty nice addition to the Alexa ecosystem

author: Full Village
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2020
review_content: After using the smart plug for a few months, I found that while the smart plug has some potential, it does unfortunately lack a few features. As far as I know, there is no way to schedule the smart plug to turn on at a preset time nor is there a way to turn it on for a set amount of time.The lag between an Alex command and the device turning on or off is very minimal, almost unnoticeable even though the command has to traverse through Amazon's servers before reaching the smart plug.I really would like to see 5G Wifi integration on the next version of the smart plug. The fact that this functionality is not included seems like a cost cutting measure by Amazon or the manufacturer.
title: Lacks a few features, but still a great buy for a smarter home.

author: Sarah Barlow
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2019
review_content: I bought 2 of these plugs. One kept becoming unresponsive .Amazon replaced it. Now a couples of months later the same issue again. I could have bought a third party smart plug for half the price of this one and now I wish I had, since these plugs really aren't any better. I called today and was told it was a technical issue being worked on. Well a message from Amazon would have been nice since I wasted my time trying to set it up several time.
title: Amazon Smart Plugs Unreliable

author: anonymouse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
review_content: The form factor for this plug is great.  Using the Alexa app to setup the plug is okay.  The troubles I had setting up the plug was with Amazon and Spectrum (my internet service provider).  The Alexa app doesn't tell you the MAC address used by the plug, and my ISP required that I had this info.  A shame Alexa hides such info.  I blame both Amazon and Spectrum for such a horrible experience.I was able to get everything to work after I created a private wifi network using a TP-Link wifi extender.  For whatever reason, that made everything work like a charm.  I give this plug a 4 star rating over all for it's form factor and relative ease of use when the network configuration is simple.  However, if you're forced to use a managed network like what Spectrum provides to some customers, I highly recommend looking into using a wifi extender or personal wifi router and have the plug connect to that.  Seems the plug doesn't play well with Spectrum/Charter equiptment.
title: Great plug once you get it working

author: M. Shigley
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
review_content: The Amazon Smart plug works very well.  WIth an Echo device already up and running, all you need to do is plug it in while logged into the Alexa App on your phone.  It automaticaly seeks out the Alexa network and all you have to do is name the device and assign it to any group.  I presently have three of them, and they control the floor lamps in my family room.  As I have them named individually and grouped in the famiy room; I can simply say, "Alexa, turn on family room light 1," or "Alexa, turn off all family room lights."  I would have one for every lamp in my house, except they are pretty expensive.  As I've been building out my smart home, I've been adding these smart plugs as they are offered with discounts for other purchases.
title: Works perfectly, but pricey

author: jsc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2020
review_content: The Amazon Smart Plug is very easy to set up and program routines to control with Amazon Alexa.  However, after a power outage the prior state is not automatically restored.  This is a royal pain since momentary power outages are rather frequent here.  Apparently Amazon argues that this behavior is a safety feature, which doesn't make sense to me.  At least Amazon should make the default state after a power outage an option.  That would seem to be a reasonable request since this smart plug is considerably more expensive than other brands.  I wonder if this is something that could be provided with a firmware revision?
title: A royal pain after a power outage

author: TMG
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2019
review_content: The Good: Once the plug is setup it works as expected.The Bad:The plug ships with old firmware and the setup process is horrid!The plug (as of 1-Jan-2019) ships with buggy firmware 1000012 that does not allow you to choose an SSID at initial config or change the SSID after it is set (proximity to WAP does not matter).  You must delete the plug and re-add hoping that it chooses the correct SSID the second time.  You may have to turn off one access point to force the correct one to be selected (2.4Ghz only).Calling Amazon support was frustrating.  The first agent didn’t know what an Amazon Plug was and had to do the normal interrogation process and account search for the purchase that is typical of today’s poor support industry.  The agent then transferred me to another agent who required that I explain my problem once again.  Although he had at least heard of the Amazon Plug, he did not know the product well enough to do anything other that search their database revealing the same lack of information available on Google.I was then put on hold for a good long time while being transferred to Advanced Support.  The Advanced Support agent was more knowledgeable.  He informed me that there was NO way to force a firmware update.  The plug just needed to be plugged in and inactive for some period of time so that it may update itself.  It took about an hour and the Alexa app needed to be restarted on the iPhone to see the update (it showed 1000012 (cached) even though the firmware was 1000015 until the app was restarted).I asked if I could RMA the plug and ensure delivery of a plug with the latest firmware.  The agent said no.Hopefully Amazon will address these software issues (at least 4) to bring the software up to the same standard as the solid hardware of the plug.
title: Amazon Plug, good hardware poor software/support

author: Dionisio L Yang
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2020
review_content: great deal for 10 bucks.  don't want to pay more than that.  There's other brands as this technology is getting cheaper.  Used this instead of manual timer box for my taco pump.  If you need anything that requires setting time schedules this is it.  I wish I can hook one up to my sprinkler system control.  Unfortunately you can't.  you technically could if the sprinkler system can be set on always on mode, but no such luck.Also have the bedroom lights connected.  Now the wife and I don't argue as to who has to get up and turn off the lights.  amazing.  I'm sold.  Just looking for good uses for these but other than that, there's nowhere else I can think of that could use this.
title: Got this when amazon had the introductory promo

author: Dave02301
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2020
review_content: I had another Alexa and Smart Plug (non Amazon) here in my Massachusetts home which worked well, but I brought them to my home in Florida. During Black Friday I purchased a 2nd gen Alexa and an Amazon Smart Plug figuring it would work together even easier. No way! First there were no real directions, just a barcode to read, which didn't read properly. The smart plug also kept jumping from the WIFI's connection to a local hotspot connection and causing an error. After weeks of playing with it I finally  got it connected. But, after I set a light on/off schedule, it kept losing it and I needed to reschedule it umpteen times. Anyway, it seems to be working OK now, but God forbid it loses it's power and programming and I may just throw it out?
title: Lots of problems with this one!

author: SuzanKen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2019
review_content: Oh my, I couldn't get Alexa on my cell to find my smart plug.  I searched and searched and found out it can't be done if you don't broadcast your SSID with a password.  I finally changed my wifi and still had connection problems.  You have to hit the button on the side til it flashes blue and red. of course that's not in the little 2 page 4" brochure. It did make me scan the 2D barcode a few times and it still wouldn't work. My phone was on Bluetooth, connected to wifi.  I don't know but I moved my cell that was 2' away from the plug to 1' and somehow it worked.  I had about given up on this.  OK, got that resolved. Then I had to figure out how to schedule so it would go on at a certain time I will say 10 pm and off at 1 am.  If you google this, it's rather vague, so here are the step to set-up a routine so it goes on and off which is REALLY two routines!!!Go to routine, select +, select when this happens, select schedule, select" at time", select your time, select repeat and indicate if it's every day, week day, weekend, or a select day. Select done, select next, select Add Action +, Select Smart Home, Select your Smart Plug, select if you want the plug to turn on or off. SAVE YOUR ROUTINESo, what you're doing is setting up 2 routines. One to turn on at a specific time/date and one to turn it off.It really shouldn't be this difficult.  I'm just glad I was able to get this to work!!!!  I attempted connecting when I bought this 3 weeks ago and it's been intimidating me every since.Amazon saves your passwords for routers, why doesn't it save your passwords if you hide your SSID.  It does for my Alexa, Fire Stick and Fire Tablet, but not my smart plug. Also this only works connected to a 2.4 GHz Wi-Fi network.. They do say that in the features but who would think to read through them. I guess lesson learned...OK maybe a few lessons learned.  I think I will really like this now, but I'm giving it 3 stars because the set-up was so frustrating.
title: Doesn't work hidden SSID with password and how to set-up a routine (schedule) SuzanKen

author: Justin B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2020
review_content: Figured getting a legit Amazon plug would be better than the offbrand smart plugs I use around the house, but I was wrong. Plugs that are half the price have been running fine for 6 months to a year, whereas I didnt even get 30 days out of the Amazon plug before it almost burnt my house down! Plug was hooked up to a box fan, nothing huge or with a large draw (0.8-1A) and the plug claims to handle 15A max. Not sure if i got a faulty one or what, the only Amazon brand one I've owned 🤷‍♂️ might be the last
title: almost burnt down my house

author: Phillip
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2020
review_content: To start, I am a tech guy and I love most of the Alexa products.  I bought this with high hopes but I got it installed and added to my Alexa app it didn't work.  I can manually turn it on and the thing I have plugged into it is on but the app won't control it......Yes, I have the correct Alexa device to run it.  Yes, I uninstalled and reinstalled several times but each time I go to the Alexa app it says that it is offline.  I don't know if I got a bad one but maybe other people have had the same problem.  I am going to send it back to see if I just got a defective one but I take these reviews very seriously and I try to be as fair as possible so I am just reporting what happened to me!
title: Dissapointed.......READ BEFORE YOU BUY!!!!

author: Colleen C.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Three weeks after installation, my smart plug just stopped working, and could not be reconnected. It's giving a "Provisioning Error" in the app, and after chatting with three support reps from Amazon, their only solution was to reset ALL of my Alexa devices, uninstall and reinstall the app on my phone, reboot, and REINSTALL EVERYTHING AGAIN. This is a ridiculous - I'm not going to spend all of that time reinstalling all of my devices just to *possibly* fix a single device that is clearly defective.I finally spoke to a representative that offered a replacement, only to be told the system is down and they can't process the replacement at this time. This is unacceptable, Amazon.
title: Stopped working after three weeks

author: Colleen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2020
review_content: This smart plug is the absolute best.  I love the QR code in the back which seamlessly is picked up and processed by Alexa.  No downloading gun an extra app is fantastic!  I have Kasa plugs and WEMO.  WEMO failed over and over.  Had to keep resetting it.  Kasa is good, but multi step process through their app which I do not like at all.  I am replacing all these plugs with This Amazon outlet.  It’s more expensive, but for me worth the ease of use.  I currently have 3 plugs working different lights on the second floor.  I set it up to work each independently of the other or I can run the group to turn on/off at once by saying goodnight/good morning.  Great investment and I already bought more.
title: Easiest, quickest and best Alexa enabled smart plug!

author: M. Najjar
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review_content: I had a plug for a couple of months, and it randomly stopped working. I got a replacement from Amazon, and that didn't work either. My Echo Dot recognizes the device is plugged in and present, but I keep getting "connection errors" and it never works.I'd suggest getting a smart plug that ISN'T from Amazon, since this is the second Amazon device in the last month I've had randomly stop working because of an inability to connect to the network.
title: Doesn't connect to network

author: Janet L McDuff
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2019
review_content: I haven’t explored all of the opportunities to use Amazon Smart Plug but I do love.  I am using it in my family room.  I have a 3 way lamp plugged into it.  As I go to enter the room in the evening or night after dark, I just say, “Alexa, turn on First Plug,” and the lamp immediately comes on just as I start to enter the room.  I also like the fact that by not having to turn switches in the light themselves, the switch does break and bulb does not burn out as quickly.  Although the price of the Amazon Smart Plug is not bad, I don’t utilize them as much as I would if they were to reduce the price to a maximum of $15 by bundling in a package of multiples.  Note:  I also have the Phillips Hue lighting system. I use that primarily on my outdoor lights and a couple of rooms indoors.
title: Absolutely love the Amazon Smart Plug

author: ChuckRey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020
review_content: Very disappointed in lack of - actually no customer service from Mone at Amazon Chat.  Our systems are down we cant do anything for you, come back later.  For a 25.00 item this person stumbled all over themselves.  Would not say I will handle and get one out when the system comes back up or anything like that.  Look, it is only 25.00 but when you have invested in 10-15 of these, 6 echo shows, 1 echo flex, & 1 echo dot gen 3 and you get a hassle on a 25.00 item that says "we got you sucker" to the customer.  So i guess it has finally happened, Amazon has gotten so big that they are going to start with providing no support or customer service!  Very disappointed and will start to migrate I guess to the google home stuff.
title: Works fine for almost a year then stops and Amazon does not back up their products

author: Zach
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2018
review_content: I was shopping around for smart plugs to use in conjunction with my Amazon Alexa. I set up on these plugs from Amazon themselves because you didn't have to have a third party app to set up the plugs. this was something I was looking for is I didn't want to have to have three or four different apps to setup things and flip between them if needed to be reset or reconnected. Setup was very simple you just plug it in wherever you want it, plug the item in question into it like a lamp or fan. Then you simply open your Alexa app scan the barcode that came on the paper in the box and in a few seconds Alexa will inform you that she sees a new plug. Then inside the app you can change the name of a plug to fan or light or whichever appliance you have plugged in. Then simply say Alexa turn on whichever device you named it. While these plugs are pricier than most, and I wouldn't mind seeing a price drop in order to entice more customers into using these Amazon branded smart plugs, they're perfect for people like me who don't want to have to use different apps from different manufacturers to set everything up with Alexa. These simply use the Alexa app and nothing else.
title: Easy to use, no need for a dozen different apps to setup

author: Dominic J. Tantillo-Rodriguez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2020
review_content: I saw the promotion for weeks on the main home page for $0.99. This is the best purchase made because I can now turn on and off the light in our living room that is plugged in behind the couch without climbing onto the couch to turn it off every night. The light only had a switch near the top so it was not the easiest to reach. Now, I can tell Alexa to turn off and on the plug and solves my problem. Thank you Alexa and Amazon for making my life just a little but easier!!
title: Best purchase!

author: K Taube
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 2, 2019
review_content: Purchased this 6 months ago.  For 5 months it worked fine.  It ran the routine I had programmed in my Alexa app.  Now it won't stay turned on.  I turn it on and it will go through whatever routine occurs during the time it's on, but at some point within 24 hours it turns completely off.  I can turn it back on with the switch on the side, but it eventually turns off again.  Very disappointed.  I was hoping I could use these to assist my disabled husband with turning on and off lights, but I don't trust it anymore.
title: Doesn't stay turned on anymore

author: kindleman42
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2020
review_content: I made my home an Alexa Smart home last year, starting with Smart Things hub, and Z-Wave devices, and other brands of smart plugs.  Often they are very hard to set up and then be discovered by Alexa.  They frequently went off line, and most have stopped responding at all after just over a year. I bought these because they were from Amazon brand, and they are absolutely great!  I just plugged them in, and when I went to my Alexa AP, they had already been discovered and added.  They are working without any flaws, and I bought 4 more.  I don't know how they work with other systems, but if you use Alexa as your main way to control your home, then these are the ones for you.  There are other cheaper ones out there but they were difficult and failed a lot.  Others more expensive also were more difficult and several failed.  This is the only type I will buy going forward.
title: For an Alexa Smart home, this is the best plug in plug, and the easiest setup.

author: LKL
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2018
review_content: FIRST OFF, I DON'T OWN/USE A CELL PHONE.IT WORKED FOR 2 DAYS USING MY PC WITH THE 'AMAZON WINDOWS APP'AFTER SPENDING A LONG TIME ON THE TELEPHONE WITH VARIOUS AMAZON SUPPORT PEOPLE, I WAS FINALLY ABLE TO TALK TO SOMEONE IN INDIANA THAT SPOKE 'ENGLISH' SHARI AT KINDLE CUSTOMER SUPPORT CARE. AFTER SEVERAL HOURS OF TROUBLESHOOTING SHE DETERMINED THAT IT WAS A BAD PLUG AND SHE HAD AMAZON SEND ME ANOTHER AND SURE ENOUGH THE FIRST ONE WAS BROKE. 5 STARS FOR SHARI.SEVERAL DAYS LATER:I PLUGGED IN THE 2ND 'NEW' PLUG AND IT WAS JUST LIKE "PLUG AND PLAY' IT WAS DISCOVERED BY ALEXA BUT IT WOULD NOT TURN ON THE LAMP THAT WAS ATTACHED BY USING THE PHRASE "OPEN PLUG" AS WAS USED ON THE FIRST PLUG (WHEN IT WORKED)THE 'WINDOWS' APP IS NOT USER FRIENDLY AT ALL. THEY SAY "ENABLE THE SKILL FOR THE PLUG"  HOW ARE YOU GOING TO ACTIVATE IT IF YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT THE SKILL'S NAME IS.TO BE CONTINUED:  FRUSTRATED
title: AMAZON SMART PLUG

author: Guy Bivens
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2020
review_content: Amazon sent me an offer after buying Echo Plus, two Echo dots for the home to buy this for .99 cents.  This was a trial sale to get me to buy more.  This one works exactly as advertised, seemless with Alexa, plugged it in, scanned for new device and added, all done.  But for $24.99 ea. there are tons more brands and probably made by the same company just not Amazon branded that do the same job for alot less money.  If the Amazon plugs were $10 or less, they'd be the ones I buy, but if you need or want more than one or two, save your money, buy the ones that appear to be made by the same company FOR Amazon but you get 3,4,5,6 or multiples for a little more than the $24.99 for one price.
title: Got this on special for being new Echo Plus owners.

author: Matt
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2019
review_content: My whole house is set up with eWelink devices that work seamlessly with Alexa. I consider myself an expert on Alexa home automation at this point. I've run into every issue possible while setting up my current system. That being said, plug found a way to make things worse.Not only did it fail to stay connected to my Wifi after several attempts (and even after confirming that it was connected), it began to take my other devices offline as soon as setup commenced. I confirmed three times that it was this smart plug killing my other devices. I had to reboot my Wifi router to undo the damage done by this plug.Everyone, do yourself a favor and go with a different smart plug. This thing is absolute garbage.
title: Garbage

author: Casper & Boo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2019
review_content: this was our first smart plug, it came with the second echo 3 we just bought and it was pretty simple to set up, start using and changing name from first plug to Light only took asking alexa to do so.. Everytime we asked alexa downstairs to turn light on or off upstairs, it did so so works great. we should of gotten into this smart house stuff years ago instead of being paranoid about it, makes like so much easier..will be buying some of these for other areas of house for sure.. i do wonder why they made these plugs so big though, half the size would of literally been big enough for any cord to be plugged in.well found i didn’t need to buy more for my main purpose since these don’t work at turning on and off things like two of our tvs and only works on things with buttons that can stay on like on coffee machines, older tv and of course plug in lights.. Still did buy 3 more since first one for it’s the quickest effective way to program fireTV sticks to turn completely off for the night instead of it not really going to sleep like it should and it instead staying on streaming dozens of shows while our spare bedroom tv wasn’t even on, good darn thing we don't get charged for excessive bandwidth nowadays!
title: easy to set up

author: MoJo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
review_content: I purchased my smart plug December 2018 and it still works great. I purchased it for my shredder because my 2 year old grandson learned how to turn on the shredder and loved shredding anything in sight. LOL The last thing we needed was him putting his little fingers down the opening. Even though he's now 3 and 10 times smarter my wife and I wouldn't give it up for the world (plug that is, but grandson or his fingers works for "it" as well)! I've set it up so when I ask Alexa to "Turn on the plug" she responds, "The plug is on" and when I tell her to turn off the plug she announces, "I'm turning off the plug." Now if I can just get her to wash the dishes and fold the laundry...
title: Dependable

author: John R. Vasquez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2019
review_content: I have tried several of these plugs, trying to integrate Alexa into my home.Though many of them work there is always an installation problem. Creating an account, adding to network etc. Then anytime the network resets so does the device and you need to reinstall. (Not always a easy task.)I cannot speak to the reset issues as they have not occured yet.What I can speak about is how easy it is to install and to use. There was a problem finding the device but simply going back one step and the device connected and works well.I have not seen how to change the name of the plug but that would be the one thing I would like to incorporate.
title: Pricey but delivers on expectations.

author: A. Stern
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2019
review_content: UPDATED 11/26:  AFTER I posted this review saying AMAZON SUCKS, they contacted me and offered to send a replacement.  The replacement came the next day and worked fine.  Grateful for their resolution, although I should not have had to waste 30 minutes on the phone and post a mean review in order for this to be resolved.  I did increase to 3 stars.Original Review:Does not work.  I have two others that work fine.  Tried to return but got an amazon person who hardly spoke English and wanted 30 mins of my time and still would not send me a new one.  First poor experience with amazon but this one was really bad.  Stand up for your products or don’t sell them!!!!
title: Amazon sucks!!!! But at least they tried!

author: Mc
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2019
review_content: So I was offered a special price to get this with my new Alexa. I wasn’t sure I needed it but at the last minute decided to try it. We have window ac unit and I’m lazy and don’t want to turn it on. This works great. I can turn it on through my Alexa app when I’m on my way home, and of course at home with Alexa. Super easy to set up, just plug in and it picks up ur WiFi signal and you connect it through the Alexa app, took maybe 1 min to do. It is great for things that will pop back on after a power outage, another words items you manually have to turn on and off. My in-laws got theirs to use on their old school coffee machine. There isn’t a lot of appliances I would need this for or be able to use on ( most things have remotes or timers etc) but I think it’s pretty cool
title: Using for old school window ac unit

author: Beth
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2020
review_content: I purchased this to turn the grow light in my greenhouse on and off and it works perfectly!  Setup was a breeze and took about a minute.  I just opened the Alexa app and it connected right away even though the wifi router is in a different room.  I tested it with voice control a couple times via the app and then set up a schedule so my light goes on and off at the same time every day.  Within five minutes everything was set up and working perfectly.  It is well worth the slightly high price so that I no longer have to worry about trying to program a mechanical timer or remember to physically plug in and unplug the light.Overall, this was super easy to set up, is ultra convenient, and I highly recommend it!
title: Super Easy to Install and Use

author: aaron m.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2018
review_content: This smart plug is missing the one feature that I was looking forward to using: turning on with an alarm on the Echo.I bought this smart plug thinking that when the alarm on my Echo goes off, this plug can turn on. My friend has smart lights and plugs from another brand that do exactly this. I thought that the Amazon Smart Plug would have easier connectivity since it's the same brand as the Echo.But no. Please Amazon, add this feature.The plug works well with the Echo. When I turn the plug on or off it has a satisfying click sound.I don't recommend this plug if you do not have an Echo or smart speaker. Yes you can control the plug via an app, but honestly, who has time to open a device, find the app, click on it, scroll and then tap your way to where the control for the plug lives.
title: Missing key feature!

author: FeedbackfromCali
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 30, 2020
review_content: I ordered this when there was a significant promotion that made if very affordable to try.  I had it for a few weeks, but it didn't work consistently, so I sent it back so I could order a replacement.  I spent over an hour on chat with 2 different people who had a really hard time understanding what boils down to this: "I want a working item with the promotion I was supposed to get.  It seems like this is not possible.  Is that correct?"  The answer, though never directly answered, is no.  So, I can't say if I got a defective plug or if these aren't reliable smart plugs.  I will say, though, that more and more, the convenience of Amazon is outweighed by the many issues I have been having with my orders.
title: Didn't work consistently

author: Rich57
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 28, 2020
review_content: I purchased two Amazon SmartPlugs at two separate times and am using them on two separate circuits in my home.  Set up was easy and connectivity very good.  I was very satisfied until a day or two before Thanksgiving 2020 when they both stopped working.  Tried all the troubleshooting steps with one of them: unplugged/replugged, then rebooted router, then reset the plug by holding in the button for 12 seconds.  Tried to reconnect after the reset - the device could not be found.  The other plug was still nonfunctional several hours later, so I ordered replacement plugs from a third party.The next morning the plug that I had not reset was working again!  I had done absolutely nothing with that one; it started working as mysteriously as it had stopped.  At that point I tried to reconnect the second plug (the one I had reset) to my home network and the set-up worked fine.  Both plugs are now working normally again.So all's well that ends well.  EXCEPT that I needed those plugs to work and they didn't for several hours.  Also, I ordered something that I now don't need; I have to return them to an always-crowded UPS Store during a COVID surge.  And I wasted a fair amount of time trying to get these things to work.  Given all that, I am not a happy camper.  These things need to be predictable and reliable.  They weren't either on that day.  Marked down to two stars.
title: Temporarily Stopped Working for No Apparent Reason

author: DrMommy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2019
review_content: I bought this as a splurge with the Alexa Show on Prime Day earlier this year.  I figured I could find something to do with it!We're an all Google home/Google products house, so this was my first adventure with Alexa.  I was impressed with how easy it was to install the plug and set it up.  We set it to turn our bedroom lamp off with voice activation.I quickly figured out how to rename "plug 1" to "lamp" which was nice.  I'm still trying to figure out how to get rid of the annoying sound that follows after I tell it to turn the lamp off.  Not sure if it's even an option, but I still try random commands to see if I can fix it.Overall, I've enjoyed this plug so far, and I might just splurge on a few more if they go on an incredible sale anytime soon!
title: Easy to set up and use

author: The Vegas Tourist
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2019
review_content: The first smart plug I bought would only sync for a few hours or maybe a day before Alexa would say she cant find it. Alexa Support did whatever they do and I moved it around and spaced the plug closer to Alexa and in the open.
